<a name="Introduction-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">1 Introduction</h2>

<p>This manual is a work in progress: many sections make no attempt to explain
basic concepts in a way suitable for novices.  Thus, if you are interested,
please get involved in improving this manual.  The entire GNU community
will benefit.
</p>
<a name="index-POSIX"></a>
<p>The GNU utilities documented here are mostly compatible with the
POSIX standard.
<a name="index-bugs_002c-reporting"></a>
</p>
<p>Please report bugs to <a href="mailto:bug-coreutils@gnu.org">bug-coreutils@gnu.org</a>.
Include the version number, machine architecture, input files, and
any other information needed to reproduce the bug: your input, what you
expected, what you got, and why it is wrong.
</p>
<p>If you have a problem with <code>sort</code> or <code>date</code>, try using the
<samp>--debug</samp> option, as it can can often help find and fix problems without
having to wait for an answer to a bug report.  If the debug output
does not suffice to fix the problem on your own, please compress and
attach it to the rest of your bug report.
</p>
<p>Although diffs are welcome,
please include a description of the problem as well, since this is
sometimes difficult to infer.  See <a href="http://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Bugs.html#Bugs">Bugs</a> in <cite>Using and Porting GNU CC</cite>.
</p>
<a name="index-Berry_002c-K_002e"></a>
<a name="index-Paterson_002c-R_002e"></a>
<a name="index-Stallman_002c-R_002e"></a>
<a name="index-Pinard_002c-F_002e"></a>
<a name="index-MacKenzie_002c-D_002e"></a>
<a name="index-Meyering_002c-J_002e"></a>
<a name="index-Youmans_002c-B_002e"></a>
<p>This manual was originally derived from the Unix man pages in the
distributions, which were written by David MacKenzie and updated by Jim
Meyering.  What you are reading now is the authoritative documentation
for these utilities; the man pages are no longer being maintained.  The
original <code>fmt</code> man page was written by Ross Paterson.  Fran&ccedil;ois
Pinard did the initial conversion to Texinfo format.  Karl Berry did the
indexing, some reorganization, and editing of the results.  Brian
Youmans of the Free Software Foundation office staff combined the
manuals for textutils, fileutils, and sh-utils to produce the present
omnibus manual.  Richard Stallman contributed his usual invaluable
insights to the overall process.
</p>
<hr>

<div class="header">

</div>
<a name="Common-options-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">2 Common options</h2>















<a name="index-common-options"></a>

<p>Certain options are available in all of these programs.  Rather than
writing identical descriptions for each of the programs, they are
described here.  (In fact, every GNU program accepts (or should accept)
these options.)
</p>
<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT"></a>
<p>Normally options and operands can appear in any order, and programs act
as if all the options appear before any operands.  For example,
&lsquo;<samp>sort -r passwd -t :</samp>&rsquo; acts like &lsquo;<samp>sort -r -t : passwd</samp>&rsquo;, since
&lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo; is an option-argument of <samp>-t</samp>.  However, if the
<code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> environment variable is set, options must appear
before operands, unless otherwise specified for a particular command.
</p>
<p>A few programs can usefully have trailing operands with leading
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  With such a program, options must precede operands even if
<code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> is not set, and this fact is noted in the
program description.  For example, the <code>env</code> command&rsquo;s options
must appear before its operands, since in some cases the operands
specify a command that itself contains options.
</p>
<p>Most programs that accept long options recognize unambiguous
abbreviations of those options.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>rmdir
--ignore-fail-on-non-empty</samp>&rsquo; can be invoked as &lsquo;<samp>rmdir
--ignore-fail</samp>&rsquo; or even &lsquo;<samp>rmdir --i</samp>&rsquo;.  Ambiguous options, such as
&lsquo;<samp>ls --h</samp>&rsquo;, are identified as such.
</p>
<p>Some of these programs recognize the <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>
options only when one of them is the sole command line argument.  For
these programs, abbreviations of the long options are not always recognized.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--help</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dhelp"></a>
<a name="index-help_002c-online"></a>
<p>Print a usage message listing all available options, then exit successfully.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--version</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dversion"></a>
<a name="index-version-number_002c-finding"></a>
<p>Print the version number, then exit successfully.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002d"></a>
<a name="index-option-delimiter"></a>
<p>Delimit the option list.  Later arguments, if any, are treated as
operands even if they begin with &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>sort --
-r</samp>&rsquo; reads from the file named <samp>-r</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-standard-input"></a>
<a name="index-standard-output"></a>
<p>A single &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; operand is not really an option, though it looks like one.  It
stands for a file operand, and some tools treat it as standard input, or as
standard output if that is clear from the context.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>sort -</samp>&rsquo;
reads from standard input, and is equivalent to plain &lsquo;<samp>sort</samp>&rsquo;.  Unless
otherwise specified, a &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; can appear as any operand that requires a file
name.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Exit-status" accesskey="1">Exit status</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Indicating program success or failure.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Backup-options" accesskey="2">Backup options</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">-b -S, in some programs.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Block-size" accesskey="3">Block size</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">BLOCK_SIZE and &ndash;block-size, in some programs.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Floating-point" accesskey="4">Floating point</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Floating point number representation.
</td></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs" accesskey="6">Disambiguating names and IDs</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">chgrp, chown, chroot, id: user and group syntax
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Random-sources" accesskey="7">Random sources</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">&ndash;random-source, in some programs.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Target-directory" accesskey="8">Target directory</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Specifying a target directory, in some programs.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Trailing-slashes" accesskey="9">Trailing slashes</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">&ndash;strip-trailing-slashes, in some programs.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">-H, -L, or -P, in some programs.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">&ndash;preserve-root and &ndash;no-preserve-root.
</td></tr>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Multi_002dcall-invocation">Multi-call invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Multi-call program invocation.
</td></tr>

<hr>
<a name="Exit-status"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Backup-options" accesskey="n" rel="next">Backup options</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Exit-status-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.1 Exit status</h3>


<p>Nearly every command invocation yields an integral <em>exit status</em>
that can be used to change how other commands work.
For the vast majority of commands, an exit status of zero indicates
success.  Failure is indicated by a nonzero value&mdash;typically
&lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;, though it may differ on unusual platforms as POSIX
requires only that it be nonzero.
</p>
<p>However, some of the programs documented here do produce
other exit status values and a few associate different
meanings with the values &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;.
Here are some of the exceptions:
<code>chroot</code>, <code>env</code>, <code>expr</code>, <code>nice</code>,
<code>nohup</code>, <code>numfmt</code>, <code>printenv</code>, <code>sort</code>,
<code>stdbuf</code>, <code>test</code>, <code>timeout</code>, <code>tty</code>.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Backup-options"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Block-size" accesskey="n" rel="next">Block size</a>, Previous: <a href="#Exit-status" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Exit status</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Backup-options-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.2 Backup options</h3>

<a name="index-backup-options"></a>

<p>Some GNU programs (at least <code>cp</code>, <code>install</code>,
<code>ln</code>, and <code>mv</code>) optionally make backups of files
before writing new versions.
These options control the details of these backups.  The options are also
briefly mentioned in the descriptions of the particular programs.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--backup[=<var>method</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbackup"></a>
<a name="index-VERSION_005fCONTROL"></a>
<a name="index-backups_002c-making"></a>
<p>Make a backup of each file that would otherwise be overwritten or removed.
Without this option, the original versions are destroyed.
Use <var>method</var> to determine the type of backups to make.
When this option is used but <var>method</var> is not specified,
then the value of the <code>VERSION_CONTROL</code>
environment variable is used.  And if <code>VERSION_CONTROL</code> is not set,
the default backup type is &lsquo;<samp>existing</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>Note that the short form of this option, <samp>-b</samp> does not accept any
argument.  Using <samp>-b</samp> is equivalent to using <samp>--backup=existing</samp>.
</p>
<a name="index-version_002dcontrol-Emacs-variable"></a>
<p>This option corresponds to the Emacs variable &lsquo;<samp>version-control</samp>&rsquo;;
the values for <var>method</var> are the same as those used in Emacs.
This option also accepts more descriptive names.
The valid <var>method</var>s are (unique abbreviations are accepted):
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>none</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>off</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-none-backup-method"></a>
<p>Never make backups.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>numbered</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-numbered-backup-method"></a>
<p>Always make numbered backups.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>existing</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nil</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-existing-backup-method"></a>
<p>Make numbered backups of files that already have them, simple backups
of the others.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>simple</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>never</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-simple-backup-method"></a>
<p>Always make simple backups.  Please note &lsquo;<samp>never</samp>&rsquo; is not to be
confused with &lsquo;<samp>none</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix"></a>
<a name="index-backup-suffix"></a>
<a name="index-SIMPLE_005fBACKUP_005fSUFFIX"></a>
<p>Append <var>suffix</var> to each backup file made with <samp>-b</samp>.  If this
option is not specified, the value of the <code>SIMPLE_BACKUP_SUFFIX</code>
environment variable is used.  And if <code>SIMPLE_BACKUP_SUFFIX</code> is not
set, the default is &lsquo;<samp>~</samp>&rsquo;, just as in Emacs.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<hr>
<a name="Block-size"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Floating-point" accesskey="n" rel="next">Floating point</a>, Previous: <a href="#Backup-options" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Backup options</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Block-size-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.3 Block size</h3>

<a name="index-block-size"></a>

<p>Some GNU programs (at least <code>df</code>, <code>du</code>, and
<code>ls</code>) display sizes in &ldquo;blocks&rdquo;.  You can adjust the block size
and method of display to make sizes easier to read.  The block size
used for display is independent of any file system block size.
Fractional block counts are rounded up to the nearest integer.
</p>
<a name="index-_002d_002dblock_002dsize_003dsize"></a>
<a name="index-BLOCKSIZE"></a>
<a name="index-BLOCK_005fSIZE"></a>
<a name="index-DF_005fBLOCK_005fSIZE"></a>
<a name="index-DU_005fBLOCK_005fSIZE"></a>
<a name="index-LS_005fBLOCK_005fSIZE"></a>
<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT_002c-and-block-size"></a>

<p>The default block size is chosen by examining the following environment
variables in turn; the first one that is set determines the block size.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt><code>DF_BLOCK_SIZE</code></dt>
<dd><p>This specifies the default block size for the <code>df</code> command.
Similarly, <code>DU_BLOCK_SIZE</code> specifies the default for <code>du</code> and
<code>LS_BLOCK_SIZE</code> for <code>ls</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>BLOCK_SIZE</code></dt>
<dd><p>This specifies the default block size for all three commands, if the
above command-specific environment variables are not set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>BLOCKSIZE</code></dt>
<dd><p>This specifies the default block size for all values that are normally
printed as blocks, if neither <code>BLOCK_SIZE</code> nor the above
command-specific environment variables are set.  Unlike the other
environment variables, <code>BLOCKSIZE</code> does not affect values that are
normally printed as byte counts, e.g., the file sizes contained in
<code>ls -l</code> output.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code></dt>
<dd><p>If neither <code><var>command</var>_BLOCK_SIZE</code>, nor <code>BLOCK_SIZE</code>, nor
<code>BLOCKSIZE</code> is set, but this variable is set, the block size
defaults to 512.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>If none of the above environment variables are set, the block size
currently defaults to 1024 bytes in most contexts, but this number may
change in the future.  For <code>ls</code> file sizes, the block size
defaults to 1 byte.
</p>
<a name="index-human_002dreadable-output"></a>
<a name="index-SI-output"></a>

<p>A block size specification can be a positive integer specifying the number
of bytes per block, or it can be <code>human-readable</code> or <code>si</code> to
select a human-readable format.  Integers may be followed by suffixes
that are upward compatible with the
<a href="http://www.bipm.org/en/publications/si-brochure/chapter3.html">SI prefixes</a>
for decimal multiples and with the
<a href="https://physics.nist.gov/cuu/Units/binary.html">ISO/IEC 80000-13
(formerly IEC 60027-2) prefixes</a> for binary multiples.
</p>
<p>With human-readable formats, output sizes are followed by a size letter
such as &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; for megabytes.  <code>BLOCK_SIZE=human-readable</code> uses
powers of 1024; &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; stands for 1,048,576 bytes.
<code>BLOCK_SIZE=si</code> is similar, but uses powers of 1000 and appends
&lsquo;<samp>B</samp>&rsquo;; &lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo; stands for 1,000,000 bytes.
</p>
<a name="index-LC_005fNUMERIC"></a>
<p>A block size specification preceded by &lsquo;<samp>'</samp>&rsquo; causes output sizes to
be displayed with thousands separators.  The <code>LC_NUMERIC</code> locale
specifies the thousands separator and grouping.  For example, in an
American English locale, &lsquo;<samp>--block-size=&quot;'1kB&quot;</samp>&rsquo; would cause a size
of 1234000 bytes to be displayed as &lsquo;<samp>1,234</samp>&rsquo;.  In the default C
locale, there is no thousands separator so a leading &lsquo;<samp>'</samp>&rsquo; has no
effect.
</p>
<p>An integer block size can be followed by a suffix to specify a
multiple of that size.  A bare size letter,
or one followed by &lsquo;<samp>iB</samp>&rsquo;, specifies
a multiple using powers of 1024.  A size letter followed by &lsquo;<samp>B</samp>&rsquo;
specifies powers of 1000 instead.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>1M</samp>&rsquo; and
&lsquo;<samp>1MiB</samp>&rsquo; are equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>1048576</samp>&rsquo;, whereas &lsquo;<samp>1MB</samp>&rsquo; is
equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>1000000</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>A plain suffix without a preceding integer acts as if &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo; were
prepended, except that it causes a size indication to be appended to
the output.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>--block-size=&quot;kB&quot;</samp>&rsquo; displays 3000 as
&lsquo;<samp>3kB</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The following suffixes are defined.  Large sizes like <code>1Y</code>
may be rejected by your computer due to limitations of its arithmetic.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>kB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-kilobyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>kilobyte: <em>10^3 = 1000</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>k</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-kibibyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>kibibyte: <em>2^{10} = 1024</em>.  &lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo; is special: the SI prefix is
&lsquo;<samp>k</samp>&rsquo; and the ISO/IEC 80000-13 prefix is &lsquo;<samp>Ki</samp>&rsquo;, but tradition and
POSIX use &lsquo;<samp>k</samp>&rsquo; to mean &lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-megabyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>megabyte: <em>10^6 = 1,000,000</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>MiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-mebibyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>mebibyte: <em>2^{20} = 1,048,576</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>GB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-gigabyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>gigabyte: <em>10^9 = 1,000,000,000</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>GiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-gibibyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>gibibyte: <em>2^{30} = 1,073,741,824</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>TB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-terabyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>terabyte:  <em>10^{12} = 1,000,000,000,000</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>TiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-tebibyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>tebibyte: <em>2^{40} = 1,099,511,627,776</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>PB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-petabyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>petabyte: <em>10^{15} = 1,000,000,000,000,000</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>PiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-pebibyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>pebibyte: <em>2^{50} = 1,125,899,906,842,624</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>EB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-exabyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>exabyte: <em>10^{18} = 1,000,000,000,000,000,000</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>EiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-exbibyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>exbibyte: <em>2^{60} = 1,152,921,504,606,846,976</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ZB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-zettabyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>zettabyte: <em>10^{21} = 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000</em>
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ZiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p><em>2^{70} = 1,180,591,620,717,411,303,424</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>YB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-yottabyte_002c-definition-of"></a>
<p>yottabyte: <em>10^{24} = 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000</em>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>YiB</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p><em>2^{80} = 1,208,925,819,614,629,174,706,176</em>.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-_002dk"></a>
<a name="index-_002dh"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dblock_002dsize"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhuman_002dreadable"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsi"></a>

<p>Block size defaults can be overridden by an explicit
<samp>--block-size=<var>size</var></samp> option.  The <samp>-k</samp>
option is equivalent to <samp>--block-size=1K</samp>, which
is the default unless the <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> environment variable is
set.  The <samp>-h</samp> or <samp>--human-readable</samp> option is equivalent to
<samp>--block-size=human-readable</samp>.  The <samp>--si</samp> option is
equivalent to <samp>--block-size=si</samp>.  Note for <code>ls</code>
the <samp>-k</samp> option does not control the display of the
apparent file sizes, whereas the <samp>--block-size</samp> option does.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Floating-point"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Signal-specifications" accesskey="n" rel="next">Signal specifications</a>, Previous: <a href="#Block-size" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Block size</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Floating-point-numbers"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.4 Floating point numbers</h3>
<a name="index-floating-point"></a>
<a name="index-IEEE-floating-point"></a>

<p>Commands that accept or produce floating point numbers employ the
floating point representation of the underlying system, and suffer
from rounding error, overflow, and similar floating-point issues.
Almost all modern systems use IEEE-754 floating point, and it is
typically portable to assume IEEE-754 behavior these days.  IEEE-754
has positive and negative infinity, distinguishes positive from
negative zero, and uses special values called NaNs to represent
invalid computations such as dividing zero by itself.  For more
information, please see David Goldberg&rsquo;s paper
<a href="https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19957-01/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html">What Every Computer Scientist Should Know About Floating-Point Arithmetic</a>.
</p>
<p>Commands that accept floating point numbers as options, operands or
input use the standard C functions <code>strtod</code> and <code>strtold</code> to
convert from text to floating point numbers.  These floating point
numbers therefore can use scientific notation like <code>1.0e-34</code> and
<code>-10e100</code>.  Commands that parse floating point also understand
case-insensitive <code>inf</code>, <code>infinity</code>, and <code>NaN</code>, although
whether such values are useful depends on the command in question.
Modern C implementations also accept hexadecimal floating point
numbers such as <code>-0x.ep-3</code>, which stands for -14/16 times
<em>2^-3</em>, which equals -0.109375.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Parsing-of-Floats">Parsing of
Floats</a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
</p>
<a name="index-LC_005fNUMERIC-1"></a>
<p>Normally the <code>LC_NUMERIC</code> locale determines the decimal-point
character.  However, some commands&rsquo; descriptions specify that they
accept numbers in either the current or the C locale; for example,
they treat &lsquo;<samp>3.14</samp>&rsquo; like &lsquo;<samp>3,14</samp>&rsquo; if the current locale uses
comma as a decimal point.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Signal-specifications"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs" accesskey="n" rel="next">Disambiguating names and IDs</a>, Previous: <a href="#Floating-point" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Floating point</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Signal-specifications-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.5 Signal specifications</h3>
<a name="index-signals_002c-specifying"></a>

<p>A <var>signal</var> may be a signal name like &lsquo;<samp>HUP</samp>&rsquo;, or a signal
number like &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;, or an exit status of a process terminated by the
signal.  A signal name can be given in canonical form or prefixed by
&lsquo;<samp>SIG</samp>&rsquo;.  The case of the letters is ignored.  The following signal names
and numbers are supported on all POSIX compliant systems:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>HUP</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>1.  Hangup.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>INT</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>2.  Terminal interrupt.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>QUIT</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>3.  Terminal quit.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ABRT</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>6.  Process abort.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>KILL</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>9.  Kill (cannot be caught or ignored).
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ALRM</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>14.  Alarm Clock.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>TERM</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>15.  Termination.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Other supported signal names have system-dependent corresponding
numbers.  All systems conforming to POSIX 1003.1-2001 also
support the following signals:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>BUS</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Access to an undefined portion of a memory object.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>CHLD</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Child process terminated, stopped, or continued.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>CONT</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Continue executing, if stopped.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>FPE</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Erroneous arithmetic operation.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ILL</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Illegal Instruction.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>PIPE</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Write on a pipe with no one to read it.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>SEGV</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Invalid memory reference.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>STOP</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Stop executing (cannot be caught or ignored).
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>TSTP</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Terminal stop.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>TTIN</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Background process attempting read.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>TTOU</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Background process attempting write.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>URG</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>High bandwidth data is available at a socket.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>USR1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>User-defined signal 1.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>USR2</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>User-defined signal 2.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>POSIX 1003.1-2001 systems that support the XSI extension
also support the following signals:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>POLL</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Pollable event.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>PROF</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Profiling timer expired.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>SYS</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Bad system call.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>TRAP</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Trace/breakpoint trap.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>VTALRM</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Virtual timer expired.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>XCPU</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>CPU time limit exceeded.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>XFSZ</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>File size limit exceeded.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>POSIX 1003.1-2001 systems that support the XRT extension
also support at least eight real-time signals called &lsquo;<samp>RTMIN</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>RTMIN+1</samp>&rsquo;, &hellip;, &lsquo;<samp>RTMAX-1</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>RTMAX</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Disambiguating-names-and-IDs"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Random-sources" accesskey="n" rel="next">Random sources</a>, Previous: <a href="#Signal-specifications" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Signal specifications</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="chown_002c-chgrp_002c-chroot_002c-id_003a-Disambiguating-user-names-and-IDs"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.6 chown, chgrp, chroot, id: Disambiguating user names and IDs</h3>
<a name="index-user-names_002c-disambiguating"></a>
<a name="index-user-IDs_002c-disambiguating"></a>
<a name="index-group-names_002c-disambiguating"></a>
<a name="index-group-IDs_002c-disambiguating"></a>
<a name="index-disambiguating-group-names-and-IDs"></a>

<p>Since the <var>user</var> and <var>group</var> arguments to these commands
may be specified as names or numeric IDs, there is an
apparent ambiguity.
What if a user or group <em>name</em> is a string of digits?
<a name="DOCF1" href="#FOOT1"><sup>1</sup></a>
Should the command interpret it as a user name or as an ID?
POSIX requires that these commands
first attempt to resolve the specified string as a name, and
only once that fails, then try to interpret it as an ID.
This is troublesome when you want to specify a numeric ID, say 42,
and it must work even in a pathological situation where
&lsquo;<samp>42</samp>&rsquo; is a user name that maps to some other user ID, say 1000.
Simply invoking <code>chown 42 F</code>, will set <samp>F</samp>s owner ID to
1000&mdash;not what you intended.
</p>
<p>GNU <code>chown</code>, <code>chgrp</code>, <code>chroot</code>, and <code>id</code>
provide a way to work around this, that at the same time may result in a
significant performance improvement by eliminating a database look-up.
Simply precede each numeric user ID and/or group ID with a &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;,
in order to force its interpretation as an integer:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">chown +42 F
chgrp +$numeric_group_id another-file
chown +0:+0 /
</pre></div>

<p>The name look-up process is skipped for each &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;-prefixed string,
because a string containing &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; is never a valid user or group name.
This syntax is accepted on most common Unix systems, but not on Solaris 10.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Random-sources"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Target-directory" accesskey="n" rel="next">Target directory</a>, Previous: <a href="#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Disambiguating names and IDs</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Sources-of-random-data"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.7 Sources of random data</h3>

<a name="index-random-sources"></a>

<p>The <code>shuf</code>, <code>shred</code>, and <code>sort</code> commands
sometimes need random data to do their work.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>sort
-R</samp>&rsquo; must choose a hash function at random, and it needs random data to
make this selection.
</p>
<p>By default these commands use an internal pseudo-random generator
initialized by a small amount of entropy, but can be directed to use
an external source with the <samp>--random-source=<var>file</var></samp> option.
An error is reported if <var>file</var> does not contain enough bytes.
</p>
<p>For example, the device file <samp>/dev/urandom</samp> could be used as the
source of random data.  Typically, this device gathers environmental
noise from device drivers and other sources into an entropy pool, and
uses the pool to generate random bits.  If the pool is short of data,
the device reuses the internal pool to produce more bits, using a
cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator.  But be aware
that this device is not designed for bulk random data generation
and is relatively slow.
</p>
<p><samp>/dev/urandom</samp> suffices for most practical uses, but applications
requiring high-value or long-term protection of private data may
require an alternate data source like <samp>/dev/random</samp> or
<samp>/dev/arandom</samp>.  The set of available sources depends on your
operating system.
</p>
<p>To reproduce the results of an earlier invocation of a command, you
can save some random data into a file and then use that file as the
random source in earlier and later invocations of the command.
<a name="index-random-seed"></a>
Rather than depending on a file, one can generate a reproducible
arbitrary amount of pseudo-random data given a seed value, using
for example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">get_seeded_random()
{
  seed=&quot;$1&quot;
  openssl enc -aes-256-ctr -pass pass:&quot;$seed&quot; -nosalt \
    &lt;/dev/zero 2&gt;/dev/null
}

shuf -i1-100 --random-source=&lt;(get_seeded_random 42)
</pre></div>

<hr>
<a name="Target-directory"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Trailing-slashes" accesskey="n" rel="next">Trailing slashes</a>, Previous: <a href="#Random-sources" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Random sources</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Target-directory-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.8 Target directory</h3>

<a name="index-target-directory"></a>

<p>The <code>cp</code>, <code>install</code>, <code>ln</code>, and <code>mv</code>
commands normally treat the last operand specially when it is a
directory or a symbolic link to a directory.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>cp
source dest</samp>&rsquo; is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>cp source dest/source</samp>&rsquo; if
<samp>dest</samp> is a directory.  Sometimes this behavior is not exactly
what is wanted, so these commands support the following options to
allow more fine-grained control:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-target-directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dtarget_002ddirectory"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-1"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory"></a>
<p>Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a directory or a
symbolic link to a directory.  This can help avoid race conditions in
programs that operate in a shared area.  For example, when the command
&lsquo;<samp>mv /tmp/source /tmp/dest</samp>&rsquo; succeeds, there is no guarantee that
<samp>/tmp/source</samp> was renamed to <samp>/tmp/dest</samp>: it could have been
renamed to <samp>/tmp/dest/source</samp> instead, if some other process
created <samp>/tmp/dest</samp> as a directory.  However, if <samp>mv
-T /tmp/source /tmp/dest</samp> succeeds, there is no
question that <samp>/tmp/source</samp> was renamed to <samp>/tmp/dest</samp>.
</p>
<p>In the opposite situation, where you want the last operand to be
treated as a directory and want a diagnostic otherwise, you can use
the <samp>--target-directory</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--target-directory=<var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtarget_002ddirectory"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-2"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-1"></a>
<p>Use <var>directory</var> as the directory component of each destination
file name.
</p>
<p>The interface for most programs is that after processing options and a
finite (possibly zero) number of fixed-position arguments, the remaining
argument list is either expected to be empty, or is a list of items
(usually files) that will all be handled identically.  The <code>xargs</code>
program is designed to work well with this convention.
</p>
<p>The commands in the <code>mv</code>-family are unusual in that they take
a variable number of arguments with a special case at the <em>end</em>
(namely, the target directory).  This makes it nontrivial to perform some
operations, e.g., &ldquo;move all files from here to ../d/&rdquo;, because
<code>mv * ../d/</code> might exhaust the argument space, and <code>ls | xargs ...</code>
doesn&rsquo;t have a clean way to specify an extra final argument for each
invocation of the subject command.  (It can be done by going through a
shell command, but that requires more human labor and brain power than
it should.)
</p>
<p>The <samp>--target-directory</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) option allows the <code>cp</code>,
<code>install</code>, <code>ln</code>, and <code>mv</code> programs to be used
conveniently with <code>xargs</code>.  For example, you can move the files
from the current directory to a sibling directory, <code>d</code> like this:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">ls | xargs mv -t ../d --
</pre></div>

<p>However, this doesn&rsquo;t move files whose names begin with &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;.
If you use the GNU <code>find</code> program, you can move those
files too, with this command:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">find . -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 \
  | xargs mv -t ../d
</pre></div>

<p>But both of the above approaches fail if there are no files in the
current directory, or if any file has a name containing a blank or
some other special characters.
The following example removes those limitations and requires both
GNU <code>find</code> and GNU <code>xargs</code>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">find . -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -print0 \
  | xargs --null --no-run-if-empty \
      mv -t ../d
</pre></div>

</dd>
</dl>

<p>The <samp>--target-directory</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) and
<samp>--no-target-directory</samp> (<samp>-T</samp>)
options cannot be combined.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Trailing-slashes"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Traversing-symlinks" accesskey="n" rel="next">Traversing symlinks</a>, Previous: <a href="#Target-directory" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Target directory</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Trailing-slashes-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.9 Trailing slashes</h3>

<a name="index-trailing-slashes"></a>

<p>Some GNU programs (at least <code>cp</code> and <code>mv</code>) allow you to
remove any trailing slashes from each <var>source</var> argument before
operating on it.  The <samp>--strip-trailing-slashes</samp> option enables
this behavior.
</p>
<p>This is useful when a <var>source</var> argument may have a trailing slash and
specify a symbolic link to a directory.  This scenario is in fact rather
common because some shells can automatically append a trailing slash when
performing file name completion on such symbolic links.  Without this
option, <code>mv</code>, for example, (via the system&rsquo;s rename function) must
interpret a trailing slash as a request to dereference the symbolic link
and so must rename the indirectly referenced <em>directory</em> and not
the symbolic link.  Although it may seem surprising that such behavior
be the default, it is required by POSIX and is consistent with
other parts of that standard.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Traversing-symlinks"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially" accesskey="n" rel="next">Treating / specially</a>, Previous: <a href="#Trailing-slashes" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Trailing slashes</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Traversing-symlinks-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.10 Traversing symlinks</h3>

<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-controlling-traversal-of"></a>

<p>The following options modify how <code>chown</code> and <code>chgrp</code>
traverse a hierarchy when the <samp>--recursive</samp> (<samp>-R</samp>)
option is also specified.
If more than one of the following options is specified, only the final
one takes effect.
These options specify whether processing a symbolic link to a directory
entails operating on just the symbolic link or on all files in the
hierarchy rooted at that directory.
</p>
<p>These options are independent of <samp>--dereference</samp> and
<samp>--no-dereference</samp> (<samp>-h</samp>), which control whether to modify
a symlink or its referent.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-if-on-the-command-line"></a>
<p>If <samp>--recursive</samp> (<samp>-R</samp>) is specified and
a command line argument is a symbolic link to a directory, traverse it.
</p>


</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-each-that-is-encountered"></a>
<p>In a recursive traversal, traverse every symbolic link to a directory
that is encountered.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-never-traverse"></a>
<p>Do not traverse any symbolic links.
This is the default if none of <samp>-H</samp>, <samp>-L</samp>,
or <samp>-P</samp> is specified.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Treating-_002f-specially"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Special-built_002din-utilities" accesskey="n" rel="next">Special built-in utilities</a>, Previous: <a href="#Traversing-symlinks" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Traversing symlinks</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Treating-_002f-specially-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.11 Treating <samp>/</samp> specially</h3>

<p>Certain commands can operate destructively on entire hierarchies.
For example, if a user with appropriate privileges mistakenly runs
&lsquo;<samp>rm -rf / tmp/junk</samp>&rsquo;, that may remove
all files on the entire system.  Since there are so few
legitimate uses for such a command,
GNU <code>rm</code> normally declines to operate on any directory
that resolves to <samp>/</samp>.  If you really want to try to remove all
the files on your system, you can use the <samp>--no-preserve-root</samp>
option, but the default behavior, specified by the
<samp>--preserve-root</samp> option, is safer for most purposes.
</p>
<p>The commands <code>chgrp</code>, <code>chmod</code> and <code>chown</code>
can also operate destructively on entire hierarchies, so they too
support these options.  Although, unlike <code>rm</code>, they don&rsquo;t
actually unlink files, these commands are arguably more dangerous
when operating recursively on <samp>/</samp>, since they often work much
more quickly, and hence damage more files before an alert user can
interrupt them.  Tradition and POSIX require these commands
to operate recursively on <samp>/</samp>, so they default to
<samp>--no-preserve-root</samp>, but using the <samp>--preserve-root</samp>
option makes them safer for most purposes.  For convenience you can
specify <samp>--preserve-root</samp> in an alias or in a shell function.
</p>
<p>Note that the <samp>--preserve-root</samp> option also ensures
that <code>chgrp</code> and <code>chown</code> do not modify <samp>/</samp>
even when dereferencing a symlink pointing to <samp>/</samp>.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Special-built_002din-utilities"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Standards-conformance" accesskey="n" rel="next">Standards conformance</a>, Previous: <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Treating / specially</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Special-built_002din-utilities-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.12 Special built-in utilities</h3>

<p>Some programs like <code>nice</code> can invoke other programs; for
example, the command &lsquo;<samp>nice cat file</samp>&rsquo; invokes the program
<code>cat</code> by executing the command &lsquo;<samp>cat file</samp>&rsquo;.  However,
<em>special built-in utilities</em> like <code>exit</code> cannot be invoked
this way.  For example, the command &lsquo;<samp>nice exit</samp>&rsquo; does not have a
well-defined behavior: it may generate an error message instead of
exiting.
</p>
<p>Here is a list of the special built-in utilities that are standardized
by POSIX 1003.1-2004.
</p>
<blockquote>
<p><tt>. : break continue eval exec exit export readonly
return set shift times trap unset</tt>
</p></blockquote>

<p>For example, because &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>exec</samp>&rsquo; are special,
the commands &lsquo;<samp>nice . foo.sh</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>nice :</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>nice exec
pwd</samp>&rsquo; do not work as you might expect.
</p>
<p>Many shells extend this list.  For example, Bash has several extra
special built-in utilities like <code>history</code>, and
<code>suspend</code>, and with Bash the command &lsquo;<samp>nice suspend</samp>&rsquo;
generates an error message instead of suspending.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Standards-conformance"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Multi_002dcall-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">Multi-call invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#Special-built_002din-utilities" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Special built-in utilities</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Standards-conformance-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.13 Standards conformance</h3>

<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-1"></a>
<p>In a few cases, the GNU utilities&rsquo; default behavior is
incompatible with the POSIX standard.  To suppress these
incompatibilities, define the <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> environment
variable.  Unless you are checking for POSIX conformance, you
probably do not need to define <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code>.
</p>
<p>Newer versions of POSIX are occasionally incompatible with older
versions.  For example, older versions of POSIX required the
command &lsquo;<samp>sort +1</samp>&rsquo; to sort based on the second and succeeding
fields in each input line, but in POSIX 1003.1-2001
the same command is required to sort the file named <samp>+1</samp>, and you
must instead use the command &lsquo;<samp>sort -k 2</samp>&rsquo; to get the field-based
sort.  To complicate things further, POSIX 1003.1-2008 allows an
implementation to have either the old or the new behavior.
</p>
<a name="index-_005fPOSIX2_005fVERSION"></a>
<p>The GNU utilities normally conform to the version of POSIX
that is standard for your system.  To cause them to conform to a
different version of POSIX, define the <code>_POSIX2_VERSION</code>
environment variable to a value of the form <var>yyyymm</var> specifying
the year and month the standard was adopted.  Three values are currently
supported for <code>_POSIX2_VERSION</code>: &lsquo;<samp>199209</samp>&rsquo; stands for
POSIX 1003.2-1992, &lsquo;<samp>200112</samp>&rsquo; stands for POSIX
1003.1-2001, and &lsquo;<samp>200809</samp>&rsquo; stands for POSIX 1003.1-2008.
For example, if you have a POSIX 1003.1-2001 system but are running software
containing traditional usage like &lsquo;<samp>sort +1</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>tail +10</samp>&rsquo;,
you can work around the compatibility problems by setting
&lsquo;<samp>_POSIX2_VERSION=200809</samp>&rsquo; in your environment.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Multi_002dcall-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Standards-conformance" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Standards conformance</a>, Up: <a href="#Common-options" accesskey="u" rel="up">Common options</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="coreutils_003a-Multi_002dcall-program"></a>
<h3 class="section">2.14 <code>coreutils</code>: Multi-call program</h3>

<a name="index-multicall"></a>
<a name="index-combined"></a>
<a name="index-calling-combined-multi_002dcall-program"></a>

<p>The <code>coreutils</code> command invokes an individual utility, either
implicitly selected by the last component of the name used to invoke
<code>coreutils</code>, or explicitly with the
<samp>--coreutils-prog</samp> option.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">coreutils <samp>--coreutils-prog=PROGRAM</samp> &hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The <code>coreutils</code> command is not installed by default, so
portable scripts should not rely on its existence.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Output-of-entire-files"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>

<a name="Output-of-entire-files-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">3 Output of entire files</h2>

<a name="index-output-of-entire-files"></a>
<a name="index-entire-files_002c-output-of"></a>

<p>These commands read and write entire files, possibly transforming them
in some way.
</p>

</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#nl-invocation" accesskey="3">nl invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Number lines and write files.

<p>
