<a name="cat_003a-Concatenate-and-write-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">3.1 <code>cat</code>: Concatenate and write files</h3>

<a name="index-cat"></a>
<a name="index-concatenate-and-write-files"></a>
<a name="index-copying-files"></a>

<p><code>cat</code> copies each <var>file</var> (&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; means standard input), or
standard input if none are given, to standard output.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">cat [<var>option</var>] [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-A</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--show-all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dA"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dshow_002dall"></a>
<p>Equivalent to <samp>-vET</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--number-nonblank</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumber_002dnonblank"></a>
<p>Number all nonempty output lines, starting with 1.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de"></a>
<p>Equivalent to <samp>-vE</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-E</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--show-ends</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dE"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dshow_002dends"></a>
<p>Display a &lsquo;<samp>$</samp>&rsquo; after the end of each line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--number</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumber"></a>
<p>Number all output lines, starting with 1.  This option is ignored
if <samp>-b</samp> is in effect.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--squeeze-blank</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsqueeze_002dblank"></a>
<a name="index-squeezing-empty-lines"></a>
<a name="index-squeezing-blank-lines"></a>
<p>Suppress repeated adjacent blank lines; output just one empty line
instead of several.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt"></a>
<p>Equivalent to <samp>-vT</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--show-tabs</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dshow_002dtabs"></a>
<p>Display TAB characters as &lsquo;<samp>^I</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du"></a>
<p>Ignored; for POSIX compatibility.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--show-nonprinting</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dshow_002dnonprinting"></a>
<p>Display control characters except for LFD and TAB using
&lsquo;<samp>^</samp>&rsquo; notation and precede characters that have the high bit set with
&lsquo;<samp>M-</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>On systems like MS-DOS that distinguish between text and binary files,
<code>cat</code> normally reads and writes in binary mode.  However,
<code>cat</code> reads in text mode if one of the options
<samp>-bensAE</samp> is used or if <code>cat</code> is reading from standard
input and standard input is a terminal.  Similarly, <code>cat</code>
writes in text mode if one of the options <samp>-bensAE</samp> is used or
if standard output is a terminal.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Output f's contents, then standard input, then g's contents.
cat f - g

# Copy standard input to standard output.
cat
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="tac-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#nl-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">nl invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#cat-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">cat invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-entire-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of entire files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="tac_003a-Concatenate-and-write-files-in-reverse"></a>
<h3 class="section">3.2 <code>tac</code>: Concatenate and write files in reverse</h3>

<a name="index-tac"></a>
<a name="index-reversing-files"></a>

<p><code>tac</code> copies each <var>file</var> (&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; means standard input), or
standard input if none are given, to standard output, reversing the
records (lines by default) in each separately.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tac [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><em>Records</em> are separated by instances of a string (newline by
default).  By default, this separator string is attached to the end of
the record that it follows in the file.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--before</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbefore"></a>
<p>The separator is attached to the beginning of the record that it
precedes in the file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--regex</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dregex"></a>
<p>Treat the separator string as a regular expression.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>separator</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--separator=<var>separator</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dseparator"></a>
<p>Use <var>separator</var> as the record separator, instead of newline.
Note an empty <var>separator</var> is treated as a zero byte.
I.e., input and output items are delimited with ASCII NUL.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>On systems like MS-DOS that distinguish between text and binary files,
<code>tac</code> reads and writes in binary mode.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Reverse a file character by character.
tac -r -s 'x\|[^x]'
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="nl-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#od-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">od invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#tac-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">tac invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-entire-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of entire files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="nl_003a-Number-lines-and-write-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">3.3 <code>nl</code>: Number lines and write files</h3>

<a name="index-nl-1"></a>
<a name="index-numbering-lines"></a>
<a name="index-line-numbering"></a>

<p><code>nl</code> writes each <var>file</var> (&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; means standard input), or
standard input if none are given, to standard output, with line numbers
added to some or all of the lines.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">nl [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-logical-pages_002c-numbering-on"></a>
<p><code>nl</code> decomposes its input into (logical) page sections;
by default, the line number is reset to 1 at each logical page section.
<code>nl</code> treats all of the input files as a single document;
it does not reset line numbers or logical pages between files.
</p>
<a name="index-headers_002c-numbering"></a>
<a name="index-body_002c-numbering"></a>
<a name="index-footers_002c-numbering"></a>
<p>A logical page consists of three sections: header, body, and footer.
Any of the sections can be empty.  Each can be numbered in a different
style from the others.
</p>
<p>The beginnings of the sections of logical pages are indicated in the
input file by a line containing exactly one of these delimiter strings:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\:\:\:</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>start of header;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\:\:</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>start of body;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\:</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>start of footer.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>The two characters from which these strings are made can be changed from
&lsquo;<samp>\</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo; via options (see below), but the pattern and
length of each string cannot be changed.
</p>
<p>A section delimiter is replaced by an empty line on output.  Any text
that comes before the first section delimiter string in the input file
is considered to be part of a body section, so <code>nl</code> treats a
file that contains no section delimiters as a single body section.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b <var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--body-numbering=<var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbody_002dnumbering"></a>
<p>Select the numbering style for lines in the body section of each
logical page.  When a line is not numbered, the current line number
is not incremented, but the line number separator character is still
prepended to the line.  The styles are:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>number all lines,
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>number only nonempty lines (default for body),
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>do not number lines (default for header and footer),
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>p<var>bre</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>number only lines that contain a match for the basic regular
expression <var>bre</var>.
See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/grep/manual/grep.html#Regular-Expressions">Regular Expressions</a> in <cite>The GNU Grep Manual</cite>.
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>cd</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--section-delimiter=<var>cd</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsection_002ddelimiter"></a>
<a name="index-section-delimiters-of-pages"></a>
<p>Set the section delimiter characters to <var>cd</var>; default is
&lsquo;<samp>\:</samp>&rsquo;.  If only <var>c</var> is given, the second remains &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;.
(Remember to protect &lsquo;<samp>\</samp>&rsquo; or other metacharacters from shell
expansion with quotes or extra backslashes.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f <var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--footer-numbering=<var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfooter_002dnumbering"></a>
<p>Analogous to <samp>--body-numbering</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h <var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--header-numbering=<var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dheader_002dnumbering"></a>
<p>Analogous to <samp>--body-numbering</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--line-increment=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dline_002dincrement"></a>
<p>Increment line numbers by <var>number</var> (default 1).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--join-blank-lines=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002djoin_002dblank_002dlines"></a>
<a name="index-empty-lines_002c-numbering"></a>
<a name="index-blank-lines_002c-numbering"></a>
<p>Consider <var>number</var> (default 1) consecutive empty lines to be one
logical line for numbering, and only number the last one.  Where fewer
than <var>number</var> consecutive empty lines occur, do not number them.
An empty line is one that contains no characters, not even spaces
or tabs.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n <var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--number-format=<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumber_002dformat"></a>
<p>Select the line numbering format (default is <code>rn</code>):
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ln</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ln-format-for-nl"></a>
<p>left justified, no leading zeros;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>rn</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-rn-format-for-nl"></a>
<p>right justified, no leading zeros;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>rz</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-rz-format-for-nl"></a>
<p>right justified, leading zeros.
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-renumber</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002drenumber"></a>
<p>Do not reset the line number at the start of a logical page.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--number-separator=<var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumber_002dseparator"></a>
<p>Separate the line number from the text line in the output with
<var>string</var> (default is the TAB character).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--starting-line-number=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dstarting_002dline_002dnumber"></a>
<p>Set the initial line number on each logical page to <var>number</var> (default 1).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--number-width=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumber_002dwidth"></a>
<p>Use <var>number</var> characters for line numbers (default 6).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="od-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#base32-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">base32 invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#nl-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">nl invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-entire-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of entire files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="od_003a-Write-files-in-octal-or-other-formats"></a>
<h3 class="section">3.4 <code>od</code>: Write files in octal or other formats</h3>

<a name="index-od"></a>
<a name="index-octal-dump-of-files"></a>
<a name="index-hex-dump-of-files"></a>
<a name="index-ASCII-dump-of-files"></a>
<a name="index-file-contents_002c-dumping-unambiguously"></a>

<p><code>od</code> writes an unambiguous representation of each <var>file</var>
(&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; means standard input), or standard input if none are given.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">od [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
od [-abcdfilosx]&hellip; [<var>file</var>] [[+]<var>offset</var>[.][b]]
od [<var>option</var>]&hellip; --traditional [<var>file</var>] [[+]<var>offset</var>[.][b] [[+]<var>label</var>[.][b]]]
</pre></div>

<p>Each line of output consists of the offset in the input, followed by
groups of data from the file.  By default, <code>od</code> prints the offset in
octal, and each group of file data is a C <code>short int</code>&rsquo;s worth of input
printed as a single octal number.
</p>
<p>If <var>offset</var> is given, it specifies how many input bytes to skip
before formatting and writing.  By default, it is interpreted as an
octal number, but the optional trailing decimal point causes it to be
interpreted as decimal.  If no decimal is specified and the offset
begins with &lsquo;<samp>0x</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>0X</samp>&rsquo; it is interpreted as a hexadecimal
number.  If there is a trailing &lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;, the number of bytes skipped
will be <var>offset</var> multiplied by 512.
</p>
<p>If a command is of both the first and second forms, the second form is
assumed if the last operand begins with &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; or (if there are two
operands) a digit.  For example, in &lsquo;<samp>od foo 10</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>od +10</samp>&rsquo;
the &lsquo;<samp>10</samp>&rsquo; is an offset, whereas in &lsquo;<samp>od 10</samp>&rsquo; the &lsquo;<samp>10</samp>&rsquo; is a
file name.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-A <var>radix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--address-radix=<var>radix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dA-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002daddress_002dradix"></a>
<a name="index-radix-for-file-offsets"></a>
<a name="index-file-offset-radix"></a>
<p>Select the base in which file offsets are printed.  <var>radix</var> can
be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>decimal;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>o</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>octal;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hexadecimal;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>none (do not print offsets).
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>The default is octal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--endian=<var>order</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dendian"></a>
<a name="index-byte_002dswapping"></a>
<a name="index-endianness"></a>
<p>Reorder input bytes, to handle inputs with differing byte orders,
or to provide consistent output independent of the endian convention
of the current system.  Swapping is performed according to the
specified <samp>--type</samp> size and endian <var>order</var>, which can be
&lsquo;<samp>little</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>big</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-j <var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--skip-bytes=<var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dj"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dskip_002dbytes"></a>
<p>Skip <var>bytes</var> input bytes before formatting and writing.  If
<var>bytes</var> begins with &lsquo;<samp>0x</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>0X</samp>&rsquo;, it is interpreted in
hexadecimal; otherwise, if it begins with &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;, in octal; otherwise,
in decimal.
<var>bytes</var> may be, or may be an integer optionally followed by,
one of the following multiplicative suffixes:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;            512 (&quot;blocks&quot;)
&lsquo;<samp>KB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;           1000 (KiloBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;           1024 (KibiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;      1000*1000 (MegaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;      1024*1024 (MebiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>GB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt; 1000*1000*1000 (GigaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; 1024*1024*1024 (GibiBytes)
</pre></div>
<p>and so on for &lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;.
Binary prefixes can be used, too: &lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>MiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;,
and so on.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-N <var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--read-bytes=<var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dN"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dread_002dbytes"></a>
<p>Output at most <var>bytes</var> bytes of the input.  Prefixes and suffixes on
<code>bytes</code> are interpreted as for the <samp>-j</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--strings[=<var>bytes</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dstrings"></a>
<a name="index-string-constants_002c-outputting"></a>
<p>Instead of the normal output, output only <em>string constants</em>: at
least <var>bytes</var> consecutive ASCII graphic characters,
followed by a zero byte (ASCII NUL).
Prefixes and suffixes on <var>bytes</var> are interpreted as for the
<samp>-j</samp> option.
</p>
<p>If <var>bytes</var> is omitted with <samp>--strings</samp>, the default is 3.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>type</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=<var>type</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat"></a>
<p>Select the format in which to output the file data.  <var>type</var> is a
string of one or more of the below type indicator characters.  If you
include more than one type indicator character in a single <var>type</var>
string, or use this option more than once, <code>od</code> writes one copy
of each output line using each of the data types that you specified,
in the order that you specified.
</p>
<p>Adding a trailing &ldquo;z&rdquo; to any type specification appends a display
of the single byte character representation of the printable characters
to the output line generated by the type specification.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>named character, ignoring high-order bit
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>printable single byte character, C backslash escape
or a 3 digit octal sequence
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>signed decimal
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>floating point (see <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>o</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>octal
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>unsigned decimal
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hexadecimal
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>The type <code>a</code> outputs things like &lsquo;<samp>sp</samp>&rsquo; for space, &lsquo;<samp>nl</samp>&rsquo; for
newline, and &lsquo;<samp>nul</samp>&rsquo; for a zero byte.  Only the least significant
seven bits of each byte is used; the high-order bit is ignored.
Type <code>c</code> outputs
&lsquo;<samp> </samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>\n</samp>&rsquo;, and <code>\0</code>, respectively.
</p>
<a name="index-type-size"></a>
<p>Except for types &lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;, you can specify the number
of bytes to use in interpreting each number in the given data type
by following the type indicator character with a decimal integer.
Alternately, you can specify the size of one of the C compiler&rsquo;s
built-in data types by following the type indicator character with
one of the following characters.  For integers (&lsquo;<samp>d</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>o</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;):
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>C</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>char
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>S</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>short
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>I</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>int
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>long
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>For floating point (<code>f</code>):
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>F</dt>
<dd><p>float
</p></dd>
<dt>D</dt>
<dd><p>double
</p></dd>
<dt>L</dt>
<dd><p>long double
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output-duplicates</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002doutput_002dduplicates"></a>
<p>Output consecutive lines that are identical.  By default, when two or
more consecutive output lines would be identical, <code>od</code> outputs only
the first line, and puts just an asterisk on the following line to
indicate the elision.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w[<var>n</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--width[=<var>n</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwidth"></a>
<p>Dump <code>n</code> input bytes per output line.  This must be a multiple of
the least common multiple of the sizes associated with the specified
output types.
</p>
<p>If this option is not given at all, the default is 16.  If <var>n</var> is
omitted, the default is 32.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>The next several options are shorthands for format specifications.
GNU <code>od</code> accepts any combination of shorthands and format
specification options.  These options accumulate.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da"></a>
<p>Output as named characters.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t a</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-4"></a>
<p>Output as octal bytes.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t o1</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc"></a>
<p>Output as printable single byte characters, C backslash escapes
or 3 digit octal sequences.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t c</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-1"></a>
<p>Output as unsigned decimal two-byte units.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t u2</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-1"></a>
<p>Output as floats.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t fF</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-1"></a>
<p>Output as decimal ints.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t dI</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-1"></a>
<p>Output as decimal long ints.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t dL</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do"></a>
<p>Output as octal two-byte units.  Equivalent to <samp>-t o2</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-3"></a>
<p>Output as decimal two-byte units.  Equivalent to <samp>-t d2</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx"></a>
<p>Output as hexadecimal two-byte units.  Equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-t x2</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--traditional</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtraditional"></a>
<p>Recognize the non-option label argument that traditional <code>od</code>
accepted.  The following syntax:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">od --traditional [<var>file</var>] [[+]<var>offset</var>[.][b] [[+]<var>label</var>[.][b]]]
</pre></div>

<p>can be used to specify at most one file and optional arguments
specifying an offset and a pseudo-start address, <var>label</var>.
The <var>label</var> argument is interpreted
just like <var>offset</var>, but it specifies an initial pseudo-address.  The
pseudo-addresses are displayed in parentheses following any normal
address.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="base32-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#base64-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">base64 invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#od-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">od invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-entire-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of entire files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="base32_003a-Transform-data-into-printable-data"></a>
<h3 class="section">3.5 <code>base32</code>: Transform data into printable data</h3>

<a name="index-base32"></a>
<a name="index-base32-encoding"></a>

<p><code>base32</code> transforms data read from a file, or standard input,
into (or from) base32 encoded form.  The base32 encoded form uses
printable ASCII characters to represent binary data.
The usage and options of this command are precisely the
same as for <code>base64</code>.  See <a href="#base64-invocation">base64 invocation</a>.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="base64-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#basenc-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">basenc invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#base32-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">base32 invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-entire-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of entire files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="base64_003a-Transform-data-into-printable-data"></a>
<h3 class="section">3.6 <code>base64</code>: Transform data into printable data</h3>

<a name="index-base64"></a>
<a name="index-base64-encoding"></a>

<p><code>base64</code> transforms data read from a file, or standard input,
into (or from) base64 encoded form.  The base64 encoded form uses
printable ASCII characters to represent binary data.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">base64 [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]
base64 --decode [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>The base64 encoding expands data to roughly 133% of the original.
The base32 encoding expands data to roughly 160% of the original.
The format conforms to
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc4648">RFC 4648</a>.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>cols</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--wrap=<var>cols</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwrap"></a>
<a name="index-wrap-data"></a>
<a name="index-column-to-wrap-data-after"></a>
<p>During encoding, wrap lines after <var>cols</var> characters.  This must be
a positive number.
</p>
<p>The default is to wrap after 76 characters.  Use the value 0 to
disable line wrapping altogether.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--decode</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddecode"></a>
<a name="index-Decode-base64-data"></a>
<a name="index-Base64-decoding"></a>
<p>Change the mode of operation, from the default of encoding data, to
decoding data.  Input is expected to be base64 encoded data, and the
output will be the original data.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-garbage</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dgarbage"></a>
<a name="index-Ignore-garbage-in-base64-stream"></a>
<p>When decoding, newlines are always accepted.
During decoding, ignore unrecognized bytes,
to permit distorted data to be decoded.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="basenc-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#base64-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">base64 invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-entire-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of entire files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="basenc_003a-Transform-data-into-printable-data"></a>
<h3 class="section">3.7 <code>basenc</code>: Transform data into printable data</h3>

<a name="index-basenc"></a>
<a name="index-base32-encoding-1"></a>

<p><code>basenc</code> transforms data read from a file, or standard input,
into (or from) various common encoding forms.  The encoded form uses
printable ASCII characters to represent binary data.
</p>
<p>Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">basenc <var>encoding</var> [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]
basenc <var>encoding</var> --decode [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>The <var>encoding</var> argument is required. If <var>file</var> is omitted,
reads input from stdin. The <samp>-w/--wrap</samp>,<samp>-i/--ignore-garbage</samp>,
<samp>-d/--decode</samp> options of this command are precisely the same as
for <code>base64</code>. See <a href="#base64-invocation">base64 invocation</a>.
</p>

<p>Supported <var>encoding</var>s are:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--base64</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbase64"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) base64 form.
The format conforms to
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc4648#section-4">RFC 4648#4</a>.
Equivalent to the <code>base64</code> command.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--base64url</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbase64url"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) file-and-url-safe
base64 form (using &lsquo;<samp>_</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; instead of &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo;).
The format conforms to
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc4648#section-5">RFC 4648#5</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--base32</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbase32"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) base32 form.
The encoded data uses the &lsquo;<samp>ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ234567=</samp>&rsquo; characters.
The format conforms to
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc4648#section-6">RFC 4648#6</a>.
Equivalent to the <code>base32</code> command.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--base32hex</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbase32hex"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) Extended Hex Alphabet
base32 form. The encoded data uses the
&lsquo;<samp>0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUV=</samp>&rsquo; characters. The format conforms to
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc4648#section-7">RFC 4648#7</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--base16</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbase16"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) base16 (hexadecimal)
form. The encoded data uses the &lsquo;<samp>0123456789ABCDEF</samp>&rsquo; characters. The format
conforms to
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc4648#section-8">RFC 4648#8</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--base2lsbf</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbase2lsbf"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) binary string form
(&lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;) with the <em>least</em> significant bit of every byte
first.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--base2msbf</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbase2msbf"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) binary string form
(&lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;) with the <em>most</em> significant bit of every byte
first.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--z85</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dz85"></a>
<p>Encode into (or decode from with <samp>-d/--decode</samp>) Z85 form
(a modified Ascii85 form). The encoded data uses the
&lsquo;<samp>0123456789abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTU&nbsp;VWXYZ.-:+=^!/*?&amp;&lt;&gt;()[]{}@%$#</samp>&rsquo;.
characters. The format conforms to
<a href="https://rfc.zeromq.org/spec:32/Z85/">ZeroMQ spec:32/Z85</a>.
</p>
<p>When encoding with <samp>--z85</samp>, input length must be a multiple of 4;
when decoding with <samp>--z85</samp>, input length must be a multiple of 5.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>



<p>Encoding/decoding examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ printf '\376\117\202' | basenc --base64
/k+C

$ printf '\376\117\202' | basenc --base64url
_k-C

$ printf '\376\117\202' | basenc --base32
7ZHYE===

$ printf '\376\117\202' | basenc --base32hex
VP7O4===

$ printf '\376\117\202' | basenc --base16
FE4F82

$ printf '\376\117\202' | basenc --base2lsbf
011111111111001001000001

$ printf '\376\117\202' | basenc --base2msbf
111111100100111110000010

$ printf '\376\117\202\000' | basenc --z85
@.FaC

$ printf 01010100 | basenc --base2msbf --decode
T

$ printf 01010100 | basenc --base2lsbf --decode
*
</pre></div>



<hr>
<a name="Formatting-file-contents"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
