</div>
<a name="Formatting-file-contents-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">4 Formatting file contents</h2>

<a name="index-formatting-file-contents"></a>

<p>These commands reformat the contents of files.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#fmt-invocation" accesskey="1">fmt invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Reformat paragraph text.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#pr-invocation" accesskey="2">pr invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Paginate or columnate files for printing.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#fold-invocation" accesskey="3">fold invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Wrap input lines to fit in specified width.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="fmt-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#pr-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">pr invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Formatting-file-contents" accesskey="u" rel="up">Formatting file contents</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="fmt_003a-Reformat-paragraph-text"></a>
<h3 class="section">4.1 <code>fmt</code>: Reformat paragraph text</h3>

<a name="index-fmt"></a>
<a name="index-reformatting-paragraph-text"></a>
<a name="index-paragraphs_002c-reformatting"></a>
<a name="index-text_002c-reformatting"></a>

<p><code>fmt</code> fills and joins lines to produce output lines of (at most)
a given number of characters (75 by default).  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">fmt [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><code>fmt</code> reads from the specified <var>file</var> arguments (or standard
input if none are given), and writes to standard output.
</p>
<p>By default, blank lines, spaces between words, and indentation are
preserved in the output; successive input lines with different
indentation are not joined; tabs are expanded on input and introduced on
output.
</p>
<a name="index-line_002dbreaking"></a>
<a name="index-sentences-and-line_002dbreaking"></a>
<a name="index-Knuth_002c-Donald-E_002e"></a>
<a name="index-Plass_002c-Michael-F_002e"></a>
<p><code>fmt</code> prefers breaking lines at the end of a sentence, and tries to
avoid line breaks after the first word of a sentence or before the last
word of a sentence.  A <em>sentence break</em> is defined as either the end
of a paragraph or a word ending in any of &lsquo;<samp>.?!</samp>&rsquo;, followed by two
spaces or end of line, ignoring any intervening parentheses or quotes.
Like TeX, <code>fmt</code> reads entire &ldquo;paragraphs&rdquo; before choosing line
breaks; the algorithm is a variant of that given by Donald E. Knuth
and Michael F. Plass in &ldquo;Breaking Paragraphs Into Lines&rdquo;,
<cite>Software&mdash;Practice &amp; Experience</cite> <b>11</b>, 11 (November 1981),
1119&ndash;1184.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--crown-margin</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcrown_002dmargin"></a>
<a name="index-crown-margin"></a>
<p><em>Crown margin</em> mode: preserve the indentation of the first two
lines within a paragraph, and align the left margin of each subsequent
line with that of the second line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--tagged-paragraph</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtagged_002dparagraph"></a>
<a name="index-tagged-paragraphs"></a>
<p><em>Tagged paragraph</em> mode: like crown margin mode, except that if
indentation of the first line of a paragraph is the same as the
indentation of the second, the first line is treated as a one-line
paragraph.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--split-only</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsplit_002donly"></a>
<p>Split lines only.  Do not join short lines to form longer ones.  This
prevents sample lines of code, and other such &ldquo;formatted&rdquo; text from
being unduly combined.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--uniform-spacing</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002duniform_002dspacing"></a>
<p>Uniform spacing.  Reduce spacing between words to one space, and spacing
between sentences to two spaces.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-<var>width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--width=<var>width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dwidth"></a>
<a name="index-_002dw-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwidth-1"></a>
<p>Fill output lines up to <var>width</var> characters (default 75 or <var>goal</var>
plus 10, if <var>goal</var> is provided).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g <var>goal</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--goal=<var>goal</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dgoal"></a>
<p><code>fmt</code> initially tries to make lines <var>goal</var> characters wide.
By default, this is 7% shorter than <var>width</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p <var>prefix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--prefix=<var>prefix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Only lines beginning with <var>prefix</var> (possibly preceded by whitespace)
are subject to formatting.  The prefix and any preceding whitespace are
stripped for the formatting and then re-attached to each formatted output
line.  One use is to format certain kinds of program comments, while
leaving the code unchanged.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="pr-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#fold-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">fold invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#fmt-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">fmt invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Formatting-file-contents" accesskey="u" rel="up">Formatting file contents</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="pr_003a-Paginate-or-columnate-files-for-printing"></a>
<h3 class="section">4.2 <code>pr</code>: Paginate or columnate files for printing</h3>

<a name="index-pr"></a>
<a name="index-printing_002c-preparing-files-for"></a>
<a name="index-multicolumn-output_002c-generating"></a>
<a name="index-merging-files-in-parallel"></a>

<p><code>pr</code> writes each <var>file</var> (&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; means standard input), or
standard input if none are given, to standard output, paginating and
optionally outputting in multicolumn format; optionally merges all
<var>file</var>s, printing all in parallel, one per column.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">pr [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-LC_005fMESSAGES"></a>
<p>By default, a 5-line header is printed at each page: two blank lines;
a line with the date, the file name, and the page count; and two more
blank lines.  A footer of five blank lines is also printed.
The default <var>page_length</var> is 66
lines.  The default number of text lines is therefore 56.
The text line of the header takes the form
&lsquo;<samp><var>date</var> <var>string</var> <var>page</var></samp>&rsquo;, with spaces inserted around
<var>string</var> so that the line takes up the full <var>page_width</var>.  Here,
<var>date</var> is the date (see the <samp>-D</samp> or <samp>--date-format</samp>
option for details), <var>string</var> is the centered header string, and
<var>page</var> identifies the page number.  The <code>LC_MESSAGES</code> locale
category affects the spelling of <var>page</var>; in the default C locale, it
is &lsquo;<samp>Page <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo; where <var>number</var> is the decimal page
number.
</p>
<p>Form feeds in the input cause page breaks in the output.  Multiple form
feeds produce empty pages.
</p>
<p>Columns are of equal width, separated by an optional string (default
is &lsquo;<samp>space</samp>&rsquo;).  For multicolumn output, lines will always be truncated to
<var>page_width</var> (default 72), unless you use the <samp>-J</samp> option.
For single
column output no line truncation occurs by default.  Use <samp>-W</samp> option to
truncate lines in that case.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>+<var>first_page</var>[:<var>last_page</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--pages=<var>first_page</var>[:<var>last_page</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002bpage_005frange"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dpages_003dpage_005frange"></a>
<p>Begin printing with page <var>first_page</var> and stop with <var>last_page</var>.
Missing &lsquo;<samp>:<var>last_page</var></samp>&rsquo; implies end of file.  While estimating
the number of skipped pages each form feed in the input file results
in a new page.  Page counting with and without &lsquo;<samp>+<var>first_page</var></samp>&rsquo;
is identical.  By default, counting starts with the first page of input
file (not first page printed).  Line numbering may be altered by <samp>-N</samp>
option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-<var>column</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--columns=<var>column</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dcolumn"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcolumns"></a>
<a name="index-down-columns"></a>
<p>With each single <var>file</var>, produce <var>column</var> columns of output
(default is 1) and print columns down, unless <samp>-a</samp> is used.  The
column width is automatically decreased as <var>column</var> increases; unless
you use the <samp>-W/-w</samp> option to increase <var>page_width</var> as well.
This option might well cause some lines to be truncated.  The number of
lines in the columns on each page are balanced.  The options <samp>-e</samp>
and <samp>-i</samp> are on for multiple text-column output.  Together with
<samp>-J</samp> option column alignment and line truncation is turned off.
Lines of full length are joined in a free field format and <samp>-S</samp>
option may set field separators.  <samp>-<var>column</var></samp> may not be used
with <samp>-m</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--across</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dacross"></a>
<a name="index-across-columns"></a>
<p>With each single <var>file</var>, print columns across rather than down.  The
<samp>-<var>column</var></samp> option must be given with <var>column</var> greater than one.
If a line is too long to fit in a column, it is truncated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--show-control-chars</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dshow_002dcontrol_002dchars"></a>
<p>Print control characters using hat notation (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>^G</samp>&rsquo;); print
other nonprinting characters in octal backslash notation.  By default,
nonprinting characters are not changed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--double-space</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddouble_002dspace"></a>
<a name="index-double-spacing"></a>
<p>Double space the output.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-D <var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--date-format=<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-time-formats"></a>
<a name="index-formatting-times"></a>
<p>Format header dates using <var>format</var>, using the same conventions as
for the command &lsquo;<samp>date +<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;.  See <a href="#date-invocation">date invocation</a>.
Except for directives, which start with
&lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo;, characters in <var>format</var> are printed unchanged.  You can use
this option to specify an arbitrary string in place of the header date,
e.g., <samp>--date-format=&quot;Monday morning&quot;</samp>.
</p>
<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-2"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fTIME"></a>
<p>The default date format is &lsquo;<samp>%Y-%m-%d %H:%M</samp>&rsquo; (for example,
&lsquo;<samp>2001-12-04 23:59</samp>&rsquo;);
but if the <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> environment variable is set
and the <code>LC_TIME</code> locale category specifies the POSIX
locale, the default is &lsquo;<samp>%b %e %H:%M %Y</samp>&rsquo; (for example,
&lsquo;<samp>Dec&nbsp;&nbsp;4 23:59 2001</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<a name="index-TZ"></a>
<p>Timestamps are listed according to the time zone rules specified by
the <code>TZ</code> environment variable, or by the system default rules if
<code>TZ</code> is not set.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable">Specifying the Time Zone
with <code>TZ</code></a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e[<var>in-tabchar</var>[<var>in-tabwidth</var>]]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--expand-tabs[=<var>in-tabchar</var>[<var>in-tabwidth</var>]]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dexpand_002dtabs"></a>
<a name="index-input-tabs"></a>
<p>Expand <var>tab</var>s to spaces on input.  Optional argument <var>in-tabchar</var> is
the input tab character (default is the TAB character).  Second optional
argument <var>in-tabwidth</var> is the input tab character&rsquo;s width (default
is 8).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-F</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--form-feed</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dF"></a>
<a name="index-_002df-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dform_002dfeed"></a>
<p>Use a form feed instead of newlines to separate output pages.  This does
not alter the default page length of 66 lines.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h <var>header</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--header=<var>header</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dheader"></a>
<p>Replace the file name in the header with the centered string <var>header</var>.
When using the shell, <var>header</var> should be quoted and should be
separated from <samp>-h</samp> by a space.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i[<var>out-tabchar</var>[<var>out-tabwidth</var>]]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output-tabs[=<var>out-tabchar</var>[<var>out-tabwidth</var>]]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002doutput_002dtabs"></a>
<a name="index-output-tabs"></a>
<p>Replace spaces with <var>tab</var>s on output.  Optional argument <var>out-tabchar</var>
is the output tab character (default is the TAB character).  Second optional
argument <var>out-tabwidth</var> is the output tab character&rsquo;s width (default
is 8).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-J</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--join-lines</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dJ"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002djoin_002dlines"></a>
<p>Merge lines of full length.  Used together with the column options
<samp>-<var>column</var></samp>, <samp>-a -<var>column</var></samp> or <samp>-m</samp>.  Turns off
<samp>-W/-w</samp> line truncation;
no column alignment used; may be used with
<samp>--sep-string[=<var>string</var>]</samp>.  <samp>-J</samp> has been introduced
(together with <samp>-W</samp> and <samp>--sep-string</samp>)
to disentangle the old (POSIX-compliant) options <samp>-w</samp> and
<samp>-s</samp> along with the three column options.
</p>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l <var>page_length</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--length=<var>page_length</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlength"></a>
<p>Set the page length to <var>page_length</var> (default 66) lines, including
the lines of the header [and the footer].  If <var>page_length</var> is less
than or equal to 10, the header and footer are omitted, as if the
<samp>-t</samp> option had been given.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--merge</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmerge"></a>
<p>Merge and print all <var>file</var>s in parallel, one in each column.  If a
line is too long to fit in a column, it is truncated, unless the <samp>-J</samp>
option is used.  <samp>--sep-string[=<var>string</var>]</samp> may be used.
Empty pages in
some <var>file</var>s (form feeds set) produce empty columns, still marked
by <var>string</var>.  The result is a continuous line numbering and column
marking throughout the whole merged file.  Completely empty merged pages
show no separators or line numbers.  The default header becomes
&lsquo;<samp><var>date</var> <var>page</var></samp>&rsquo; with spaces inserted in the middle; this
may be used with the <samp>-h</samp> or <samp>--header</samp> option to fill up
the middle blank part.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n[<var>number-separator</var>[<var>digits</var>]]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--number-lines[=<var>number-separator</var>[<var>digits</var>]]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumber_002dlines"></a>
<p>Provide <var>digits</var> digit line numbering (default for <var>digits</var> is
5).  With multicolumn output the number occupies the first <var>digits</var>
column positions of each text column or only each line of <samp>-m</samp>
output.  With single column output the number precedes each line just as
<samp>-m</samp> does.  Default counting of the line numbers starts with the
first line of the input file (not the first line printed, compare the
<samp>--page</samp> option and <samp>-N</samp> option).
Optional argument <var>number-separator</var> is the character appended to
the line number to separate it from the text followed.  The default
separator is the TAB character.  In a strict sense a TAB is always
printed with single column output only.  The TAB width varies
with the TAB position, e.g., with the left <var>margin</var> specified
by <samp>-o</samp> option.  With multicolumn output priority is given to
&lsquo;<samp>equal width of output columns</samp>&rsquo; (a POSIX specification).
The TAB width is fixed to the value of the first column and does
not change with different values of left <var>margin</var>.  That means a
fixed number of spaces is always printed in the place of the
<var>number-separator</var> TAB.  The tabification depends upon the output
position.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-N <var>line_number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--first-line-number=<var>line_number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dN-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfirst_002dline_002dnumber"></a>
<p>Start line counting with the number <var>line_number</var> at first line of
first page printed (in most cases not the first line of the input file).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o <var>margin</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--indent=<var>margin</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dindent"></a>
<a name="index-indenting-lines"></a>
<a name="index-left-margin"></a>
<p>Indent each line with a margin <var>margin</var> spaces wide (default is zero).
The total page width is the size of the margin plus the <var>page_width</var>
set with the <samp>-W/-w</samp> option.  A limited overflow may occur with
numbered single column output (compare <samp>-n</samp> option).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-file-warnings</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dfile_002dwarnings"></a>
<p>Do not print a warning message when an argument <var>file</var> cannot be
opened.  (The exit status will still be nonzero, however.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s[<var>char</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--separator[=<var>char</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dseparator-1"></a>
<p>Separate columns by a single character <var>char</var>.  The default for
<var>char</var> is the TAB character without <samp>-w</samp> and &lsquo;<samp>no
character</samp>&rsquo; with <samp>-w</samp>.  Without <samp>-s</samp> the default separator
&lsquo;<samp>space</samp>&rsquo; is set.  <samp>-s[char]</samp> turns off line truncation of all
three column options (<samp>-COLUMN</samp>|<samp>-a -COLUMN</samp>|<samp>-m</samp>) unless
<samp>-w</samp> is set.  This is a POSIX-compliant formulation.
</p>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S[<var>string</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sep-string[=<var>string</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsep_002dstring"></a>
<p>Use <var>string</var> to separate output columns.  The <samp>-S</samp> option doesn&rsquo;t
affect the <samp>-W/-w</samp> option, unlike the <samp>-s</samp> option which does.  It
does not affect line truncation or column alignment.
Without <samp>-S</samp>, and with <samp>-J</samp>, <code>pr</code> uses the default output
separator, TAB.
Without <samp>-S</samp> or <samp>-J</samp>, <code>pr</code> uses a &lsquo;<samp>space</samp>&rsquo;
(same as <samp>-S&quot;&nbsp;<!-- /@w -->&quot;</samp>).
If no &lsquo;<samp><var>string</var></samp>&rsquo; argument is specified, &lsquo;<samp>&quot;&quot;</samp>&rsquo; is assumed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--omit-header</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002domit_002dheader"></a>
<p>Do not print the usual header [and footer] on each page, and do not fill
out the bottom of pages (with blank lines or a form feed).  No page
structure is produced, but form feeds set in the input files are retained.
The predefined pagination is not changed.  <samp>-t</samp> or <samp>-T</samp> may be
useful together with other options; e.g.: <samp>-t -e4</samp>, expand TAB characters
in the input file to 4 spaces but don&rsquo;t make any other changes.  Use of
<samp>-t</samp> overrides <samp>-h</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--omit-pagination</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002domit_002dpagination"></a>
<p>Do not print header [and footer].  In addition eliminate all form feeds
set in the input files.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--show-nonprinting</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dshow_002dnonprinting-1"></a>
<p>Print nonprinting characters in octal backslash notation.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>page_width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--width=<var>page_width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwidth-2"></a>
<p>Set page width to <var>page_width</var> characters for multiple text-column
output only (default for <var>page_width</var> is 72).  The specified
<var>page_width</var> is rounded down so that columns have equal width.
<samp>-s[CHAR]</samp> turns off the default page width and any line truncation
and column alignment.
Lines of full length are merged, regardless of the column options
set.  No <var>page_width</var> setting is possible with single column output.
A POSIX-compliant formulation.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-W <var>page_width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--page_width=<var>page_width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dW"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dpage_005fwidth"></a>
<p>Set the page width to <var>page_width</var> characters, honored with and
without a column option.  With a column option, the specified <var>page_width</var>
is rounded down so that columns have equal width.  Text lines are truncated,
unless <samp>-J</samp> is used. Together with one of the three column options
(<samp>-<var>column</var></samp>, <samp>-a -<var>column</var></samp> or <samp>-m</samp>) column
alignment is always used.  The separator options <samp>-S</samp> or <samp>-s</samp>
don&rsquo;t disable the <samp>-W</samp> option.  Default is 72 characters.  Without
<samp>-W <var>page_width</var></samp> and without any of the column options NO line
truncation is used (defined to keep downward compatibility and to meet
most frequent tasks).  That&rsquo;s equivalent to <samp>-W 72 -J</samp>.  The header
line is never truncated.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="fold-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#pr-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">pr invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Formatting-file-contents" accesskey="u" rel="up">Formatting file contents</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="fold_003a-Wrap-input-lines-to-fit-in-specified-width"></a>
<h3 class="section">4.3 <code>fold</code>: Wrap input lines to fit in specified width</h3>

<a name="index-fold"></a>
<a name="index-wrapping-long-input-lines"></a>
<a name="index-folding-long-input-lines"></a>

<p><code>fold</code> writes each <var>file</var> (<samp>-</samp> means standard input), or
standard input if none are given, to standard output, breaking long
lines.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">fold [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>By default, <code>fold</code> breaks lines wider than 80 columns.  The output
is split into as many lines as necessary.
</p>
<a name="index-screen-columns"></a>
<p><code>fold</code> counts screen columns by default; thus, a tab may count more
than one column, backspace decreases the column count, and carriage
return sets the column to zero.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bytes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbytes"></a>
<p>Count bytes rather than columns, so that tabs, backspaces, and carriage
returns are each counted as taking up one column, just like other
characters.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--spaces</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dspaces"></a>
<p>Break at word boundaries: the line is broken after the last blank before
the maximum line length.  If the line contains no such blanks, the line
is broken at the maximum line length as usual.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--width=<var>width</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwidth-3"></a>
<p>Use a maximum line length of <var>width</var> columns instead of 80.
</p>
<p>For compatibility <code>fold</code> supports an obsolete option syntax
<samp>-<var>width</var></samp>.  New scripts should use <samp>-w <var>width</var></samp>
instead.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Output-of-parts-of-files"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="n" rel="next">Summarizing files</a>, Previous: <a href="#Formatting-file-contents" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Formatting file contents</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Output-of-parts-of-files-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">5 Output of parts of files</h2>

<a name="index-output-of-parts-of-files"></a>
<a name="index-parts-of-files_002c-output-of"></a>

<p>These commands output pieces of the input.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#head-invocation" accesskey="1">head invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Output the first part of files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#tail-invocation" accesskey="2">tail invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Output the last part of files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#split-invocation" accesskey="3">split invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Split a file into pieces.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#csplit-invocation" accesskey="4">csplit invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Split a file into context-determined pieces.
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="head-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#tail-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">tail invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-parts-of-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of parts of files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="head_003a-Output-the-first-part-of-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">5.1 <code>head</code>: Output the first part of files</h3>

<a name="index-head"></a>
<a name="index-initial-part-of-files_002c-outputting"></a>
<a name="index-first-part-of-files_002c-outputting"></a>

<p><code>head</code> prints the first part (10 lines by default) of each
<var>file</var>; it reads from standard input if no files are given or
when given a <var>file</var> of <samp>-</samp>.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">head [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If more than one <var>file</var> is specified, <code>head</code> prints a
one-line header consisting of:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">==&gt; <var>file name</var> &lt;==
</pre></div>

<p>before the output for each <var>file</var>.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c [-]<var>num</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bytes=[-]<var>num</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbytes-1"></a>
<p>Print the first <var>num</var> bytes, instead of initial lines.
However, if <var>num</var> is prefixed with a &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;,
print all but the last <var>num</var> bytes of each file.
<var>num</var> may be, or may be an integer optionally followed by,
one of the following multiplicative suffixes:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;            512 (&quot;blocks&quot;)
&lsquo;<samp>KB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;           1000 (KiloBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;           1024 (KibiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;      1000*1000 (MegaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;      1024*1024 (MebiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>GB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt; 1000*1000*1000 (GigaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; 1024*1024*1024 (GibiBytes)
</pre></div>
<p>and so on for &lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;.
Binary prefixes can be used, too: &lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>MiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;,
and so on.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n [-]<var>num</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--lines=[-]<var>num</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlines"></a>
<p>Output the first <var>num</var> lines.
However, if <var>num</var> is prefixed with a &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;,
print all but the last <var>num</var> lines of each file.
Size multiplier suffixes are the same as with the <samp>-c</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dq"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent"></a>
<p>Never print file name headers.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose"></a>
<p>Always print file name headers.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>For compatibility <code>head</code> also supports an obsolete option syntax
<samp>-[<var>num</var>][bkm][cqv]</samp>, which is recognized only if it is
specified first.  <var>num</var> is a decimal number optionally followed
by a size letter (&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>k</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>m</samp>&rsquo;) as in <samp>-c</samp>, or
&lsquo;<samp>l</samp>&rsquo; to mean count by lines, or other option letters (&lsquo;<samp>cqv</samp>&rsquo;).
Scripts intended for standard hosts should use <samp>-c <var>num</var></samp>
or <samp>-n <var>num</var></samp> instead.  If your script must also run on
hosts that support only the obsolete syntax, it is usually simpler to
avoid <code>head</code>, e.g., by using &lsquo;<samp>sed 5q</samp>&rsquo; instead of
&lsquo;<samp>head -5</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="tail-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#split-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">split invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#head-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">head invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-parts-of-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of parts of files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="tail_003a-Output-the-last-part-of-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">5.2 <code>tail</code>: Output the last part of files</h3>

<a name="index-tail"></a>
<a name="index-last-part-of-files_002c-outputting"></a>

<p><code>tail</code> prints the last part (10 lines by default) of each
<var>file</var>; it reads from standard input if no files are given or
when given a <var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tail [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If more than one <var>file</var> is specified, <code>tail</code> prints a
one-line header before the output for each <var>file</var>, consisting of:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">==&gt; <var>file name</var> &lt;==
</pre></div>

<p>For further processing of tail output, it can be useful to convert the
file headers to line prefixes, which can be done like:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tail &hellip; |
awk '
  /^==&gt; .* &lt;==$/ {prefix=substr($0,5,length-8)&quot;:&quot;; next}
  {print prefix$0}
' | &hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-BSD-tail"></a>
<p>GNU <code>tail</code> can output any amount of data (some other versions of
<code>tail</code> cannot).  It also has no <samp>-r</samp> option (print in
reverse), since reversing a file is really a different job from printing
the end of a file; BSD <code>tail</code> (which is the one with <samp>-r</samp>) can
only reverse files that are at most as large as its buffer, which is
typically 32 KiB.  A more reliable and versatile way to reverse files is
the GNU <code>tac</code> command.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c [+]<var>num</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bytes=[+]<var>num</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbytes-2"></a>
<p>Output the last <var>num</var> bytes, instead of final lines.
However, if <var>num</var> is prefixed with a &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;, start printing with
byte <var>num</var> from the start of each file, instead of from the end.
<var>num</var> may be, or may be an integer optionally followed by,
one of the following multiplicative suffixes:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;            512 (&quot;blocks&quot;)
&lsquo;<samp>KB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;           1000 (KiloBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;           1024 (KibiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;      1000*1000 (MegaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;      1024*1024 (MebiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>GB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt; 1000*1000*1000 (GigaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; 1024*1024*1024 (GibiBytes)
</pre></div>
<p>and so on for &lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;.
Binary prefixes can be used, too: &lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>MiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;,
and so on.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--follow[=<var>how</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfollow"></a>
<a name="index-growing-files"></a>
<a name="index-name-follow-option"></a>
<a name="index-descriptor-follow-option"></a>
<p>Loop forever trying to read more characters at the end of the file,
presumably because the file is growing.
If more than one file is given, <code>tail</code> prints a header whenever it
gets output from a different file, to indicate which file that output is
from.
</p>
<p>There are two ways to specify how you&rsquo;d like to track files with this option,
but that difference is noticeable only when a followed file is removed or
renamed.
If you&rsquo;d like to continue to track the end of a growing file even after
it has been unlinked, use <samp>--follow=descriptor</samp>.  This is the default
behavior, but it is not useful if you&rsquo;re tracking a log file that may be
rotated (removed or renamed, then reopened).  In that case, use
<samp>--follow=name</samp> to track the named file, perhaps by reopening it
periodically to see if it has been removed and recreated by some other program.
Note that the inotify-based implementation handles this case without
the need for any periodic reopening.
</p>
<p>No matter which method you use, if the tracked file is determined to have
shrunk, <code>tail</code> prints a message saying the file has been truncated
and resumes tracking the end of the file from the newly-determined endpoint.
</p>
<p>When a file is removed, <code>tail</code>&rsquo;s behavior depends on whether it is
following the name or the descriptor.  When following by name, tail can
detect that a file has been removed and gives a message to that effect,
and if <samp>--retry</samp> has been specified it will continue checking
periodically to see if the file reappears.
When following a descriptor, tail does not detect that the file has
been unlinked or renamed and issues no message;  even though the file
may no longer be accessible via its original name, it may still be
growing.
</p>
<p>The option values &lsquo;<samp>descriptor</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>name</samp>&rsquo; may be specified only
with the long form of the option, not with <samp>-f</samp>.
</p>
<p>The <samp>-f</samp> option is ignored if
no <var>file</var> operand is specified and standard input is a FIFO or a pipe.
Likewise, the <samp>-f</samp> option has no effect for any
operand specified as &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, when standard input is a FIFO or a pipe.
</p>
<p>With kernel inotify support, output is triggered by file changes
and is generally very prompt.
Otherwise, <code>tail</code> sleeps for one second between checks&mdash;
use <samp>--sleep-interval=<var>n</var></samp> to change that default&mdash;which can
make the output appear slightly less responsive or bursty.
When using tail without inotify support, you can make it more responsive
by using a sub-second sleep interval, e.g., via an alias like this:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">alias tail='tail -s.1'
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-F</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dF-1"></a>
<p>This option is the same as <samp>--follow=name --retry</samp>.  That is, tail
will attempt to reopen a file when it is removed.  Should this fail, tail
will keep trying until it becomes accessible again.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--max-unchanged-stats=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dmax_002dunchanged_002dstats"></a>
<p>When tailing a file by name, if there have been <var>n</var> (default
n=5) consecutive
iterations for which the file has not changed, then
<code>open</code>/<code>fstat</code> the file to determine if that file name is
still associated with the same device/inode-number pair as before.
When following a log file that is rotated, this is approximately the
number of seconds between when tail prints the last pre-rotation lines
and when it prints the lines that have accumulated in the new log file.
This option is meaningful only when polling (i.e., without inotify)
and when following by name.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n [+]<var>num</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--lines=[+]<var></var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlines-1"></a>
<p>Output the last <var>num</var> lines.
However, if <var>num</var> is prefixed with a &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;, start printing with
line <var>num</var> from the start of each file, instead of from the end.
Size multiplier suffixes are the same as with the <samp>-c</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--pid=<var>pid</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpid"></a>
<p>When following by name or by descriptor, you may specify the process ID,
<var>pid</var>, of the sole writer of all <var>file</var> arguments.  Then, shortly
after that process terminates, tail will also terminate.  This will
work properly only if the writer and the tailing process are running on
the same machine.  For example, to save the output of a build in a file
and to watch the file grow, if you invoke <code>make</code> and <code>tail</code>
like this then the tail process will stop when your build completes.
Without this option, you would have had to kill the <code>tail -f</code>
process yourself.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ make &gt;&amp; makerr &amp; tail --pid=$! -f makerr
</pre></div>

<p>If you specify a <var>pid</var> that is not in use or that does not correspond
to the process that is writing to the tailed files, then <code>tail</code>
may terminate long before any <var>file</var>s stop growing or it may not
terminate until long after the real writer has terminated.
Note that <samp>--pid</samp> cannot be supported on some systems; <code>tail</code>
will print a warning if this is the case.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dq-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent-1"></a>
<p>Never print file name headers.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--retry</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dretry"></a>
<p>Indefinitely try to open the specified file.
This option is useful mainly when following (and otherwise issues a warning).
</p>
<p>When following by file descriptor (i.e., with <samp>--follow=descriptor</samp>),
this option only affects the initial open of the file, as after a successful
open, <code>tail</code> will start following the file descriptor.
</p>
<p>When following by name (i.e., with <samp>--follow=name</samp>), <code>tail</code>
infinitely retries to re-open the given files until killed.
</p>
<p>Without this option, when <code>tail</code> encounters a file that doesn&rsquo;t
exist or is otherwise inaccessible, it reports that fact and
never checks it again.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sleep-interval=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsleep_002dinterval"></a>
<p>Change the number of seconds to wait between iterations (the default is 1.0).
During one iteration, every specified file is checked to see if it has
changed size.
When <code>tail</code> uses inotify, this polling-related option
is usually ignored.  However, if you also specify <samp>--pid=<var>p</var></samp>,
<code>tail</code> checks whether process <var>p</var> is alive at least
every <var>number</var> seconds.
The <var>number</var> must be non-negative and can be a floating-point number
in either the current or the C locale.  See <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-1"></a>
<p>Always print file name headers.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-1"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-1"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>For compatibility <code>tail</code> also supports an obsolete usage
&lsquo;<samp>tail -[<var>num</var>][bcl][f] [<var>file</var>]</samp>&rsquo;, which is recognized
only if it does not conflict with the usage described
above.  This obsolete form uses exactly one option and at most one
file.  In the option, <var>num</var> is an optional decimal number optionally
followed by a size letter (&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>l</samp>&rsquo;) to mean count
by 512-byte blocks, bytes, or lines, optionally followed by &lsquo;<samp>f</samp>&rsquo;
which has the same meaning as <samp>-f</samp>.
</p>
<a name="index-_005fPOSIX2_005fVERSION-1"></a>
<p>On systems not conforming to POSIX 1003.1-2001, the leading &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;
can be replaced by &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; in the traditional option syntax with the
same meaning as in counts, and on obsolete systems predating POSIX
1003.1-2001 traditional usage overrides normal usage when the two
conflict.  This behavior can be controlled with the
<code>_POSIX2_VERSION</code> environment variable (see <a href="#Standards-conformance">Standards conformance</a>).
</p>
<p>Scripts intended for use on standard hosts should avoid traditional
syntax and should use <samp>-c <var>num</var>[b]</samp>, <samp>-n
<var>num</var></samp>, and/or <samp>-f</samp> instead.  If your script must also
run on hosts that support only the traditional syntax, you can often
rewrite it to avoid problematic usages, e.g., by using &lsquo;<samp>sed -n
'$p'</samp>&rsquo; rather than &lsquo;<samp>tail -1</samp>&rsquo;.  If that&rsquo;s not possible, the script
can use a test like &lsquo;<samp>if tail -c +1 &lt;/dev/null &gt;/dev/null 2&gt;&amp;1;
then &hellip;</samp>&rsquo; to decide which syntax to use.
</p>
<p>Even if your script assumes the standard behavior, you should still
beware usages whose behaviors differ depending on the POSIX
version.  For example, avoid &lsquo;<samp>tail - main.c</samp>&rsquo;, since it might be
interpreted as either &lsquo;<samp>tail main.c</samp>&rsquo; or as &lsquo;<samp>tail -- -
main.c</samp>&rsquo;; avoid &lsquo;<samp>tail -c 4</samp>&rsquo;, since it might mean either &lsquo;<samp>tail
-c4</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>tail -c 10 4</samp>&rsquo;; and avoid &lsquo;<samp>tail +4</samp>&rsquo;, since it might
mean either &lsquo;<samp>tail ./+4</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>tail -n +4</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="split-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#csplit-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">csplit invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#tail-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">tail invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-parts-of-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of parts of files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="split_003a-Split-a-file-into-pieces_002e"></a>
<h3 class="section">5.3 <code>split</code>: Split a file into pieces.</h3>

<a name="index-split"></a>
<a name="index-splitting-a-file-into-pieces"></a>
<a name="index-pieces_002c-splitting-a-file-into"></a>

<p><code>split</code> creates output files containing consecutive or interleaved
sections of <var>input</var>  (standard input if none is given or <var>input</var>
is &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;).  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">split [<var>option</var>] [<var>input</var> [<var>prefix</var>]]
</pre></div>

<p>By default, <code>split</code> puts 1000 lines of <var>input</var> (or whatever is
left over for the last section), into each output file.
</p>
<a name="index-output-file-name-prefix"></a>
<p>The output files&rsquo; names consist of <var>prefix</var> (&lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo; by default)
followed by a group of characters (&lsquo;<samp>aa</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>ab</samp>&rsquo;, &hellip; by
default), such that concatenating the output files in traditional
sorted order by file name produces the original input file (except
<samp>-nr/<var>n</var></samp>).  By default split will initially create files
with two generated suffix characters, and will increase this width by two
when the next most significant position reaches the last character.
(&lsquo;<samp>yz</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>zaaa</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>zaab</samp>&rsquo;, &hellip;).  In this way an arbitrary
number of output files are supported, which sort as described above,
even in the presence of an <samp>--additional-suffix</samp> option.
If the <samp>-a</samp> option is specified and the output file names are
exhausted, <code>split</code> reports an error without deleting the
output files that it did create.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l <var>lines</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--lines=<var>lines</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlines-2"></a>
<p>Put <var>lines</var> lines of <var>input</var> into each output file.
If <samp>--separator</samp> is specified, then <var>lines</var> determines
the number of records.
</p>
<p>For compatibility <code>split</code> also supports an obsolete
option syntax <samp>-<var>lines</var></samp>.  New scripts should use
<samp>-l <var>lines</var></samp> instead.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b <var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bytes=<var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbytes-3"></a>
<p>Put <var>size</var> bytes of <var>input</var> into each output file.
<var>size</var> may be, or may be an integer optionally followed by,
one of the following multiplicative suffixes:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;            512 (&quot;blocks&quot;)
&lsquo;<samp>KB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;           1000 (KiloBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;           1024 (KibiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;      1000*1000 (MegaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;      1024*1024 (MebiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>GB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt; 1000*1000*1000 (GigaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; 1024*1024*1024 (GibiBytes)
</pre></div>
<p>and so on for &lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;.
Binary prefixes can be used, too: &lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>MiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;,
and so on.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-C <var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--line-bytes=<var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dC"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dline_002dbytes"></a>
<p>Put into each output file as many complete lines of <var>input</var> as
possible without exceeding <var>size</var> bytes.  Individual lines or records
longer than <var>size</var> bytes are broken into multiple files.
<var>size</var> has the same format as for the <samp>--bytes</samp> option.
If <samp>--separator</samp> is specified, then <var>lines</var> determines
the number of records.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--filter=<var>command</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfilter"></a>
<p>With this option, rather than simply writing to each output file,
write through a pipe to the specified shell <var>command</var> for each output file.
<var>command</var> should use the $FILE environment variable, which is set
to a different output file name for each invocation of the command.
For example, imagine that you have a 1TiB compressed file
that, if uncompressed, would be too large to reside on disk,
yet you must split it into individually-compressed pieces
of a more manageable size.
To do that, you might run this command:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">xz -dc BIG.xz | split -b200G --filter='xz &gt; $FILE.xz' - big-
</pre></div>

<p>Assuming a 10:1 compression ratio, that would create about fifty 20GiB files
with names <samp>big-aa.xz</samp>, <samp>big-ab.xz</samp>, <samp>big-ac.xz</samp>, etc.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n <var>chunks</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--number=<var>chunks</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumber-1"></a>

<p>Split <var>input</var> to <var>chunks</var> output files where <var>chunks</var> may be:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"><var>n</var>      generate <var>n</var> files based on current size of <var>input</var>
<var>k</var>/<var>n</var>    only output <var>k</var>th of <var>n</var> to stdout
l/<var>n</var>    generate <var>n</var> files without splitting lines or records
l/<var>k</var>/<var>n</var>  likewise but only output <var>k</var>th of <var>n</var> to stdout
r/<var>n</var>    like &lsquo;<samp>l</samp>&rsquo; but use round robin distribution
r/<var>k</var>/<var>n</var>  likewise but only output <var>k</var>th of <var>n</var> to stdout
</pre></div>

<p>Any excess bytes remaining after dividing the <var>input</var>
into <var>n</var> chunks, are assigned to the last chunk.
Any excess bytes appearing after the initial calculation are discarded
(except when using &lsquo;<samp>r</samp>&rsquo; mode).
</p>
<p>All <var>n</var> files are created even if there are fewer than <var>n</var> lines,
or the <var>input</var> is truncated.
</p>
<p>For &lsquo;<samp>l</samp>&rsquo; mode, chunks are approximately <var>input</var> size / <var>n</var>.
The <var>input</var> is partitioned into <var>n</var> equal sized portions, with
the last assigned any excess.  If a line <em>starts</em> within a partition
it is written completely to the corresponding file.  Since lines or records
are not split even if they overlap a partition, the files written
can be larger or smaller than the partition size, and even empty
if a line/record is so long as to completely overlap the partition.
</p>
<p>For &lsquo;<samp>r</samp>&rsquo; mode, the size of <var>input</var> is irrelevant,
and so can be a pipe for example.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a <var>length</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix-length=<var>length</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix_002dlength"></a>
<p>Use suffixes of length <var>length</var>.  If a <var>length</var> of 0 is specified,
this is the same as if (any previous) <samp>-a</samp> was not specified, and
thus enables the default behavior, which starts the suffix length at 2,
and unless <samp>-n</samp> or <samp>--numeric-suffixes=<var>from</var></samp> is
specified, will auto increase the length by 2 as required.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--numeric-suffixes[=<var>from</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumeric_002dsuffixes"></a>
<p>Use digits in suffixes rather than lower-case letters.  The numerical
suffix counts from <var>from</var> if specified, 0 otherwise.
</p>
<p><var>from</var> is supported with the long form option, and is used to either set the
initial suffix for a single run, or to set the suffix offset for independently
split inputs, and consequently the auto suffix length expansion described above
is disabled.  Therefore you may also want to use option <samp>-a</samp> to allow
suffixes beyond &lsquo;<samp>99</samp>&rsquo;.  Note if option <samp>--number</samp> is specified and
the number of files is less than <var>from</var>, a single run is assumed and the
minimum suffix length required is automatically determined.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--hex-suffixes[=<var>from</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhex_002dsuffixes"></a>
<p>Like <samp>--numeric-suffixes</samp>, but use hexadecimal numbers (in lower case).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--additional-suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dadditional_002dsuffix"></a>
<p>Append an additional <var>suffix</var> to output file names.  <var>suffix</var>
must not contain slash.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--elide-empty-files</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002delide_002dempty_002dfiles"></a>
<p>Suppress the generation of zero-length output files.  This can happen
with the <samp>--number</samp> option if a file is (truncated to be) shorter
than the number requested, or if a line is so long as to completely
span a chunk.  The output file sequence numbers, always run consecutively
even when this option is specified.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>separator</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--separator=<var>separator</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dseparator-2"></a>
<a name="index-line-separator-character"></a>
<a name="index-record-separator-character"></a>
<p>Use character <var>separator</var> as the record separator instead of the default
newline character (ASCII LF).
To specify ASCII NUL as the separator, use the two-character string &lsquo;<samp>\0</samp>&rsquo;,
e.g., &lsquo;<samp>split -t '\0'</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--unbuffered</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dunbuffered"></a>
<p>Immediately copy input to output in <samp>--number r/&hellip;</samp> mode,
which is a much slower mode of operation.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-2"></a>
<p>Write a diagnostic just before each output file is opened.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Here are a few examples to illustrate how the
<samp>--number</samp> (<samp>-n</samp>) option works:
</p>
<p>Notice how, by default, one line may be split onto two or more:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq -w 6 10 &gt; k; split -n3 k; head xa?
==&gt; xaa &lt;==
06
07
==&gt; xab &lt;==

08
0
==&gt; xac &lt;==
9
10
</pre></div>

<p>Use the &quot;l/&quot; modifier to suppress that:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq -w 6 10 &gt; k; split -nl/3 k; head xa?
==&gt; xaa &lt;==
06
07

==&gt; xab &lt;==
08
09

==&gt; xac &lt;==
10
</pre></div>

<p>Use the &quot;r/&quot; modifier to distribute lines in a round-robin fashion:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq -w 6 10 &gt; k; split -nr/3 k; head xa?
==&gt; xaa &lt;==
06
09

==&gt; xab &lt;==
07
10

==&gt; xac &lt;==
08
</pre></div>

<p>You can also extract just the Kth chunk.
This extracts and prints just the 7th &quot;chunk&quot; of 33:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq 100 &gt; k; split -nl/7/33 k
20
21
22
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="csplit-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#split-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">split invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Output-of-parts-of-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Output of parts of files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="csplit_003a-Split-a-file-into-context_002ddetermined-pieces"></a>
<h3 class="section">5.4 <code>csplit</code>: Split a file into context-determined pieces</h3>

<a name="index-csplit"></a>
<a name="index-context-splitting"></a>
<a name="index-splitting-a-file-into-pieces-by-context"></a>

<p><code>csplit</code> creates zero or more output files containing sections of
<var>input</var> (standard input if <var>input</var> is &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;).  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">csplit [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>input</var> <var>pattern</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The contents of the output files are determined by the <var>pattern</var>
arguments, as detailed below.  An error occurs if a <var>pattern</var>
argument refers to a nonexistent line of the input file (e.g., if no
remaining line matches a given regular expression).  After every
<var>pattern</var> has been matched, any remaining input is copied into one
last output file.
</p>
<p>By default, <code>csplit</code> prints the number of bytes written to each
output file after it has been created.
</p>
<p>The types of pattern arguments are:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Create an output file containing the input up to but not including line
<var>n</var> (a positive integer).  If followed by a repeat count, also
create an output file containing the next <var>n</var> lines of the input
file once for each repeat.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>/<var>regexp</var>/[<var>offset</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Create an output file containing the current line up to (but not
including) the next line of the input file that contains a match for
<var>regexp</var>.  The optional <var>offset</var> is an integer.
If it is given, the input up to (but not including) the
matching line plus or minus <var>offset</var> is put into the output file,
and the line after that begins the next section of input.
Note lines within a negative offset of a regexp pattern
are not matched in subsequent regexp patterns.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%<var>regexp</var>%[<var>offset</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Like the previous type, except that it does not create an output
file, so that section of the input file is effectively ignored.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>{<var>repeat-count</var>}</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Repeat the previous pattern <var>repeat-count</var> additional
times.  The <var>repeat-count</var> can either be a positive integer or an
asterisk, meaning repeat as many times as necessary until the input is
exhausted.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>The output files&rsquo; names consist of a prefix (&lsquo;<samp>xx</samp>&rsquo; by default)
followed by a suffix.  By default, the suffix is an ascending sequence
of two-digit decimal numbers from &lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo; to &lsquo;<samp>99</samp>&rsquo;.  In any case,
concatenating the output files in sorted order by file name produces the
original input file, excluding portions skipped with a %<var>regexp</var>%
pattern or the <samp>--suppress-matched</samp> option.
</p>
<p>By default, if <code>csplit</code> encounters an error or receives a hangup,
interrupt, quit, or terminate signal, it removes any output files
that it has created so far before it exits.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f <var>prefix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--prefix=<var>prefix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dprefix"></a>
<a name="index-output-file-name-prefix-1"></a>
<p>Use <var>prefix</var> as the output file name prefix.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b <var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix-format=<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix_002dformat"></a>
<a name="index-output-file-name-suffix"></a>
<p>Use <var>format</var> as the output file name suffix.  When this option is
specified, the suffix string must include exactly one
<code>printf(3)</code>-style conversion specification, possibly including
format specification flags, a field width, a precision specifications,
or all of these kinds of modifiers.  The format letter must convert a
binary unsigned integer argument to readable form.  The format letters
&lsquo;<samp>d</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>i</samp>&rsquo; are aliases for &lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo;, and the
&lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>o</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo; conversions are allowed.  The
entire <var>format</var> is given (with the current output file number) to
<code>sprintf(3)</code> to form the file name suffixes for each of the
individual output files in turn.  If this option is used, the
<samp>--digits</samp> option is ignored.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n <var>digits</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--digits=<var>digits</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddigits"></a>
<p>Use output file names containing numbers that are <var>digits</var> digits
long instead of the default 2.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-k</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--keep-files</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dk-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dkeep_002dfiles"></a>
<p>Do not remove output files when errors are encountered.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suppress-matched</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsuppress_002dmatched"></a>
<p>Do not output lines matching the specified <var>pattern</var>.
I.e., suppress the boundary line from the start of the second
and subsequent splits.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--elide-empty-files</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002delide_002dempty_002dfiles-1"></a>
<p>Suppress the generation of zero-length output files.  (In cases where
the section delimiters of the input file are supposed to mark the first
lines of each of the sections, the first output file will generally be a
zero-length file unless you use this option.)  The output file sequence
numbers always run consecutively starting from 0, even when this option
is specified.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002dq-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-2"></a>
<p>Do not print counts of output file sizes.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Here is an example of its usage.
First, create an empty directory for the exercise,
and cd into it:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ mkdir d &amp;&amp; cd d
</pre></div>

<p>Now, split the sequence of 1..14 on lines that end with 0 or 5:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq 14 | csplit - '/[05]$/' '{*}'
8
10
15
</pre></div>

<p>Each number printed above is the size of an output
file that csplit has just created.
List the names of those output files:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ ls
xx00  xx01  xx02
</pre></div>

<p>Use <code>head</code> to show their contents:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ head xx*
==&gt; xx00 &lt;==
1
2
3
4

==&gt; xx01 &lt;==
5
6
7
8
9

==&gt; xx02 &lt;==
10
11
12
13
14
</pre></div>

<p>Example of splitting input by empty lines:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ csplit --suppress-matched <var>input.txt</var> '/^$/' '{*}'
</pre></div>


<hr>

<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Operating-on-sorted-files" accesskey="n" rel="next">Operating on sorted files</a>, Previous: <a href="#Output-of-parts-of-files" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Output of parts of files</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Summarizing-files-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">6 Summarizing files</h2>

<a name="index-summarizing-files"></a>

<p>These commands generate just a few numbers representing entire
contents of files.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#wc-invocation" accesskey="1">wc invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print newline, word, and byte counts.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#sum-invocation" accesskey="2">sum invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print checksum and block counts.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#cksum-invocation" accesskey="3">cksum invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print CRC checksum and byte counts.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#b2sum-invocation" accesskey="4">b2sum invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print or check BLAKE2 digests.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#md5sum-invocation" accesskey="5">md5sum invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print or check MD5 digests.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#sha1sum-invocation" accesskey="6">sha1sum invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print or check SHA-1 digests.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#sha2-utilities" accesskey="7">sha2 utilities</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print or check SHA-2 digests.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="wc-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#sum-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">sum invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Summarizing files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="wc_003a-Print-newline_002c-word_002c-and-byte-counts"></a>
<h3 class="section">6.1 <code>wc</code>: Print newline, word, and byte counts</h3>

<a name="index-wc"></a>
<a name="index-byte-count"></a>
<a name="index-character-count"></a>
<a name="index-word-count"></a>
<a name="index-line-count"></a>

<p><code>wc</code> counts the number of bytes, characters, whitespace-separated
words, and newlines in each given <var>file</var>, or standard input if none
are given or for a <var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">wc [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-total-counts"></a>
<p><code>wc</code> prints one line of counts for each file, and if the file was
given as an argument, it prints the file name following the counts.  If
more than one <var>file</var> is given, <code>wc</code> prints a final line
containing the cumulative counts, with the file name <samp>total</samp>.  The
counts are printed in this order: newlines, words, characters, bytes,
maximum line length.
Each count is printed right-justified in a field with at least one
space between fields so that the numbers and file names normally line
up nicely in columns.  The width of the count fields varies depending
on the inputs, so you should not depend on a particular field width.
However, as a GNU extension, if only one count is printed,
it is guaranteed to be printed without leading spaces.
</p>
<p>By default, <code>wc</code> prints three counts: the newline, words, and byte
counts.  Options can specify that only certain counts be printed.
Options do not undo others previously given, so
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">wc --bytes --words
</pre></div>

<p>prints both the byte counts and the word counts.
</p>
<p>With the <samp>--max-line-length</samp> option, <code>wc</code> prints the length
of the longest line per file, and if there is more than one file it
prints the maximum (not the sum) of those lengths.  The line lengths here
are measured in screen columns, according to the current locale and
assuming tab positions in every 8th column.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bytes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbytes-4"></a>
<p>Print only the byte counts.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--chars</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dchars"></a>
<p>Print only the character counts.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--words</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwords"></a>
<p>Print only the word counts.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--lines</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlines-3"></a>
<p>Print only the newline counts.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--max-line-length</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmax_002dline_002dlength"></a>
<p>Print only the maximum display widths.
Tabs are set at every 8th column.
Display widths of wide characters are considered.
Non-printable characters are given 0 width.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--files0-from=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfiles0_002dfrom_003dfile"></a>
<p>Disallow processing files named on the command line, and instead process
those named in file <var>file</var>; each name being terminated by a zero byte
(ASCII NUL).
This is useful 
when the list of file names is so long that it may exceed a command line
length limitation.
In such cases, running <code>wc</code> via <code>xargs</code> is undesirable
because it splits the list into pieces and makes <code>wc</code> print
a total for each sublist rather than for the entire list.
One way to produce a list of ASCII NUL terminated file
names is with GNU
<code>find</code>, using its <samp>-print0</samp> predicate.
If <var>file</var> is &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; then the ASCII NUL terminated
file names are read from standard input.
</p>
<p>For example, to find the length of the longest line in any <samp>.c</samp> or
<samp>.h</samp> file in the current hierarchy, do this:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">find . -name '*.[ch]' -print0 |
  wc -L --files0-from=- | tail -n1
</pre></div>

</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="sum-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#cksum-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">cksum invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#wc-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">wc invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Summarizing files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="sum_003a-Print-checksum-and-block-counts"></a>
<h3 class="section">6.2 <code>sum</code>: Print checksum and block counts</h3>

<a name="index-sum"></a>
<a name="index-16_002dbit-checksum"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-16_002dbit"></a>

<p><code>sum</code> computes a 16-bit checksum for each given <var>file</var>, or
standard input if none are given or for a <var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sum [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><code>sum</code> prints the checksum for each <var>file</var> followed by the
number of blocks in the file (rounded up).  If more than one <var>file</var>
is given, file names are also printed (by default).  (With the
<samp>--sysv</samp> option, corresponding file names are printed when there is
at least one file argument.)
</p>
<p>By default, GNU <code>sum</code> computes checksums using an algorithm
compatible with BSD <code>sum</code> and prints file sizes in units of
1024-byte blocks.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-2"></a>
<a name="index-BSD-sum"></a>
<p>Use the default (BSD compatible) algorithm.  This option is included for
compatibility with the System V <code>sum</code>.  Unless <samp>-s</samp> was also
given, it has no effect.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sysv</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsysv"></a>
<a name="index-System-V-sum"></a>
<p>Compute checksums using an algorithm compatible with System V
<code>sum</code>&rsquo;s default, and print file sizes in units of 512-byte blocks.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p><code>sum</code> is provided for compatibility; the <code>cksum</code> program (see
next section) is preferable in new applications.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="cksum-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
