Next: <a href="#b2sum-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">b2sum invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#sum-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">sum invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Summarizing files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="cksum_003a-Print-CRC-checksum-and-byte-counts"></a>
<h3 class="section">6.3 <code>cksum</code>: Print CRC checksum and byte counts</h3>

<a name="index-cksum"></a>
<a name="index-cyclic-redundancy-check"></a>
<a name="index-CRC-checksum"></a>

<p><code>cksum</code> computes a cyclic redundancy check (CRC) checksum for each
given <var>file</var>, or standard input if none are given or for a
<var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">cksum [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><code>cksum</code> prints the CRC checksum for each file along with the number
of bytes in the file, and the file name unless no arguments were given.
</p>
<p><code>cksum</code> is typically used to ensure that files
transferred by unreliable means (e.g., netnews) have not been corrupted,
by comparing the <code>cksum</code> output for the received files with the
<code>cksum</code> output for the original files (typically given in the
distribution).
</p>
<p>The CRC algorithm is specified by the POSIX standard.  It is not
compatible with the BSD or System V <code>sum</code> algorithms (see the
previous section); it is more robust.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="b2sum-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#md5sum-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">md5sum invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#cksum-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">cksum invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Summarizing files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="b2sum_003a-Print-or-check-BLAKE2-digests"></a>
<h3 class="section">6.4 <code>b2sum</code>: Print or check BLAKE2 digests</h3>

<a name="index-b2sum"></a>
<a name="index-BLAKE2"></a>
<a name="index-512_002dbit-checksum"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-512_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-fingerprint_002c-512_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-message_002ddigest_002c-512_002dbit"></a>

<p><code>b2sum</code> computes a 512-bit checksum for each specified
<var>file</var>.  The same usage and options as the <code>md5sum</code>
command are supported.  See <a href="#md5sum-invocation">md5sum invocation</a>.
In addition <code>b2sum</code> supports the following options.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--length</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlength-1"></a>
<a name="index-BLAKE2-hash-length"></a>
<p>Change (shorten) the default digest length.
This is specified in bits and thus must be a multiple of 8.
This option is ignored when <samp>--check</samp> is specified,
as the length is automatically determined when checking.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<hr>
<a name="md5sum-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#sha1sum-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">sha1sum invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#b2sum-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">b2sum invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Summarizing files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="md5sum_003a-Print-or-check-MD5-digests"></a>
<h3 class="section">6.5 <code>md5sum</code>: Print or check MD5 digests</h3>

<a name="index-md5sum"></a>
<a name="index-MD5"></a>
<a name="index-128_002dbit-checksum"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-128_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-fingerprint_002c-128_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-message_002ddigest_002c-128_002dbit"></a>

<p><code>md5sum</code> computes a 128-bit checksum (or <em>fingerprint</em> or
<em>message-digest</em>) for each specified <var>file</var>.
</p>
<p>Note: The MD5 digest is more reliable than a simple CRC (provided by
the <code>cksum</code> command) for detecting accidental file corruption,
as the chances of accidentally having two files with identical MD5
are vanishingly small.  However, it should not be considered secure
against malicious tampering: although finding a file with a given MD5
fingerprint is considered infeasible at the moment, it is known how
to modify certain files, including digital certificates, so that they
appear valid when signed with an MD5 digest.  For more secure hashes,
consider using SHA-2, or the newer <code>b2sum</code> command.
See <a href="#sha2-utilities">sha2 utilities</a>. See <a href="#b2sum-invocation">b2sum invocation</a>.
</p>
<p>If a <var>file</var> is specified as &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; or if no files are given
<code>md5sum</code> computes the checksum for the standard input.
<code>md5sum</code> can also determine whether a file and checksum are
consistent.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">md5sum [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>For each <var>file</var>, &lsquo;<samp>md5sum</samp>&rsquo; outputs by default, the MD5 checksum,
a space, a flag indicating binary or text input mode, and the file name.
Binary mode is indicated with &lsquo;<samp>*</samp>&rsquo;, text mode with &lsquo;<samp> </samp>&rsquo; (space).
Binary mode is the default on systems where it&rsquo;s significant,
otherwise text mode is the default.
Without <samp>--zero</samp>, if <var>file</var> contains a backslash or newline,
the line is started with a backslash, and each problematic character in
the file name is escaped with a backslash, making the output
unambiguous even in the presence of arbitrary file names.
If <var>file</var> is omitted or specified as &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, standard input is read.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--binary</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbinary"></a>
<a name="index-binary-input-files"></a>
<p>Treat each input file as binary, by reading it in binary mode and
outputting a &lsquo;<samp>*</samp>&rsquo; flag.  This is the inverse of <samp>--text</samp>.
On systems like GNU that do not distinguish between binary
and text files, this option merely flags each input mode as binary:
the MD5 checksum is unaffected.  This option is the default on systems
like MS-DOS that distinguish between binary and text files, except
for reading standard input when standard input is a terminal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Read file names and checksum information (not data) from each
<var>file</var> (or from stdin if no <var>file</var> was specified) and report
whether the checksums match the contents of the named files.
The input to this mode of <code>md5sum</code> is usually the output of
a prior, checksum-generating run of &lsquo;<samp>md5sum</samp>&rsquo;.
Three input formats are supported.  Either the default output
format described above, the <samp>--tag</samp> output format,
or the BSD reversed mode format which is similar to the default mode,
but doesn&rsquo;t use a character to distinguish binary and text modes.
Output with <samp>--zero</samp> enabled is not supported by <samp>--check</samp>.
</p><br>
<p>For each such line, <code>md5sum</code> reads the named file and computes its
MD5 checksum.  Then, if the computed message digest does not match the
one on the line with the file name, the file is noted as having
failed the test.  Otherwise, the file passes the test.
By default, for each valid line, one line is written to standard
output indicating whether the named file passed the test.
After all checks have been performed, if there were any failures,
a warning is issued to standard error.
Use the <samp>--status</samp> option to inhibit that output.
If any listed file cannot be opened or read, if any valid line has
an MD5 checksum inconsistent with the associated file, or if no valid
line is found, <code>md5sum</code> exits with nonzero status.  Otherwise,
it exits successfully.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-missing</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dmissing"></a>
<a name="index-verifying-MD5-checksums"></a>
<p>This option is useful only when verifying checksums.
When verifying checksums, don&rsquo;t fail or report any status
for missing files.  This is useful when verifying a subset
of downloaded files given a larger list of checksums.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-3"></a>
<a name="index-verifying-MD5-checksums-1"></a>
<p>This option is useful only when verifying checksums.
When verifying checksums, don&rsquo;t generate an &rsquo;OK&rsquo; message per successfully
checked file.  Files that fail the verification are reported in the
default one-line-per-file format.  If there is any checksum mismatch,
print a warning summarizing the failures to standard error.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--status</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dstatus"></a>
<a name="index-verifying-MD5-checksums-2"></a>
<p>This option is useful only when verifying checksums.
When verifying checksums, don&rsquo;t generate the default one-line-per-file
diagnostic and don&rsquo;t output the warning summarizing any failures.
Failures to open or read a file still evoke individual diagnostics to
standard error.
If all listed files are readable and are consistent with the associated
MD5 checksums, exit successfully.  Otherwise exit with a status code
indicating there was a failure.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--tag</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtag"></a>
<a name="index-BSD-output"></a>
<p>Output BSD style checksums, which indicate the checksum algorithm used.
As a GNU extension, if <samp>--zero</samp> is not used, file names with problematic
characters are escaped as described above, with the same escaping indicator of
&lsquo;<samp>\</samp>&rsquo; at the start of the line, being used.
The <samp>--tag</samp> option implies binary mode, and is disallowed with
<samp>--text</samp> mode as supporting that would unnecessarily complicate
the output format, while providing little benefit.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--text</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtext"></a>
<a name="index-text-input-files"></a>
<p>Treat each input file as text, by reading it in text mode and
outputting a &lsquo;<samp> </samp>&rsquo; flag.  This is the inverse of <samp>--binary</samp>.
This option is the default on systems like GNU that do not
distinguish between binary and text files.  On other systems, it is
the default for reading standard input when standard input is a
terminal.  This mode is never defaulted to if <samp>--tag</samp> is used.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--warn</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwarn"></a>
<a name="index-verifying-MD5-checksums-3"></a>
<p>When verifying checksums, warn about improperly formatted MD5 checksum lines.
This option is useful only if all but a few lines in the checked input
are valid.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--strict</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dstrict"></a>
<a name="index-verifying-MD5-checksums-4"></a>
<p>When verifying checksums,
if one or more input line is invalid,
exit nonzero after all warnings have been issued.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
Also file name escaping is not used.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="sha1sum-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#sha2-utilities" accesskey="n" rel="next">sha2 utilities</a>, Previous: <a href="#md5sum-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">md5sum invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Summarizing files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="sha1sum_003a-Print-or-check-SHA_002d1-digests"></a>
<h3 class="section">6.6 <code>sha1sum</code>: Print or check SHA-1 digests</h3>

<a name="index-sha1sum"></a>
<a name="index-SHA_002d1"></a>
<a name="index-160_002dbit-checksum"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-160_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-fingerprint_002c-160_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-message_002ddigest_002c-160_002dbit"></a>

<p><code>sha1sum</code> computes a 160-bit checksum for each specified
<var>file</var>.  The usage and options of this command are precisely the
same as for <code>md5sum</code>.  See <a href="#md5sum-invocation">md5sum invocation</a>.
</p>
<p>Note: The SHA-1 digest is more reliable than a simple CRC (provided by
the <code>cksum</code> command) for detecting accidental file corruption,
as the chances of accidentally having two files with identical SHA-1
are vanishingly small.  However, it should not be considered secure
against malicious tampering: although finding a file with a given SHA-1
fingerprint is considered infeasible at the moment, it is known how
to modify certain files, including digital certificates, so that they
appear valid when signed with an SHA-1 digest.  For more secure hashes,
consider using SHA-2, or the newer <code>b2sum</code> command.
See <a href="#sha2-utilities">sha2 utilities</a>. See <a href="#b2sum-invocation">b2sum invocation</a>.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="sha2-utilities"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#sha1sum-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">sha1sum invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Summarizing files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="sha2-utilities_003a-Print-or-check-SHA_002d2-digests"></a>
<h3 class="section">6.7 sha2 utilities: Print or check SHA-2 digests</h3>

<a name="index-sha224sum"></a>
<a name="index-sha256sum"></a>
<a name="index-sha384sum"></a>
<a name="index-sha512sum"></a>
<a name="index-SHA_002d2"></a>
<a name="index-224_002dbit-checksum"></a>
<a name="index-256_002dbit-checksum"></a>
<a name="index-384_002dbit-checksum"></a>
<a name="index-512_002dbit-checksum-1"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-224_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-256_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-384_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-checksum_002c-512_002dbit-1"></a>
<a name="index-fingerprint_002c-224_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-fingerprint_002c-256_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-fingerprint_002c-384_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-fingerprint_002c-512_002dbit-1"></a>
<a name="index-message_002ddigest_002c-224_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-message_002ddigest_002c-256_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-message_002ddigest_002c-384_002dbit"></a>
<a name="index-message_002ddigest_002c-512_002dbit-1"></a>

<p>The commands <code>sha224sum</code>, <code>sha256sum</code>,
<code>sha384sum</code> and <code>sha512sum</code> compute checksums of
various lengths (respectively 224, 256, 384 and 512 bits),
collectively known as the SHA-2 hashes.  The usage and options of
these commands are precisely the same as for <code>md5sum</code>
and <code>sha1sum</code>.
See <a href="#md5sum-invocation">md5sum invocation</a>.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Operating-on-sorted-files"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Operating-on-fields" accesskey="n" rel="next">Operating on fields</a>, Previous: <a href="#Summarizing-files" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Summarizing files</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Operating-on-sorted-files-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">7 Operating on sorted files</h2>

<a name="index-operating-on-sorted-files"></a>
<a name="index-sorted-files_002c-operations-on"></a>

<p>These commands work with (or produce) sorted files.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#sort-invocation" accesskey="1">sort invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Sort text files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#shuf-invocation" accesskey="2">shuf invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Shuffle text files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#uniq-invocation" accesskey="3">uniq invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Uniquify files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#comm-invocation" accesskey="4">comm invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Compare two sorted files line by line.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="5">ptx invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Produce a permuted index of file contents.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#tsort-invocation" accesskey="6">tsort invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Topological sort.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="sort-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#shuf-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">shuf invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-sorted-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on sorted files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="sort_003a-Sort-text-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">7.1 <code>sort</code>: Sort text files</h3>

<a name="index-sort"></a>
<a name="index-sorting-files"></a>

<p><code>sort</code> sorts, merges, or compares all the lines from the given
files, or standard input if none are given or for a <var>file</var> of
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  By default, <code>sort</code> writes the results to standard
output.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sort [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-sort-stability"></a>
<a name="index-sort_0027s-last_002dresort-comparison"></a>
<p>Many options affect how <code>sort</code> compares lines; if the results
are unexpected, try the <samp>--debug</samp> option to see what happened.
A pair of lines is compared as follows:
<code>sort</code> compares each pair of fields (see <samp>--key</samp>), in the
order specified on the command line, according to the associated
ordering options, until a difference is found or no fields are left.
If no key fields are specified, <code>sort</code> uses a default key of
the entire line.  Finally, as a last resort when all keys compare
equal, <code>sort</code> compares entire lines as if no ordering options
other than <samp>--reverse</samp> (<samp>-r</samp>) were specified.  The
<samp>--stable</samp> (<samp>-s</samp>) option disables this <em>last-resort
comparison</em> so that lines in which all fields compare equal are left
in their original relative order.  The <samp>--unique</samp>
(<samp>-u</samp>) option also disables the last-resort comparison.
<a name="index-LC_005fALL"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fCOLLATE"></a>
</p>
<p>Unless otherwise specified, all comparisons use the character collating
sequence specified by the <code>LC_COLLATE</code> locale.<a name="DOCF2" href="#FOOT2"><sup>2</sup></a>
A line&rsquo;s trailing newline is not part of the line for comparison
purposes.  If the final byte of an input file is not a newline, GNU
<code>sort</code> silently supplies one.  GNU <code>sort</code> (as
specified for all GNU utilities) has no limit on input line length or
restrictions on bytes allowed within lines.
</p>
<p><code>sort</code> has three modes of operation: sort (the default), merge,
and check for sortedness.  The following options change the operation
mode:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check=diagnose-first</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcheck"></a>
<a name="index-checking-for-sortedness"></a>
<p>Check whether the given file is already sorted: if it is not all
sorted, print a diagnostic containing the first out-of-order line and
exit with a status of 1.
Otherwise, exit successfully.
At most one input file can be given.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-C</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check=quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check=silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcheck-1"></a>
<a name="index-checking-for-sortedness-1"></a>
<p>Exit successfully if the given file is already sorted, and
exit with status 1 otherwise.
At most one input file can be given.
This is like <samp>-c</samp>, except it does not print a diagnostic.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--merge</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmerge-1"></a>
<a name="index-merging-sorted-files"></a>
<p>Merge the given files by sorting them as a group.  Each input file must
always be individually sorted.  It always works to sort instead of
merge; merging is provided because it is faster, in the case where it
works.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-sort"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if no error occurred
1 if invoked with <samp>-c</samp> or <samp>-C</samp> and the input is not sorted
2 if an error occurred
</pre></div>

<a name="index-TMPDIR"></a>
<p>If the environment variable <code>TMPDIR</code> is set, <code>sort</code> uses its
value as the directory for temporary files instead of <samp>/tmp</samp>.  The
<samp>--temporary-directory</samp> (<samp>-T</samp>) option in turn overrides
the environment variable.
</p>
<p>The following options affect the ordering of output lines.  They may be
specified globally or as part of a specific key field.  If no key
fields are specified, global options apply to comparison of entire
lines; otherwise the global options are inherited by key fields that do
not specify any special options of their own.  In pre-POSIX
versions of <code>sort</code>, global options affect only later key fields,
so portable shell scripts should specify global options first.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-leading-blanks</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dleading_002dblanks"></a>
<a name="index-blanks_002c-ignoring-leading"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fCTYPE"></a>
<p>Ignore leading blanks when finding sort keys in each line.
By default a blank is a space or a tab, but the <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale
can change this.  Note blanks may be ignored by your locale&rsquo;s collating
rules, but without this option they will be significant for character
positions specified in keys with the <samp>-k</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dictionary-order</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddictionary_002dorder"></a>
<a name="index-dictionary-order"></a>
<a name="index-phone-directory-order"></a>
<a name="index-telephone-directory-order"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fCTYPE-1"></a>
<p>Sort in <em>phone directory</em> order: ignore all characters except
letters, digits and blanks when sorting.
By default letters and digits are those of ASCII and a blank
is a space or a tab, but the <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale can change this.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-case</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dcase"></a>
<a name="index-ignoring-case"></a>
<a name="index-case-folding"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fCTYPE-2"></a>
<p>Fold lowercase characters into the equivalent uppercase characters when
comparing so that, for example, &lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>B</samp>&rsquo; sort as equal.
The <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale determines character types.
When used with <samp>--unique</samp> those lower case equivalent lines are
thrown away.  (There is currently no way to throw away the upper case
equivalent instead.  (Any <samp>--reverse</samp> given would only affect
the final result, after the throwing away.))
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--general-numeric-sort</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=general-numeric</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dgeneral_002dnumeric_002dsort"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort"></a>
<a name="index-general-numeric-sort"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fNUMERIC-2"></a>
<p>Sort numerically, converting a prefix of each line to a long
double-precision floating point number.  See <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>.
Do not report overflow, underflow, or conversion errors.
Use the following collating sequence:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Lines that do not start with numbers (all considered to be equal).
</li><li> NaNs (&ldquo;Not a Number&rdquo; values, in IEEE floating point arithmetic)
in a consistent but machine-dependent order.
</li><li> Minus infinity.
</li><li> Finite numbers in ascending numeric order (with <em>-0</em> and <em>+0</em> equal).
</li><li> Plus infinity.
</li></ul>

<p>Use this option only if there is no alternative; it is much slower than
<samp>--numeric-sort</samp> (<samp>-n</samp>) and it can lose information when
converting to floating point.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--human-numeric-sort</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=human-numeric</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhuman_002dnumeric_002dsort"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-1"></a>
<a name="index-human-numeric-sort"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fNUMERIC-3"></a>
<p>Sort numerically, first by numeric sign (negative, zero, or positive);
then by SI suffix (either empty, or &lsquo;<samp>k</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, or
one of &lsquo;<samp>MGTPEZY</samp>&rsquo;, in that order; see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>); and finally
by numeric value.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>1023M</samp>&rsquo; sorts before &lsquo;<samp>1G</samp>&rsquo;
because &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; (mega) precedes &lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo; (giga) as an SI
suffix.  This option sorts values that are consistently scaled to the
nearest suffix, regardless of whether suffixes denote powers of 1000
or 1024, and it therefore sorts the output of any single invocation of
the <code>df</code>, <code>du</code>, or <code>ls</code> commands that are
invoked with their <samp>--human-readable</samp> or <samp>--si</samp> options.
The syntax for numbers is the same as for the <samp>--numeric-sort</samp>
option; the SI suffix must immediately follow the number.
Note also the <code>numfmt</code> command, which can be used to reformat
numbers to human format <em>after</em> the sort, thus often allowing
sort to operate on more accurate numbers.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-nonprinting</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dnonprinting"></a>
<a name="index-nonprinting-characters_002c-ignoring"></a>
<a name="index-unprintable-characters_002c-ignoring"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fCTYPE-3"></a>
<p>Ignore nonprinting characters.
The <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale determines character types.
This option has no effect if the stronger <samp>--dictionary-order</samp>
(<samp>-d</samp>) option is also given.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-M</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--month-sort</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=month</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dM"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmonth_002dsort"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-2"></a>
<a name="index-months_002c-sorting-by"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fTIME-1"></a>
<p>An initial string, consisting of any amount of blanks, followed
by a month name abbreviation, is folded to UPPER case and
compared in the order &lsquo;<samp>JAN</samp>&rsquo; &lt; &lsquo;<samp>FEB</samp>&rsquo; &lt; &hellip; &lt; &lsquo;<samp>DEC</samp>&rsquo;.
Invalid names compare low to valid names.  The <code>LC_TIME</code> locale
category determines the month spellings.
By default a blank is a space or a tab, but the <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale
can change this.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--numeric-sort</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=numeric</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumeric_002dsort"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-3"></a>
<a name="index-numeric-sort"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fNUMERIC-4"></a>
<p>Sort numerically.  The number begins each line and consists
of optional blanks, an optional &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; sign, and zero or more
digits possibly separated by thousands separators, optionally followed
by a decimal-point character and zero or more digits.  An empty
number is treated as &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;.  The <code>LC_NUMERIC</code>
locale specifies the decimal-point character and thousands separator.
By default a blank is a space or a tab, but the <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale
can change this.
</p>
<p>Comparison is exact; there is no rounding error.
</p>
<p>Neither a leading &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; nor exponential notation is recognized.
To compare such strings numerically, use the
<samp>--general-numeric-sort</samp> (<samp>-g</samp>) option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-V</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--version-sort</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dV"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dversion_002dsort"></a>
<a name="index-version-number-sort"></a>
<p>Sort by version name and number.  It behaves like a standard sort,
except that each sequence of decimal digits is treated numerically
as an index/version number.  (See <a href="#Details-about-version-sort">Details about version sort</a>.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reverse</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dreverse"></a>
<a name="index-reverse-sorting"></a>
<p>Reverse the result of comparison, so that lines with greater key values
appear earlier in the output instead of later.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--random-sort</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=random</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drandom_002dsort"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-4"></a>
<a name="index-random-sort"></a>
<p>Sort by hashing the input keys and then sorting the hash values.
Choose the hash function at random, ensuring that it is free of
collisions so that differing keys have differing hash values.  This is
like a random permutation of the inputs (see <a href="#shuf-invocation">shuf invocation</a>),
except that keys with the same value sort together.
</p>
<p>If multiple random sort fields are specified, the same random hash
function is used for all fields.  To use different random hash
functions for different fields, you can invoke <code>sort</code> more
than once.
</p>
<p>The choice of hash function is affected by the
<samp>--random-source</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>Other options are:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--compress-program=<var>prog</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Compress any temporary files with the program <var>prog</var>.
</p>
<p>With no arguments, <var>prog</var> must compress standard input to standard
output, and when given the <samp>-d</samp> option it must decompress
standard input to standard output.
</p>
<p>Terminate with an error if <var>prog</var> exits with nonzero status.
</p>
<p>White space and the backslash character should not appear in
<var>prog</var>; they are reserved for future use.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--files0-from=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfiles0_002dfrom_003dfile-1"></a>
<p>Disallow processing files named on the command line, and instead process
those named in file <var>file</var>; each name being terminated by a zero byte
(ASCII NUL).
This is useful 
when the list of file names is so long that it may exceed a command line
length limitation.
In such cases, running <code>sort</code> via <code>xargs</code> is undesirable
because it splits the list into pieces and makes <code>sort</code> print
sorted output for each sublist rather than for the entire list.
One way to produce a list of ASCII NUL terminated file
names is with GNU
<code>find</code>, using its <samp>-print0</samp> predicate.
If <var>file</var> is &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; then the ASCII NUL terminated
file names are read from standard input.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-k <var>pos1</var>[,<var>pos2</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--key=<var>pos1</var>[,<var>pos2</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dk-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dkey"></a>
<a name="index-sort-field"></a>
<p>Specify a sort field that consists of the part of the line between
<var>pos1</var> and <var>pos2</var> (or the end of the line, if <var>pos2</var> is
omitted), <em>inclusive</em>.
</p>
<p>In its simplest form <var>pos</var> specifies a field number (starting with 1),
with fields being separated by runs of blank characters, and by default
those blanks being included in the comparison at the start of each field.
To adjust the handling of blank characters see the <samp>-b</samp> and
<samp>-t</samp> options.
</p>
<p>More generally,
each <var>pos</var> has the form &lsquo;<samp><var>f</var>[.<var>c</var>][<var>opts</var>]</samp>&rsquo;,
where <var>f</var> is the number of the field to use, and <var>c</var> is the number
of the first character from the beginning of the field.  Fields and character
positions are numbered starting with 1; a character position of zero in
<var>pos2</var> indicates the field&rsquo;s last character.  If &lsquo;<samp>.<var>c</var></samp>&rsquo; is
omitted from <var>pos1</var>, it defaults to 1 (the beginning of the field);
if omitted from <var>pos2</var>, it defaults to 0 (the end of the field).
<var>opts</var> are ordering options, allowing individual keys to be sorted
according to different rules; see below for details.  Keys can span
multiple fields.
</p>
<p>Example:  To sort on the second field, use <samp>--key=2,2</samp>
(<samp>-k 2,2</samp>).  See below for more notes on keys and more examples.
See also the <samp>--debug</samp> option to help determine the part
of the line being used in the sort.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--debug</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Highlight the portion of each line used for sorting.
Also issue warnings about questionable usage to stderr.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--batch-size=<var>nmerge</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dbatch_002dsize"></a>
<a name="index-number-of-inputs-to-merge_002c-nmerge"></a>
<p>Merge at most <var>nmerge</var> inputs at once.
</p>
<p>When <code>sort</code> has to merge more than <var>nmerge</var> inputs,
it merges them in groups of <var>nmerge</var>, saving the result in
a temporary file, which is then used as an input in a subsequent merge.
</p>
<p>A large value of <var>nmerge</var> may improve merge performance and decrease
temporary storage utilization at the expense of increased memory usage
and I/O.  Conversely a small value of <var>nmerge</var> may reduce memory
requirements and I/O at the expense of temporary storage consumption and
merge performance.
</p>
<p>The value of <var>nmerge</var> must be at least 2.  The default value is
currently 16, but this is implementation-dependent and may change in
the future.
</p>
<p>The value of <var>nmerge</var> may be bounded by a resource limit for open
file descriptors.  The commands &lsquo;<samp>ulimit -n</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>getconf
OPEN_MAX</samp>&rsquo; may display limits for your systems; these limits may be
modified further if your program already has some files open, or if
the operating system has other limits on the number of open files.  If
the value of <var>nmerge</var> exceeds the resource limit, <code>sort</code>
silently uses a smaller value.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o <var>output-file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output=<var>output-file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002doutput"></a>
<a name="index-overwriting-of-input_002c-allowed"></a>
<p>Write output to <var>output-file</var> instead of standard output.
Normally, <code>sort</code> reads all input before opening
<var>output-file</var>, so you can sort a file in place by using
commands like <code>sort -o F F</code> and <code>cat F | sort -o F</code>.
However, it is often safer to output to an otherwise-unused file, as
data may be lost if the system crashes or <code>sort</code> encounters
an I/O or other serious error while a file is being sorted in place.
Also, <code>sort</code> with <samp>--merge</samp> (<samp>-m</samp>) can open
the output file before reading all input, so a command like <code>cat
F | sort -m -o F - G</code> is not safe as <code>sort</code> might start
writing <samp>F</samp> before <code>cat</code> is done reading it.
</p>
<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-3"></a>
<p>On newer systems, <samp>-o</samp> cannot appear after an input file if
<code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> is set, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>sort F -o F</samp>&rsquo;.  Portable
scripts should specify <samp>-o <var>output-file</var></samp> before any input
files.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--random-source=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002drandom_002dsource"></a>
<a name="index-random-source-for-sorting"></a>
<p>Use <var>file</var> as a source of random data used to determine which
random hash function to use with the <samp>-R</samp> option.  See <a href="#Random-sources">Random sources</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--stable</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dstable"></a>
<a name="index-sort-stability-1"></a>
<a name="index-sort_0027s-last_002dresort-comparison-1"></a>

<p>Make <code>sort</code> stable by disabling its last-resort comparison.
This option has no effect if no fields or global ordering options
other than <samp>--reverse</samp> (<samp>-r</samp>) are specified.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--buffer-size=<var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbuffer_002dsize"></a>
<a name="index-size-for-main-memory-sorting"></a>
<p>Use a main-memory sort buffer of the given <var>size</var>.  By default,
<var>size</var> is in units of 1024 bytes.  Appending &lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo; causes
<var>size</var> to be interpreted as a percentage of physical memory.
Appending &lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo; multiplies <var>size</var> by 1024 (the default),
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; by 1,048,576, &lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo; by 1,073,741,824, and so on for
&lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;.  Appending
&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo; causes <var>size</var> to be interpreted as a byte count, with no
multiplication.
</p>
<p>This option can improve the performance of <code>sort</code> by causing it
to start with a larger or smaller sort buffer than the default.
However, this option affects only the initial buffer size.  The buffer
grows beyond <var>size</var> if <code>sort</code> encounters input lines larger
than <var>size</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>separator</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--field-separator=<var>separator</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfield_002dseparator"></a>
<a name="index-field-separator-character"></a>
<p>Use character <var>separator</var> as the field separator when finding the
sort keys in each line.  By default, fields are separated by the empty
string between a non-blank character and a blank character.
By default a blank is a space or a tab, but the <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale
can change this.
</p>
<p>That is, given the input line &lsquo;<samp>&nbsp;foo&nbsp;bar</samp>&rsquo;<!-- /@w -->, <code>sort</code> breaks it
into fields &lsquo;<samp>&nbsp;foo</samp>&rsquo;<!-- /@w --> and &lsquo;<samp>&nbsp;bar</samp>&rsquo;<!-- /@w -->.  The field separator is
not considered to be part of either the field preceding or the field
following, so with &lsquo;<samp>sort <span class="nolinebreak">-t</span>&nbsp;&quot;&nbsp;&quot;<!-- /@w --></samp>&rsquo; the same input line has
three fields: an empty field, &lsquo;<samp>foo</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>bar</samp>&rsquo;.
However, fields that extend to the end of the line,
as <samp>-k 2</samp>, or fields consisting of a range, as <samp>-k 2,3</samp>,
retain the field separators present between the endpoints of the range.
</p>
<p>To specify ASCII NUL as the field separator,
use the two-character string &lsquo;<samp>\0</samp>&rsquo;, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>sort -t '\0'</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T <var>tempdir</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--temporary-directory=<var>tempdir</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtemporary_002ddirectory"></a>
<a name="index-temporary-directory"></a>
<a name="index-TMPDIR-1"></a>
<p>Use directory <var>tempdir</var> to store temporary files, overriding the
<code>TMPDIR</code> environment variable.  If this option is given more than
once, temporary files are stored in all the directories given.  If you
have a large sort or merge that is I/O-bound, you can often improve
performance by using this option to specify directories on different
disks and controllers.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--parallel=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dparallel"></a>
<a name="index-multithreaded-sort"></a>
<p>Set the number of sorts run in parallel to <var>n</var>. By default,
<var>n</var> is set to the number of available processors, but limited
to 8, as there are diminishing performance gains after that.
Note also that using <var>n</var> threads increases the memory usage by
a factor of log <var>n</var>.  Also see <a href="#nproc-invocation">nproc invocation</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--unique</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dunique"></a>
<a name="index-uniquifying-output"></a>

<p>Normally, output only the first of a sequence of lines that compare
equal.  For the <samp>--check</samp> (<samp>-c</samp> or <samp>-C</samp>) option,
check that no pair of consecutive lines compares equal.
</p>
<p>This option also disables the default last-resort comparison.
</p>
<p>The commands <code>sort -u</code> and <code>sort | uniq</code> are equivalent, but
this equivalence does not extend to arbitrary <code>sort</code> options.
For example, <code>sort -n -u</code> inspects only the value of the initial
numeric string when checking for uniqueness, whereas <code>sort -n |
uniq</code> inspects the entire line.  See <a href="#uniq-invocation">uniq invocation</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-2"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-2"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>Historical (BSD and System V) implementations of <code>sort</code> have
differed in their interpretation of some options, particularly
<samp>-b</samp>, <samp>-f</samp>, and <samp>-n</samp>.
GNU sort follows the POSIX
behavior, which is usually (but not always!) like the System V behavior.
According to POSIX, <samp>-n</samp> no longer implies <samp>-b</samp>.  For
consistency, <samp>-M</samp> has been changed in the same way.  This may
affect the meaning of character positions in field specifications in
obscure cases.  The only fix is to add an explicit <samp>-b</samp>.
</p>
<p>A position in a sort field specified with <samp>-k</samp> may have any
of the option letters &lsquo;<samp>MbdfghinRrV</samp>&rsquo; appended to it, in which case no
global ordering options are inherited by that particular field.  The
<samp>-b</samp> option may be independently attached to either or both of
the start and end positions of a field specification, and if it is
inherited from the global options it will be attached to both.
If input lines can contain leading or adjacent blanks and <samp>-t</samp>
is not used, then <samp>-k</samp> is typically combined with <samp>-b</samp> or
an option that implicitly ignores leading blanks (&lsquo;<samp>Mghn</samp>&rsquo;) as otherwise
the varying numbers of leading blanks in fields can cause confusing results.
</p>
<p>If the start position in a sort field specifier falls after the end of
the line or after the end field, the field is empty.  If the <samp>-b</samp>
option was specified, the &lsquo;<samp>.<var>c</var></samp>&rsquo; part of a field specification
is counted from the first nonblank character of the field.
</p>
<a name="index-_005fPOSIX2_005fVERSION-2"></a>
<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-4"></a>
<p>On systems not conforming to POSIX 1003.1-2001,
<code>sort</code> supports a traditional origin-zero
syntax &lsquo;<samp>+<var>pos1</var> [-<var>pos2</var>]</samp>&rsquo; for specifying sort keys.
The traditional command &lsquo;<samp>sort +<var>a</var>.<var>x</var> -<var>b</var>.<var>y</var></samp>&rsquo;
is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>sort -k <var>a+1</var>.<var>x+1</var>,<var>b</var></samp>&rsquo; if <var>y</var>
is &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; or absent, otherwise it is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>sort -k
<var>a+1</var>.<var>x+1</var>,<var>b+1</var>.<var>y</var></samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>This traditional behavior can be controlled with the
<code>_POSIX2_VERSION</code> environment variable (see <a href="#Standards-conformance">Standards conformance</a>); it can also be enabled when <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> is
not set by using the traditional syntax with &lsquo;<samp>-<var>pos2</var></samp>&rsquo; present.
</p>
<p>Scripts intended for use on standard hosts should avoid traditional
syntax and should use <samp>-k</samp> instead.  For example, avoid
&lsquo;<samp>sort +2</samp>&rsquo;, since it might be interpreted as either &lsquo;<samp>sort
./+2</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>sort -k 3</samp>&rsquo;.  If your script must also run on hosts that
support only the traditional syntax, it can use a test like &lsquo;<samp>if sort
-k 1 &lt;/dev/null &gt;/dev/null 2&gt;&amp;1; then &hellip;</samp>&rsquo; to decide which syntax
to use.
</p>
<p>Here are some examples to illustrate various combinations of options.
</p>
<ul>
<li> Sort in descending (reverse) numeric order.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sort -n -r
</pre></div>

</li><li> Run no more than 4 sorts concurrently, using a buffer size of 10M.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sort --parallel=4 -S 10M
</pre></div>

</li><li> Sort alphabetically, omitting the first and second fields
and the blanks at the start of the third field.
This uses a single key composed of the characters beginning
at the start of the first nonblank character in field three
and extending to the end of each line.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sort -k 3b
</pre></div>

</li><li> Sort numerically on the second field and resolve ties by sorting
alphabetically on the third and fourth characters of field five.
Use &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo; as the field delimiter.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sort -t : -k 2,2n -k 5.3,5.4
</pre></div>

<p>Note that if you had written <samp>-k 2n</samp> instead of <samp>-k 2,2n</samp>
<code>sort</code> would have used all characters beginning in the second field
and extending to the end of the line as the primary <em>numeric</em>
key.  For the large majority of applications, treating keys spanning
more than one field as numeric will not do what you expect.
</p>
<p>Also note that the &lsquo;<samp>n</samp>&rsquo; modifier was applied to the field-end
specifier for the first key.  It would have been equivalent to
specify <samp>-k 2n,2</samp> or <samp>-k 2n,2n</samp>.  All modifiers except
&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo; apply to the associated <em>field</em>, regardless of whether
the modifier character is attached to the field-start and/or the
field-end part of the key specifier.
</p>
</li><li> Sort the password file on the fifth field and ignore any
leading blanks.  Sort lines with equal values in field five
on the numeric user ID in field three.  Fields are separated
by &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sort -t : -k 5b,5 -k 3,3n /etc/passwd
sort -t : -n -k 5b,5 -k 3,3 /etc/passwd
sort -t : -b -k 5,5 -k 3,3n /etc/passwd
</pre></div>

<p>These three commands have equivalent effect.  The first specifies that
the first key&rsquo;s start position ignores leading blanks and the second
key is sorted numerically.  The other two commands rely on global
options being inherited by sort keys that lack modifiers.  The inheritance
works in this case because <samp>-k 5b,5b</samp> and <samp>-k 5b,5</samp> are
equivalent, as the location of a field-end lacking a &lsquo;<samp>.<var>c</var></samp>&rsquo;
character position is not affected by whether initial blanks are
skipped.
</p>
</li><li> Sort a set of log files, primarily by IPv4 address and secondarily by
timestamp.  If two lines&rsquo; primary and secondary keys are identical,
output the lines in the same order that they were input.  The log
files contain lines that look like this:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">4.150.156.3 - - [01/Apr/2004:06:31:51 +0000] message 1
211.24.3.231 - - [24/Apr/2004:20:17:39 +0000] message 2
</pre></div>

<p>Fields are separated by exactly one space.  Sort IPv4 addresses
lexicographically, e.g., 212.61.52.2 sorts before 212.129.233.201
because 61 is less than 129.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sort -s -t ' ' -k 4.9n -k 4.5M -k 4.2n -k 4.14,4.21 file*.log |
sort -s -t '.' -k 1,1n -k 2,2n -k 3,3n -k 4,4n
</pre></div>

<p>This example cannot be done with a single <code>sort</code> invocation,
since IPv4 address components are separated by &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; while dates
come just after a space.  So it is broken down into two invocations of
<code>sort</code>: the first sorts by timestamp and the second by IPv4
address.  The timestamp is sorted by year, then month, then day, and
finally by hour-minute-second field, using <samp>-k</samp> to isolate each
field.  Except for hour-minute-second there&rsquo;s no need to specify the
end of each key field, since the &lsquo;<samp>n</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; modifiers sort
based on leading prefixes that cannot cross field boundaries.  The
IPv4 addresses are sorted lexicographically.  The second sort uses
&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo; so that ties in the primary key are broken by the secondary
key; the first sort uses &lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo; so that the combination of the two
sorts is stable.
</p>
</li><li> Generate a tags file in case-insensitive sorted order.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">find src -type f -print0 | sort -z -f | xargs -0 etags --append
</pre></div>

<p>The use of <samp>-print0</samp>, <samp>-z</samp>, and <samp>-0</samp> in this case means
that file names that contain blanks or other special characters are
not broken up
by the sort operation.
</p>

</li><li> Use the common DSU, Decorate Sort Undecorate idiom to
sort lines according to their length.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">awk '{print length, $0}' /etc/passwd | sort -n | cut -f2- -d' '
</pre></div>

<p>In general this technique can be used to sort data that the <code>sort</code>
command does not support, or is inefficient at, sorting directly.
</p>
</li><li> Shuffle a list of directories, but preserve the order of files within
each directory.  For instance, one could use this to generate a music
playlist in which albums are shuffled but the songs of each album are
played in order.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">ls */* | sort -t / -k 1,1R -k 2,2
</pre></div>

</li></ul>


<hr>
<a name="shuf-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#uniq-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">uniq invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#sort-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">sort invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-sorted-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on sorted files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="shuf_003a-Shuffling-text"></a>
<h3 class="section">7.2 <code>shuf</code>: Shuffling text</h3>

<a name="index-shuf"></a>
<a name="index-shuffling-files"></a>

<p><code>shuf</code> shuffles its input by outputting a random permutation
of its input lines.  Each output permutation is equally likely.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shuf [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]
shuf -e [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>arg</var>]&hellip;
shuf -i <var>lo</var>-<var>hi</var> [<var>option</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><code>shuf</code> has three modes of operation that affect where it
obtains its input lines.  By default, it reads lines from standard
input.  The following options change the operation mode:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--echo</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002decho"></a>
<a name="index-command_002dline-operands-to-shuffle"></a>
<p>Treat each command-line operand as an input line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i <var>lo</var>-<var>hi</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--input-range=<var>lo</var>-<var>hi</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinput_002drange"></a>
<a name="index-input-range-to-shuffle"></a>
<p>Act as if input came from a file containing the range of unsigned
decimal integers <var>lo</var>&hellip;<var>hi</var>, one per line.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p><code>shuf</code>&rsquo;s other options can affect its behavior in all
operation modes:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n <var>count</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--head-count=<var>count</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhead_002dcount"></a>
<a name="index-head-of-output"></a>
<p>Output at most <var>count</var> lines.  By default, all input lines are
output.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o <var>output-file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output=<var>output-file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002doutput-1"></a>
<a name="index-overwriting-of-input_002c-allowed-1"></a>
<p>Write output to <var>output-file</var> instead of standard output.
<code>shuf</code> reads all input before opening
<var>output-file</var>, so you can safely shuffle a file in place by using
commands like <code>shuf -o F &lt;F</code> and <code>cat F | shuf -o F</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--random-source=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002drandom_002dsource-1"></a>
<a name="index-random-source-for-shuffling"></a>
<p>Use <var>file</var> as a source of random data used to determine which
permutation to generate.  See <a href="#Random-sources">Random sources</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--repeat</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drepeat"></a>
<a name="index-repeat-output-values"></a>
<p>Repeat output values, that is, select with replacement.  With this
option the output is not a permutation of the input; instead, each
output line is randomly chosen from all the inputs.  This option is
typically combined with <samp>--head-count</samp>; if
<samp>--head-count</samp> is not given, <code>shuf</code> repeats
indefinitely.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-3"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-3"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>For example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shuf &lt;&lt;EOF
A man,
a plan,
a canal:
Panama!
EOF
</pre></div>

<p>might produce the output
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">Panama!
A man,
a canal:
a plan,
</pre></div>

<p>Similarly, the command:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shuf -e clubs hearts diamonds spades
</pre></div>

<p>might output:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">clubs
diamonds
spades
hearts
</pre></div>

<p>and the command &lsquo;<samp>shuf -i 1-4</samp>&rsquo; might output:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">4
2
1
3
</pre></div>

<p>The above examples all have four input lines, so <code>shuf</code> might
produce any of the twenty-four possible permutations of the input.  In
general, if there are <var>n</var> input lines, there are <var>n</var>! (i.e.,
<var>n</var> factorial, or <var>n</var> * (<var>n</var> - 1) * &hellip; * 1) possible
output permutations.
</p>
<p>To output 50 random numbers each in the range 0 through 9, use:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shuf -r -n 50 -i 0-9
</pre></div>

<p>To simulate 100 coin flips, use:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shuf -r -n 100 -e Head Tail
</pre></div>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="uniq-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#comm-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">comm invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#shuf-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">shuf invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-sorted-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on sorted files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="uniq_003a-Uniquify-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">7.3 <code>uniq</code>: Uniquify files</h3>

<a name="index-uniq"></a>
<a name="index-uniquify-files"></a>

<p><code>uniq</code> writes the unique lines in the given <samp>input</samp>, or
standard input if nothing is given or for an <var>input</var> name of
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">uniq [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>input</var> [<var>output</var>]]
</pre></div>

<p>By default, <code>uniq</code> prints its input lines, except that
it discards all but the first of adjacent repeated lines, so that
no output lines are repeated.  Optionally, it can instead discard
lines that are not repeated, or all repeated lines.
</p>
<p>The input need not be sorted, but repeated input lines are detected
only if they are adjacent.  If you want to discard non-adjacent
duplicate lines, perhaps you want to use <code>sort -u</code>.
See <a href="#sort-invocation">sort invocation</a>.
</p>
<a name="index-LC_005fCOLLATE-1"></a>
<p>Comparisons honor the rules specified by the <code>LC_COLLATE</code>
locale category.
</p>
<p>If no <var>output</var> file is specified, <code>uniq</code> writes to standard
output.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--skip-fields=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dskip_002dfields"></a>
<p>Skip <var>n</var> fields on each line before checking for uniqueness.  Use
a null string for comparison if a line has fewer than <var>n</var> fields.  Fields
are sequences of non-space non-tab characters that are separated from
each other by at least one space or tab.
</p>
<p>For compatibility <code>uniq</code> supports a traditional option syntax
<samp>-<var>n</var></samp>.  New scripts should use <samp>-f <var>n</var></samp> instead.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--skip-chars=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dskip_002dchars"></a>
<p>Skip <var>n</var> characters before checking for uniqueness.  Use a null string
for comparison if a line has fewer than <var>n</var> characters.  If you use both
the field and character skipping options, fields are skipped over first.
</p>
<a name="index-_005fPOSIX2_005fVERSION-3"></a>
<p>On systems not conforming to POSIX 1003.1-2001,
<code>uniq</code> supports a traditional option syntax
<samp>+<var>n</var></samp>.
Although this traditional behavior can be controlled with the
<code>_POSIX2_VERSION</code> environment variable (see <a href="#Standards-conformance">Standards conformance</a>), portable scripts should avoid commands whose
behavior depends on this variable.
For example, use &lsquo;<samp>uniq ./+10</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>uniq -s 10</samp>&rsquo; rather than
the ambiguous &lsquo;<samp>uniq +10</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--count</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcount"></a>
<p>Print the number of times each line occurred along with the line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-case</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dcase-1"></a>
<p>Ignore differences in case when comparing lines.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--repeated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drepeated"></a>
<a name="index-repeated-lines_002c-outputting"></a>
<p>Discard lines that are not repeated.  When used by itself, this option
causes <code>uniq</code> to print the first copy of each repeated line,
and nothing else.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-D</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all-repeated[=<var>delimit-method</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dD"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall_002drepeated"></a>
<a name="index-all-repeated-lines_002c-outputting"></a>
<p>Do not discard the second and subsequent repeated input lines,
but discard lines that are not repeated.
This option is useful mainly in conjunction with other options e.g.,
to ignore case or to compare only selected fields.
The optional <var>delimit-method</var>, supported with the long form option,
specifies how to delimit groups of repeated lines, and must be one of the
following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>none</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Do not delimit groups of repeated lines.
This is equivalent to <samp>--all-repeated</samp> (<samp>-D</samp>).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>prepend</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Output a newline before each group of repeated lines.
With <samp>--zero-terminated</samp> (<samp>-z</samp>), use a zero
byte (ASCII NUL) instead of a newline as the delimiter.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>separate</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Separate groups of repeated lines with a single newline.
This is the same as using &lsquo;<samp>prepend</samp>&rsquo;, except that
no delimiter is inserted before the first group, and hence
may be better suited for output direct to users.
With <samp>--zero-terminated</samp> (<samp>-z</samp>), use a zero
byte (ASCII NUL) instead of a newline as the delimiter.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Note that when groups are delimited and the input stream contains
blank lines, then the output is ambiguous.
To avoid that, filter the input through &lsquo;<samp>tr -s '\n'</samp>&rsquo; to
remove blank lines.
</p>
<p>This is a GNU extension.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--group[=<var>delimit-method</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dgroup"></a>
<a name="index-all-lines_002c-grouping"></a>
<p>Output all lines, and delimit each unique group.
With <samp>--zero-terminated</samp> (<samp>-z</samp>), use a zero
byte (ASCII NUL) instead of a newline as the delimiter.
The optional <var>delimit-method</var> specifies how to delimit
groups, and must be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>separate</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Separate unique groups with a single delimiter.
This is the default delimiting method if none is specified,
and better suited for output direct to users.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>prepend</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Output a delimiter before each group of unique items.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>append</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Output a delimiter after each group of unique items.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>both</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Output a delimiter around each group of unique items.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Note that when groups are delimited and the input stream contains
blank lines, then the output is ambiguous.
To avoid that, filter the input through &lsquo;<samp>tr -s '\n'</samp>&rsquo; to
remove blank lines.
</p>
<p>This is a GNU extension.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--unique</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dunique-1"></a>
<a name="index-unique-lines_002c-outputting"></a>
<p>Discard the last line that would be output for a repeated input group.
When used by itself, this option causes <code>uniq</code> to print unique
lines, and nothing else.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check-chars=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcheck_002dchars"></a>
<p>Compare at most <var>n</var> characters on each line (after skipping any specified
fields and characters).  By default the entire rest of the lines are
compared.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-4"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-4"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
Note with <samp>-z</samp> the newline character is treated as a field separator.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="comm-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">ptx invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#uniq-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">uniq invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-sorted-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on sorted files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="comm_003a-Compare-two-sorted-files-line-by-line"></a>
<h3 class="section">7.4 <code>comm</code>: Compare two sorted files line by line</h3>

<a name="index-comm"></a>
<a name="index-line_002dby_002dline-comparison"></a>
<a name="index-comparing-sorted-files"></a>

<p><code>comm</code> writes to standard output lines that are common, and lines
that are unique, to two input files; a file name of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; means
standard input.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">comm [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>file1</var> <var>file2</var>
</pre></div>

<a name="index-LC_005fCOLLATE-2"></a>
<p>Before <code>comm</code> can be used, the input files must be sorted using the
collating sequence specified by the <code>LC_COLLATE</code> locale.
If an input file ends in a non-newline
character, a newline is silently appended.  The <code>sort</code> command with
no options always outputs a file that is suitable input to <code>comm</code>.
</p>
<a name="index-differing-lines"></a>
<a name="index-common-lines"></a>
<p>With no options, <code>comm</code> produces three-column output.  Column one
contains lines unique to <var>file1</var>, column two contains lines unique
to <var>file2</var>, and column three contains lines common to both files.
Columns are separated by a single TAB character.
</p>
<a name="index-_002d1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d3"></a>
<p>The options <samp>-1</samp>, <samp>-2</samp>, and <samp>-3</samp> suppress printing of
the corresponding columns (and separators).  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>Unlike some other comparison utilities, <code>comm</code> has an exit
status that does not depend on the result of the comparison.
Upon normal completion <code>comm</code> produces an exit code of zero.
If there is an error it exits with nonzero status.
</p>
<p>If the <samp>--check-order</samp> option is given, unsorted inputs will
cause a fatal error message.  If the option <samp>--nocheck-order</samp>
is given, unsorted inputs will never cause an error message.  If neither
of these options is given, wrongly sorted inputs are diagnosed
only if an input file is found to contain unpairable
lines.
If an input file is diagnosed as being unsorted, the <code>comm</code>
command will exit with a nonzero status (and the output should not be used).
</p>
<p>Forcing <code>comm</code> to process wrongly sorted input files
containing unpairable lines by specifying <samp>--nocheck-order</samp> is
not guaranteed to produce any particular output.  The output will
probably not correspond with whatever you hoped it would be.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check-order</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Fail with an error message if either input file is wrongly ordered.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--nocheck-order</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Do not check that both input files are in sorted order.
</p>
<p>Other options are:
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output-delimiter=<var>str</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print <var>str</var> between adjacent output columns,
rather than the default of a single TAB character.
</p>
<p>The delimiter <var>str</var> may not be empty.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--total</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Output a summary at the end.
</p>
<p>Similar to the regular output,
column one contains the total number of lines unique to <var>file1</var>,
column two contains the total number of lines unique to <var>file2</var>, and
column three contains the total number of lines common to both files,
followed by the word &lsquo;<samp>total</samp>&rsquo; in the additional column four.
</p>
<p>In the following example, <code>comm</code> omits the regular output
(<samp>-123</samp>), thus just printing the summary:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ printf '%s\n' a b c d e     &gt; file1
$ printf '%s\n'   b c d e f g &gt; file2
$ comm --total -123 file1 file2
1       2       4       total
</pre></div>

<p>This option is a GNU extension.  Portable scripts should use <code>wc</code> to
get the totals, e.g. for the above example files:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ comm -23 file1 file2 | wc -l    # number of lines only in file1
1
$ comm -13 file1 file2 | wc -l    # number of lines only in file2
2
$ comm -12 file1 file2 | wc -l    # number of lines common to both files
4
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-5"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-5"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<hr>
<a name="ptx-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#tsort-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">tsort invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#comm-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">comm invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-sorted-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on sorted files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="ptx_003a-Produce-permuted-indexes"></a>
<h3 class="section">7.5 <code>ptx</code>: Produce permuted indexes</h3>

<a name="index-ptx"></a>

<p><code>ptx</code> reads a text file and essentially produces a permuted index, with
each keyword in its context.  The calling sketch is either one of:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">ptx [<var>option</var> &hellip;] [<var>file</var> &hellip;]
ptx -G [<var>option</var> &hellip;] [<var>input</var> [<var>output</var>]]
</pre></div>

<p>The <samp>-G</samp> (or its equivalent: <samp>--traditional</samp>) option disables
all GNU extensions and reverts to traditional mode, thus introducing some
limitations and changing several of the program&rsquo;s default option values.
When <samp>-G</samp> is not specified, GNU extensions are always enabled.
GNU extensions to <code>ptx</code> are documented wherever appropriate in this
document.  See <a href="#Compatibility-in-ptx">Compatibility in ptx</a>, for the full list.
</p>
<p>Individual options are explained in the following sections.
</p>
<p>When GNU extensions are enabled, there may be zero, one or several
<var>file</var>s after the options.  If there is no <var>file</var>, the program
reads the standard input.  If there is one or several <var>file</var>s, they
give the name of input files which are all read in turn, as if all the
input files were concatenated.  However, there is a full contextual
break between each file and, when automatic referencing is requested,
file names and line numbers refer to individual text input files.  In
all cases, the program outputs the permuted index to the standard
output.
</p>
<p>When GNU extensions are <em>not</em> enabled, that is, when the program
operates in traditional mode, there may be zero, one or two parameters
besides the options.  If there are no parameters, the program reads the
standard input and outputs the permuted index to the standard output.
If there is only one parameter, it names the text <var>input</var> to be read
instead of the standard input.  If two parameters are given, they give
respectively the name of the <var>input</var> file to read and the name of
the <var>output</var> file to produce.  <em>Be very careful</em> to note that,
in this case, the contents of file given by the second parameter is
destroyed.  This behavior is dictated by System V <code>ptx</code>
compatibility; GNU Standards normally discourage output parameters not
introduced by an option.
</p>
<p>Note that for <em>any</em> file named as the value of an option or as an
input text file, a single dash &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; may be used, in which case
standard input is assumed.  However, it would not make sense to use this
convention more than once per program invocation.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#General-options-in-ptx" accesskey="1">General options in ptx</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Options which affect general program behavior.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Charset-selection-in-ptx" accesskey="2">Charset selection in ptx</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Underlying character set considerations.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Input-processing-in-ptx" accesskey="3">Input processing in ptx</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Input fields, contexts, and keyword selection.
</td></tr>

</td></tr>
