<hr>
<a name="General-options-in-ptx"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Charset-selection-in-ptx" accesskey="n" rel="next">Charset selection in ptx</a>, Up: <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ptx invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="General-options"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">7.5.1 General options</h4>

<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-G</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--traditional</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>As already explained, this option disables all GNU extensions to
<code>ptx</code> and switches to traditional mode.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--help</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print a short help on standard output, then exit without further
processing.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--version</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print the program version on standard output, then exit without further
processing.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Charset-selection-in-ptx"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Input-processing-in-ptx" accesskey="n" rel="next">Input processing in ptx</a>, Previous: <a href="#General-options-in-ptx" accesskey="p" rel="prev">General options in ptx</a>, Up: <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ptx invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Charset-selection"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">7.5.2 Charset selection</h4>

<p>As it is set up now, the program assumes that the input file is coded
using 8-bit ISO 8859-1 code, also known as Latin-1 character set,
<em>unless</em> it is compiled for MS-DOS, in which case it uses the
character set of the IBM-PC.  (GNU <code>ptx</code> is not known to work on
smaller MS-DOS machines anymore.)  Compared to 7-bit ASCII, the set
of characters which are letters is different; this alters the behavior
of regular expression matching.  Thus, the default regular expression
for a keyword allows foreign or diacriticized letters.  Keyword sorting,
however, is still crude; it obeys the underlying character set ordering
quite blindly.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-case</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dcase-2"></a>
<p>Fold lower case letters to upper case for sorting.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Input-processing-in-ptx"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Output-formatting-in-ptx" accesskey="n" rel="next">Output formatting in ptx</a>, Previous: <a href="#Charset-selection-in-ptx" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Charset selection in ptx</a>, Up: <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ptx invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Word-selection-and-input-processing"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">7.5.3 Word selection and input processing</h4>

<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--break-file=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbreak_002dfile"></a>

<p>This option provides an alternative (to <samp>-W</samp>) method of describing
which characters make up words.  It introduces the name of a
file which contains a list of characters which can<em>not</em> be part of
one word; this file is called the <em>Break file</em>.  Any character which
is not part of the Break file is a word constituent.  If both options
<samp>-b</samp> and <samp>-W</samp> are specified, then <samp>-W</samp> has precedence and
<samp>-b</samp> is ignored.
</p>
<p>When GNU extensions are enabled, the only way to avoid newline as a
break character is to write all the break characters in the file with no
newline at all, not even at the end of the file.  When GNU extensions
are disabled, spaces, tabs and newlines are always considered as break
characters even if not included in the Break file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-file=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dfile"></a>

<p>The file associated with this option contains a list of words which will
never be taken as keywords in concordance output.  It is called the
<em>Ignore file</em>.  The file contains exactly one word in each line; the
end of line separation of words is not subject to the value of the
<samp>-S</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--only-file=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002donly_002dfile"></a>

<p>The file associated with this option contains a list of words which will
be retained in concordance output; any word not mentioned in this file
is ignored.  The file is called the <em>Only file</em>.  The file contains
exactly one word in each line; the end of line separation of words is
not subject to the value of the <samp>-S</samp> option.
</p>
<p>There is no default for the Only file.  When both an Only file and an
Ignore file are specified, a word is considered a keyword only
if it is listed in the Only file and not in the Ignore file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--references</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dreferences"></a>

<p>On each input line, the leading sequence of non-white space characters will be
taken to be a reference that has the purpose of identifying this input
line in the resulting permuted index.
See <a href="#Output-formatting-in-ptx">Output formatting in ptx</a>,
for more information about reference production.
Using this option changes the default value for option <samp>-S</samp>.
</p>
<p>Using this option, the program does not try very hard to remove
references from contexts in output, but it succeeds in doing so
<em>when</em> the context ends exactly at the newline.  If option
<samp>-r</samp> is used with <samp>-S</samp> default value, or when GNU extensions
are disabled, this condition is always met and references are completely
excluded from the output contexts.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>regexp</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sentence-regexp=<var>regexp</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsentence_002dregexp"></a>

<p>This option selects which regular expression will describe the end of a
line or the end of a sentence.  In fact, this regular expression is not
the only distinction between end of lines or end of sentences, and input
line boundaries have no special significance outside this option.  By
default, when GNU extensions are enabled and if <samp>-r</samp> option is not
used, end of sentences are used.  In this case, this <var>regex</var> is
imported from GNU Emacs:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">[.?!][]\&quot;')}]*\\($\\|\t\\|  \\)[ \t\n]*
</pre></div>

<p>Whenever GNU extensions are disabled or if <samp>-r</samp> option is used, end
of lines are used; in this case, the default <var>regexp</var> is just:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">\n
</pre></div>

<p>Using an empty <var>regexp</var> is equivalent to completely disabling end of
line or end of sentence recognition.  In this case, the whole file is
considered to be a single big line or sentence.  The user might want to
disallow all truncation flag generation as well, through option <samp>-F
&quot;&quot;</samp>.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_mono/emacs.html#Regexps">Syntax of Regular Expressions</a> in <cite>The GNU Emacs
Manual</cite>.
</p>
<p>When the keywords happen to be near the beginning of the input line or
sentence, this often creates an unused area at the beginning of the
output context line; when the keywords happen to be near the end of the
input line or sentence, this often creates an unused area at the end of
the output context line.  The program tries to fill those unused areas
by wrapping around context in them; the tail of the input line or
sentence is used to fill the unused area on the left of the output line;
the head of the input line or sentence is used to fill the unused area
on the right of the output line.
</p>
<p>As a matter of convenience to the user, many usual backslashed escape
sequences from the C language are recognized and converted to the
corresponding characters by <code>ptx</code> itself.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-W <var>regexp</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--word-regexp=<var>regexp</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dW-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dword_002dregexp"></a>

<p>This option selects which regular expression will describe each keyword.
By default, if GNU extensions are enabled, a word is a sequence of
letters; the <var>regexp</var> used is &lsquo;<samp>\w+</samp>&rsquo;.  When GNU extensions are
disabled, a word is by default anything which ends with a space, a tab
or a newline; the <var>regexp</var> used is &lsquo;<samp>[^ \t\n]+</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>An empty <var>regexp</var> is equivalent to not using this option.
See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_mono/emacs.html#Regexps">Syntax of Regular Expressions</a> in <cite>The GNU Emacs
Manual</cite>.
</p>
<p>As a matter of convenience to the user, many usual backslashed escape
sequences, as found in the C language, are recognized and converted to
the corresponding characters by <code>ptx</code> itself.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Output-formatting-in-ptx"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Compatibility-in-ptx" accesskey="n" rel="next">Compatibility in ptx</a>, Previous: <a href="#Input-processing-in-ptx" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Input processing in ptx</a>, Up: <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ptx invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Output-formatting"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">7.5.4 Output formatting</h4>

<p>Output format is mainly controlled by the <samp>-O</samp> and <samp>-T</samp> options
described in the table below.  When neither <samp>-O</samp> nor <samp>-T</samp> are
selected, and if GNU extensions are enabled, the program chooses an
output format suitable for a dumb terminal.  Each keyword occurrence is
output to the center of one line, surrounded by its left and right
contexts.  Each field is properly justified, so the concordance output
can be readily observed.  As a special feature, if automatic
references are selected by option <samp>-A</samp> and are output before the
left context, that is, if option <samp>-R</samp> is <em>not</em> selected, then
a colon is added after the reference; this nicely interfaces with GNU
Emacs <code>next-error</code> processing.  In this default output format, each
white space character, like newline and tab, is merely changed to
exactly one space, with no special attempt to compress consecutive
spaces.  This might change in the future.  Except for those white space
characters, every other character of the underlying set of 256
characters is transmitted verbatim.
</p>
<p>Output format is further controlled by the following options.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--gap-size=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dgap_002dsize"></a>

<p>Select the size of the minimum white space gap between the fields on the
output line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--width=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwidth-4"></a>

<p>Select the maximum output width of each final line.  If references are
used, they are included or excluded from the maximum output width
depending on the value of option <samp>-R</samp>.  If this option is not
selected, that is, when references are output before the left context,
the maximum output width takes into account the maximum length of all
references.  If this option is selected, that is, when references are
output after the right context, the maximum output width does not take
into account the space taken by references, nor the gap that precedes
them.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-A</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--auto-reference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dA-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dauto_002dreference"></a>

<p>Select automatic references.  Each input line will have an automatic
reference made up of the file name and the line ordinal, with a single
colon between them.  However, the file name will be empty when standard
input is being read.  If both <samp>-A</samp> and <samp>-r</samp> are selected, then
the input reference is still read and skipped, but the automatic
reference is used at output time, overriding the input reference.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--right-side-refs</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dright_002dside_002drefs"></a>

<p>In the default output format, when option <samp>-R</samp> is not used, any
references produced by the effect of options <samp>-r</samp> or <samp>-A</samp> are
placed to the far right of output lines, after the right context.  With
default output format, when the <samp>-R</samp> option is specified, references
are rather placed at the beginning of each output line, before the left
context.  For any other output format, option <samp>-R</samp> is
ignored, with one exception:  with <samp>-R</samp> the width of references
is <em>not</em> taken into account in total output width given by <samp>-w</samp>.
</p>
<p>This option is automatically selected whenever GNU extensions are
disabled.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-F <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--flag-truncation=<var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dF-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dflag_002dtruncation"></a>

<p>This option will request that any truncation in the output be reported
using the string <var>string</var>.  Most output fields theoretically extend
towards the beginning or the end of the current line, or current
sentence, as selected with option <samp>-S</samp>.  But there is a maximum
allowed output line width, changeable through option <samp>-w</samp>, which is
further divided into space for various output fields.  When a field has
to be truncated because it cannot extend beyond the beginning or the end of
the current line to fit in, then a truncation occurs.  By default,
the string used is a single slash, as in <samp>-F /</samp>.
</p>
<p><var>string</var> may have more than one character, as in <samp>-F &hellip;</samp>.
Also, in the particular case when <var>string</var> is empty (<samp>-F &quot;&quot;</samp>),
truncation flagging is disabled, and no truncation marks are appended in
this case.
</p>
<p>As a matter of convenience to the user, many usual backslashed escape
sequences, as found in the C language, are recognized and converted to
the corresponding characters by <code>ptx</code> itself.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-M <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--macro-name=<var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dM-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmacro_002dname"></a>

<p>Select another <var>string</var> to be used instead of &lsquo;<samp>xx</samp>&rsquo;, while
generating output suitable for <code>nroff</code>, <code>troff</code> or TeX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-O</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=roff</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dO"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat_003droff"></a>

<p>Choose an output format suitable for <code>nroff</code> or <code>troff</code>
processing.  Each output line will look like:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">.xx &quot;<var>tail</var>&quot; &quot;<var>before</var>&quot; &quot;<var>keyword_and_after</var>&quot; &quot;<var>head</var>&quot; &quot;<var>ref</var>&quot;
</pre></div>

<p>so it will be possible to write a &lsquo;<samp>.xx</samp>&rsquo; roff macro to take care of
the output typesetting.  This is the default output format when GNU
extensions are disabled.  Option <samp>-M</samp> can be used to change
&lsquo;<samp>xx</samp>&rsquo; to another macro name.
</p>
<p>In this output format, each non-graphical character, like newline and
tab, is merely changed to exactly one space, with no special attempt to
compress consecutive spaces.  Each quote character &lsquo;<samp>&quot;</samp>&rsquo; is doubled
so it will be correctly processed by <code>nroff</code> or <code>troff</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=tex</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat_003dtex"></a>

<p>Choose an output format suitable for TeX processing.  Each output
line will look like:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">\xx {<var>tail</var>}{<var>before</var>}{<var>keyword</var>}{<var>after</var>}{<var>head</var>}{<var>ref</var>}
</pre></div>

<p>so it will be possible to write a <code>\xx</code> definition to take care of
the output typesetting.  Note that when references are not being
produced, that is, neither option <samp>-A</samp> nor option <samp>-r</samp> is
selected, the last parameter of each <code>\xx</code> call is inhibited.
Option <samp>-M</samp> can be used to change &lsquo;<samp>xx</samp>&rsquo; to another macro
name.
</p>
<p>In this output format, some special characters, like &lsquo;<samp>$</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>&amp;</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>_</samp>&rsquo; are automatically protected with a
backslash.  Curly brackets &lsquo;<samp>{</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>}</samp>&rsquo; are protected with a
backslash and a pair of dollar signs (to force mathematical mode).  The
backslash itself produces the sequence <code>\backslash{}</code>.
Circumflex and tilde diacritical marks produce the sequence <code>^\{ }</code> and
<code>~\{ }</code> respectively.  Other diacriticized characters of the
underlying character set produce an appropriate TeX sequence as far
as possible.  The other non-graphical characters, like newline and tab,
and all other characters which are not part of ASCII, are merely
changed to exactly one space, with no special attempt to compress
consecutive spaces.  Let me know how to improve this special character
processing for TeX.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Compatibility-in-ptx"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Output-formatting-in-ptx" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Output formatting in ptx</a>, Up: <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ptx invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="The-GNU-extensions-to-ptx"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">7.5.5 The GNU extensions to <code>ptx</code></h4>

<p>This version of <code>ptx</code> contains a few features which do not exist in
System V <code>ptx</code>.  These extra features are suppressed by using the
<samp>-G</samp> command line option, unless overridden by other command line
options.  Some GNU extensions cannot be recovered by overriding, so the
simple rule is to avoid <samp>-G</samp> if you care about GNU extensions.
Here are the differences between this program and System V <code>ptx</code>.
</p>
<ul>
<li> This program can read many input files at once, it always writes the
resulting concordance on standard output.  On the other hand, System V
<code>ptx</code> reads only one file and sends the result to standard output
or, if a second <var>file</var> parameter is given on the command, to that
<var>file</var>.

<p>Having output parameters not introduced by options is a dangerous
practice which GNU avoids as far as possible.  So, for using <code>ptx</code>
portably between GNU and System V, you should always use it with a
single input file, and always expect the result on standard output.  You
might also want to automatically configure in a <samp>-G</samp> option to
<code>ptx</code> calls in products using <code>ptx</code>, if the configurator finds
that the installed <code>ptx</code> accepts <samp>-G</samp>.
</p>
</li><li> The only options available in System V <code>ptx</code> are options <samp>-b</samp>,
<samp>-f</samp>, <samp>-g</samp>, <samp>-i</samp>, <samp>-o</samp>, <samp>-r</samp>, <samp>-t</samp> and
<samp>-w</samp>.  All other options are GNU extensions and are not repeated in
this enumeration.  Moreover, some options have a slightly different
meaning when GNU extensions are enabled, as explained below.

</li><li> By default, concordance output is not formatted for <code>troff</code> or
<code>nroff</code>.  It is rather formatted for a dumb terminal.  <code>troff</code>
or <code>nroff</code> output may still be selected through option <samp>-O</samp>.

</li><li> Unless <samp>-R</samp> option is used, the maximum reference width is
subtracted from the total output line width.  With GNU extensions
disabled, width of references is not taken into account in the output
line width computations.

</li><li> All 256 bytes, even ASCII NUL bytes, are always read and
processed from input file with no adverse effect, even if GNU extensions
are disabled.  However, System V <code>ptx</code> does not accept 8-bit
characters, a few control characters are rejected, and the tilde
&lsquo;<samp>~</samp>&rsquo; is also rejected.

</li><li> Input line length is only limited by available memory, even if GNU
extensions are disabled.  However, System V <code>ptx</code> processes only
the first 200 characters in each line.

</li><li> The break (non-word) characters default to be every character except all
letters of the underlying character set, diacriticized or not.  When GNU
extensions are disabled, the break characters default to space, tab and
newline only.

</li><li> The program makes better use of output line width.  If GNU extensions
are disabled, the program rather tries to imitate System V <code>ptx</code>,
but still, there are some slight disposition glitches this program does
not completely reproduce.

</li><li> The user can specify both an Ignore file and an Only file.  This is not
allowed with System V <code>ptx</code>.

</li></ul>


<hr>
<a name="tsort-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#ptx-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">ptx invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-sorted-files" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on sorted files</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="tsort_003a-Topological-sort"></a>
<h3 class="section">7.6 <code>tsort</code>: Topological sort</h3>

<a name="index-tsort"></a>
<a name="index-topological-sort"></a>

<p><code>tsort</code> performs a topological sort on the given <var>file</var>, or
standard input if no input file is given or for a <var>file</var> of
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  For more details and some history, see <a href="#tsort-background">tsort background</a>.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tsort [<var>option</var>] [<var>file</var>]
</pre></div>

<p><code>tsort</code> reads its input as pairs of strings, separated by blanks,
indicating a partial ordering.  The output is a total ordering that
corresponds to the given partial ordering.
</p>
<p>For example
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tsort &lt;&lt;EOF
a b c
d
e f
b c d e
EOF
</pre></div>

<p>will produce the output
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">a
b
c
d
e
f
</pre></div>

<p>Consider a more realistic example.
You have a large set of functions all in one file, and they may all be
declared static except one.  Currently that one (say <code>main</code>) is the
first function defined in the file, and the ones it calls directly follow
it, followed by those they call, etc.  Let&rsquo;s say that you are determined
to take advantage of prototypes, so you have to choose between declaring
all of those functions (which means duplicating a lot of information from
the definitions) and rearranging the functions so that as many as possible
are defined before they are used.  One way to automate the latter process
is to get a list for each function of the functions it calls directly.
Many programs can generate such lists.  They describe a call graph.
Consider the following list, in which a given line indicates that the
function on the left calls the one on the right directly.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">main parse_options
main tail_file
main tail_forever
tail_file pretty_name
tail_file write_header
tail_file tail
tail_forever recheck
tail_forever pretty_name
tail_forever write_header
tail_forever dump_remainder
tail tail_lines
tail tail_bytes
tail_lines start_lines
tail_lines dump_remainder
tail_lines file_lines
tail_lines pipe_lines
tail_bytes xlseek
tail_bytes start_bytes
tail_bytes dump_remainder
tail_bytes pipe_bytes
file_lines dump_remainder
recheck pretty_name
</pre></div>

<p>then you can use <code>tsort</code> to produce an ordering of those
functions that satisfies your requirement.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">example$ tsort call-graph | tac
dump_remainder
start_lines
file_lines
pipe_lines
xlseek
start_bytes
pipe_bytes
tail_lines
tail_bytes
pretty_name
write_header
tail
recheck
parse_options
tail_file
tail_forever
main
</pre></div>

<p><code>tsort</code> detects any cycles in the input and writes the first cycle
encountered to standard error.
</p>
<p>Note that for a given partial ordering, generally there is no unique
total ordering.  In the context of the call graph above, the function
<code>parse_options</code> may be placed anywhere in the list as long as it
precedes <code>main</code>.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#tsort-background" accesskey="1">tsort background</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Where tsort came from.
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="tsort-background"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Up: <a href="#tsort-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">tsort invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="tsort_003a-Background"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">7.6.1 <code>tsort</code>: Background</h4>

<p><code>tsort</code> exists because very early versions of the Unix linker processed
an archive file exactly once, and in order.  As <code>ld</code> read each object
in the archive, it decided whether it was needed in the program based on
whether it defined any symbols which were undefined at that point in
the link.
</p>
<p>This meant that dependencies within the archive had to be handled
specially.  For example, <code>scanf</code> probably calls <code>read</code>.  That means
that in a single pass through an archive, it was important for <code>scanf.o</code>
to appear before read.o, because otherwise a program which calls
<code>scanf</code> but not <code>read</code> might end up with an unexpected unresolved
reference to <code>read</code>.
</p>
<p>The way to address this problem was to first generate a set of
dependencies of one object file on another.  This was done by a shell
script called <code>lorder</code>.  The GNU tools don&rsquo;t provide a version of
lorder, as far as I know, but you can still find it in BSD
distributions.
</p>
<p>Then you ran <code>tsort</code> over the <code>lorder</code> output, and you used the
resulting sort to define the order in which you added objects to the archive.
</p>
<p>This whole procedure has been obsolete since about 1980, because
Unix archives now contain a symbol table (traditionally built by
<code>ranlib</code>, now generally built by <code>ar</code> itself), and the Unix
linker uses the symbol table to effectively make multiple passes over
an archive file.
</p>
<p>Anyhow, that&rsquo;s where tsort came from.  To solve an old problem with
the way the linker handled archive files, which has since been solved
in different ways.
</p>

<hr>

</div>

<h2 class="chapter">8 Operating on fields</h2>

<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#cut-invocation" accesskey="1">cut invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print selected parts of lines.

</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="3">join invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Join lines on a common field.
</td></tr>
</table>
