<a name="cut-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#paste-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">paste invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-fields" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on fields</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="cut_003a-Print-selected-parts-of-lines"></a>
<h3 class="section">8.1 <code>cut</code>: Print selected parts of lines</h3>

<a name="index-cut"></a>
<p><code>cut</code> writes to standard output selected parts of each line of each
input file, or standard input if no files are given or for a file name of
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">cut <var>option</var>&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>In the table which follows, the <var>byte-list</var>, <var>character-list</var>,
and <var>field-list</var> are one or more numbers or ranges (two numbers
separated by a dash) separated by commas.  Bytes, characters, and
fields are numbered starting at 1.  Incomplete ranges may be
given: <samp>-<var>m</var></samp> means &lsquo;<samp>1-<var>m</var></samp>&rsquo;; &lsquo;<samp><var>n</var>-</samp>&rsquo; means
&lsquo;<samp><var>n</var></samp>&rsquo; through end of line or last field.  The list elements
can be repeated, can overlap, and can be specified in any order; but
the selected input is written in the same order that it is read, and
is written exactly once.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b <var>byte-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bytes=<var>byte-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbytes-5"></a>
<p>Select for printing only the bytes in positions listed in
<var>byte-list</var>.  Tabs and backspaces are treated like any other
character; they take up 1 byte.  If an output delimiter is specified,
(see the description of <samp>--output-delimiter</samp>), then output that
string between ranges of selected bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c <var>character-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--characters=<var>character-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcharacters"></a>
<p>Select for printing only the characters in positions listed in
<var>character-list</var>.  The same as <samp>-b</samp> for now, but
internationalization will change that.  Tabs and backspaces are
treated like any other character; they take up 1 character.  If an
output delimiter is specified, (see the description of
<samp>--output-delimiter</samp>), then output that string between ranges
of selected bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f <var>field-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--fields=<var>field-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfields"></a>
<p>Select for printing only the fields listed in <var>field-list</var>.
Fields are separated by a TAB character by default.  Also print any
line that contains no delimiter character, unless the
<samp>--only-delimited</samp> (<samp>-s</samp>) option is specified.
</p>
<p>Note <code>awk</code> supports more sophisticated field processing,
like reordering fields, and handling fields aligned with blank characters.
By default <code>awk</code> uses (and discards) runs of blank characters
to separate fields, and ignores leading and trailing blanks.
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="verbatim">awk '{print $2}'      # print the second field
awk '{print $(NF-1)}' # print the penultimate field
awk '{print $2,$1}'   # reorder the first two fields
</pre></div>
<p>Note while <code>cut</code> accepts field specifications in
arbitrary order, output is always in the order encountered in the file.
</p>
<p>In the unlikely event that <code>awk</code> is unavailable,
one can use the <code>join</code> command, to process blank
characters as <code>awk</code> does above.
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="verbatim">join -a1 -o 1.2     - /dev/null # print the second field
join -a1 -o 1.2,1.1 - /dev/null # reorder the first two fields
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>input_delim_byte</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--delimiter=<var>input_delim_byte</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddelimiter"></a>
<p>With <samp>-f</samp>, use the first byte of <var>input_delim_byte</var> as
the input fields separator (default is TAB).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-9"></a>
<p>Do not split multi-byte characters (no-op for now).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--only-delimited</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002donly_002ddelimited"></a>
<p>For <samp>-f</samp>, do not print lines that do not contain the field separator
character.  Normally, any line without a field separator is printed verbatim.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output-delimiter=<var>output_delim_string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002doutput_002ddelimiter"></a>
<p>With <samp>-f</samp>, output fields are separated by <var>output_delim_string</var>.
The default with <samp>-f</samp> is to use the input delimiter.
When using <samp>-b</samp> or <samp>-c</samp> to select ranges of byte or
character offsets (as opposed to ranges of fields),
output <var>output_delim_string</var> between non-overlapping
ranges of selected bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--complement</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dcomplement"></a>
<p>This option is a GNU extension.
Select for printing the complement of the bytes, characters or fields
selected with the <samp>-b</samp>, <samp>-c</samp> or <samp>-f</samp> options.
In other words, do <em>not</em> print the bytes, characters or fields
specified via those options.  This option is useful when you have
many fields and want to print all but a few of them.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-6"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-6"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="paste-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">join invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#cut-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">cut invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-fields" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on fields</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="paste_003a-Merge-lines-of-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">8.2 <code>paste</code>: Merge lines of files</h3>

<a name="index-paste"></a>
<a name="index-merging-files"></a>

<p><code>paste</code> writes to standard output lines consisting of sequentially
corresponding lines of each given file, separated by a TAB character.
Standard input is used for a file name of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; or if no input files
are given.
</p>
<p>Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">paste [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>For example, with:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat num2
1
2
$ cat let3
a
b
c
</pre></div>

<p>Take lines sequentially from each file:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ paste num2 let3
1       a
2       b
       &nbsp;c
</pre></div>

<p>Duplicate lines from a file:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ paste num2 let3 num2
1       a      1
2       b      2
       &nbsp;c
</pre></div>

<p>Intermix lines from stdin:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ paste - let3 - &lt; num2
1       a      2
       &nbsp;b
       &nbsp;c
</pre></div>

<p>Join consecutive lines with a space:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq 4 | paste -d ' ' - -
1 2
3 4
</pre></div>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--serial</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dserial"></a>
<p>Paste the lines of one file at a time rather than one line from each
file.  Using the above example data:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ paste -s num2 let3
1       2
a       b       c
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>delim-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--delimiters=<var>delim-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddelimiters"></a>
<p>Consecutively use the characters in <var>delim-list</var> instead of
TAB to separate merged lines.  When <var>delim-list</var> is
exhausted, start again at its beginning.  Using the above example data:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ paste -d '%_' num2 let3 num2
1%a_1
2%b_2
%c_
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-7"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-7"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="join-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#paste-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">paste invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-fields" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on fields</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="join_003a-Join-lines-on-a-common-field"></a>
<h3 class="section">8.3 <code>join</code>: Join lines on a common field</h3>

<a name="index-join"></a>
<a name="index-common-field_002c-joining-on"></a>

<p><code>join</code> writes to standard output a line for each pair of input
lines that have identical join fields.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">join [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>file1</var> <var>file2</var>
</pre></div>

<p>Either <var>file1</var> or <var>file2</var> (but not both) can be &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;,
meaning standard input.  <var>file1</var> and <var>file2</var> should be
sorted on the join fields.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat file1
a 1
b 2
e 5

$ cat file2
a X
e Y
f Z

$ join file1 file2
a 1 X
e 5 Y
</pre></div>


<p><code>join</code>&rsquo;s default behavior (when no options are given):
</p><ul>
<li> the join field is the first field in each line;
</li><li> fields in the input are separated by one or more blanks, with leading
blanks on the line ignored;
</li><li> fields in the output are separated by a space;
</li><li> each output line consists of the join field, the remaining
fields from <var>file1</var>, then the remaining fields from <var>file2</var>.
</li></ul>


<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#General-options-in-join" accesskey="1">General options in join</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Options which affect general program behavior.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Sorting-files-for-join" accesskey="2">Sorting files for join</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Using <code>sort</code> before <code>join</code>.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Working-with-fields" accesskey="3">Working with fields</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Joining on different fields.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Paired-and-unpaired-lines" accesskey="4">Paired and unpaired lines</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Controlling <code>join</code>&rsquo;s field matching.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Header-lines" accesskey="5">Header lines</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Working with header lines in files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Set-operations" accesskey="6">Set operations</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Union, Intersection and Difference of files.
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="General-options-in-join"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Sorting-files-for-join" accesskey="n" rel="next">Sorting files for join</a>, Up: <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">join invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="General-options-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">8.3.1 General options</h4>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a <var>file-number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-3"></a>
<p>Print a line for each unpairable line in file <var>file-number</var> (either
&lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>2</samp>&rsquo;), in addition to the normal output.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--check-order</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Fail with an error message if either input file is wrongly ordered.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--nocheck-order</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Do not check that both input files are in sorted order.  This is the default.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-3"></a>
<p>Replace those output fields that are missing in the input with <var>string</var>.
I.e., missing fields specified with the <samp>-12jo</samp> options.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--header</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dheader-1"></a>
<p>Treat the first line of each input file as a header line.  The header lines
will be joined and printed as the first output line.  If <samp>-o</samp> is used to
specify output format, the header line will be printed according to the
specified format.  The header lines will not be checked for ordering even if
<samp>--check-order</samp> is specified.  Also if the header lines from each file
do not match, the heading fields from the first file will be used.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-case</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dcase-3"></a>
<p>Ignore differences in case when comparing keys.
With this option, the lines of the input files must be ordered in the same way.
Use &lsquo;<samp>sort -f</samp>&rsquo; to produce this ordering.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-1 <var>field</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d1-1"></a>
<p>Join on field <var>field</var> (a positive integer) of file 1.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-2 <var>field</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d2-1"></a>
<p>Join on field <var>field</var> (a positive integer) of file 2.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-j <var>field</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Equivalent to <samp>-1 <var>field</var> -2 <var>field</var></samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o <var>field-list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o auto</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>If the keyword &lsquo;<samp>auto</samp>&rsquo; is specified, infer the output format from
the first line in each file.  This is the same as the default output format
but also ensures the same number of fields are output for each line.
Missing fields are replaced with the <samp>-e</samp> option and extra fields
are discarded.
</p>
<p>Otherwise, construct each output line according to the format in
<var>field-list</var>.  Each element in <var>field-list</var> is either the single
character &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; or has the form <var>m.n</var> where the file number, <var>m</var>,
is &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>2</samp>&rsquo; and <var>n</var> is a positive field number.
</p>
<p>A field specification of &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; denotes the join field.
In most cases, the functionality of the &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; field spec
may be reproduced using the explicit <var>m.n</var> that corresponds
to the join field.  However, when printing unpairable lines
(using either of the <samp>-a</samp> or <samp>-v</samp> options), there is no way
to specify the join field using <var>m.n</var> in <var>field-list</var>
if there are unpairable lines in both files.
To give <code>join</code> that functionality, POSIX invented the &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;
field specification notation.
</p>
<p>The elements in <var>field-list</var>
are separated by commas or blanks.
Blank separators typically need to be quoted for the shell.  For
example, the commands &lsquo;<samp>join -o 1.2,2.2</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>join -o '1.2
2.2'</samp>&rsquo; are equivalent.
</p>
<p>All output lines&mdash;including those printed because of any -a or -v
option&mdash;are subject to the specified <var>field-list</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>char</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Use character <var>char</var> as the input and output field separator.
Treat as significant each occurrence of <var>char</var> in the input file.
Use &lsquo;<samp>sort -t <var>char</var></samp>&rsquo;, without the <samp>-b</samp> option of
&lsquo;<samp>sort</samp>&rsquo;, to produce this ordering.  If &lsquo;<samp>join -t ''</samp>&rsquo; is specified,
the whole line is considered, matching the default operation of sort.
If &lsquo;<samp>-t '\0'</samp>&rsquo; is specified then the ASCII NUL
character is used to delimit the fields.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v <var>file-number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print a line for each unpairable line in file <var>file-number</var>
(either &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>2</samp>&rsquo;), instead of the normal output.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-8"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-8"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
Note with <samp>-z</samp> the newline character is treated as a field separator.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>If the <samp>--check-order</samp> option is given, unsorted inputs will
cause a fatal error message.  If the option <samp>--nocheck-order</samp>
is given, unsorted inputs will never cause an error message.  If neither
of these options is given, wrongly sorted inputs are diagnosed
only if an input file is found to contain unpairable
lines, and when both input files are non empty.
If an input file is diagnosed as being unsorted, the <code>join</code>
command will exit with a nonzero status (and the output should not be used).
</p>
<p>Forcing <code>join</code> to process wrongly sorted input files
containing unpairable lines by specifying <samp>--nocheck-order</samp> is
not guaranteed to produce any particular output.  The output will
probably not correspond with whatever you hoped it would be.
</p>


<hr>
<a name="Sorting-files-for-join"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Working-with-fields" accesskey="n" rel="next">Working with fields</a>, Previous: <a href="#General-options-in-join" accesskey="p" rel="prev">General options in join</a>, Up: <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">join invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Pre_002dsorting"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">8.3.2 Pre-sorting</h4>

<p><code>join</code> requires sorted input files. Each input file should be
sorted according to the key (=field/column number) used in
<code>join</code>. The recommended sorting option is &lsquo;<samp>sort -k 1b,1</samp>&rsquo;
(assuming the desired key is in the first column).
</p>
<p>Typical usage:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ sort -k 1b,1 file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ sort -k 1b,1 file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>

<a name="index-LC_005fCOLLATE-3"></a>
<p>Normally, the sort order is that of the
collating sequence specified by the <code>LC_COLLATE</code> locale.  Unless
the <samp>-t</samp> option is given, the sort comparison ignores blanks at
the start of the join field, as in <code>sort -b</code>.  If the
<samp>--ignore-case</samp> option is given, the sort comparison ignores
the case of characters in the join field, as in <code>sort -f</code>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ sort -k 1bf,1 file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ sort -k 1bf,1 file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join --ignore-case file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>

<p>The <code>sort</code> and <code>join</code> commands should use consistent
locales and options if the output of <code>sort</code> is fed to
<code>join</code>.  You can use a command like &lsquo;<samp>sort -k 1b,1</samp>&rsquo; to
sort a file on its default join field, but if you select a non-default
locale, join field, separator, or comparison options, then you should
do so consistently between <code>join</code> and <code>sort</code>.
</p>
<p>To avoid any locale-related issues, it is recommended to use the
&lsquo;<samp>C</samp>&rsquo; locale for both commands:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ LC_ALL=C sort -k 1b,1 file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ LC_ALL=C sort -k 1b,1 file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ LC_ALL=C join file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="Working-with-fields"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Paired-and-unpaired-lines" accesskey="n" rel="next">Paired and unpaired lines</a>, Previous: <a href="#Sorting-files-for-join" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Sorting files for join</a>, Up: <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">join invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Working-with-fields-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">8.3.3 Working with fields</h4>

<p>Use <samp>-1</samp>,<samp>-2</samp> to set the key fields for each of the input files.
Ensure the preceding <code>sort</code> commands operated on the same fields.
</p>
<p>The following example joins two files, using the values from seventh field
of the first file and the third field of the second file:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ sort -k 7b,7 file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ sort -k 3b,3 file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join -1 7 -2 3 file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>

<p>If the field number is the same for both files, use <samp>-j</samp>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ sort -k4b,4 file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ sort -k4b,4 file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join -j4    file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>

<p>Both <code>sort</code> and <code>join</code> operate of whitespace-delimited
fields. To specify a different delimiter, use <samp>-t</samp> in <em>both</em>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ sort -t, -k3b,3 file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ sort -t, -k3b,3 file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join -t, -j3    file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>

<p>To specify a tab (<small>ASCII</small> 0x09) character instead of whitespace, use
<a name="DOCF3" href="#FOOT3"><sup>3</sup></a>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ sort -t$'\t' -k3b,3 file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ sort -t$'\t' -k3b,3 file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join -t$'\t' -j3    file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>


<p>If &lsquo;<samp>join -t ''</samp>&rsquo; is specified then the whole line is considered which
matches the default operation of sort:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ sort file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ sort file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join -t '' file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="Paired-and-unpaired-lines"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Header-lines" accesskey="n" rel="next">Header lines</a>, Previous: <a href="#Working-with-fields" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Working with fields</a>, Up: <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">join invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Controlling-join_0027s-field-matching"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">8.3.4 Controlling <code>join</code>&rsquo;s field matching</h4>

<p>In this section the <code>sort</code> commands are omitted for brevity.
Sorting the files before joining is still required.
</p>
<p><code>join</code>&rsquo;s default behavior is to print only lines common to
both input files. Use <samp>-a</samp> and <samp>-v</samp> to print unpairable lines
from one or both files.
</p>
<p>All examples below use the following two (pre-sorted) input files:
</p>
<table>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat file1
a 1
b 2
</pre></div></td><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat file2
a A
c C
</pre></div></td></tr>
</table>


<table>
<thead><tr><th width="50%">Command</th><th width="50%">Outcome</th></tr></thead>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join file1 file2
a 1 A
</pre></div></td><td width="50%">common lines
(<em>intersection</em>)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join -a 1 file1 file2
a 1 A
b 2
</pre></div></td><td width="50%">common lines <em>and</em> unpaired
lines from the first file</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join -a 2 file1 file2
a 1 A
c C
</pre></div></td><td width="50%">common lines <em>and</em> unpaired lines from the second file</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join -a 1 -a 2 file1 file2
a 1 A
b 2
c C
</pre></div></td><td width="50%">all lines (paired and unpaired) from both files
(<em>union</em>).
<br>
see note below regarding <code>-o auto</code>.</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join -v 1 file1 file2
b 2
</pre></div></td><td width="50%">unpaired lines from the first file
(<em>difference</em>)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join -v 2 file1 file2
c C
</pre></div></td><td width="50%">unpaired lines from the second file
(<em>difference</em>)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join -v 1 -v 2 file1 file2
b 2
c C
</pre></div></td><td width="50%">unpaired lines from both files, omitting common lines
(<em>symmetric difference</em>).</td></tr>
</table>

<p>The <samp>-o auto -e X</samp> options are useful when dealing with unpaired lines.
The following example prints all lines (common and unpaired) from both files.
Without <samp>-o auto</samp> it is not easy to discern which fields originate from
which file:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ join -a 1 -a 2 file1 file2
a 1 A
b 2
c C

$ join -o auto -e X -a 1 -a 2 file1 file2
a 1 A
b 2 X
c X C
</pre></div>


<p>If the input has no unpairable lines, a GNU extension is
available; the sort order can be any order that considers two fields
to be equal if and only if the sort comparison described above
considers them to be equal.  For example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat file1
a a1
c c1
b b1

$ cat file2
a a2
c c2
b b2

$ join file1 file2
a a1 a2
c c1 c2
b b1 b2
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="Header-lines"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Set-operations" accesskey="n" rel="next">Set operations</a>, Previous: <a href="#Paired-and-unpaired-lines" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Paired and unpaired lines</a>, Up: <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">join invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Header-lines-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">8.3.5 Header lines</h4>

<p>The <samp>--header</samp> option can be used when the files to join
have a header line which is not sorted:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat file1
Name     Age
Alice    25
Charlie  34

$ cat file2
Name   Country
Alice  France
Bob    Spain

$ join --header -o auto -e NA -a1 -a2 file1 file2
Name     Age   Country
Alice    25    France
Bob      NA    Spain
Charlie  34    NA
</pre></div>


<p>To sort a file with a header line, use GNU <code>sed -u</code>.
The following example sort the files but keeps the first line of each
file in place:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ ( sed -u 1q ; sort -k2b,2 ) &lt; file1 &gt; file1.sorted
$ ( sed -u 1q ; sort -k2b,2 ) &lt; file2 &gt; file2.sorted
$ join --header -o auto -e NA -a1 -a2 file1.sorted file2.sorted &gt; file3
</pre></div>

<hr>
<a name="Set-operations"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Header-lines" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Header lines</a>, Up: <a href="#join-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">join invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Union_002c-Intersection-and-Difference-of-files"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">8.3.6 Union, Intersection and Difference of files</h4>

<p>Combine <code>sort</code>, <code>uniq</code> and <code>join</code> to
perform the equivalent of set operations on files:
</p>
<table>
<thead><tr><th width="50%">Command</th><th width="50%">outcome</th></tr></thead>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>sort -u file1 file2</code></td><td width="50%">Union of unsorted files</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>sort file1 file2 | uniq -d</code></td><td width="50%">Intersection of unsorted files</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>sort file1 file1 file2 | uniq</code></td><td width="50%">Difference of unsorted files</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>sort file1 file2 | uniq -u</code></td><td width="50%">Symmetric Difference of unsorted files</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>join -t '' -a1 -a2 file1 file2</code></td><td width="50%">Union of sorted files</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>join -t '' file1 file2</code></td><td width="50%">Intersection of sorted files</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>join -t '' -v2 file1 file2</code></td><td width="50%">Difference of sorted files</td></tr>
<tr><td width="50%"><code>join -t '' -v1 -v2 file1 file2</code></td><td width="50%">Symmetric Difference of sorted files</td></tr>
</table>

<p>All examples above operate on entire lines and not on specific fields:
<code>sort</code> without <samp>-k</samp> and <code>join -t ''</code> both consider
entire lines as the key.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Operating-on-characters"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Directory-listing" accesskey="n" rel="next">Directory listing</a>, Previous: <a href="#Operating-on-fields" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Operating on fields</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Operating-on-characters-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">9 Operating on characters</h2>

<a name="index-operating-on-characters"></a>

<p>These commands operate on individual characters.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#tr-invocation" accesskey="1">tr invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Translate, squeeze, and/or delete characters.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#expand-invocation" accesskey="2">expand invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Convert tabs to spaces.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#unexpand-invocation" accesskey="3">unexpand invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Convert spaces to tabs.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="tr-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#expand-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">expand invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-characters" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on characters</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="tr_003a-Translate_002c-squeeze_002c-and_002for-delete-characters"></a>
<h3 class="section">9.1 <code>tr</code>: Translate, squeeze, and/or delete characters</h3>

<a name="index-tr"></a>

<p>Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>set1</var> [<var>set2</var>]
</pre></div>

<p><code>tr</code> copies standard input to standard output, performing
one of the following operations:
</p>
<ul>
<li> translate, and optionally squeeze repeated characters in the result,
</li><li> squeeze repeated characters,
</li><li> delete characters,
</li><li> delete characters, then squeeze repeated characters from the result.
</li></ul>

<p>The <var>set1</var> and (if given) <var>set2</var> arguments define ordered
sets of characters, referred to below as <var>set1</var> and <var>set2</var>.  These
sets are the characters of the input that <code>tr</code> operates on.
The <samp>--complement</samp> (<samp>-c</samp>, <samp>-C</samp>) option replaces
<var>set1</var> with its
complement (all of the characters that are not in <var>set1</var>).
</p>
<p>Currently <code>tr</code> fully supports only single-byte characters.
Eventually it will support multibyte characters; when it does, the
<samp>-C</samp> option will cause it to complement the set of characters,
whereas <samp>-c</samp> will cause it to complement the set of values.
This distinction will matter only when some values are not characters,
and this is possible only in locales using multibyte encodings when
the input contains encoding errors.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>
options.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.  Options must precede operands.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Character-sets" accesskey="1">Character sets</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Specifying sets of characters.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Translating" accesskey="2">Translating</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Changing one set of characters to another.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Squeezing-and-deleting" accesskey="3">Squeezing and deleting</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Removing characters.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="Character-sets"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Translating" accesskey="n" rel="next">Translating</a>, Up: <a href="#tr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">tr invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Specifying-sets-of-characters"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">9.1.1 Specifying sets of characters</h4>

<a name="index-specifying-sets-of-characters"></a>

<p>The format of the <var>set1</var> and <var>set2</var> arguments resembles
the format of regular expressions; however, they are not regular
expressions, only lists of characters.  Most characters simply
represent themselves in these strings, but the strings can contain
the shorthands listed below, for convenience.  Some of them can be
used only in <var>set1</var> or <var>set2</var>, as noted below.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>Backslash escapes</dt>
<dd><a name="index-backslash-escapes"></a>

<p>The following backslash escape sequences are recognized:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Control-G.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Control-H.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Control-L.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Control-J.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Control-M.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Control-I.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Control-K.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\<var>ooo</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>The 8-bit character with the value given by <var>ooo</var>, which is 1 to 3
octal digits.  Note that &lsquo;<samp>\400</samp>&rsquo; is interpreted as the two-byte
sequence, &lsquo;<samp>\040</samp>&rsquo; &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\\</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>A backslash.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>While a backslash followed by a character not listed above is
interpreted as that character, the backslash also effectively
removes any special significance, so it is useful to escape
&lsquo;<samp>[</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>]</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>*</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>Ranges</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ranges"></a>

<p>The notation &lsquo;<samp><var>m</var>-<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo; expands to all of the characters
from <var>m</var> through <var>n</var>, in ascending order.  <var>m</var> should
collate before <var>n</var>; if it doesn&rsquo;t, an error results.  As an example,
&lsquo;<samp>0-9</samp>&rsquo; is the same as &lsquo;<samp>0123456789</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>GNU <code>tr</code> does not support the System V syntax that uses square
brackets to enclose ranges.  Translations specified in that format
sometimes work as expected, since the brackets are often transliterated
to themselves.  However, they should be avoided because they sometimes
behave unexpectedly.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>tr -d '[0-9]'</samp>&rsquo; deletes brackets
as well as digits.
</p>
<p>Many historically common and even accepted uses of ranges are not
portable.  For example, on EBCDIC hosts using the &lsquo;<samp>A-Z</samp>&rsquo;
range will not do what most would expect because &lsquo;<samp>A</samp>&rsquo; through &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;
are not contiguous as they are in ASCII.
If you can rely on a POSIX compliant version of <code>tr</code>, then
the best way to work around this is to use character classes (see below).
Otherwise, it is most portable (and most ugly) to enumerate the members
of the ranges.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>Repeated characters</dt>
<dd><a name="index-repeated-characters"></a>

<p>The notation &lsquo;<samp>[<var>c</var>*<var>n</var>]</samp>&rsquo; in <var>set2</var> expands to <var>n</var>
copies of character <var>c</var>.  Thus, &lsquo;<samp>[y*6]</samp>&rsquo; is the same as
&lsquo;<samp>yyyyyy</samp>&rsquo;.  The notation &lsquo;<samp>[<var>c</var>*]</samp>&rsquo; in <var>string2</var> expands
to as many copies of <var>c</var> as are needed to make <var>set2</var> as long as
<var>set1</var>.  If <var>n</var> begins with &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;, it is interpreted in
octal, otherwise in decimal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>Character classes</dt>
<dd><a name="index-character-classes"></a>

<p>The notation &lsquo;<samp>[:<var>class</var>:]</samp>&rsquo; expands to all of the characters in
the (predefined) class <var>class</var>.  The characters expand in no
particular order, except for the <code>upper</code> and <code>lower</code> classes,
which expand in ascending order.  When the <samp>--delete</samp> (<samp>-d</samp>)
and <samp>--squeeze-repeats</samp> (<samp>-s</samp>) options are both given, any
character class can be used in <var>set2</var>.  Otherwise, only the
character classes <code>lower</code> and <code>upper</code> are accepted in
<var>set2</var>, and then only if the corresponding character class
(<code>upper</code> and <code>lower</code>, respectively) is specified in the same
relative position in <var>set1</var>.  Doing this specifies case conversion.
The class names are given below; an error results when an invalid class
name is given.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt><code>alnum</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-alnum"></a>
<p>Letters and digits.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>alpha</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-alpha"></a>
<p>Letters.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>blank</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-blank"></a>
<p>Horizontal whitespace.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>cntrl</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-cntrl"></a>
<p>Control characters.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>digit</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-digit"></a>
<p>Digits.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>graph</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-graph"></a>
<p>Printable characters, not including space.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>lower</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-lower"></a>
<p>Lowercase letters.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>print</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-print"></a>
<p>Printable characters, including space.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>punct</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-punct"></a>
<p>Punctuation characters.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>space</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-space"></a>
<p>Horizontal or vertical whitespace.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>upper</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-upper"></a>
<p>Uppercase letters.
</p></dd>
<dt><code>xdigit</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-xdigit"></a>
<p>Hexadecimal digits.
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>Equivalence classes</dt>
<dd><a name="index-equivalence-classes"></a>

<p>The syntax &lsquo;<samp>[=<var>c</var>=]</samp>&rsquo; expands to all of the characters that are
equivalent to <var>c</var>, in no particular order.  Equivalence classes are
a relatively recent invention intended to support non-English alphabets.
But there seems to be no standard way to define them or determine their
contents.  Therefore, they are not fully implemented in GNU <code>tr</code>;
each character&rsquo;s equivalence class consists only of that character,
which is of no particular use.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Translating"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Squeezing-and-deleting" accesskey="n" rel="next">Squeezing and deleting</a>, Previous: <a href="#Character-sets" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Character sets</a>, Up: <a href="#tr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">tr invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Translating-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">9.1.2 Translating</h4>

<a name="index-translating-characters"></a>

<p><code>tr</code> performs translation when <var>set1</var> and <var>set2</var> are
both given and the <samp>--delete</samp> (<samp>-d</samp>) option is not given.
<code>tr</code> translates each character of its input that is in <var>set1</var>
to the corresponding character in <var>set2</var>.  Characters not in
<var>set1</var> are passed through unchanged.  When a character appears more
than once in <var>set1</var> and the corresponding characters in <var>set2</var>
are not all the same, only the final one is used.  For example, these
two commands are equivalent:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr aaa xyz
tr a z
</pre></div>

<p>A common use of <code>tr</code> is to convert lowercase characters to
uppercase.  This can be done in many ways.  Here are three of them:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ
tr a-z A-Z
tr '[:lower:]' '[:upper:]'
</pre></div>

<p>But note that using ranges like <code>a-z</code> above is not portable.
</p>
<p>When <code>tr</code> is performing translation, <var>set1</var> and <var>set2</var>
typically have the same length.  If <var>set1</var> is shorter than
<var>set2</var>, the extra characters at the end of <var>set2</var> are ignored.
</p>
<p>On the other hand, making <var>set1</var> longer than <var>set2</var> is not
portable; POSIX says that the result is undefined.  In this situation,
BSD <code>tr</code> pads <var>set2</var> to the length of <var>set1</var> by repeating
the last character of <var>set2</var> as many times as necessary.  System V
<code>tr</code> truncates <var>set1</var> to the length of <var>set2</var>.
</p>
<p>By default, GNU <code>tr</code> handles this case like BSD <code>tr</code>.
When the <samp>--truncate-set1</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) option is given,
GNU <code>tr</code> handles this case like the System V <code>tr</code>
instead.  This option is ignored for operations other than translation.
</p>
<p>Acting like System V <code>tr</code> in this case breaks the relatively common
BSD idiom:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -cs A-Za-z0-9 '\012'
</pre></div>

<p>because it converts only zero bytes (the first element in the
complement of <var>set1</var>), rather than all non-alphanumerics, to
newlines.
</p>
<p>By the way, the above idiom is not portable because it uses ranges, and
it assumes that the octal code for newline is 012.
Assuming a POSIX compliant <code>tr</code>, here is a better
way to write it:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -cs '[:alnum:]' '[\n*]'
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="Squeezing-and-deleting"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Translating" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Translating</a>, Up: <a href="#tr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">tr invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Squeezing-repeats-and-deleting"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">9.1.3 Squeezing repeats and deleting</h4>

<a name="index-squeezing-repeat-characters"></a>
<a name="index-deleting-characters"></a>
<a name="index-removing-characters"></a>

<p>When given just the <samp>--delete</samp> (<samp>-d</samp>) option, <code>tr</code>
removes any input characters that are in <var>set1</var>.
</p>
<p>When given just the <samp>--squeeze-repeats</samp> (<samp>-s</samp>) option
and not translating, <code>tr</code> replaces each input sequence of a
repeated character that is in <var>set1</var> with a single occurrence of
that character.
</p>
<p>When given both <samp>--delete</samp> and <samp>--squeeze-repeats</samp>, <code>tr</code>
first performs any deletions using <var>set1</var>, then squeezes repeats
from any remaining characters using <var>set2</var>.
</p>
<p>The <samp>--squeeze-repeats</samp> option may also be used when translating,
in which case <code>tr</code> first performs translation, then squeezes
repeats from any remaining characters using <var>set2</var>.
</p>
<p>Here are some examples to illustrate various combinations of options:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Remove all zero bytes:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -d '\0'
</pre></div>

</li><li> Put all words on lines by themselves.  This converts all
non-alphanumeric characters to newlines, then squeezes each string
of repeated newlines into a single newline:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -cs '[:alnum:]' '[\n*]'
</pre></div>

</li><li> Convert each sequence of repeated newlines to a single newline.
I.e., delete blank lines:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -s '\n'
</pre></div>

</li><li> Find doubled occurrences of words in a document.
For example, people often write &ldquo;the <!-- /@w -->the&rdquo; with the repeated words
separated by a newline.  The Bourne shell script below works first
by converting each sequence of punctuation and blank characters to a
single newline.  That puts each &ldquo;word&rdquo; on a line by itself.
Next it maps all uppercase characters to lower case, and finally it
runs <code>uniq</code> with the <samp>-d</samp> option to print out only the words
that were repeated.

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/bin/sh
cat -- &quot;$@&quot; \
  | tr -s '[:punct:][:blank:]' '[\n*]' \
  | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]' \
  | uniq -d
</pre></div>

</li><li> Deleting a small set of characters is usually straightforward.  For example,
to remove all &lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo;s, &lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;s, and &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;s you would do this:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -d axM
</pre></div>

<p>However, when &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; is one of those characters, it can be tricky because
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; has special meanings.  Performing the same task as above but also
removing all &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; characters, we might try <code>tr -d -axM</code>, but
that would fail because <code>tr</code> would try to interpret <samp>-a</samp> as
a command-line option.  Alternatively, we could try putting the hyphen
inside the string, <code>tr -d a-xM</code>, but that wouldn&rsquo;t work either because
it would make <code>tr</code> interpret <code>a-x</code> as the range of characters
&lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo; rather than the three.
One way to solve the problem is to put the hyphen at the end of the list
of characters:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -d axM-
</pre></div>

<p>Or you can use &lsquo;<samp>--</samp>&rsquo; to terminate option processing:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -d -- -axM
</pre></div>

<p>More generally, use the character class notation <code>[=c=]</code>
with &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; (or any other character) in place of the &lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tr -d '[=-=]axM'
</pre></div>

<p>Note how single quotes are used in the above example to protect the
square brackets from interpretation by a shell.
</p>
</li></ul>


<hr>
<a name="expand-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#unexpand-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">unexpand invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#tr-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">tr invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-characters" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on characters</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="expand_003a-Convert-tabs-to-spaces"></a>
<h3 class="section">9.2 <code>expand</code>: Convert tabs to spaces</h3>

<a name="index-expand"></a>
<a name="index-tabs-to-spaces_002c-converting"></a>
<a name="index-converting-tabs-to-spaces"></a>

<p><code>expand</code> writes the contents of each given <var>file</var>, or standard
input if none are given or for a <var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, to standard
output, with tab characters converted to the appropriate number of
spaces.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">expand [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>By default, <code>expand</code> converts all tabs to spaces.  It preserves
backspace characters in the output; they decrement the column count for
tab calculations.  The default action is equivalent to <samp>-t 8</samp> (set
tabs every 8 columns).
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>tab1</var>[,<var>tab2</var>]&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--tabs=<var>tab1</var>[,<var>tab2</var>]&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtabs"></a>
<a name="index-tab-stops_002c-setting"></a>
<p>If only one tab stop is given, set the tabs <var>tab1</var> spaces apart
(default is 8).  Otherwise, set the tabs at columns <var>tab1</var>,
<var>tab2</var>, &hellip; (numbered from 0), and replace any tabs beyond the
last tab stop given with single spaces.
Tab stops can be separated by blanks as well as by commas.
</p>
<p>As a GNU extension the last <var>tab</var> specified can be prefixed
with a &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; to indicate a tab size to use for remaining positions.
For example, <samp>--tabs=2,4,/8</samp> will set tab stops at position 2 and 4,
and every multiple of 8 after that.
</p>
<p>Also the last <var>tab</var> specified can be prefixed with a &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; to indicate
a tab size to use for remaining positions, offset from the final explicitly
specified tab stop.
For example, to ignore the 1 character gutter present in diff output,
one can specify a 1 character offset using <samp>--tabs=1,+8</samp>,
which will set tab stops at positions 1,9,17,&hellip;
</p>

<p>For compatibility, GNU <code>expand</code> also accepts the obsolete
option syntax, <samp>-<var>t1</var>[,<var>t2</var>]&hellip;</samp>.  New scripts
should use <samp>-t <var>t1</var>[,<var>t2</var>]&hellip;</samp> instead.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--initial</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinitial"></a>
<a name="index-initial-tabs_002c-converting"></a>
<p>Only convert initial tabs (those that precede all non-space or non-tab
characters) on each line to spaces.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="unexpand-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#expand-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">expand invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Operating-on-characters" accesskey="u" rel="up">Operating on characters</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="unexpand_003a-Convert-spaces-to-tabs"></a>
<h3 class="section">9.3 <code>unexpand</code>: Convert spaces to tabs</h3>

<a name="index-unexpand"></a>

<p><code>unexpand</code> writes the contents of each given <var>file</var>, or
standard input if none are given or for a <var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, to
standard output, converting blanks at the beginning of each line into
as many tab characters as needed.  In the default POSIX
locale, a <em>blank</em> is a space or a tab; other locales may specify
additional blank characters.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">unexpand [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>By default, <code>unexpand</code> converts only initial blanks (those
that precede all non-blank characters) on each line.  It
preserves backspace characters in the output; they decrement the column
count for tab calculations.  By default, tabs are set at every 8th
column.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>tab1</var>[,<var>tab2</var>]&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--tabs=<var>tab1</var>[,<var>tab2</var>]&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtabs-1"></a>
<p>If only one tab stop is given, set the tabs <var>tab1</var> columns apart
instead of the default 8.  Otherwise, set the tabs at columns
<var>tab1</var>, <var>tab2</var>, &hellip; (numbered from 0), and leave blanks
beyond the tab stops given unchanged.
Tab stops can be separated by blanks as well as by commas.
</p>
<p>As a GNU extension the last <var>tab</var> specified can be prefixed
with a &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; to indicate a tab size to use for remaining positions.
For example, <samp>--tabs=2,4,/8</samp> will set tab stops at position 2 and 4,
and every multiple of 8 after that.
</p>
<p>Also the last <var>tab</var> specified can be prefixed with a &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; to indicate
a tab size to use for remaining positions, offset from the final explicitly
specified tab stop.
For example, to ignore the 1 character gutter present in diff output,
one can specify a 1 character offset using <samp>--tabs=1,+8</samp>,
which will set tab stops at positions 1,9,17,&hellip;
</p>
<p>This option implies the <samp>-a</samp> option.
</p>
<p>For compatibility, GNU <code>unexpand</code> supports the obsolete option syntax,
<samp>-<var>tab1</var>[,<var>tab2</var>]&hellip;</samp>, where tab stops must be
separated by commas.  (Unlike <samp>-t</samp>, this obsolete option does
not imply <samp>-a</samp>.)  New scripts should use <samp>--first-only -t
<var>tab1</var>[,<var>tab2</var>]&hellip;</samp> instead.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall"></a>
<p>Also convert all sequences of two or more blanks just before a tab stop,
even if they occur after non-blank characters in a line.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>

<h2 class="chapter">10 Directory listing</h2>

<p>This chapter describes the <code>ls</code> command and its variants <code>dir</code>
and <code>vdir</code>, which list information about files.
</p>

<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#dircolors-invocation" accesskey="4">dircolors invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Color setup for ls, etc.
</td></tr>

<a name="ls-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#dir-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">dir invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Directory-listing" accesskey="u" rel="up">Directory listing</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="ls_003a-List-directory-contents"></a>
<h3 class="section">10.1 <code>ls</code>: List directory contents</h3>

<a name="index-ls"></a>
<a name="index-directory-listing"></a>

<p>The <code>ls</code> program lists information about files (of any type,
including directories).  Options and file arguments can be intermixed
arbitrarily, as usual.
</p>
<p>For non-option command-line arguments that are directories, by default
<code>ls</code> lists the contents of directories, not recursively, and
omitting files with names beginning with &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;.  For other non-option
arguments, by default <code>ls</code> lists just the file name.  If no
non-option argument is specified, <code>ls</code> operates on the current
directory, acting as if it had been invoked with a single argument of &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<a name="index-LC_005fALL-1"></a>
<p>By default, the output is sorted alphabetically, according to the locale
settings in effect.<a name="DOCF4" href="#FOOT4"><sup>4</sup></a>
If standard output is
a terminal, the output is in columns (sorted vertically) and control
characters are output as question marks; otherwise, the output is listed
one per line and control characters are output as-is.
</p>
<p>Because <code>ls</code> is such a fundamental program, it has accumulated many
options over the years.  They are described in the subsections below;
within each section, options are listed alphabetically (ignoring case).
The division of options into the subsections is not absolute, since some
options affect more than one aspect of <code>ls</code>&rsquo;s operation.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-ls"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 success
1 minor problems  (e.g., failure to access a file or directory not
  specified as a command line argument.  This happens when listing a
  directory in which entries are actively being removed or renamed.)
2 serious trouble (e.g., memory exhausted, invalid option, failure
  to access a file or directory specified as a command line argument
  or a directory loop)
</pre></div>

<p>Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>

<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#What-information-is-listed" accesskey="2">What information is listed</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">
</td></tr>

</td></tr>
