<a name="Which-files-are-listed"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#What-information-is-listed" accesskey="n" rel="next">What information is listed</a>, Up: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ls invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Which-files-are-listed-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">10.1.1 Which files are listed</h4>

<p>These options determine which files <code>ls</code> lists information for.
By default, <code>ls</code> lists files and the contents of any
directories on the command line, except that in directories it ignores
files whose names start with &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall-1"></a>
<p>In directories, do not ignore file names that start with &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-A</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--almost-all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dA-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dalmost_002dall"></a>
<p>In directories, do not ignore all file names that start with &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;;
ignore only <samp>.</samp> and <samp>..</samp>.  The <samp>--all</samp> (<samp>-a</samp>)
option overrides this option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-B</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-backups</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dB"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dbackups"></a>
<a name="index-backup-files_002c-ignoring"></a>
<p>In directories, ignore files that end with &lsquo;<samp>~</samp>&rsquo;.  This option is
equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>--ignore='*~' --ignore='.*~'</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddirectory"></a>
<p>List just the names of directories, as with other types of files, rather
than listing their contents.
Do not follow symbolic links listed on the
command line unless the <samp>--dereference-command-line</samp> (<samp>-H</samp>),
<samp>--dereference</samp> (<samp>-L</samp>), or
<samp>--dereference-command-line-symlink-to-dir</samp> options are specified.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference-command-line</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddereference_002dcommand_002dline"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing"></a>
<p>If a command line argument specifies a symbolic link, show information
for the file the link references rather than for the link itself.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference-command-line-symlink-to-dir</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002ddereference_002dcommand_002dline_002dsymlink_002dto_002ddir"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-1"></a>
<p>Do not dereference symbolic links, with one exception:
if a command line argument specifies a symbolic link that refers to
a directory, show information for that directory rather than for the
link itself.
This is the default behavior when no other dereferencing-related
option has been specified (<samp>--classify</samp> (<samp>-F</samp>),
<samp>--directory</samp> (<samp>-d</samp>),
(<samp>-l</samp>),
<samp>--dereference</samp> (<samp>-L</samp>), or
<samp>--dereference-command-line</samp> (<samp>-H</samp>)).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--group-directories-first</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dgroup_002ddirectories_002dfirst"></a>
<p>Group all the directories before the files and then sort the
directories and the files separately using the selected sort key
(see &ndash;sort option).
That is, this option specifies a primary sort key,
and the &ndash;sort option specifies a secondary key.
However, any use of <samp>--sort=none</samp>
(<samp>-U</samp>) disables this option altogether.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--hide=PATTERN</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dhide_003dpattern"></a>
<p>In directories, ignore files whose names match the shell pattern
<var>pattern</var>, unless the <samp>--all</samp> (<samp>-a</samp>) or
<samp>--almost-all</samp> (<samp>-A</samp>) is also given.  This
option acts like <samp>--ignore=<var>pattern</var></samp> except that it has no
effect if <samp>--all</samp> (<samp>-a</samp>) or <samp>--almost-all</samp>
(<samp>-A</samp>) is also given.
</p>
<p>This option can be useful in shell aliases.  For example, if
<code>lx</code> is an alias for &lsquo;<samp>ls --hide='*~'</samp>&rsquo; and <code>ly</code> is
an alias for &lsquo;<samp>ls --ignore='*~'</samp>&rsquo;, then the command &lsquo;<samp>lx -A</samp>&rsquo;
lists the file <samp>README~</samp> even though &lsquo;<samp>ly -A</samp>&rsquo; would not.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-I <var>pattern</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore=<var>pattern</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dI"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_003dpattern"></a>
<p>In directories, ignore files whose names match the shell pattern
(not regular expression) <var>pattern</var>.  As
in the shell, an initial &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; in a file name does not match a
wildcard at the start of <var>pattern</var>.  Sometimes it is useful
to give this option several times.  For example,
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ ls --ignore='.??*' --ignore='.[^.]' --ignore='#*'
</pre></div>

<p>The first option ignores names of length 3 or more that start with &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;,
the second ignores all two-character names that start with &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;
except &lsquo;<samp>..</samp>&rsquo;, and the third ignores names that start with &lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddereference"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-2"></a>
<p>When showing file information for a symbolic link, show information
for the file the link references rather than the link itself.
However, even with this option, <code>ls</code> still prints the name
of the link itself, not the name of the file that the link points to.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--recursive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drecursive"></a>
<a name="index-recursive-directory-listing"></a>
<a name="index-directory-listing_002c-recursive"></a>
<p>List the contents of all directories recursively.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="What-information-is-listed"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Sorting-the-output" accesskey="n" rel="next">Sorting the output</a>, Previous: <a href="#Which-files-are-listed" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Which files are listed</a>, Up: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ls invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="What-information-is-listed-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">10.1.2 What information is listed</h4>

<p>These options affect the information that <code>ls</code> displays.  By
default, only file names are shown.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--author</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dauthor"></a>
<a name="index-hurd_002c-author_002c-printing"></a>
<p>List each file&rsquo;s author when producing long format directory listings.
In GNU/Hurd, file authors can differ from their owners, but in other
operating systems the two are the same.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-D</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dired</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dD-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddired"></a>
<a name="index-dired-Emacs-mode-support"></a>
<p>With the long listing (<samp>-l</samp>) format, print an additional line after
the main output:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">//DIRED// <var>beg1</var> <var>end1</var> <var>beg2</var> <var>end2</var> &hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The <var>begn</var> and <var>endn</var> are unsigned integers that record the
byte position of the beginning and end of each file name in the output.
This makes it easy for Emacs to find the names, even when they contain
unusual characters such as space or newline, without fancy searching.
</p>
<p>If directories are being listed recursively (<samp>-R</samp>), output a similar
line with offsets for each subdirectory name:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">//SUBDIRED// <var>beg1</var> <var>end1</var> &hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>Finally, output a line of the form:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">//DIRED-OPTIONS// --quoting-style=<var>word</var>
</pre></div>

<p>where <var>word</var> is the quoting style (see <a href="#Formatting-the-file-names">Formatting the file names</a>).
</p>
<p>Here is an actual example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ mkdir -p a/sub/deeper a/sub2
$ touch a/f1 a/f2
$ touch a/sub/deeper/file
$ ls -gloRF --dired a
  a:
  total 8
  -rw-r--r-- 1    0 Jun 10 12:27 f1
  -rw-r--r-- 1    0 Jun 10 12:27 f2
  drwxr-xr-x 3 4096 Jun 10 12:27 sub/
  drwxr-xr-x 2 4096 Jun 10 12:27 sub2/

  a/sub:
  total 4
  drwxr-xr-x 2 4096 Jun 10 12:27 deeper/

  a/sub/deeper:
  total 0
  -rw-r--r-- 1 0 Jun 10 12:27 file

  a/sub2:
  total 0
//DIRED// 48 50 84 86 120 123 158 162 217 223 282 286
//SUBDIRED// 2 3 167 172 228 240 290 296
//DIRED-OPTIONS// --quoting-style=literal
</pre></div>

<p>Note that the pairs of offsets on the &lsquo;<samp>//DIRED//</samp>&rsquo; line above delimit
these names: <samp>f1</samp>, <samp>f2</samp>, <samp>sub</samp>, <samp>sub2</samp>, <samp>deeper</samp>,
<samp>file</samp>.
The offsets on the &lsquo;<samp>//SUBDIRED//</samp>&rsquo; line delimit the following
directory names: <samp>a</samp>, <samp>a/sub</samp>, <samp>a/sub/deeper</samp>, <samp>a/sub2</samp>.
</p>
<p>Here is an example of how to extract the fifth entry name, &lsquo;<samp>deeper</samp>&rsquo;,
corresponding to the pair of offsets, 222 and 228:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ ls -gloRF --dired a &gt; out
$ dd bs=1 skip=222 count=6 &lt; out 2&gt;/dev/null; echo
deeper
</pre></div>

<p>Note that although the listing above includes a trailing slash
for the &lsquo;<samp>deeper</samp>&rsquo; entry, the offsets select the name without
the trailing slash.  However, if you invoke <code>ls</code> with <samp>--dired</samp>
along with an option like <samp>--escape</samp> (aka <samp>-b</samp>) and operate
on a file whose name contains special characters, notice that the backslash
<em>is</em> included:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ touch 'a b'
$ ls -blog --dired 'a b'
  -rw-r--r-- 1 0 Jun 10 12:28 a\ b
//DIRED// 30 34
//DIRED-OPTIONS// --quoting-style=escape
</pre></div>

<p>If you use a quoting style that adds quote marks
(e.g., <samp>--quoting-style=c</samp>), then the offsets include the quote marks.
So beware that the user may select the quoting style via the environment
variable <code>QUOTING_STYLE</code>.  Hence, applications using <samp>--dired</samp>
should either specify an explicit <samp>--quoting-style=literal</samp> option
(aka <samp>-N</samp> or <samp>--literal</samp>) on the command line, or else be
prepared to parse the escaped names.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--full-time</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfull_002dtime"></a>
<p>Produce long format directory listings, and list times in full.  It is
equivalent to using <samp>--format=long</samp> with
<samp>--time-style=full-iso</samp> (see <a href="#Formatting-file-timestamps">Formatting file timestamps</a>).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg-3"></a>
<p>Produce long format directory listings, but don&rsquo;t display owner information.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-G</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-group</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dG"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dgroup"></a>
<p>Inhibit display of group information in a long format directory listing.
(This is the default in some non-GNU versions of <code>ls</code>, so we
provide this option for compatibility.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--human-readable</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhuman_002dreadable-1"></a>
<a name="index-human_002dreadable-output-1"></a>
<p>Append a size letter to each size, such as &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; for mebibytes.
Powers of 1024 are used, not 1000; &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; stands for 1,048,576 bytes.
This option is equivalent to <samp>--block-size=human-readable</samp>.
Use the <samp>--si</samp> option if you prefer powers of 1000.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--inode</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinode"></a>
<a name="index-inode-number_002c-printing"></a>
<p>Print the inode number (also called the file serial number and index
number) of each file to the left of the file name.  (This number
uniquely identifies each file within a particular file system.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=long</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat-1"></a>
<a name="index-long-ls-format"></a>
<a name="index-verbose-ls-format"></a>
<p>In addition to the name of each file, print the file type, file mode bits,
number of hard links, owner name, group name, size, and
timestamp (see <a href="#Formatting-file-timestamps">Formatting file timestamps</a>), normally
the modification timestamp (the mtime, see <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>).
Print question marks for information that
cannot be determined.
</p>
<p>Normally the size is printed as a byte count without punctuation, but
this can be overridden (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).  For example, <samp>-h</samp>
prints an abbreviated, human-readable count, and
&lsquo;<samp>--block-size=&quot;'1&quot;</samp>&rsquo; prints a byte count with the thousands
separator of the current locale.
</p>
<p>For each directory that is listed, preface the files with a line
&lsquo;<samp>total <var>blocks</var></samp>&rsquo;, where <var>blocks</var> is the total disk allocation
for all files in that directory.  The block size currently defaults to 1024
bytes, but this can be overridden (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
The <var>blocks</var> computed counts each hard link separately;
this is arguably a deficiency.
</p>
<p>The file type is one of the following characters:
</p>

<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>regular file
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>block special file
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>character special file
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>C</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>high performance (&ldquo;contiguous data&rdquo;) file
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>directory
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>D</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>door (Solaris 2.5 and up)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>symbolic link
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>off-line (&ldquo;migrated&rdquo;) file (Cray DMF)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>network special file (HP-UX)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>FIFO (named pipe)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>port (Solaris 10 and up)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>socket
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>?</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>some other file type
</p></dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-permissions_002c-output-by-ls"></a>
<p>The file mode bits listed are similar to symbolic mode specifications
(see <a href="#Symbolic-Modes">Symbolic Modes</a>).  But <code>ls</code> combines multiple bits into the
third character of each set of permissions as follows:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>If the set-user-ID or set-group-ID bit and the corresponding executable bit
are both set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>S</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>If the set-user-ID or set-group-ID bit is set but the corresponding
executable bit is not set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>If the restricted deletion flag or sticky bit, and the
other-executable bit, are both set.  The restricted deletion flag is
another name for the sticky bit.  See <a href="#Mode-Structure">Mode Structure</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>If the restricted deletion flag or sticky bit is set but the
other-executable bit is not set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>If the executable bit is set and none of the above apply.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Otherwise.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Following the file mode bits is a single character that specifies
whether an alternate access method such as an access control list
applies to the file.  When the character following the file mode bits is a
space, there is no alternate access method.  When it is a printing
character, then there is such a method.
</p>
<p>GNU <code>ls</code> uses a &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; character to indicate a file
with a security context, but no other alternate access method.
</p>
<p>A file with any other combination of alternate access methods
is marked with a &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; character.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--numeric-uid-gid</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnumeric_002duid_002dgid"></a>
<a name="index-numeric-uid-and-gid"></a>
<a name="index-numeric-user-and-group-IDs"></a>
<p>Produce long format directory listings, but
display numeric user and group IDs instead of the owner and group names.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-5"></a>
<p>Produce long format directory listings, but don&rsquo;t display group information.
It is equivalent to using <samp>--format=long</samp> with <samp>--no-group</samp> .
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--size</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsize"></a>
<a name="index-disk-allocation"></a>
<a name="index-size-of-files_002c-reporting"></a>
<p>Print the disk allocation of each file to the left of the file name.
This is the amount of disk space used by the file, which is usually a
bit more than the file&rsquo;s size, but it can be less if the file has holes.
</p>
<p>Normally the disk allocation is printed in units of
1024 bytes, but this can be overridden (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
</p>
<a name="index-NFS-mounts-from-BSD-to-HP_002dUX"></a>
<p>For files that are NFS-mounted from an HP-UX system to a BSD system,
this option reports sizes that are half the correct values.  On HP-UX
systems, it reports sizes that are twice the correct values for files
that are NFS-mounted from BSD systems.  This is due to a flaw in HP-UX;
it also affects the HP-UX <code>ls</code> program.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--si</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsi-1"></a>
<a name="index-SI-output-1"></a>
<p>Append an SI-style abbreviation to each size, such as &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; for
megabytes.  Powers of 1000 are used, not 1024; &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; stands for
1,000,000 bytes.  This option is equivalent to
<samp>--block-size=si</samp>.  Use the <samp>-h</samp> or
<samp>--human-readable</samp> option if
you prefer powers of 1024.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux"></a>
<a name="index-security-context"></a>
<p>Display the SELinux security context or &lsquo;<samp>?</samp>&rsquo; if none is found.
When used with the <samp>-l</samp> option, print the security context
to the left of the size column.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Sorting-the-output"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Details-about-version-sort" accesskey="n" rel="next">Details about version sort</a>, Previous: <a href="#What-information-is-listed" accesskey="p" rel="prev">What information is listed</a>, Up: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ls invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Sorting-the-output-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">10.1.3 Sorting the output</h4>

<a name="index-sorting-ls-output"></a>
<p>These options change the order in which <code>ls</code> sorts the information
it outputs.  By default, sorting is done by character code
(e.g., ASCII order).
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=ctime</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=status</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtime"></a>
<a name="index-ctime_002c-printing-or-sorting-by"></a>
<a name="index-status-time_002c-printing-or-sorting-by"></a>
<a name="index-use-time_002c-printing-or-sorting-files-by"></a>
<p>If the long listing format (e.g., <samp>-l</samp>, <samp>-o</samp>) is being used,
print the status change timestamp (the ctime) instead of the mtime.
When explicitly sorting by time (<samp>--sort=time</samp> or <samp>-t</samp>)
or when not using a long listing format,
sort according to the ctime.  See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-9"></a>
<a name="index-unsorted-directory-listing"></a>
<a name="index-directory-order_002c-listing-by"></a>
<p>Primarily, like <samp>-U</samp>&mdash;do not sort; list the files in whatever
order they are stored in the directory.  But also enable <samp>-a</samp> (list
all files) and disable <samp>-l</samp>, <samp>--color</samp>, and <samp>-s</samp> (if they
were specified before the <samp>-f</samp>).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reverse</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dreverse-1"></a>
<a name="index-reverse-sorting-1"></a>
<p>Reverse whatever the sorting method is&mdash;e.g., list files in reverse
alphabetical order, youngest first, smallest first, or whatever.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=size</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-5"></a>
<a name="index-size-of-files_002c-sorting-files-by"></a>
<p>Sort by file size, largest first.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=time</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-6"></a>
<a name="index-modification-timestamp_002c-sorting-files-by"></a>
<p>Sort by modification timestamp (mtime), newest first.
See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=atime</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=access</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=use</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtime-1"></a>
<a name="index-use-time_002c-printing-or-sorting-files-by-1"></a>
<a name="index-atime_002c-printing-or-sorting-files-by"></a>
<a name="index-access-timestamp_002c-printing-or-sorting-files-by"></a>
<p>If the long listing format (e.g., <samp>--format=long</samp>) is being used,
print the last access timestamp (the atime).
When explicitly sorting by time (<samp>--sort=time</samp> or <samp>-t</samp>)
or when not using a long listing format, sort according to the atime.
See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-U</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=none</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dU"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-7"></a>
<a name="index-none_002c-sorting-option-for-ls"></a>
<p>Do not sort; list the files in whatever order they are
stored in the directory.  (Do not do any of the other unrelated things
that <samp>-f</samp> does.)  This is especially useful when listing very large
directories, since not doing any sorting can be noticeably faster.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=version</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-8"></a>
<a name="index-version_002c-sorting-option-for-ls"></a>
<p>Sort by version name and number, lowest first.  It behaves like a default
sort, except that each sequence of decimal digits is treated numerically
as an index/version number.  (See <a href="#Details-about-version-sort">Details about version sort</a>.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-X</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sort=extension</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dX"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsort-9"></a>
<a name="index-extension_002c-sorting-files-by"></a>
<p>Sort directory contents alphabetically by file extension (characters
after the last &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;); files with no extension are sorted first.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Details-about-version-sort"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#General-output-formatting" accesskey="n" rel="next">General output formatting</a>, Previous: <a href="#Sorting-the-output" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Sorting the output</a>, Up: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ls invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Details-about-version-sort-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">10.1.4 Details about version sort</h4>

<p>Version sorting handles the fact that file names frequently include indices or
version numbers.  Standard sorting usually does not produce the order that one
expects because comparisons are made on a character-by-character basis.
Version sorting is especially useful when browsing directories that contain
many files with indices/version numbers in their names:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ ls -1            $ ls -1v
abc.zml-1.gz       abc.zml-1.gz
abc.zml-12.gz      abc.zml-2.gz
abc.zml-2.gz       abc.zml-12.gz
</pre></div>

<p>Version-sorted strings are compared such that if <var>ver1</var> and <var>ver2</var>
are version numbers and <var>prefix</var> and <var>suffix</var> (<var>suffix</var> matching
the regular expression &lsquo;<samp>(\.[A-Za-z~][A-Za-z0-9~]*)*</samp>&rsquo;) are strings then
<var>ver1</var> &lt; <var>ver2</var> implies that the name composed of
&ldquo;<var>prefix</var> <var>ver1</var> <var>suffix</var>&rdquo; sorts before
&ldquo;<var>prefix</var> <var>ver2</var> <var>suffix</var>&rdquo;.
</p>
<p>Note also that leading zeros of numeric parts are ignored:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ ls -1            $ ls -1v
abc-1.007.tgz      abc-1.01a.tgz
abc-1.012b.tgz     abc-1.007.tgz
abc-1.01a.tgz      abc-1.012b.tgz
</pre></div>

<p>This functionality is implemented using gnulib&rsquo;s <code>filevercmp</code> function,
which has some caveats worth noting.
</p>
<ul>
<li> <code>LC_COLLATE</code> is ignored, which means &lsquo;<samp>ls -v</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>sort -V</samp>&rsquo;
will sort non-numeric prefixes as if the <code>LC_COLLATE</code> locale category
was set to &lsquo;<samp>C</samp>&rsquo;.
</li><li> Some suffixes will not be matched by the regular
expression mentioned above.  Consequently these examples may
not sort as you expect:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">abc-1.2.3.4.7z
abc-1.2.3.7z
</pre></div>

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">abc-1.2.3.4.x86_64.rpm
abc-1.2.3.x86_64.rpm
</pre></div>
</li></ul>

<hr>
<a name="General-output-formatting"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Formatting-file-timestamps" accesskey="n" rel="next">Formatting file timestamps</a>, Previous: <a href="#Details-about-version-sort" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Details about version sort</a>, Up: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ls invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="General-output-formatting-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">10.1.5 General output formatting</h4>

<p>These options affect the appearance of the overall output.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=single-column</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d1-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat-2"></a>
<a name="index-single_002dcolumn-output-of-files"></a>
<p>List one file per line.  This is the default for <code>ls</code> when standard
output is not a terminal.  See also the <samp>-b</samp> and <samp>-q</samp> options
to suppress direct output of newline characters within a file name.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-C</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=vertical</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dC-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat-3"></a>
<a name="index-vertical-sorted-files-in-columns"></a>
<p>List files in columns, sorted vertically.  This is the default for
<code>ls</code> if standard output is a terminal.  It is always the default
for the <code>dir</code> program.
GNU <code>ls</code> uses variable width columns to display as many files as
possible in the fewest lines.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--color [=<var>when</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dcolor"></a>
<a name="index-color_002c-distinguishing-file-types-with"></a>
<p>Specify whether to use color for distinguishing file types.  <var>when</var>
may be omitted, or one of:
</p><ul>
<li> none
<a name="index-none-color-option"></a>
- Do not use color at all.  This is the default.
</li><li> auto
<a name="index-auto-color-option"></a>
<a name="index-terminal_002c-using-color-iff"></a>
- Only use color if standard output is a terminal.
</li><li> always
<a name="index-always-color-option"></a>
- Always use color.
</li></ul>
<p>Specifying <samp>--color</samp> and no <var>when</var> is equivalent to
<samp>--color=always</samp>.
If piping a colorized listing through a pager like <code>less</code>,
use the <samp>-R</samp> option to pass the color codes to the terminal.
</p>
<a name="index-LS_005fCOLORS"></a>
<a name="index-SHELL-environment-variable_002c-and-color"></a>
<p>Note that using the <samp>--color</samp> option may incur a noticeable
performance penalty when run in a directory with very many entries,
because the default settings require that <code>ls</code> <code>stat</code> every
single file it lists.
However, if you would like most of the file-type coloring
but can live without the other coloring options (e.g.,
executable, orphan, sticky, other-writable, capability), use
<code>dircolors</code> to set the <code>LS_COLORS</code> environment variable like this,
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">eval $(dircolors -p | perl -pe \
  's/^((CAP|S[ET]|O[TR]|M|E)\w+).*/$1 00/' | dircolors -)
</pre></div>
<p>and on a <code>dirent.d_type</code>-capable file system, <code>ls</code>
will perform only one <code>stat</code> call per command line argument.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-F</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--classify</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--indicator-style=classify</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dF-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dclassify"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dindicator_002dstyle"></a>
<a name="index-file-type-and-executables_002c-marking"></a>
<a name="index-executables-and-file-type_002c-marking"></a>
<p>Append a character to each file name indicating the file type.  Also,
for regular files that are executable, append &lsquo;<samp>*</samp>&rsquo;.  The file type
indicators are &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; for directories, &lsquo;<samp>@</samp>&rsquo; for symbolic links,
&lsquo;<samp>|</samp>&rsquo; for FIFOs, &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; for sockets, &lsquo;<samp>&gt;</samp>&rsquo; for doors,
and nothing for regular files.
Do not follow symbolic links listed on the
command line unless the <samp>--dereference-command-line</samp> (<samp>-H</samp>),
<samp>--dereference</samp> (<samp>-L</samp>), or
<samp>--dereference-command-line-symlink-to-dir</samp> options are specified.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--file-type</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--indicator-style=file-type</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfile_002dtype"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dindicator_002dstyle-1"></a>
<a name="index-file-type_002c-marking"></a>
<p>Append a character to each file name indicating the file type.  This is
like <samp>-F</samp>, except that executables are not marked.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--hyperlink [=<var>when</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dhyperlink"></a>
<a name="index-hyperlink_002c-linking-to-files"></a>
<p>Output codes recognized by some terminals to link
to files using the &lsquo;<samp>file://</samp>&rsquo; URI format.
<var>when</var> may be omitted, or one of:
</p><ul>
<li> none
<a name="index-none-hyperlink-option"></a>
- Do not use hyperlinks at all.  This is the default.
</li><li> auto
<a name="index-auto-hyperlink-option"></a>
<a name="index-terminal_002c-using-hyperlink-iff"></a>
- Only use hyperlinks if standard output is a terminal.
</li><li> always
<a name="index-always-hyperlink-option"></a>
- Always use hyperlinks.
</li></ul>
<p>Specifying <samp>--hyperlink</samp> and no <var>when</var> is equivalent to
<samp>--hyperlink=always</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--indicator-style=<var>word</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dindicator_002dstyle-2"></a>
<p>Append a character indicator with style <var>word</var> to entry names,
as follows:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>none</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Do not append any character indicator; this is the default.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>slash</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Append &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; for directories.  This is the same as the <samp>-p</samp>
option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>file-type</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Append &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; for directories, &lsquo;<samp>@</samp>&rsquo; for symbolic links, &lsquo;<samp>|</samp>&rsquo;
for FIFOs, &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; for sockets, and nothing for regular files.  This is
the same as the <samp>--file-type</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>classify</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Append &lsquo;<samp>*</samp>&rsquo; for executable regular files, otherwise behave as for
&lsquo;<samp>file-type</samp>&rsquo;.  This is the same as the <samp>-F</samp> or
<samp>--classify</samp> option.
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-k</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--kibibytes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dk-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dkibibytes"></a>
<p>Set the default block size to its normal value of 1024 bytes,
overriding any contrary specification in environment variables
(see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).  This option is in turn overridden by the
<samp>--block-size</samp>, <samp>-h</samp> or <samp>--human-readable</samp>, and
<samp>--si</samp> options.
</p>
<p>The <samp>-k</samp> or <samp>--kibibytes</samp> option affects the
per-directory block count written by the <samp>-l</samp> and similar
options, and the size written by the <samp>-s</samp> or <samp>--size</samp>
option.  It does not affect the file size written by <samp>-l</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=commas</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat-4"></a>
<a name="index-commas_002c-outputting-between-files"></a>
<p>List files horizontally, with as many as will fit on each line,
separated by &lsquo;<samp>, </samp>&rsquo; (a comma and a space).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--indicator-style=slash</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dindicator_002dstyle-3"></a>
<a name="index-file-type_002c-marking-1"></a>
<p>Append a &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; to directory names.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=across</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=horizontal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat-5"></a>
<a name="index-across_002c-listing-files"></a>
<a name="index-horizontal_002c-listing-files"></a>
<p>List the files in columns, sorted horizontally.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T <var>cols</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--tabsize=<var>cols</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtabsize"></a>
<p>Assume that each tab stop is <var>cols</var> columns wide.  The default is 8.
<code>ls</code> uses tabs where possible in the output, for efficiency.  If
<var>cols</var> is zero, do not use tabs at all.
</p>
<p>Some terminal emulators might not properly align columns to the right of a
TAB following a non-ASCII byte.  You can avoid that issue by using the
<samp>-T0</samp> option or put <code>TABSIZE=0</code> in your environment, to tell
<code>ls</code> to align using spaces, not tabs.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>cols</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--width=<var>cols</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwidth-5"></a>
<a name="index-COLUMNS"></a>
<p>Assume the screen is <var>cols</var> columns wide.  The default is taken
from the terminal settings if possible; otherwise the environment
variable <code>COLUMNS</code> is used if it is set; otherwise the default
is 80.  With a <var>cols</var> value of &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;, there is no limit on
the length of the output line, and that single output line will
be delimited with spaces, not tabs.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Formatting-file-timestamps"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Formatting-the-file-names" accesskey="n" rel="next">Formatting the file names</a>, Previous: <a href="#General-output-formatting" accesskey="p" rel="prev">General output formatting</a>, Up: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ls invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Formatting-file-timestamps-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">10.1.6 Formatting file timestamps</h4>

<p>By default, file timestamps are listed in abbreviated form, using
a date like &lsquo;<samp>Mar 30&nbsp;&nbsp;2002</samp>&rsquo; for non-recent timestamps, and a
date-without-year and time like &lsquo;<samp>Mar 30 23:45</samp>&rsquo; for recent timestamps.
This format can change depending on the current locale as detailed below.
</p>
<a name="index-clock-skew"></a>
<p>A timestamp is considered to be <em>recent</em> if it is less than six
months old, and is not dated in the future.  If a timestamp dated
today is not listed in recent form, the timestamp is in the future,
which means you probably have clock skew problems which may break
programs like <code>make</code> that rely on file timestamps.
See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
<a name="index-TZ-1"></a>
<p>Timestamps are listed according to the time zone rules specified by
the <code>TZ</code> environment variable, or by the system default rules if
<code>TZ</code> is not set.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable">Specifying the Time Zone
with <code>TZ</code></a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
</p>
<p>The following option changes how file timestamps are printed.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time-style=<var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtime_002dstyle"></a>
<a name="index-time-style"></a>
<p>List timestamps in style <var>style</var>.  The <var>style</var> should
be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>+<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-LC_005fTIME-2"></a>
<p>List timestamps using <var>format</var>, where <var>format</var> is interpreted
like the format argument of <code>date</code> (see <a href="#date-invocation">date invocation</a>).
For example, <samp>--time-style=&quot;+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S&quot;</samp> causes
<code>ls</code> to list timestamps like &lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30 23:45:56</samp>&rsquo;.  As
with <code>date</code>, <var>format</var>&rsquo;s interpretation is affected by the
<code>LC_TIME</code> locale category.
</p>
<p>If <var>format</var> contains two format strings separated by a newline,
the former is used for non-recent files and the latter for recent
files; if you want output columns to line up, you may need to insert
spaces in one of the two formats.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>full-iso</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>List timestamps in full using ISO 8601-like date, time, and time zone
components with nanosecond precision, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30
23:45:56.477817180 -0700</samp>&rsquo;.  This style is equivalent to
&lsquo;<samp>+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%N %z</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>This is useful because the time output includes all the information that
is available from the operating system.  For example, this can help
explain <code>make</code>&rsquo;s behavior, since GNU <code>make</code>
uses the full timestamp to determine whether a file is out of date.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>long-iso</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>List ISO 8601 date and time components with minute precision, e.g.,
&lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30 23:45</samp>&rsquo;.  These timestamps are shorter than
&lsquo;<samp>full-iso</samp>&rsquo; timestamps, and are usually good enough for everyday
work.  This style is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iso</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>List ISO 8601 dates for non-recent timestamps (e.g.,
&lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30&nbsp;</samp>&rsquo;), and ISO 8601-like month, day, hour, and
minute for recent timestamps (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>03-30 23:45</samp>&rsquo;).  These
timestamps are uglier than &lsquo;<samp>long-iso</samp>&rsquo; timestamps, but they carry
nearly the same information in a smaller space and their brevity helps
<code>ls</code> output fit within traditional 80-column output lines.
The following two <code>ls</code> invocations are equivalent:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">newline='
'
ls -l --time-style=&quot;+%Y-%m-%d $newline%m-%d %H:%M&quot;
ls -l --time-style=&quot;iso&quot;
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>locale</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-LC_005fTIME-3"></a>
<p>List timestamps in a locale-dependent form.  For example, a Finnish
locale might list non-recent timestamps like &lsquo;<samp>maalis 30&nbsp;&nbsp;2002</samp>&rsquo;
and recent timestamps like &lsquo;<samp>maalis 30 23:45</samp>&rsquo;.  Locale-dependent
timestamps typically consume more space than &lsquo;<samp>iso</samp>&rsquo; timestamps and
are harder for programs to parse because locale conventions vary so
widely, but they are easier for many people to read.
</p>
<p>The <code>LC_TIME</code> locale category specifies the timestamp format.  The
default POSIX locale uses timestamps like &lsquo;<samp>Mar 30&nbsp;&nbsp;2002</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>Mar 30 23:45</samp>&rsquo;; in this locale, the following two
<code>ls</code> invocations are equivalent:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">newline='
'
ls -l --time-style=&quot;+%b %e  %Y$newline%b %e %H:%M&quot;
ls -l --time-style=&quot;locale&quot;
</pre></div>

<p>Other locales behave differently.  For example, in a German locale,
<samp>--time-style=&quot;locale&quot;</samp> might be equivalent to
<samp>--time-style=&quot;+%e. %b %Y $newline%e. %b %H:%M&quot;</samp>
and might generate timestamps like &lsquo;<samp>30. M&auml;r 2002&nbsp;</samp>&rsquo; and
&lsquo;<samp>30. M&auml;r 23:45</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>posix-<var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-LC_005fTIME-4"></a>
<p>List POSIX-locale timestamps if the <code>LC_TIME</code> locale
category is POSIX, <var>style</var> timestamps otherwise.  For
example, the &lsquo;<samp>posix-long-iso</samp>&rsquo; style lists
timestamps like &lsquo;<samp>Mar 30&nbsp;&nbsp;2002</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>Mar 30 23:45</samp>&rsquo; when in
the POSIX locale, and like &lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30 23:45</samp>&rsquo; otherwise.
</p></dd>
</dl>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-TIME_005fSTYLE"></a>
<p>You can specify the default value of the <samp>--time-style</samp> option
with the environment variable <code>TIME_STYLE</code>; if <code>TIME_STYLE</code> is not set
the default style is &lsquo;<samp>locale</samp>&rsquo;.  GNU Emacs 21.3 and
later use the <samp>--dired</samp> option and therefore can parse any date
format, but if you are using Emacs 21.1 or 21.2 and specify a
non-POSIX locale you may need to set
&lsquo;<samp>TIME_STYLE=&quot;posix-long-iso&quot;</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>To avoid certain denial-of-service attacks, timestamps that would be
longer than 1000 bytes may be treated as errors.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Formatting-the-file-names"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Formatting-file-timestamps" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Formatting file timestamps</a>, Up: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">ls invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Formatting-the-file-names-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">10.1.7 Formatting the file names</h4>

<p>These options change how file names themselves are printed.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--escape</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quoting-style=escape</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002descape"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquoting_002dstyle"></a>
<a name="index-backslash-sequences-for-file-names"></a>
<p>Quote nongraphic characters in file names using alphabetic and octal
backslash sequences like those used in C.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-N</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--literal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quoting-style=literal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dN-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dliteral"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquoting_002dstyle-1"></a>
<p>Do not quote file names.  However, with <code>ls</code> nongraphic
characters are still printed as question marks if the output is a
terminal and you do not specify the <samp>--show-control-chars</samp>
option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--hide-control-chars</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dq-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhide_002dcontrol_002dchars"></a>
<p>Print question marks instead of nongraphic characters in file names.
This is the default if the output is a terminal and the program is
<code>ls</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quote-name</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quoting-style=c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dQ"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquote_002dname"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquoting_002dstyle-2"></a>
<p>Enclose file names in double quotes and quote nongraphic characters as
in C.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quoting-style=<var>word</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dquoting_002dstyle-3"></a>
<a name="index-quoting-style"></a>
<p>Use style <var>word</var> to quote file names and other strings that may
contain arbitrary characters.  The <var>word</var> should
be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>literal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Output strings as-is; this is the same as the <samp>-N</samp> or
<samp>--literal</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings for the shell if they contain shell metacharacters or would
cause ambiguous output.
The quoting is suitable for POSIX-compatible shells like
<code>bash</code>, but it does not always work for incompatible shells
like <code>csh</code>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell-always</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings for the shell, even if they would normally not require quoting.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell-escape</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Like &lsquo;<samp>shell</samp>&rsquo;, but also quoting non-printable characters using the POSIX
proposed &lsquo;<samp>$''</samp>&rsquo; syntax suitable for most shells.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell-escape-always</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Like &lsquo;<samp>shell-escape</samp>&rsquo;, but quote strings even if they would
normally not require quoting.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, including the
surrounding double-quote characters; this is the same as the
<samp>-Q</samp> or <samp>--quote-name</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>escape</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, except omit the
surrounding double-quote
characters; this is the same as the <samp>-b</samp> or <samp>--escape</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>clocale</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, except use
surrounding quotation marks appropriate for the
locale.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>locale</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, except use
surrounding quotation marks appropriate for the locale, and quote
<tt>'like this'</tt> instead of <tt>&quot;like
this&quot;</tt> in the default C locale.  This looks nicer on many displays.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>You can specify the default value of the <samp>--quoting-style</samp> option
with the environment variable <code>QUOTING_STYLE</code>.  If that environment
variable is not set, the default value is &lsquo;<samp>shell-escape</samp>&rsquo; when the
output is a terminal, and &lsquo;<samp>literal</samp>&rsquo; otherwise.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--show-control-chars</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dshow_002dcontrol_002dchars-1"></a>
<p>Print nongraphic characters as-is in file names.
This is the default unless the output is a terminal and the program is
<code>ls</code>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="dir-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#vdir-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">vdir invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#ls-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">ls invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Directory-listing" accesskey="u" rel="up">Directory listing</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="dir_003a-Briefly-list-directory-contents"></a>
<h3 class="section">10.2 <code>dir</code>: Briefly list directory contents</h3>

<a name="index-dir"></a>
<a name="index-directory-listing_002c-brief"></a>

<p><code>dir</code> is equivalent to <code>ls -C
-b</code>; that is, by default files are listed in columns, sorted vertically,
and special characters are represented by backslash escape sequences.
</p>
<p>See <a href="#ls-invocation"><code>ls</code></a>.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="vdir-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#dircolors-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">dircolors invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#dir-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">dir invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Directory-listing" accesskey="u" rel="up">Directory listing</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="vdir_003a-Verbosely-list-directory-contents"></a>
<h3 class="section">10.3 <code>vdir</code>: Verbosely list directory contents</h3>

<a name="index-vdir"></a>
<a name="index-directory-listing_002c-verbose"></a>

<p><code>vdir</code> is equivalent to <code>ls -l
-b</code>; that is, by default files are listed in long format and special
characters are represented by backslash escape sequences.
</p>
<p>See <a href="#ls-invocation"><code>ls</code></a>.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="dircolors-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#vdir-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">vdir invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Directory-listing" accesskey="u" rel="up">Directory listing</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="dircolors_003a-Color-setup-for-ls"></a>
<h3 class="section">10.4 <code>dircolors</code>: Color setup for <code>ls</code></h3>

<a name="index-dircolors"></a>
<a name="index-color-setup"></a>
<a name="index-setup-for-color"></a>

<p><code>dircolors</code> outputs a sequence of shell commands to set up the
terminal for color output from <code>ls</code> (and <code>dir</code>, etc.).
Typical usage:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">eval &quot;$(dircolors [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>])&quot;
</pre></div>

<p>If <var>file</var> is specified, <code>dircolors</code> reads it to determine which
colors to use for which file types and extensions.  Otherwise, a
precompiled database is used.  For details on the format of these files,
run &lsquo;<samp>dircolors --print-database</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>To make <code>dircolors</code> read a <samp>~/.dircolors</samp> file if it
exists, you can put the following lines in your <samp>~/.bashrc</samp> (or
adapt them to your favorite shell):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">d=.dircolors
test -r $d &amp;&amp; eval &quot;$(dircolors $d)&quot;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-LS_005fCOLORS-1"></a>
<a name="index-SHELL-environment-variable_002c-and-color-1"></a>
<p>The output is a shell command to set the <code>LS_COLORS</code> environment
variable.  You can specify the shell syntax to use on the command line,
or <code>dircolors</code> will guess it from the value of the <code>SHELL</code>
environment variable.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sh</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bourne-shell</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsh"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbourne_002dshell"></a>
<a name="index-Bourne-shell-syntax-for-color-setup"></a>
<a name="index-sh-syntax-for-color-setup"></a>
<p>Output Bourne shell commands.  This is the default if the <code>SHELL</code>
environment variable is set and does not end with &lsquo;<samp>csh</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>tcsh</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--csh</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--c-shell</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcsh"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dc_002dshell"></a>
<a name="index-C-shell-syntax-for-color-setup"></a>
<a name="index-csh-syntax-for-color-setup"></a>
<p>Output C shell commands.  This is the default if <code>SHELL</code> ends with
<code>csh</code> or <code>tcsh</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--print-database</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dprint_002ddatabase"></a>
<a name="index-color-database_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-database-for-color-setup_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-printing-color-database"></a>
<p>Print the (compiled-in) default color configuration database.  This
output is itself a valid configuration file, and is fairly descriptive
of the possibilities.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>

<a name="Basic-operations-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">11 Basic operations</h2>

<a name="index-manipulating-files"></a>

<p>This chapter describes the commands for basic file manipulation:
copying, moving (renaming), and deleting (removing).
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#cp-invocation" accesskey="1">cp invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Copy files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#dd-invocation" accesskey="2">dd invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Convert and copy a file.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#install-invocation" accesskey="3">install invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Copy files and set attributes.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#mv-invocation" accesskey="4">mv invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Move (rename) files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#rm-invocation" accesskey="5">rm invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Remove files or directories.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#shred-invocation" accesskey="6">shred invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Remove files more securely.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="cp-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#dd-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">dd invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Basic-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Basic operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="cp_003a-Copy-files-and-directories"></a>
<h3 class="section">11.1 <code>cp</code>: Copy files and directories</h3>

<a name="index-cp"></a>
<a name="index-copying-files-and-directories"></a>
<a name="index-files_002c-copying"></a>
<a name="index-directories_002c-copying"></a>

<p><code>cp</code> copies files (or, optionally, directories).  The copy is
completely independent of the original.  You can either copy one file to
another, or copy arbitrarily many files to a destination directory.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">cp [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [-T] <var>source</var> <var>dest</var>
cp [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>source</var>&hellip; <var>directory</var>
cp [<var>option</var>]&hellip; -t <var>directory</var> <var>source</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<ul>
<li> If two file names are given, <code>cp</code> copies the first file to the
second.

</li><li> If the <samp>--target-directory</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) option is given, or
failing that if the last file is a directory and the
<samp>--no-target-directory</samp> (<samp>-T</samp>) option is not given,
<code>cp</code> copies each <var>source</var> file to the specified directory,
using the <var>source</var>s&rsquo; names.
</li></ul>

<p>Generally, files are written just as they are read.  For exceptions,
see the <samp>--sparse</samp> option below.
</p>
<p>By default, <code>cp</code> does not copy directories.  However, the
<samp>-R</samp>, <samp>-a</samp>, and <samp>-r</samp> options cause <code>cp</code> to
copy recursively by descending into source directories and copying files
to corresponding destination directories.
</p>
<p>When copying from a symbolic link, <code>cp</code> normally follows the
link only when not copying recursively or when <samp>--link</samp>
(<samp>-l</samp>) is used.  This default can be overridden with the
<samp>--archive</samp> (<samp>-a</samp>), <samp>-d</samp>, <samp>--dereference</samp>
(<samp>-L</samp>), <samp>--no-dereference</samp> (<samp>-P</samp>), and
<samp>-H</samp> options.  If more than one of these options is specified,
the last one silently overrides the others.
</p>
<p>When copying to a symbolic link, <code>cp</code> follows the
link only when it refers to an existing regular file.
However, when copying to a dangling symbolic link, <code>cp</code>
refuses by default, and fails with a diagnostic, since the operation
is inherently dangerous.  This behavior is contrary to historical
practice and to POSIX.
Set <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> to make <code>cp</code> attempt to create
the target of a dangling destination symlink, in spite of the possible risk.
Also, when an option like
<samp>--backup</samp> or <samp>--link</samp> acts to rename or remove the
destination before copying, <code>cp</code> renames or removes the
symbolic link rather than the file it points to.
</p>
<p>By default, <code>cp</code> copies the contents of special files only
when not copying recursively.  This default can be overridden with the
<samp>--copy-contents</samp> option.
</p>
<a name="index-self_002dbackups"></a>
<a name="index-backups_002c-making-only"></a>
<p><code>cp</code> generally refuses to copy a file onto itself, with the
following exception: if <samp>--force --backup</samp> is specified with
<var>source</var> and <var>dest</var> identical, and referring to a regular file,
<code>cp</code> will make a backup file, either regular or numbered, as
specified in the usual ways (see <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>).  This is useful when
you simply want to make a backup of an existing file before changing it.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--archive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002darchive"></a>
<p>Preserve as much as possible of the structure and attributes of the
original files in the copy (but do not attempt to preserve internal
directory structure; i.e., &lsquo;<samp>ls -U</samp>&rsquo; may list the entries in a copied
directory in a different order).
Try to preserve SELinux security context and extended attributes (xattr),
but ignore any failure to do that and print no corresponding diagnostic.
Equivalent to <samp>-dR --preserve=all</samp> with the reduced diagnostics.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--attributes-only</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dattributes_002donly"></a>
<p>Copy only the specified attributes of the source file to the destination.
If the destination already exists, do not alter its contents.
See the <samp>--preserve</samp> option for controlling which attributes to copy.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--backup[=<var>method</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbackup-1"></a>
<a name="index-VERSION_005fCONTROL-1"></a>
<a name="index-backups_002c-making-1"></a>
<p>See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
Make a backup of each file that would otherwise be overwritten or removed.
As a special case, <code>cp</code> makes a backup of <var>source</var> when the force
and backup options are given and <var>source</var> and <var>dest</var> are the same
name for an existing, regular file.  One useful application of this
combination of options is this tiny Bourne shell script:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/bin/sh
# Usage: backup FILE...
# Create a GNU-style backup of each listed FILE.
fail=0
for i; do
  cp --backup --force --preserve=all -- &quot;$i&quot; &quot;$i&quot; || fail=1
done
exit $fail
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--copy-contents</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-directories_002c-copying-recursively"></a>
<a name="index-copying-directories-recursively"></a>
<a name="index-recursively-copying-directories"></a>
<a name="index-non_002ddirectories_002c-copying-as-special-files"></a>
<p>If copying recursively, copy the contents of any special files (e.g.,
FIFOs and device files) as if they were regular files.  This means
trying to read the data in each source file and writing it to the
destination.  It is usually a mistake to use this option, as it
normally has undesirable effects on special files like FIFOs and the
ones typically found in the <samp>/dev</samp> directory.  In most cases,
<code>cp -R --copy-contents</code> will hang indefinitely trying to read
from FIFOs and special files like <samp>/dev/console</samp>, and it will
fill up your destination disk if you use it to copy <samp>/dev/zero</samp>.
This option has no effect unless copying recursively, and it does not
affect the copying of symbolic links.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-10"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-copying"></a>
<a name="index-hard-links_002c-preserving"></a>
<p>Copy symbolic links as symbolic links rather than copying the files that
they point to, and preserve hard links between source files in the copies.
Equivalent to <samp>--no-dereference --preserve=links</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--force</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dforce"></a>
<p>When copying without this option and an existing destination file cannot
be opened for writing, the copy fails.  However, with <samp>--force</samp>,
when a destination file cannot be opened, <code>cp</code> then
tries to recreate the file by first removing it.  Note <samp>--force</samp>
alone will not remove dangling symlinks.
When this option is combined with
<samp>--link</samp> (<samp>-l</samp>) or <samp>--symbolic-link</samp>
(<samp>-s</samp>), the destination link is replaced, and unless
<samp>--backup</samp> (<samp>-b</samp>) is also given there is no brief
moment when the destination does not exist.  Also see the
description of <samp>--remove-destination</samp>.
</p>
<p>This option is independent of the <samp>--interactive</samp> or
<samp>-i</samp> option: neither cancels the effect of the other.
</p>
<p>This option is ignored when the <samp>--no-clobber</samp> or <samp>-n</samp> option
is also used.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-2"></a>
<p>If a command line argument specifies a symbolic link, then copy the
file it points to rather than the symbolic link itself.  However,
copy (preserving its nature) any symbolic link that is encountered
via recursive traversal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--interactive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinteractive"></a>
<p>When copying a file other than a directory, prompt whether to
overwrite an existing destination file.  The <samp>-i</samp> option overrides
a previous <samp>-n</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--link</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlink"></a>
<p>Make hard links instead of copies of non-directories.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddereference-1"></a>
<p>Follow symbolic links when copying from them.
With this option, <code>cp</code> cannot create a symbolic link.
For example, a symlink (to regular file) in the source tree will be copied to
a regular file in the destination tree.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-clobber</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dclobber"></a>
<p>Do not overwrite an existing file; silently do nothing instead.
This option overrides a previous
<samp>-i</samp> option.  This option is mutually exclusive with <samp>-b</samp> or
<samp>--backup</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-copying-1"></a>
<p>Copy symbolic links as symbolic links rather than copying the files that
they point to.  This option affects only symbolic links in the source;
symbolic links in the destination are always followed if possible.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve[=<var>attribute_list</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve"></a>
<a name="index-file-information_002c-preserving_002c-extended-attributes_002c-xattr"></a>
<p>Preserve the specified attributes of the original files.
If specified, the <var>attribute_list</var> must be a comma-separated list
of one or more of the following strings:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>mode</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Preserve the file mode bits and access control lists.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ownership</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Preserve the owner and group.  On most modern systems,
only users with appropriate privileges may change the owner of a file,
and ordinary users
may preserve the group ownership of a file only if they happen to be
a member of the desired group.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>timestamps</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Preserve the times of last access and last modification, when possible.
On older systems, it is not possible to preserve these attributes
when the affected file is a symbolic link.
However, many systems now provide the <code>utimensat</code> function,
which makes it possible even for symbolic links.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>links</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Preserve in the destination files
any links between corresponding source files.
Note that with <samp>-L</samp> or <samp>-H</samp>, this option can convert
symbolic links to hard links.  For example,
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ mkdir c; : &gt; a; ln -s a b; cp -aH a b c; ls -i1 c
74161745 a
74161745 b
</pre></div>
<p>Note the inputs: <samp>b</samp> is a symlink to regular file <samp>a</samp>,
yet the files in destination directory, <samp>c/</samp>, are hard-linked.
Since <samp>-a</samp> implies <samp>--no-dereference</samp> it would copy the symlink,
but the later <samp>-H</samp> tells <code>cp</code> to dereference the command line
arguments where it then sees two files with the same inode number.
Then the <samp>--preserve=links</samp> option also implied by <samp>-a</samp>
will preserve the perceived hard link.
</p>
<p>Here is a similar example that exercises <code>cp</code>&rsquo;s <samp>-L</samp> option:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ mkdir b c; (cd b; : &gt; a; ln -s a b); cp -aL b c; ls -i1 c/b
74163295 a
74163295 b
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>context</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Preserve SELinux security context of the file, or fail with full diagnostics.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>xattr</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Preserve extended attributes of the file, or fail with full diagnostics.
If <code>cp</code> is built without xattr support, ignore this option.
If SELinux context, ACLs or Capabilities are implemented using xattrs,
they are preserved implicitly by this option as well, i.e., even without
specifying <samp>--preserve=mode</samp> or <samp>--preserve=context</samp>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Preserve all file attributes.
Equivalent to specifying all of the above, but with the difference
that failure to preserve SELinux security context or extended attributes
does not change <code>cp</code>&rsquo;s exit status.  In contrast to <samp>-a</samp>,
all but &lsquo;<samp>Operation not supported</samp>&rsquo; warnings are output.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Using <samp>--preserve</samp> with no <var>attribute_list</var> is equivalent
to <samp>--preserve=mode,ownership,timestamps</samp>.
</p>
<p>In the absence of this option, the permissions of existing destination
files are unchanged.  Each new file is created with the mode of the
corresponding source file minus the set-user-ID, set-group-ID, and
sticky bits as the create mode; the operating system then applies either
the umask or a default ACL, possibly resulting in a more restrictive
file mode.
See <a href="#File-permissions">File permissions</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-preserve=<var>attribute_list</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-file-information_002c-preserving"></a>
<p>Do not preserve the specified attributes.  The <var>attribute_list</var>
has the same form as for <samp>--preserve</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--parents</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dparents"></a>
<a name="index-parent-directories-and-cp"></a>
<p>Form the name of each destination file by appending to the target
directory a slash and the specified name of the source file.  The last
argument given to <code>cp</code> must be the name of an existing directory.
For example, the command:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">cp --parents a/b/c existing_dir
</pre></div>

<p>copies the file <samp>a/b/c</samp> to <samp>existing_dir/a/b/c</samp>, creating
any missing intermediate directories.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--recursive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002dr-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drecursive-1"></a>
<a name="index-directories_002c-copying-recursively-1"></a>
<a name="index-copying-directories-recursively-1"></a>
<a name="index-recursively-copying-directories-1"></a>
<a name="index-non_002ddirectories_002c-copying-as-special-files-1"></a>
<p>Copy directories recursively.  By default, do not follow symbolic
links in the source unless used together with the <samp>--link</samp>
(<samp>-l</samp>) option; see the <samp>--archive</samp> (<samp>-a</samp>), <samp>-d</samp>,
<samp>--dereference</samp> (<samp>-L</samp>), <samp>--no-dereference</samp>
(<samp>-P</samp>), and <samp>-H</samp> options.  Special files are copied by
creating a destination file of the same type as the source; see the
<samp>--copy-contents</samp> option.  It is not portable to use
<samp>-r</samp> to copy symbolic links or special files.  On some
non-GNU systems, <samp>-r</samp> implies the equivalent of
<samp>-L</samp> and <samp>--copy-contents</samp> for historical reasons.
Also, it is not portable to use <samp>-R</samp> to copy symbolic links
unless you also specify <samp>-P</samp>, as POSIX allows
implementations that dereference symbolic links by default.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reflink[=<var>when</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dreflink_005b_003dwhen_005d"></a>
<a name="index-COW"></a>
<a name="index-clone"></a>
<a name="index-copy-on-write"></a>
<p>Perform a lightweight, copy-on-write (COW) copy, if supported by the
file system.  Once it has succeeded, beware that the source and destination
files share the same disk data blocks as long as they remain unmodified.
Thus, if a disk I/O error affects data blocks of one of the files,
the other suffers the same fate.
</p>
<p>The <var>when</var> value can be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>always</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>The default behavior: if the copy-on-write operation is not supported
then report the failure for each file and exit with a failure status.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>auto</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>If the copy-on-write operation is not supported then fall back
to the standard copy behavior.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>never</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Disable copy-on-write operation and use the standard copy behavior.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>This option is overridden by the <samp>--link</samp>, <samp>--symbolic-link</samp>
and <samp>--attributes-only</samp> options, thus allowing it to be used
to configure the default data copying behavior for <code>cp</code>.
For example, with the following alias, <code>cp</code> will use the
minimum amount of space supported by the file system.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">alias cp='cp --reflink=auto --sparse=always'
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--remove-destination</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dremove_002ddestination"></a>
<p>Remove each existing destination file before attempting to open it
(contrast with <samp>-f</samp> above).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sparse=<var>when</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsparse_003dwhen"></a>
<a name="index-sparse-files_002c-copying"></a>
<a name="index-holes_002c-copying-files-with"></a>
<a name="index-read-system-call_002c-and-holes"></a>
<p>A <em>sparse file</em> contains <em>holes</em>&mdash;a sequence of zero bytes that
does not occupy any physical disk blocks; the &lsquo;<samp>read</samp>&rsquo; system call
reads these as zeros.  This can both save considerable disk space and
increase speed, since many binary files contain lots of consecutive zero
bytes.  By default, <code>cp</code> detects holes in input source files via a crude
heuristic and makes the corresponding output file sparse as well.
Only regular files may be sparse.
</p>
<p>The <var>when</var> value can be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>auto</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>The default behavior: if the input file is sparse, attempt to make
the output file sparse, too.  However, if an output file exists but
refers to a non-regular file, then do not attempt to make it sparse.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>always</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>For each sufficiently long sequence of zero bytes in the input file,
attempt to create a corresponding hole in the output file, even if the
input file does not appear to be sparse.
This is useful when the input file resides on a file system
that does not support sparse files
(for example,  &lsquo;<samp>efs</samp>&rsquo; file systems in SGI IRIX 5.3 and earlier),
but the output file is on a type of file system that does support them.
Holes may be created only in regular files, so if the destination file
is of some other type, <code>cp</code> does not even try to make it sparse.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>never</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Never make the output file sparse.
This is useful in creating a file for use with the <code>mkswap</code> command,
since such a file must not have any holes.
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--strip-trailing-slashes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dstrip_002dtrailing_002dslashes"></a>
<a name="index-stripping-trailing-slashes"></a>
<p>Remove any trailing slashes from each <var>source</var> argument.
See <a href="#Trailing-slashes">Trailing slashes</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--symbolic-link</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsymbolic_002dlink"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-copying-with"></a>
<p>Make symbolic links instead of copies of non-directories.  All source
file names must be absolute (starting with &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo;) unless the
destination files are in the current directory.  This option merely
results in an error message on systems that do not support symbolic links.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix-1"></a>
<p>Append <var>suffix</var> to each backup file made with <samp>-b</samp>.
See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--target-directory=<var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtarget_002ddirectory-1"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-3"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-2"></a>
<p>Specify the destination <var>directory</var>.
