See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-target-directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dtarget_002ddirectory-1"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-4"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-3"></a>
<p>Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a directory or a
symbolic link to a directory.  See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--update</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dupdate"></a>
<a name="index-newer-files_002c-copying-only"></a>
<p>Do not copy a non-directory that has an existing destination with the
same or newer modification timestamp.  If timestamps are being preserved,
the comparison is to the source timestamp truncated to the
resolutions of the destination file system and of the system calls
used to update timestamps; this avoids duplicate work if several
&lsquo;<samp>cp -pu</samp>&rsquo; commands are executed with the same source and destination.
This option is ignored if the <samp>-n</samp> or <samp>--no-clobber</samp>
option is also specified.
Also, if <samp>--preserve=links</samp> is also specified (like with &lsquo;<samp>cp -au</samp>&rsquo;
for example), that will take precedence; consequently, depending on the
order that files are processed from the source, newer files in the destination
may be replaced, to mirror hard links in the source.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-3"></a>
<p>Print the name of each file before copying it.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--one-file-system</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002done_002dfile_002dsystem"></a>
<a name="index-file-systems_002c-omitting-copying-to-different"></a>
<p>Skip subdirectories that are on different file systems from the one that
the copy started on.
However, mount point directories <em>are</em> copied.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context[=<var>context</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext-1"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-1"></a>
<p>Without a specified <var>context</var>, adjust the SELinux security context according
to the system default type for destination files, similarly to the
<code>restorecon</code> command.
The long form of this option with a specific context specified,
will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a warning is
issued.
This option is mutually exclusive with the <samp>--preserve=context</samp>
option, and overrides the <samp>--preserve=all</samp> and <samp>-a</samp> options.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="dd-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#install-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">install invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#cp-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">cp invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Basic-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Basic operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="dd_003a-Convert-and-copy-a-file"></a>
<h3 class="section">11.2 <code>dd</code>: Convert and copy a file</h3>

<a name="index-dd"></a>
<a name="index-converting-while-copying-a-file"></a>

<p><code>dd</code> copies a file (from standard input to standard output, by
default) with a changeable I/O block size, while optionally performing
conversions on it.  Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">dd [<var>operand</var>]&hellip;
dd <var>option</var>
</pre></div>

<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.
See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.  <code>dd</code> accepts the following operands,
whose syntax was inspired by the DD (data definition) statement of
OS/360 JCL.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>if=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-if"></a>
<p>Read from <var>file</var> instead of standard input.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>of=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-of"></a>
<p>Write to <var>file</var> instead of standard output.  Unless
&lsquo;<samp>conv=notrunc</samp>&rsquo; is given, <code>dd</code> truncates <var>file</var> to zero
bytes (or the size specified with &lsquo;<samp>seek=</samp>&rsquo;).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ibs=<var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ibs"></a>
<a name="index-block-size-of-input"></a>
<a name="index-input-block-size"></a>
<p>Set the input block size to <var>bytes</var>.
This makes <code>dd</code> read <var>bytes</var> per block.
The default is 512 bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>obs=<var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-obs"></a>
<a name="index-block-size-of-output"></a>
<a name="index-output-block-size"></a>
<p>Set the output block size to <var>bytes</var>.
This makes <code>dd</code> write <var>bytes</var> per block.
The default is 512 bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>bs=<var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-bs"></a>
<a name="index-block-size-1"></a>
<p>Set both input and output block sizes to <var>bytes</var>.
This makes <code>dd</code> read and write <var>bytes</var> per block,
overriding any &lsquo;<samp>ibs</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>obs</samp>&rsquo; settings.
In addition, if no data-transforming <samp>conv</samp> option is specified,
input is copied to the output as soon as it&rsquo;s read,
even if it is smaller than the block size.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cbs=<var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cbs"></a>
<a name="index-block-size-of-conversion"></a>
<a name="index-conversion-block-size"></a>
<a name="index-fixed_002dlength-records_002c-converting-to-variable_002dlength"></a>
<a name="index-variable_002dlength-records_002c-converting-to-fixed_002dlength"></a>
<p>Set the conversion block size to <var>bytes</var>.
When converting variable-length records to fixed-length ones
(<samp>conv=block</samp>) or the reverse (<samp>conv=unblock</samp>),
use <var>bytes</var> as the fixed record length.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>skip=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-skip"></a>
<p>Skip <var>n</var> &lsquo;<samp>ibs</samp>&rsquo;-byte blocks in the input file before copying.
If &lsquo;<samp>iflag=skip_bytes</samp>&rsquo; is specified, <var>n</var> is interpreted
as a byte count rather than a block count.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>seek=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-seek"></a>
<p>Skip <var>n</var> &lsquo;<samp>obs</samp>&rsquo;-byte blocks in the output file before copying.
if &lsquo;<samp>oflag=seek_bytes</samp>&rsquo; is specified, <var>n</var> is interpreted
as a byte count rather than a block count.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>count=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-count"></a>
<p>Copy <var>n</var> &lsquo;<samp>ibs</samp>&rsquo;-byte blocks from the input file, instead
of everything until the end of the file.
if &lsquo;<samp>iflag=count_bytes</samp>&rsquo; is specified, <var>n</var> is interpreted
as a byte count rather than a block count.
Note if the input may return short reads as could be the case
when reading from a pipe for example, &lsquo;<samp>iflag=fullblock</samp>&rsquo;
will ensure that &lsquo;<samp>count=</samp>&rsquo; corresponds to complete input blocks
rather than the traditional POSIX specified behavior of counting
input read operations.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>status=<var>level</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-status"></a>
<p>Transfer information is normally output to stderr upon
receipt of the &lsquo;<samp>INFO</samp>&rsquo; signal or when <code>dd</code> exits.
Specifying <var>level</var> will adjust the amount of information printed,
with the last <var>level</var> specified taking precedence.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>none</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-none-dd-status_003d"></a>
<p>Do not print any informational or warning messages to stderr.
Error messages are output as normal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>noxfer</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-noxfer-dd-status_003d"></a>
<p>Do not print the final transfer rate and volume statistics
that normally make up the last status line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>progress</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-progress-dd-status_003d"></a>
<p>Print the transfer rate and volume statistics on stderr,
when processing each input block.  Statistics are output
on a single line at most once every second, but updates
can be delayed when waiting on I/O.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>conv=<var>conversion</var>[,<var>conversion</var>]&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-conv"></a>
<p>Convert the file as specified by the <var>conversion</var> argument(s).
(No spaces around any comma(s).)
</p>
<p>Conversions:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ascii</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ascii_002c-converting-to"></a>
<p>Convert EBCDIC to ASCII,
using the conversion table specified by POSIX.
This provides a 1:1 translation for all 256 bytes.
This option implies &lsquo;<samp>conv=unblock</samp>&rsquo;; input is converted to
ASCII before trailing spaces are deleted.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ebcdic</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ebcdic_002c-converting-to"></a>
<p>Convert ASCII to EBCDIC.
This is the inverse of the &lsquo;<samp>ascii</samp>&rsquo; conversion.
This option implies &lsquo;<samp>conv=block</samp>&rsquo;; trailing spaces are added
before being converted to EBCDIC.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ibm</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-alternate-ebcdic_002c-converting-to"></a>
<p>This acts like &lsquo;<samp>conv=ebcdic</samp>&rsquo;, except it
uses the alternate conversion table specified by POSIX.
This is not a 1:1 translation, but reflects common historical practice
for &lsquo;<samp>~</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>[</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>]</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>ascii</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>ebcdic</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>ibm</samp>&rsquo; conversions are
mutually exclusive.  If you use any of these options, you should also
use the &lsquo;<samp>cbs=</samp>&rsquo; option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>block</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-block-_0028space_002dpadding_0029"></a>
<p>For each line in the input, output &lsquo;<samp>cbs</samp>&rsquo; bytes, replacing the
input newline with a space and padding with spaces as necessary.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>unblock</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-unblock"></a>
<p>Remove any trailing spaces in each &lsquo;<samp>cbs</samp>&rsquo;-sized input block,
and append a newline.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>block</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>unblock</samp>&rsquo; conversions are mutually exclusive.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>lcase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-lcase_002c-converting-to"></a>
<p>Change uppercase letters to lowercase.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ucase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ucase_002c-converting-to"></a>
<p>Change lowercase letters to uppercase.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>lcase</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>ucase</samp>&rsquo; conversions are mutually exclusive.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>sparse</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-sparse"></a>
<p>Try to seek rather than write NUL output blocks.
On a file system that supports sparse files, this will create
sparse output when extending the output file.
Be careful when using this option in conjunction with
&lsquo;<samp>conv=notrunc</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>oflag=append</samp>&rsquo;.
With &lsquo;<samp>conv=notrunc</samp>&rsquo;, existing data in the output file
corresponding to NUL blocks from the input, will be untouched.
With &lsquo;<samp>oflag=append</samp>&rsquo; the seeks performed will be ineffective.
Similarly, when the output is a device rather than a file,
NUL input blocks are not copied, and therefore this option
is most useful with virtual or pre zeroed devices.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>swab</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-swab-_0028byte_002dswapping_0029"></a>
<a name="index-byte_002dswapping-1"></a>
<p>Swap every pair of input bytes.  GNU <code>dd</code>, unlike others, works
when an odd number of bytes are read&mdash;the last byte is simply copied
(since there is nothing to swap it with).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>sync</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-sync-_0028padding-with-ASCII-NULs_0029"></a>
<p>Pad every input block to size of &lsquo;<samp>ibs</samp>&rsquo; with trailing zero bytes.
When used with &lsquo;<samp>block</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>unblock</samp>&rsquo;, pad with spaces instead of
zero bytes.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>The following &ldquo;conversions&rdquo; are really file flags
and don&rsquo;t affect internal processing:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>excl</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-excl"></a>
<a name="index-creating-output-file_002c-requiring"></a>
<p>Fail if the output file already exists; <code>dd</code> must create the
output file itself.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nocreat</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-nocreat"></a>
<a name="index-creating-output-file_002c-avoiding"></a>
<p>Do not create the output file; the output file must already exist.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>excl</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>nocreat</samp>&rsquo; conversions are mutually exclusive.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>notrunc</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-notrunc"></a>
<a name="index-truncating-output-file_002c-avoiding"></a>
<p>Do not truncate the output file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>noerror</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-noerror"></a>
<a name="index-read-errors_002c-ignoring"></a>
<p>Continue after read errors.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>fdatasync</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-fdatasync"></a>
<a name="index-synchronized-data-writes_002c-before-finishing"></a>
<p>Synchronize output data just before finishing.  This forces a physical
write of output data.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>fsync</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-fsync"></a>
<a name="index-synchronized-data-and-metadata-writes_002c-before-finishing"></a>
<p>Synchronize output data and metadata just before finishing.  This
forces a physical write of output data and metadata.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iflag=<var>flag</var>[,<var>flag</var>]&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-iflag"></a>
<p>Access the input file using the flags specified by the <var>flag</var>
argument(s).  (No spaces around any comma(s).)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>oflag=<var>flag</var>[,<var>flag</var>]&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-oflag"></a>
<p>Access the output file using the flags specified by the <var>flag</var>
argument(s).  (No spaces around any comma(s).)
</p>
<p>Here are the flags.  Not every flag is supported on every operating
system.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>append</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-append"></a>
<a name="index-appending-to-the-output-file"></a>
<p>Write in append mode, so that even if some other process is writing to
this file, every <code>dd</code> write will append to the current
contents of the file.  This flag makes sense only for output.
If you combine this flag with the &lsquo;<samp>of=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo; operand,
you should also specify &lsquo;<samp>conv=notrunc</samp>&rsquo; unless you want the
output file to be truncated before being appended to.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cio</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cio"></a>
<a name="index-concurrent-I_002fO"></a>
<p>Use concurrent I/O mode for data.  This mode performs direct I/O
and drops the POSIX requirement to serialize all I/O to the same file.
A file cannot be opened in CIO mode and with a standard open at the
same time.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>direct</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-direct"></a>
<a name="index-direct-I_002fO"></a>
<p>Use direct I/O for data, avoiding the buffer cache.
Note that the kernel may impose restrictions on read or write buffer sizes.
For example, with an ext4 destination file system and a Linux-based kernel,
using &lsquo;<samp>oflag=direct</samp>&rsquo; will cause writes to fail with <code>EINVAL</code> if the
output buffer size is not a multiple of 512.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-directory"></a>
<a name="index-directory-I_002fO"></a>

<p>Fail unless the file is a directory.  Most operating systems do not
allow I/O to a directory, so this flag has limited utility.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>dsync</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-dsync"></a>
<a name="index-synchronized-data-reads"></a>
<p>Use synchronized I/O for data.  For the output file, this forces a
physical write of output data on each write.  For the input file,
this flag can matter when reading from a remote file that has been
written to synchronously by some other process.  Metadata (e.g.,
last-access and last-modified time) is not necessarily synchronized.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>sync</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-sync"></a>
<a name="index-synchronized-data-and-metadata-I_002fO"></a>
<p>Use synchronized I/O for both data and metadata.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nocache</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-nocache"></a>
<a name="index-discarding-file-cache"></a>
<p>Request to discard the system data cache for a file.
When count=0 all cached data for the file is specified,
otherwise the cache is dropped for the processed
portion of the file.  Also when count=0,
failure to discard the cache is diagnosed
and reflected in the exit status.
</p>
<p>Note data that is not already persisted to storage will not
be discarded from cache, so note the use of the &ldquo;sync&rdquo; options
in the examples below, which are used to maximize the
effectiveness of the &lsquo;<samp>nocache</samp>&rsquo; flag.
</p>
<p>Here are some usage examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Advise to drop cache for whole file
dd if=ifile iflag=nocache count=0

# Ensure drop cache for the whole file
dd of=ofile oflag=nocache conv=notrunc,fdatasync count=0

# Advise to drop cache for part of file
# Note the kernel will only consider complete and
# already persisted pages.
dd if=ifile iflag=nocache skip=10 count=10 of=/dev/null

# Stream data using just the read-ahead cache.
# See also the &lsquo;<samp>direct</samp>&rsquo; flag.
dd if=ifile of=ofile iflag=nocache oflag=nocache,sync
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nonblock</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-nonblock"></a>
<a name="index-nonblocking-I_002fO"></a>
<p>Use non-blocking I/O.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>noatime</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-noatime"></a>
<a name="index-access-timestamp"></a>
<p>Do not update the file&rsquo;s access timestamp.
See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
Some older file systems silently ignore this flag, so it is a good
idea to test it on your files before relying on it.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>noctty</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-noctty"></a>
<a name="index-controlling-terminal"></a>
<p>Do not assign the file to be a controlling terminal for <code>dd</code>.
This has no effect when the file is not a terminal.
On many hosts (e.g., GNU/Linux hosts), this option has no effect
at all.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nofollow</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-nofollow"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-following"></a>
<p>Do not follow symbolic links.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nolinks</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-nolinks"></a>
<a name="index-hard-links"></a>
<p>Fail if the file has multiple hard links.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>binary</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-binary"></a>
<a name="index-binary-I_002fO"></a>
<p>Use binary I/O.  This option has an effect only on nonstandard
platforms that distinguish binary from text I/O.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>text</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-text"></a>
<a name="index-text-I_002fO"></a>
<p>Use text I/O.  Like &lsquo;<samp>binary</samp>&rsquo;, this option has no effect on
standard platforms.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>fullblock</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-fullblock"></a>
<p>Accumulate full blocks from input.  The <code>read</code> system call
may return early if a full block is not available.
When that happens, continue calling <code>read</code> to fill the remainder
of the block.
This flag can be used only with <code>iflag</code>.
This flag is useful with pipes for example
as they may return short reads. In that case,
this flag is needed to ensure that a &lsquo;<samp>count=</samp>&rsquo; argument is
interpreted as a block count rather than a count of read operations.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>count_bytes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-count_005fbytes"></a>
<p>Interpret the &lsquo;<samp>count=</samp>&rsquo; operand as a byte count,
rather than a block count, which allows specifying
a length that is not a multiple of the I/O block size.
This flag can be used only with <code>iflag</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>skip_bytes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-skip_005fbytes"></a>
<p>Interpret the &lsquo;<samp>skip=</samp>&rsquo; operand as a byte count,
rather than a block count, which allows specifying
an offset that is not a multiple of the I/O block size.
This flag can be used only with <code>iflag</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>seek_bytes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-seek_005fbytes"></a>
<p>Interpret the &lsquo;<samp>seek=</samp>&rsquo; operand as a byte count,
rather than a block count, which allows specifying
an offset that is not a multiple of the I/O block size.
This flag can be used only with <code>oflag</code>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>These flags are not supported on all systems, and &lsquo;<samp>dd</samp>&rsquo; rejects
attempts to use them when they are not supported.  When reading from
standard input or writing to standard output, the &lsquo;<samp>nofollow</samp>&rsquo; and
&lsquo;<samp>noctty</samp>&rsquo; flags should not be specified, and the other flags
(e.g., &lsquo;<samp>nonblock</samp>&rsquo;) can affect how other processes behave with the
affected file descriptors, even after <code>dd</code> exits.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-multipliers-after-numbers"></a>
<p>The numeric-valued strings above (<var>n</var> and <var>bytes</var>)
can be followed by a multiplier: &lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;=512, &lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;=1,
&lsquo;<samp>w</samp>&rsquo;=2, &lsquo;<samp>x<var>m</var></samp>&rsquo;=<var>m</var>, or any of the
standard block size suffixes like &lsquo;<samp>k</samp>&rsquo;=1024 (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
</p>
<p>Any block size you specify via &lsquo;<samp>bs=</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>ibs=</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>obs=</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>cbs=</samp>&rsquo;
should not be too large&mdash;values larger than a few megabytes
are generally wasteful or (as in the gigabyte..exabyte case) downright
counterproductive or error-inducing.
</p>
<p>To process data that is at an offset or size that is not a
multiple of the I/O&nbsp;block size, you can use the &lsquo;<samp>skip_bytes</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>seek_bytes</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>count_bytes</samp>&rsquo; flags.  Alternatively
the traditional method of separate <code>dd</code> invocations can be used.
For example, the following shell commands copy data
in 512 KiB blocks between a disk and a tape, but do not save
or restore a 4 KiB label at the start of the disk:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">disk=/dev/rdsk/c0t1d0s2
tape=/dev/rmt/0

# Copy all but the label from disk to tape.
(dd bs=4k skip=1 count=0 &amp;&amp; dd bs=512k) &lt;$disk &gt;$tape

# Copy from tape back to disk, but leave the disk label alone.
(dd bs=4k seek=1 count=0 &amp;&amp; dd bs=512k) &lt;$tape &gt;$disk
</pre></div>

<a name="index-ddrescue"></a>
<a name="index-disks_002c-failing"></a>
<p>For failing disks, other tools come with a great variety of extra
functionality to ease the saving of as much data as possible before the
disk finally dies, e.g.
<a href="https://www.gnu.org/software/ddrescue/">GNU <code>ddrescue</code></a>.
However, in some cases such a tool is not available or the administrator
feels more comfortable with the handling of <code>dd</code>.
As a simple rescue method, call <code>dd</code> as shown in the following
example: the options &lsquo;<samp>conv=noerror,sync</samp>&rsquo; are used to continue
after read errors and to pad out bad reads with NULs, while
&lsquo;<samp>iflag=fullblock</samp>&rsquo; caters for short reads (which traditionally never
occur on disk based devices):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Rescue data from an (unmounted!) partition of a failing disk.
dd conv=noerror,sync iflag=fullblock &lt;/dev/sda1 &gt; /mnt/rescue.img
</pre></div>

<p>Sending an &lsquo;<samp>INFO</samp>&rsquo; signal (or &lsquo;<samp>USR1</samp>&rsquo; signal where that is unavailable)
to a running <code>dd</code> process makes it print I/O statistics to
standard error and then resume copying.   In the example below,
<code>dd</code> is run in the background to copy 5GB of data.
The <code>kill</code> command makes it output intermediate I/O statistics,
and when <code>dd</code> completes normally or is killed by the
<code>SIGINT</code> signal, it outputs the final statistics.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Ignore the signal so we never inadvertently terminate the dd child.
# Note this is not needed when SIGINFO is available.
trap '' USR1

# Run dd with the fullblock iflag to avoid short reads
# which can be triggered by reception of signals.
dd iflag=fullblock if=/dev/zero of=/dev/null count=5000000 bs=1000 &amp; pid=$!

# Output stats every second.
while kill -s USR1 $pid 2&gt;/dev/null; do sleep 1; done
</pre></div>

<p>The above script will output in the following format:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">3441325+0 records in
3441325+0 records out
3441325000 bytes (3.4 GB, 3.2 GiB) copied, 1.00036 s, 3.4 GB/s
5000000+0 records in
5000000+0 records out
5000000000 bytes (5.0 GB, 4.7 GiB) copied, 1.44433 s, 3.5 GB/s
</pre></div>

<p>The &lsquo;<samp>status=progress</samp>&rsquo; option periodically updates the last line
of the transfer statistics above.
</p>
<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-5"></a>
<p>On systems lacking the &lsquo;<samp>INFO</samp>&rsquo; signal <code>dd</code> responds to the
&lsquo;<samp>USR1</samp>&rsquo; signal instead, unless the <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code>
environment variable is set.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="install-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#mv-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">mv invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#dd-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">dd invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Basic-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Basic operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="install_003a-Copy-files-and-set-attributes"></a>
<h3 class="section">11.3 <code>install</code>: Copy files and set attributes</h3>

<a name="index-install"></a>
<a name="index-copying-files-and-setting-attributes"></a>

<p><code>install</code> copies files while setting their file mode bits and, if
possible, their owner and group.  Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">install [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [-T] <var>source</var> <var>dest</var>
install [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>source</var>&hellip; <var>directory</var>
install [<var>option</var>]&hellip; -t <var>directory</var> <var>source</var>&hellip;
install [<var>option</var>]&hellip; -d <var>directory</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<ul>
<li> If two file names are given, <code>install</code> copies the first file to the
second.

</li><li> If the <samp>--target-directory</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) option is given, or
failing that if the last file is a directory and the
<samp>--no-target-directory</samp> (<samp>-T</samp>) option is not given,
<code>install</code> copies each <var>source</var> file to the specified
directory, using the <var>source</var>s&rsquo; names.

</li><li> If the <samp>--directory</samp> (<samp>-d</samp>) option is given,
<code>install</code> creates each <var>directory</var> and any missing parent
directories.  Parent directories are created with mode
&lsquo;<samp>u=rwx,go=rx</samp>&rsquo; (755), regardless of the <samp>-m</samp> option or the
current umask.  See <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>, for how the
set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of parent directories are inherited.
</li></ul>

<a name="index-Makefiles_002c-installing-programs-in"></a>
<p><code>install</code> is similar to <code>cp</code>, but allows you to control the
attributes of destination files.  It is typically used in Makefiles to
copy programs into their destination directories.  It refuses to copy
files onto themselves.
</p>
<a name="index-extended-attributes_002c-xattr"></a>
<p><code>install</code> never preserves extended attributes (xattr).
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--backup[=<var>method</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbackup-2"></a>
<a name="index-VERSION_005fCONTROL-2"></a>
<a name="index-backups_002c-making-2"></a>
<p>See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
Make a backup of each file that would otherwise be overwritten or removed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-C</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--compare</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dC-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcompare"></a>
<p>Compare each pair of source and destination files, and if the destination has
identical content and any specified owner, group, permissions, and possibly
SELinux context, then do not modify the destination at all.
Note this option is best used in conjunction with <samp>--user</samp>,
<samp>--group</samp> and <samp>--mode</samp> options, lest <code>install</code>
incorrectly determines the default attributes that installed files would have
(as it doesn&rsquo;t consider setgid directories and POSIX default ACLs for example).
This could result in redundant copies or attributes that are not reset to the
correct defaults.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-13"></a>
<p>Ignored; for compatibility with old Unix versions of <code>install</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-D</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dD-2"></a>
<p>Create any missing parent directories of <var>dest</var>,
then copy <var>source</var> to <var>dest</var>.
Explicitly specifying the <samp>--target-directory=<var>dir</var></samp> will similarly
ensure the presence of that hierarchy before copying <var>source</var> arguments.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddirectory-1"></a>
<a name="index-directories_002c-creating-with-given-attributes"></a>
<a name="index-parent-directories_002c-creating-missing"></a>
<a name="index-leading-directories_002c-creating-missing"></a>
<p>Create any missing parent directories, giving them the default
attributes.  Then create each given directory, setting their owner,
group and mode as given on the command line or to the defaults.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g <var>group</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--group=<var>group</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dgroup-1"></a>
<a name="index-group-ownership-of-installed-files_002c-setting"></a>
<p>Set the group ownership of installed files or directories to
<var>group</var>.  The default is the process&rsquo;s current group.  <var>group</var>
may be either a group name or a numeric group ID.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m <var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--mode=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmode"></a>
<a name="index-permissions-of-installed-files_002c-setting"></a>
<p>Set the file mode bits for the installed file or directory to <var>mode</var>,
which can be either an octal number, or a symbolic mode as in
<code>chmod</code>, with &lsquo;<samp>a=</samp>&rsquo; (no access allowed to anyone) as the
point of departure (see <a href="#File-permissions">File permissions</a>).
The default mode is &lsquo;<samp>u=rwx,go=rx,a-s</samp>&rsquo;&mdash;read, write, and
execute for the owner, read and execute for group and other, and with
set-user-ID and set-group-ID disabled.
This default is not quite the same as &lsquo;<samp>755</samp>&rsquo;, since it disables
instead of preserving set-user-ID and set-group-ID on directories.
See <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o <var>owner</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--owner=<var>owner</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002downer"></a>
<a name="index-ownership-of-installed-files_002c-setting"></a>
<a name="index-appropriate-privileges"></a>
<a name="index-root-as-default-owner"></a>
<p>If <code>install</code> has appropriate privileges (is run as root), set the
ownership of installed files or directories to <var>owner</var>.  The default
is <code>root</code>.  <var>owner</var> may be either a user name or a numeric user
ID.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-context</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002dcontext"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux-1"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-2"></a>
<p>Preserve the SELinux security context of files and directories.
Failure to preserve the context in all of the files or directories
will result in an exit status of 1.  If SELinux is disabled then
print a warning and ignore the option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-timestamps</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002dtimestamps"></a>
<a name="index-timestamps-of-installed-files_002c-preserving"></a>
<p>Set the time of last access and the time of last modification of each
installed file to match those of each corresponding original file.
When a file is installed without this option, its last access and
last modification timestamps are both set to the time of installation.
This option is useful if you want to use the last modification timestamps
of installed files to keep track of when they were last built as opposed
to when they were last installed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--strip</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dstrip"></a>
<a name="index-symbol-table-information_002c-stripping"></a>
<a name="index-stripping-symbol-table-information"></a>
<p>Strip the symbol tables from installed binary executables.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--strip-program=<var>program</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dstrip_002dprogram"></a>
<a name="index-symbol-table-information_002c-stripping_002c-program"></a>
<p>Program used to strip binaries.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix-2"></a>
<p>Append <var>suffix</var> to each backup file made with <samp>-b</samp>.
See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--target-directory=<var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtarget_002ddirectory-2"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-5"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-4"></a>
<p>Specify the destination <var>directory</var>.
See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
Also specifying the <samp>-D</samp> option will ensure the directory is present.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-target-directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dtarget_002ddirectory-2"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-6"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-5"></a>
<p>Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a directory or a
symbolic link to a directory.  See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-4"></a>
<p>Print the name of each file before copying it.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context[=<var>context</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext-2"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context-1"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-3"></a>
<p>Without a specified <var>context</var>, adjust the SELinux security context according
to the system default type for destination files, similarly to the
<code>restorecon</code> command.
The long form of this option with a specific context specified,
will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a warning is
issued.
This option is mutually exclusive with the <samp>--preserve-context</samp> option.
</p>

</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="mv-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#rm-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">rm invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#install-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">install invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Basic-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Basic operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="mv_003a-Move-_0028rename_0029-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">11.4 <code>mv</code>: Move (rename) files</h3>

<a name="index-mv"></a>

<p><code>mv</code> moves or renames files (or directories).  Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">mv [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [-T] <var>source</var> <var>dest</var>
mv [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>source</var>&hellip; <var>directory</var>
mv [<var>option</var>]&hellip; -t <var>directory</var> <var>source</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<ul>
<li> If two file names are given, <code>mv</code> moves the first file to the
second.

</li><li> If the <samp>--target-directory</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) option is given, or
failing that if the last file is a directory and the
<samp>--no-target-directory</samp> (<samp>-T</samp>) option is not given,
<code>mv</code> moves each <var>source</var> file to the specified
directory, using the <var>source</var>s&rsquo; names.
</li></ul>

<p><code>mv</code> can move any type of file from one file system to another.
Prior to version <code>4.0</code> of the fileutils,
<code>mv</code> could move only regular files between file systems.
For example, now <code>mv</code> can move an entire directory hierarchy
including special device files from one partition to another.  It first
uses some of the same code that&rsquo;s used by <code>cp -a</code> to copy the
requested directories and files, then (assuming the copy succeeded)
it removes the originals.  If the copy fails, then the part that was
copied to the destination partition is removed.  If you were to copy
three directories from one partition to another and the copy of the first
directory succeeded, but the second didn&rsquo;t, the first would be left on
the destination partition and the second and third would be left on the
original partition.
</p>
<a name="index-extended-attributes_002c-xattr-1"></a>
<p><code>mv</code> always tries to copy extended attributes (xattr), which may
include SELinux context, ACLs or Capabilities.
Upon failure all but &lsquo;<samp>Operation not supported</samp>&rsquo; warnings are output.
</p>
<a name="index-prompting_002c-and-mv"></a>
<p>If a destination file exists but is normally unwritable, standard input
is a terminal, and the <samp>-f</samp> or <samp>--force</samp> option is not given,
<code>mv</code> prompts the user for whether to replace the file.  (You might
own the file, or have write permission on its directory.)  If the
response is not affirmative, the file is skipped.
</p>
<p><em>Warning</em>: Avoid specifying a source name with a trailing slash,
when it might be a symlink to a directory.
Otherwise, <code>mv</code> may do something very surprising, since
its behavior depends on the underlying rename system call.
On a system with a modern Linux-based kernel, it fails with
<code>errno=ENOTDIR</code>.
However, on other systems (at least FreeBSD 6.1 and Solaris 10) it silently
renames not the symlink but rather the directory referenced by the symlink.
See <a href="#Trailing-slashes">Trailing slashes</a>.
</p>
<p><em>Note</em>: <code>mv</code> will only replace empty directories in the
destination.  Conflicting populated directories are skipped with a diagnostic.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--backup[=<var>method</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbackup-3"></a>
<a name="index-VERSION_005fCONTROL-3"></a>
<a name="index-backups_002c-making-3"></a>
<p>See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
Make a backup of each file that would otherwise be overwritten or removed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--force</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dforce-1"></a>
<a name="index-prompts_002c-omitting"></a>
<p>Do not prompt the user before removing a destination file.
If you specify more than one of the <samp>-i</samp>, <samp>-f</samp>, <samp>-n</samp>
options, only the final one takes effect.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--interactive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinteractive-1"></a>
<a name="index-prompts_002c-forcing"></a>
<p>Prompt whether to overwrite each existing destination file, regardless
of its permissions.
If the response is not affirmative, the file is skipped.
If you specify more than one of the <samp>-i</samp>, <samp>-f</samp>, <samp>-n</samp>
options, only the final one takes effect.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-clobber</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dclobber-1"></a>
<a name="index-prompts_002c-omitting-1"></a>
<p>Do not overwrite an existing file; silently do nothing instead.
If you specify more than one of the <samp>-i</samp>, <samp>-f</samp>, <samp>-n</samp>
options, only the final one takes effect.
This option is mutually exclusive with <samp>-b</samp> or <samp>--backup</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--update</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dupdate-1"></a>
<a name="index-newer-files_002c-moving-only"></a>
<p>Do not move a non-directory that has an existing destination with the
same or newer modification timestamp.
If the move is across file system boundaries, the comparison is to the
source timestamp truncated to the resolutions of the destination file
system and of the system calls used to update timestamps; this avoids
duplicate work if several &lsquo;<samp>mv -u</samp>&rsquo; commands are executed with the
same source and destination.
This option is ignored if the <samp>-n</samp> or <samp>--no-clobber</samp>
option is also specified.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-5"></a>
<p>Print the name of each file before moving it.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--strip-trailing-slashes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dstrip_002dtrailing_002dslashes-1"></a>
<a name="index-stripping-trailing-slashes-1"></a>
<p>Remove any trailing slashes from each <var>source</var> argument.
See <a href="#Trailing-slashes">Trailing slashes</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix-3"></a>
<p>Append <var>suffix</var> to each backup file made with <samp>-b</samp>.
See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--target-directory=<var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtarget_002ddirectory-3"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-7"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-6"></a>
<p>Specify the destination <var>directory</var>.
See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-target-directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dtarget_002ddirectory-3"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-8"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-7"></a>
<p>Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a directory or a
symbolic link to a directory.  See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext-3"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux_002c-restoring-security-context"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-4"></a>
<p>This option functions similarly to the <code>restorecon</code> command,
by adjusting the SELinux security context according
to the system default type for destination files and each created directory.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="rm-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#shred-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">shred invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#mv-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">mv invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Basic-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Basic operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="rm_003a-Remove-files-or-directories"></a>
<h3 class="section">11.5 <code>rm</code>: Remove files or directories</h3>

<a name="index-rm"></a>
<a name="index-removing-files-or-directories"></a>

<p><code>rm</code> removes each given <var>file</var>.  By default, it does not remove
directories.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">rm [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-prompting_002c-and-rm"></a>
<p>If the <samp>-I</samp> or <samp>--interactive=once</samp> option is given,
and there are more than three files or the <samp>-r</samp>, <samp>-R</samp>,
or <samp>--recursive</samp> are given, then <code>rm</code> prompts the user
for whether to proceed with the entire operation.  If the response is
not affirmative, the entire command is aborted.
</p>
<p>Otherwise, if a file is unwritable, standard input is a terminal, and
the <samp>-f</samp> or <samp>--force</samp> option is not given, or the
<samp>-i</samp> or <samp>--interactive=always</samp> option <em>is</em> given,
<code>rm</code> prompts the user for whether to remove the file.
If the response is not affirmative, the file is skipped.
</p>
<p>Any attempt to remove a file whose last file name component is
<samp>.</samp> or <samp>..</samp> is rejected without any prompting, as mandated
by POSIX.
</p>
<p><em>Warning</em>: If you use <code>rm</code> to remove a file, it is usually
possible to recover the contents of that file.  If you want more assurance
that the contents are truly unrecoverable, consider using <code>shred</code>.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dir</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddir"></a>
<a name="index-directories_002c-removing"></a>
<p>Remove the listed directories if they are empty.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--force</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dforce-2"></a>
<p>Ignore nonexistent files and missing operands, and never prompt the user.
Ignore any previous <samp>--interactive</samp> (<samp>-i</samp>) option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-13"></a>
<p>Prompt whether to remove each file.
If the response is not affirmative, the file is skipped.
Ignore any previous <samp>--force</samp> (<samp>-f</samp>) option.
Equivalent to <samp>--interactive=always</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-I</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dI-1"></a>
<p>Prompt once whether to proceed with the command, if more than three
files are named or if a recursive removal is requested.  Ignore any
previous <samp>--force</samp> (<samp>-f</samp>) option.  Equivalent to
<samp>--interactive=once</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--interactive [=<var>when</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dinteractive-2"></a>
<p>Specify when to issue an interactive prompt.  <var>when</var> may be
omitted, or one of:
</p><ul>
<li> never
<a name="index-never-interactive-option"></a>
- Do not prompt at all.
</li><li> once
<a name="index-once-interactive-option"></a>
- Prompt once if more than three files are named or if a recursive
removal is requested.  Equivalent to <samp>-I</samp>.
</li><li> always
<a name="index-always-interactive-option"></a>
- Prompt for every file being removed.  Equivalent to <samp>-i</samp>.
</li></ul>
<p><samp>--interactive</samp> with no <var>when</var> is equivalent to
<samp>--interactive=always</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--one-file-system</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002done_002dfile_002dsystem-1"></a>
<a name="index-one-file-system_002c-restricting-rm-to"></a>
<p>When removing a hierarchy recursively, skip any directory that is on a
file system different from that of the corresponding command line argument.
<a name="index-bind-mount"></a>
This option is useful when removing a build &ldquo;chroot&rdquo; hierarchy,
which normally contains no valuable data.  However, it is not uncommon
to bind-mount <samp>/home</samp> into such a hierarchy, to make it easier to
use one&rsquo;s start-up file.  The catch is that it&rsquo;s easy to forget to
unmount <samp>/home</samp>.  Then, when you use <code>rm -rf</code> to remove
your normally throw-away chroot, that command will remove everything
under <samp>/home</samp>, too.
Use the <samp>--one-file-system</samp> option, and it will
warn about and skip directories on other file systems.
Of course, this will not save your <samp>/home</samp> if it and your
chroot happen to be on the same file system.
See also <samp>--preserve-root=all</samp> to protect command line arguments
themselves.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-root [=all]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-disallow-recursive-destruction"></a>
<p>Fail upon any attempt to remove the root directory, <samp>/</samp>,
when used with the <samp>--recursive</samp> option.
This is the default behavior.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
When &lsquo;<samp>all</samp>&rsquo; is specified, reject any command line argument
that is not on the same file system as its parent.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-allow-recursive-destruction"></a>
<p>Do not treat <samp>/</samp> specially when removing recursively.
This option is not recommended unless you really want to
remove all the files on your computer.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--recursive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002dR-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drecursive-2"></a>
<a name="index-directories_002c-removing-_0028recursively_0029"></a>
<p>Remove the listed directories and their contents recursively.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-6"></a>
<p>Print the name of each file before removing it.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-files-beginning-with-_002d_002c-removing"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002c-removing-files-beginning-with"></a>
<p>One common question is how to remove files whose names begin with a
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  GNU <code>rm</code>, like every program that uses the <code>getopt</code>
function to parse its arguments, lets you use the &lsquo;<samp>--</samp>&rsquo; option to
indicate that all following arguments are non-options.  To remove a file
called <samp>-f</samp> in the current directory, you could type either:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">rm -- -f
</pre></div>

<p>or:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">rm ./-f
</pre></div>

<a name="index-_002d-and-Unix-rm"></a>
<p>The Unix <code>rm</code> program&rsquo;s use of a single &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; for this purpose
predates the development of the <code>getopt</code> standard syntax.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="shred-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#rm-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">rm invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Basic-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Basic operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="shred_003a-Remove-files-more-securely"></a>
<h3 class="section">11.6 <code>shred</code>: Remove files more securely</h3>

<a name="index-shred"></a>
<a name="index-data_002c-erasing"></a>
<a name="index-erasing-data"></a>

<p><code>shred</code> overwrites devices or files, to help prevent even
very expensive hardware from recovering the data.
</p>
<p>Ordinarily when you remove a file (see <a href="#rm-invocation">rm invocation</a>), the data is
not actually destroyed.  Only the index listing where the file is
stored is destroyed, and the storage is made available for reuse.
There are undelete utilities that will attempt to reconstruct the index
and can bring the file back if the parts were not reused.
</p>
<p>On a busy system with a nearly-full drive, space can get reused in a few
seconds.  But there is no way to know for sure.  If you have sensitive
data, you may want to be sure that recovery is not possible by actually
overwriting the file with non-sensitive data.
</p>
<p>However, even after doing that, it is possible to take the disk back
to a laboratory and use a lot of sensitive (and expensive) equipment
to look for the faint &ldquo;echoes&rdquo; of the original data underneath the
overwritten data.  If the data has only been overwritten once, it&rsquo;s not
even that hard.
</p>
<p>The best way to remove something irretrievably is to destroy the media
it&rsquo;s on with acid, melt it down, or the like.  For cheap removable media
like floppy disks, this is the preferred method.  However, hard drives
are expensive and hard to melt, so the <code>shred</code> utility tries
to achieve a similar effect non-destructively.
</p>
<p>This uses many overwrite passes, with the data patterns chosen to
maximize the damage they do to the old data.  While this will work on
floppies, the patterns are designed for best effect on hard drives.
For more details, see the source code and Peter Gutmann&rsquo;s paper
<a href="https://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/~pgut001/pubs/secure_del.html"><cite>Secure Deletion of Data from Magnetic and Solid-State Memory</cite></a>,
from the proceedings of the Sixth USENIX Security Symposium (San Jose,
California, July 22&ndash;25, 1996).
</p>
<p><strong>Please note</strong> that <code>shred</code> relies on a very important assumption:
that the file system overwrites data in place.  This is the traditional
way to do things, but many modern file system designs do not satisfy this
assumption.  Exceptions include:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Log-structured or journaled file systems, such as those supplied with
AIX and Solaris, and JFS, ReiserFS, XFS, Ext3 (in <code>data=journal</code> mode),
BFS, NTFS, etc., when they are configured to journal <em>data</em>.

</li><li> File systems that write redundant data and carry on even if some writes
fail, such as RAID-based file systems.

</li><li> File systems that make snapshots, such as Network Appliance&rsquo;s NFS server.

</li><li> File systems that cache in temporary locations, such as NFS version 3
clients.

</li><li> Compressed file systems.
</li></ul>

<p>In the particular case of ext3 file systems, the above disclaimer applies (and
<code>shred</code> is thus of limited effectiveness) only in <code>data=journal</code>
mode, which journals file data in addition to just metadata.  In both
the <code>data=ordered</code> (default) and <code>data=writeback</code> modes,
<code>shred</code> works as usual.  Ext3 journaling modes can be changed
by adding the <code>data=something</code> option to the mount options for a
particular file system in the <samp>/etc/fstab</samp> file, as documented in
the mount man page (man mount).
</p>
<p>If you are not sure how your file system operates, then you should assume
that it does not overwrite data in place, which means that shred cannot
reliably operate on regular files in your file system.
</p>
<p>Generally speaking, it is more reliable to shred a device than a file,
since this bypasses the problem of file system design mentioned above.
However, even shredding devices is not always completely reliable.  For
example, most disks map out bad sectors invisibly to the application; if
the bad sectors contain sensitive data, <code>shred</code> won&rsquo;t be able to
destroy it.
</p>
<p><code>shred</code> makes no attempt to detect or report this problem, just as
it makes no attempt to do anything about backups.  However, since it is
more reliable to shred devices than files, <code>shred</code> by default does
not deallocate or remove the output file.  This default is more suitable
for devices, which typically cannot be deallocated and should not be
removed.
</p>
<p>Finally, consider the risk of backups and mirrors.
File system backups and remote mirrors may contain copies of the
file that cannot be removed, and that will allow a shredded file
to be recovered later.  So if you keep any data you may later want
to destroy using <code>shred</code>, be sure that it is not backed up or mirrored.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shred [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>file</var>[&hellip;]
</pre></div>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--force</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dforce-3"></a>
<a name="index-force-deletion"></a>
<p>Override file permissions if necessary to allow overwriting.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n <var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--iterations=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-number"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002diterations_003dnumber"></a>
<a name="index-iterations_002c-selecting-the-number-of"></a>
<p>By default, <code>shred</code> uses 3 passes of
overwrite.  You can reduce this to save time, or increase it if you think it&rsquo;s
appropriate.  After 25 passes all of the internal overwrite patterns will have
been used at least once.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--random-source=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002drandom_002dsource-2"></a>
<a name="index-random-source-for-shredding"></a>
<p>Use <var>file</var> as a source of random data used to overwrite and to
choose pass ordering.  See <a href="#Random-sources">Random sources</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--size=<var>bytes</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-bytes"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsize_003dbytes"></a>
<a name="index-size-of-file-to-shred"></a>
<p>Shred the first <var>bytes</var> bytes of the file.  The default is to shred
the whole file.  <var>bytes</var> can be followed by a size specification like
&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;, or &lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo; to specify a multiple.  See <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--remove[=<var>how</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dremove"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dremove_003dunlink"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dremove_003dwipe"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dremove_003dwipesync"></a>
<a name="index-removing-files-after-shredding"></a>
<p>After shredding a file, deallocate it (if possible) and then remove it.
If a file has multiple links, only the named links will be removed.
Often the file name is less sensitive than the file data, in which case
the optional <var>how</var> parameter, supported with the long form option,
gives control of how to more efficiently remove each directory entry.
The &lsquo;<samp>unlink</samp>&rsquo; parameter will just use a standard unlink call,
&lsquo;<samp>wipe</samp>&rsquo; will also first obfuscate bytes in the name, and
&lsquo;<samp>wipesync</samp>&rsquo; will also sync each obfuscated byte in the name to disk.
Note &lsquo;<samp>wipesync</samp>&rsquo; is the default method, but can be expensive,
requiring a sync for every character in every file.  This can become
significant with many files, or is redundant if your file system provides
synchronous metadata updates.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-7"></a>
<p>Display to standard error all status updates as sterilization proceeds.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--exact</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dexact"></a>
<p>By default, <code>shred</code> rounds the size of a regular file up to the next
multiple of the file system block size to fully erase the slack space in
the last block of the file.  This space may contain portions of the current
system memory on some systems for example.
Use <samp>--exact</samp> to suppress that behavior.
Thus, by default if you shred a 10-byte regular file on a system with 512-byte
blocks, the resulting file will be 512 bytes long.  With this option,
shred does not increase the apparent size of the file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero-1"></a>
<p>Normally, the last pass that <code>shred</code> writes is made up of
random data.  If this would be conspicuous on your hard drive (for
example, because it looks like encrypted data), or you just think
it&rsquo;s tidier, the <samp>--zero</samp> option adds an additional overwrite pass with
all zero bits.  This is in addition to the number of passes specified
by the <samp>--iterations</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>You might use the following command to erase all trace of the
file system you&rsquo;d created on the floppy disk in your first drive.
That command takes about 20 minutes to erase a &ldquo;1.44MB&rdquo; (actually
1440 KiB) floppy.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shred --verbose /dev/fd0
</pre></div>

<p>Similarly, to erase all data on a selected partition of
your hard disk, you could give a command like this:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">shred --verbose /dev/sda5
</pre></div>

<p>On modern disks, a single pass should be adequate,
and it will take one third the time of the default three-pass approach.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># 1 pass, write pseudo-random data; 3x faster than the default
shred --verbose -n1 /dev/sda5
</pre></div>

<p>To be on the safe side, use at least one pass that overwrites using
pseudo-random data.  I.e., don&rsquo;t be tempted to use &lsquo;<samp>-n0 --zero</samp>&rsquo;,
in case some disk controller optimizes the process of writing blocks
of all zeros, and thereby does not clear all bytes in a block.
Some SSDs may do just that.
</p>
<p>A <var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; denotes standard output.
The intended use of this is to shred a removed temporary file.
For example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">i=$(mktemp)
exec 3&lt;&gt;&quot;$i&quot;
rm -- &quot;$i&quot;
echo &quot;Hello, world&quot; &gt;&amp;3
shred - &gt;&amp;3
exec 3&gt;-
</pre></div>

<p>However, the command &lsquo;<samp>shred - &gt;file</samp>&rsquo; does not shred the contents
of <var>file</var>, since the shell truncates <var>file</var> before invoking
<code>shred</code>.  Use the command &lsquo;<samp>shred file</samp>&rsquo; or (if using a
Bourne-compatible shell) the command &lsquo;<samp>shred - 1&lt;&gt;file</samp>&rsquo; instead.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Special-file-types"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Changing-file-attributes" accesskey="n" rel="next">Changing file attributes</a>, Previous: <a href="#Basic-operations" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Basic operations</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Special-file-types-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">12 Special file types</h2>

<a name="index-special-file-types"></a>
<a name="index-file-types_002c-special"></a>

<p>This chapter describes commands which create special types of files (and
<code>rmdir</code>, which removes directories, one special file type).
</p>
<a name="index-special-file-types-1"></a>
<a name="index-file-types"></a>
<p>Although Unix-like operating systems have markedly fewer special file
types than others, not <em>everything</em> can be treated only as the
undifferentiated byte stream of <em>normal files</em>.  For example, when a
file is created or removed, the system must record this information,
which it does in a <em>directory</em>&mdash;a special type of file.  Although
you can read directories as normal files, if you&rsquo;re curious, in order
for the system to do its job it must impose a structure, a certain
order, on the bytes of the file.  Thus it is a &ldquo;special&rdquo; type of file.
</p>
<p>Besides directories, other special file types include named pipes
(FIFOs), symbolic links, sockets, and so-called <em>special files</em>.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#link-invocation" accesskey="1">link invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Make a hard link via the link syscall
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#ln-invocation" accesskey="2">ln invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Make links between files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#mkdir-invocation" accesskey="3">mkdir invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Make directories.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#mkfifo-invocation" accesskey="4">mkfifo invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Make FIFOs (named pipes).
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#mknod-invocation" accesskey="5">mknod invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Make block or character special files.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#readlink-invocation" accesskey="6">readlink invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print value of a symlink or canonical file name.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#rmdir-invocation" accesskey="7">rmdir invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Remove empty directories.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#unlink-invocation" accesskey="8">unlink invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Remove files via the unlink syscall
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="link-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#ln-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">ln invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="link_003a-Make-a-hard-link-via-the-link-syscall"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.1 <code>link</code>: Make a hard link via the link syscall</h3>

<a name="index-link"></a>
<a name="index-links_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-hard-links_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-creating-links-_0028hard-only_0029"></a>

<p><code>link</code> creates a single hard link at a time.
It is a minimalist interface to the system-provided
<code>link</code> function.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Hard-Links">Hard Links</a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
It avoids the bells and whistles of the more commonly-used
<code>ln</code> command (see <a href="#ln-invocation">ln invocation</a>).
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">link <var>filename</var> <var>linkname</var>
</pre></div>

<p><var>filename</var> must specify an existing file, and <var>linkname</var>
must specify a nonexistent entry in an existing directory.
<code>link</code> simply calls <code>link (<var>filename</var>, <var>linkname</var>)</code>
to create the link.
</p>
<p>On a GNU system, this command acts like &lsquo;<samp>ln --directory
--no-target-directory <var>filename</var> <var>linkname</var></samp>&rsquo;.  However, the
<samp>--directory</samp> and <samp>--no-target-directory</samp> options are
not specified by POSIX, and the <code>link</code> command is
more portable in practice.
</p>
<p>If <var>filename</var> is a symbolic link, it is unspecified whether
<var>linkname</var> will be a hard link to the symbolic link or to the
target of the symbolic link.  Use <code>ln -P</code> or <code>ln -L</code>
to specify which behavior is desired.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="ln-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#mkdir-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">mkdir invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#link-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">link invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="ln_003a-Make-links-between-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.2 <code>ln</code>: Make links between files</h3>

<a name="index-ln"></a>
<a name="index-links_002c-creating-1"></a>
<a name="index-hard-links_002c-creating-1"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-_0028soft_0029-links_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-creating-links-_0028hard-or-soft_0029"></a>

<a name="index-file-systems-and-hard-links"></a>
<p><code>ln</code> makes links between files.  By default, it makes hard links;
with the <samp>-s</samp> option, it makes symbolic (or <em>soft</em>) links.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">ln [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [-T] <var>target</var> <var>linkname</var>
ln [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>target</var>
ln [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>target</var>&hellip; <var>directory</var>
ln [<var>option</var>]&hellip; -t <var>directory</var> <var>target</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<ul>
<li> If two file names are given, <code>ln</code> creates a link to the first
file from the second.

</li><li> If one <var>target</var> is given, <code>ln</code> creates a link to that file
in the current directory.

</li><li> If the <samp>--target-directory</samp> (<samp>-t</samp>) option is given, or
failing that if the last file is a directory and the
<samp>--no-target-directory</samp> (<samp>-T</samp>) option is not given,
<code>ln</code> creates a link to each <var>target</var> file in the specified
directory, using the <var>target</var>s&rsquo; names.

</li></ul>

<p>Normally <code>ln</code> does not replace existing files.  Use the
<samp>--force</samp> (<samp>-f</samp>) option to replace them unconditionally,
the <samp>--interactive</samp> (<samp>-i</samp>) option to replace them
conditionally, and the <samp>--backup</samp> (<samp>-b</samp>) option to
rename them.  Unless the <samp>--backup</samp> (<samp>-b</samp>) option is
used there is no brief moment when the destination does not exist;
this is an extension to POSIX.
</p>
<a name="index-hard-link_002c-defined"></a>
<a name="index-inode_002c-and-hard-links"></a>
<p>A <em>hard link</em> is another name for an existing file; the link and the
original are indistinguishable.  Technically speaking, they share the
same inode, and the inode contains all the information about a
file&mdash;indeed, it is not incorrect to say that the inode <em>is</em> the
file.  Most systems prohibit making a hard link to
a directory; on those where it is allowed, only the super-user can do
so (and with caution, since creating a cycle will cause problems to many
other utilities).  Hard links cannot cross file system boundaries.  (These
restrictions are not mandated by POSIX, however.)
</p>
<a name="index-dereferencing-symbolic-links"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link_002c-defined"></a>
<p><em>Symbolic links</em> (<em>symlinks</em> for short), on the other hand, are
a special file type (which not all kernels support: System V release 3
(and older) systems lack symlinks) in which the link file actually
refers to a different file, by name.  When most operations (opening,
reading, writing, and so on) are passed the symbolic link file, the
kernel automatically <em>dereferences</em> the link and operates on the
target of the link.  But some operations (e.g., removing) work on the
link file itself, rather than on its target.  The owner and group of a
symlink are not significant to file access performed through
the link, but do have implications on deleting a symbolic link from a
directory with the restricted deletion bit set.  On the GNU system,
the mode of a symlink has no significance and cannot be changed, but
on some BSD systems, the mode can be changed and will affect whether
the symlink will be traversed in file name resolution.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Symbolic-Links">Symbolic Links</a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
</p>
<p>Symbolic links can contain arbitrary strings; a <em>dangling symlink</em>
occurs when the string in the symlink does not resolve to a file.
There are no restrictions against creating dangling symbolic links.
There are trade-offs to using absolute or relative symlinks.  An
absolute symlink always points to the same file, even if the directory
containing the link is moved.  However, if the symlink is visible from
more than one machine (such as on a networked file system), the file
pointed to might not always be the same.  A relative symbolic link is
resolved in relation to the directory that contains the link, and is
often useful in referring to files on the same device without regards
to what name that device is mounted on when accessed via networked
machines.
</p>
<p>When creating a relative symlink in a different location than the
current directory, the resolution of the symlink will be different
than the resolution of the same string from the current directory.
Therefore, many users prefer to first change directories to the
location where the relative symlink will be created, so that
tab-completion or other file resolution will find the same target as
what will be placed in the symlink.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--backup[=<var>method</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbackup-4"></a>
<a name="index-VERSION_005fCONTROL-4"></a>
<a name="index-backups_002c-making-4"></a>
<p>See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
Make a backup of each file that would otherwise be overwritten or removed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-F</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002dF-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddirectory-2"></a>
<a name="index-hard-links-to-directories"></a>
<p>Allow users with appropriate privileges to attempt to make hard links
to directories.
However, note that this will probably fail due to
system restrictions, even for the super-user.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--force</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dforce-4"></a>
<p>Remove existing destination files.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--interactive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinteractive-3"></a>
<a name="index-prompting_002c-and-ln"></a>
<p>Prompt whether to remove existing destination files.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--logical</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlogical"></a>
<p>If <samp>-s</samp> is not in effect, and the source file is a symbolic
link, create the hard link to the file referred to by the symbolic
link, rather than the symbolic link itself.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-1"></a>
<p>Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a symbolic link to
a directory.  Instead, treat it as if it were a normal file.
</p>
