<p>When the destination is an actual directory (not a symlink to one),
there is no ambiguity.  The link is created in that directory.
But when the specified destination is a symlink to a directory,
there are two ways to treat the user&rsquo;s request.  <code>ln</code> can
treat the destination just as it would a normal directory and create
the link in it.  On the other hand, the destination can be viewed as a
non-directory&mdash;as the symlink itself.  In that case, <code>ln</code>
must delete or backup that symlink before creating the new link.
The default is to treat a destination that is a symlink to a directory
just like a directory.
</p>
<p>This option is weaker than the <samp>--no-target-directory</samp>
(<samp>-T</samp>) option, so it has no effect if both options are given.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--physical</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dphysical"></a>
<p>If <samp>-s</samp> is not in effect, and the source file is a symbolic
link, create the hard link to the symbolic link itself.  On platforms
where this is not supported by the kernel, this option creates a
symbolic link with identical contents; since symbolic link contents
cannot be edited, any file name resolution performed through either
link will be the same as if a hard link had been created.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--relative</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drelative"></a>
<p>Make symbolic links relative to the link location.
</p>
<p>Example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">ln -srv /a/file /tmp
'/tmp/file' -&gt; '../a/file'
</pre></div>

<p>Relative symbolic links are generated based on their canonicalized
containing directory, and canonicalized targets.  I.e., all symbolic
links in these file names will be resolved.
See <a href="#realpath-invocation">realpath invocation</a>, which gives greater control
over relative file name generation, as demonstrated in the following example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="verbatim">ln--relative() {
  test &quot;$1&quot; = --no-symlinks &amp;&amp; { nosym=$1; shift; }
  target=&quot;$1&quot;;
  test -d &quot;$2&quot; &amp;&amp; link=&quot;$2/.&quot; || link=&quot;$2&quot;
  rtarget=&quot;$(realpath $nosym -m &quot;$target&quot; \
              --relative-to &quot;$(dirname &quot;$link&quot;)&quot;)&quot;
  ln -s -v &quot;$rtarget&quot; &quot;$link&quot;
}
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--symbolic</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsymbolic"></a>
<p>Make symbolic links instead of hard links.  This option merely produces
an error message on systems that do not support symbolic links.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix-4"></a>
<p>Append <var>suffix</var> to each backup file made with <samp>-b</samp>.
See <a href="#Backup-options">Backup options</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--target-directory=<var>directory</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtarget_002ddirectory-4"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-9"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-8"></a>
<p>Specify the destination <var>directory</var>.
See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-target-directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dtarget_002ddirectory-4"></a>
<a name="index-target-directory-10"></a>
<a name="index-destination-directory-9"></a>
<p>Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a directory or a
symbolic link to a directory.  See <a href="#Target-directory">Target directory</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-8"></a>
<p>Print the name of each file after linking it successfully.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-hard-links-to-symbolic-links"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links-and-ln"></a>
<p>If <samp>-L</samp> and <samp>-P</samp> are both given, the last one takes
precedence.  If <samp>-s</samp> is also given, <samp>-L</samp> and <samp>-P</samp>
are silently ignored.  If neither option is given, then this
implementation defaults to <samp>-P</samp> if the system <code>link</code> supports
hard links to symbolic links (such as the GNU system), and <samp>-L</samp>
if <code>link</code> follows symbolic links (such as on BSD).
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">Bad Example:

# Create link ../a pointing to a in that directory.
# Not really useful because it points to itself.
ln -s a ..

Better Example:

# Change to the target before creating symlinks to avoid being confused.
cd ..
ln -s adir/a .

Bad Example:

# Hard coded file names don't move well.
ln -s $(pwd)/a /some/dir/

Better Example:

# Relative file names survive directory moves and also
# work across networked file systems.
ln -s afile anotherfile
ln -s ../adir/afile yetanotherfile
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="mkdir-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#mkfifo-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">mkfifo invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#ln-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">ln invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="mkdir_003a-Make-directories"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.3 <code>mkdir</code>: Make directories</h3>

<a name="index-mkdir"></a>
<a name="index-directories_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-creating-directories"></a>

<p><code>mkdir</code> creates directories with the specified names.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">mkdir [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>name</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><code>mkdir</code> creates each directory <var>name</var> in the order given.
It reports an error if <var>name</var> already exists, unless the
<samp>-p</samp> option is given and <var>name</var> is a directory.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m <var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--mode=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmode-1"></a>
<a name="index-modes-of-created-directories_002c-setting"></a>
<p>Set the file permission bits of created directories to <var>mode</var>,
which uses the same syntax as
in <code>chmod</code> and uses &lsquo;<samp>a=rwx</samp>&rsquo; (read, write and execute allowed for
everyone) for the point of the departure.  See <a href="#File-permissions">File permissions</a>.
</p>
<p>Normally the directory has the desired file mode bits at the moment it
is created.  As a GNU extension, <var>mode</var> may also mention
special mode bits, but in this case there may be a temporary window
during which the directory exists but its special mode bits are
incorrect.  See <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>, for how the
set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of directories are inherited unless
overridden in this way.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--parents</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dparents-1"></a>
<a name="index-parent-directories_002c-creating"></a>
<p>Make any missing parent directories for each argument, setting their
file permission bits to the umask modified by &lsquo;<samp>u+wx</samp>&rsquo;.  Ignore
existing parent directories, and do not change their file permission
bits.
</p>
<p>To set the file permission bits of any newly-created parent
directories to a value that includes &lsquo;<samp>u+wx</samp>&rsquo;, you can set the
umask before invoking <code>mkdir</code>.  For example, if the shell
command &lsquo;<samp>(umask u=rwx,go=rx; mkdir -p P/Q)</samp>&rsquo; creates the parent
<samp>P</samp> it sets the parent&rsquo;s permission bits to &lsquo;<samp>u=rwx,go=rx</samp>&rsquo;.
To set a parent&rsquo;s special mode bits as well, you can invoke
<code>chmod</code> after <code>mkdir</code>.  See <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>, for how the set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of
newly-created parent directories are inherited.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-9"></a>
<p>Print a message for each created directory.  This is most useful with
<samp>--parents</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context[=<var>context</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext-4"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context-2"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-5"></a>
<p>Without a specified <var>context</var>, adjust the SELinux security context according
to the system default type for destination files, similarly to the
<code>restorecon</code> command.
The long form of this option with a specific context specified,
will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a warning is
issued.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="mkfifo-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#mknod-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">mknod invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#mkdir-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">mkdir invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="mkfifo_003a-Make-FIFOs-_0028named-pipes_0029"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.4 <code>mkfifo</code>: Make FIFOs (named pipes)</h3>

<a name="index-mkfifo"></a>
<a name="index-FIFOs_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-named-pipes_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-creating-FIFOs-_0028named-pipes_0029"></a>

<p><code>mkfifo</code> creates FIFOs (also called <em>named pipes</em>) with the
specified names.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">mkfifo [<var>option</var>] <var>name</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>A <em>FIFO</em> is a special file type that permits independent processes
to communicate.  One process opens the FIFO file for writing, and
another for reading, after which data can flow as with the usual
anonymous pipe in shells or elsewhere.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m <var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--mode=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmode-2"></a>
<a name="index-modes-of-created-FIFOs_002c-setting"></a>
<p>Set the mode of created FIFOs to <var>mode</var>, which is symbolic as in
<code>chmod</code> and uses &lsquo;<samp>a=rw</samp>&rsquo; (read and write allowed for everyone)
for the point of departure.  <var>mode</var> should specify only file
permission bits.  See <a href="#File-permissions">File permissions</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context[=<var>context</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext-5"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context-3"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-6"></a>
<p>Without a specified <var>context</var>, adjust the SELinux security context according
to the system default type for destination files, similarly to the
<code>restorecon</code> command.
The long form of this option with a specific context specified,
will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a warning is
issued.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="mknod-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#readlink-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">readlink invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#mkfifo-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">mkfifo invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="mknod_003a-Make-block-or-character-special-files"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.5 <code>mknod</code>: Make block or character special files</h3>

<a name="index-mknod"></a>
<a name="index-block-special-files_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-character-special-files_002c-creating"></a>

<p><code>mknod</code> creates a FIFO, character special file, or block special
file with the specified name.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">mknod [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>name</var> <var>type</var> [<var>major</var> <var>minor</var>]
</pre></div>

<a name="index-special-files"></a>
<a name="index-block-special-files"></a>
<a name="index-character-special-files"></a>
<p>Unlike the phrase &ldquo;special file type&rdquo; above, the term <em>special
file</em> has a technical meaning on Unix: something that can generate or
receive data.  Usually this corresponds to a physical piece of hardware,
e.g., a printer or a disk.  (These files are typically created at
system-configuration time.)  The <code>mknod</code> command is what creates
files of this type.  Such devices can be read either a character at a
time or a &ldquo;block&rdquo; (many characters) at a time, hence we say there are
<em>block special</em> files and <em>character special</em> files.
</p>
<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>mknod</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>mknod</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env mknod &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<p>The arguments after <var>name</var> specify the type of file to make:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-p-for-FIFO-file"></a>
<p>for a FIFO
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-b-for-block-special-file"></a>
<p>for a block special file
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-c-for-character-special-file"></a>
<p>for a character special file
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>When making a block or character special file, the major and minor
device numbers must be given after the file type.
If a major or minor device number begins with &lsquo;<samp>0x</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>0X</samp>&rsquo;,
it is interpreted as hexadecimal; otherwise, if it begins with &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;,
as octal; otherwise, as decimal.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m <var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--mode=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmode-3"></a>
<p>Set the mode of created files to <var>mode</var>, which is symbolic as in
<code>chmod</code> and uses &lsquo;<samp>a=rw</samp>&rsquo; as the point of departure.
<var>mode</var> should specify only file permission bits.
See <a href="#File-permissions">File permissions</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context[=<var>context</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext-6"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context-4"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-7"></a>
<p>Without a specified <var>context</var>, adjust the SELinux security context according
to the system default type for destination files, similarly to the
<code>restorecon</code> command.
The long form of this option with a specific context specified,
will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a warning is
issued.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="readlink-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#rmdir-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">rmdir invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#mknod-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">mknod invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="readlink_003a-Print-value-of-a-symlink-or-canonical-file-name"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.6 <code>readlink</code>: Print value of a symlink or canonical file name</h3>

<a name="index-readlink"></a>
<a name="index-displaying-value-of-a-symbolic-link"></a>
<a name="index-canonical-file-name"></a>
<a name="index-canonicalize-a-file-name"></a>
<a name="index-realpath"></a>

<p><code>readlink</code> may work in one of two supported modes:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>Readlink mode</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd>
<p><code>readlink</code> outputs the value of the given symbolic links.
If <code>readlink</code> is invoked with an argument other than the name
of a symbolic link, it produces no output and exits with a nonzero exit code.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>Canonicalize mode</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd>
<p><code>readlink</code> outputs the absolute name of the given files which contain
no <samp>.</samp>, <samp>..</samp> components nor any repeated separators
(<samp>/</samp>) or symbolic links.  Note the <code>realpath</code> command is the
preferred command to use for canonicalization.  See <a href="#realpath-invocation">realpath invocation</a>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">readlink [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>By default, <code>readlink</code> operates in readlink mode.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--canonicalize</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize"></a>
<p>Activate canonicalize mode.
If any component of the file name except the last one is missing or unavailable,
<code>readlink</code> produces no output and exits with a nonzero exit
code.  A trailing slash is ignored.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--canonicalize-existing</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dexisting"></a>
<p>Activate canonicalize mode.
If any component is missing or unavailable, <code>readlink</code> produces
no output and exits with a nonzero exit code.  A trailing slash
requires that the name resolve to a directory.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--canonicalize-missing</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dmissing"></a>
<p>Activate canonicalize mode.
If any component is missing or unavailable, <code>readlink</code> treats it
as a directory.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-newline</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dnewline"></a>
<p>Do not print the output delimiter, when a single <var>file</var> is specified.
Print a warning if specified along with multiple <var>file</var>s.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002dq-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-4"></a>
<p>Suppress most error messages.  On by default.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-10"></a>
<p>Report error messages.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero-2"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-1"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>The <code>readlink</code> utility first appeared in OpenBSD 2.1.
</p>
<p>The <code>realpath</code> command without options, operates like
<code>readlink</code> in canonicalize mode.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="rmdir-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#unlink-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">unlink invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#readlink-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">readlink invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="rmdir_003a-Remove-empty-directories"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.7 <code>rmdir</code>: Remove empty directories</h3>

<a name="index-rmdir"></a>
<a name="index-removing-empty-directories"></a>
<a name="index-directories_002c-removing-empty"></a>

<p><code>rmdir</code> removes empty directories.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">rmdir [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>directory</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If any <var>directory</var> argument does not refer to an existing empty
directory, it is an error.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-fail-on-non-empty</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dfail_002don_002dnon_002dempty"></a>
<a name="index-directory-deletion_002c-ignoring-failures"></a>
<p>Ignore each failure to remove a directory that is solely because
the directory is non-empty.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--parents</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dparents-2"></a>
<a name="index-parent-directories_002c-removing"></a>
<p>Remove <var>directory</var>, then try to remove each component of <var>directory</var>.
So, for example, &lsquo;<samp>rmdir -p a/b/c</samp>&rsquo; is similar to &lsquo;<samp>rmdir a/b/c a/b a</samp>&rsquo;.
As such, it fails if any of those directories turns out not to be empty.
Use the <samp>--ignore-fail-on-non-empty</samp> option to make it so such
a failure does not evoke a diagnostic and does not cause <code>rmdir</code> to
exit unsuccessfully.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-11"></a>
<a name="index-directory-deletion_002c-reporting"></a>
<p>Give a diagnostic for each successful removal.
<var>directory</var> is removed.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>See <a href="#rm-invocation">rm invocation</a>, for how to remove non-empty directories (recursively).
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="unlink-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#rmdir-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">rmdir invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="u" rel="up">Special file types</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="unlink_003a-Remove-files-via-the-unlink-syscall"></a>
<h3 class="section">12.8 <code>unlink</code>: Remove files via the unlink syscall</h3>

<a name="index-unlink"></a>
<a name="index-removing-files-or-directories-_0028via-the-unlink-syscall_0029"></a>

<p><code>unlink</code> deletes a single specified file name.
It is a minimalist interface to the system-provided
<code>unlink</code> function.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Deleting-Files">Deleting Files</a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.  Synopsis:
It avoids the bells and whistles of the more commonly-used
<code>rm</code> command (see <a href="#rm-invocation">rm invocation</a>).
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">unlink <var>filename</var>
</pre></div>

<p>On some systems <code>unlink</code> can be used to delete the name of a
directory.  On others, it can be used that way only by a privileged user.
In the GNU system <code>unlink</code> can never delete the name of a directory.
</p>
<p>The <code>unlink</code> command honors the <samp>--help</samp> and
<samp>--version</samp> options.  To remove a file whose name begins with
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, prefix the name with &lsquo;<samp>./</samp>&rsquo;, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>unlink ./--help</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Changing-file-attributes"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Disk-usage" accesskey="n" rel="next">Disk usage</a>, Previous: <a href="#Special-file-types" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Special file types</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Changing-file-attributes-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">13 Changing file attributes</h2>

<a name="index-changing-file-attributes"></a>
<a name="index-file-attributes_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-attributes_002c-file"></a>

<p>A file is not merely its contents, a name, and a file type
(see <a href="#Special-file-types">Special file types</a>).  A file also has an owner (a user ID), a
group (a group ID), permissions (what the owner can do with the file,
what people in the group can do, and what everyone else can do), various
timestamps, and other information.  Collectively, we call these a file&rsquo;s
<em>attributes</em>.
</p>
<p>These commands change file attributes.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#chown-invocation" accesskey="1">chown invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Change file owners and groups.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#chgrp-invocation" accesskey="2">chgrp invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Change file groups.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#chmod-invocation" accesskey="3">chmod invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Change access permissions.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#touch-invocation" accesskey="4">touch invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Change file timestamps.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="chown-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#chgrp-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">chgrp invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Changing-file-attributes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Changing file attributes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="chown_003a-Change-file-owner-and-group"></a>
<h3 class="section">13.1 <code>chown</code>: Change file owner and group</h3>

<a name="index-chown"></a>
<a name="index-file-ownership_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-group-ownership_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-changing-file-ownership"></a>
<a name="index-changing-group-ownership"></a>

<p><code>chown</code> changes the user and/or group ownership of each given <var>file</var>
to <var>new-owner</var> or to the user and group of an existing reference file.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">chown [<var>option</var>]&hellip; {<var>new-owner</var> | --reference=<var>ref_file</var>} <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If used, <var>new-owner</var> specifies the new owner and/or group as follows
(with no embedded white space):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">[<var>owner</var>] [ : [<var>group</var>] ]
</pre></div>

<p>Specifically:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt><var>owner</var></dt>
<dd><p>If only an <var>owner</var> (a user name or numeric user ID) is given, that
user is made the owner of each given file, and the files&rsquo; group is not
changed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><var>owner&lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;group</var></dt>
<dd><p>If the <var>owner</var> is followed by a colon and a <var>group</var> (a
group name or numeric group ID), with no spaces between them, the group
ownership of the files is changed as well (to <var>group</var>).
</p>
</dd>
<dt><var>owner&lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;</var></dt>
<dd><p>If a colon but no group name follows <var>owner</var>, that user is
made the owner of the files and the group of the files is changed to
<var>owner</var>&rsquo;s login group.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><var>&lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;group</var></dt>
<dd><p>If the colon and following <var>group</var> are given, but the owner
is omitted, only the group of the files is changed; in this case,
<code>chown</code> performs the same function as <code>chgrp</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><var>&lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;</var></dt>
<dd><p>If only a colon is given, or if <var>new-owner</var> is empty, neither the
owner nor the group is changed.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>If <var>owner</var> or <var>group</var> is intended to represent a numeric user
or group ID, then you may specify it with a leading &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;.
See <a href="#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs">Disambiguating names and IDs</a>.
</p>
<p>Some older scripts may still use &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; in place of the &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo; separator.
POSIX 1003.1-2001 (see <a href="#Standards-conformance">Standards conformance</a>) does not
require support for that, but for backward compatibility GNU
<code>chown</code> supports &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; so long as no ambiguity results.
New scripts should avoid the use of &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; because it is not
portable, and because it has undesirable results if the entire
<var>owner&lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;group</var> happens to identify a user whose name
contains &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>It is system dependent whether a user can change the group to an arbitrary one,
or the more portable behavior of being restricted to setting a group of
which the user is a member.
</p>
<p>The <code>chown</code> command sometimes clears the set-user-ID or
set-group-ID permission bits.  This behavior depends on the policy and
functionality of the underlying <code>chown</code> system call, which may
make system-dependent file mode modifications outside the control of
the <code>chown</code> command.  For example, the <code>chown</code> command
might not affect those bits when invoked by a user with appropriate
privileges, or when the
bits signify some function other than executable permission (e.g.,
mandatory locking).
When in doubt, check the underlying system behavior.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--changes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dchanges"></a>
<a name="index-changed-owners_002c-verbosely-describing"></a>
<p>Verbosely describe the action for each <var>file</var> whose ownership
actually changes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent-4"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-5"></a>
<a name="index-error-messages_002c-omitting"></a>
<p>Do not print error messages about files whose ownership cannot be
changed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--from=<var>old-owner</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfrom"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner"></a>
<p>Change a <var>file</var>&rsquo;s ownership only if it has current attributes specified
by <var>old-owner</var>.  <var>old-owner</var> has the same form as <var>new-owner</var>
described above.
This option is useful primarily from a security standpoint in that
it narrows considerably the window of potential abuse.
For example, to reflect a user ID numbering change for one user&rsquo;s files
without an option like this, <code>root</code> might run
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">find / -owner OLDUSER -print0 | xargs -0 chown -h NEWUSER
</pre></div>

<p>But that is dangerous because the interval between when the <code>find</code>
tests the existing file&rsquo;s owner and when the <code>chown</code> is actually run
may be quite large.
One way to narrow the gap would be to invoke chown for each file
as it is found:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">find / -owner OLDUSER -exec chown -h NEWUSER {} \;
</pre></div>

<p>But that is very slow if there are many affected files.
With this option, it is safer (the gap is narrower still)
though still not perfect:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">chown -h -R --from=OLDUSER NEWUSER /
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002ddereference-2"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner-1"></a>
<a name="index-lchown"></a>
<p>Do not act on symbolic links themselves but rather on what they point to.
This is the default when not operating recursively.
</p>
<p>Combining this dereferencing option with the <samp>--recursive</samp> option
may create a security risk:
During the traversal of the directory tree, an attacker may be able to
introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when the tool reaches that,
the operation will be performed on the target of that symlink,
possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.
</p>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-2"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner-2"></a>
<a name="index-lchown-1"></a>
<p>Act on symbolic links themselves instead of what they point to.
This mode relies on the <code>lchown</code> system call.
On systems that do not provide the <code>lchown</code> system call,
<code>chown</code> fails when a file specified on the command line
is a symbolic link.
By default, no diagnostic is issued for symbolic links encountered
during a recursive traversal, but see <samp>--verbose</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot-1"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-disallow-recursive-modification"></a>
<p>Fail upon any attempt to recursively change the root directory, <samp>/</samp>.
Without <samp>--recursive</samp>, this option has no effect.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot-1"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-allow-recursive-modification"></a>
<p>Cancel the effect of any preceding <samp>--preserve-root</samp> option.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reference=<var>ref_file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dreference"></a>
<p>Change the user and group of each <var>file</var> to be the same as those of
<var>ref_file</var>.  If <var>ref_file</var> is a symbolic link, do not use the
user and group of the symbolic link, but rather those of the file it
refers to.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-12"></a>
<p>Output a diagnostic for every file processed.
If a symbolic link is encountered during a recursive traversal
on a system without the <code>lchown</code> system call, and <samp>--no-dereference</samp>
is in effect, then issue a diagnostic saying neither the symbolic link nor
its referent is being changed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--recursive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drecursive-3"></a>
<a name="index-recursively-changing-file-ownership"></a>
<p>Recursively change ownership of directories and their contents.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-3"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-if-on-the-command-line-1"></a>
<p>If <samp>--recursive</samp> (<samp>-R</samp>) is specified and
a command line argument is a symbolic link to a directory, traverse it.
See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-5"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-each-that-is-encountered-1"></a>
<p>In a recursive traversal, traverse every symbolic link to a directory
that is encountered.
</p>
<p>Combining this dereferencing option with the <samp>--recursive</samp> option
may create a security risk:
During the traversal of the directory tree, an attacker may be able to
introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when the tool reaches that,
the operation will be performed on the target of that symlink,
possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.
</p>
<p>See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-3"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-never-traverse-1"></a>
<p>Do not traverse any symbolic links.
This is the default if none of <samp>-H</samp>, <samp>-L</samp>,
or <samp>-P</samp> is specified.
See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Change the owner of /u to &quot;root&quot;.
chown root /u

# Likewise, but also change its group to &quot;staff&quot;.
chown root:staff /u

# Change the owner of /u and subfiles to &quot;root&quot;.
chown -hR root /u
</pre></div>

<a name="chgrp_003a-Change-group-ownership"></a>
<h3 class="section">13.2 <code>chgrp</code>: Change group ownership</h3>

<a name="index-chgrp"></a>
<a name="index-group-ownership_002c-changing-1"></a>
<a name="index-changing-group-ownership-1"></a>

<p><code>chgrp</code> changes the group ownership of each given <var>file</var>
to <var>group</var> (which can be either a group name or a numeric group ID)
or to the group of an existing reference file.  See <a href="#chown-invocation">chown invocation</a>.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">chgrp [<var>option</var>]&hellip; {<var>group</var> | --reference=<var>ref_file</var>} <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If <var>group</var> is intended to represent a
numeric group ID, then you may specify it with a leading &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;.
See <a href="#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs">Disambiguating names and IDs</a>.
</p>
<p>It is system dependent whether a user can change the group to an arbitrary one,
or the more portable behavior of being restricted to setting a group of
which the user is a member.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--changes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dchanges-1"></a>
<a name="index-changed-files_002c-verbosely-describing"></a>
<p>Verbosely describe the action for each <var>file</var> whose group actually
changes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-6"></a>
<a name="index-error-messages_002c-omitting-1"></a>
<p>Do not print error messages about files whose group cannot be
changed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002ddereference-3"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner-3"></a>
<a name="index-lchown-2"></a>
<p>Do not act on symbolic links themselves but rather on what they point to.
This is the default when not operating recursively.
</p>
<p>Combining this dereferencing option with the <samp>--recursive</samp> option
may create a security risk:
During the traversal of the directory tree, an attacker may be able to
introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when the tool reaches that,
the operation will be performed on the target of that symlink,
possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.
</p>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-3"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-group"></a>
<a name="index-lchown-3"></a>
<p>Act on symbolic links themselves instead of what they point to.
This mode relies on the <code>lchown</code> system call.
On systems that do not provide the <code>lchown</code> system call,
<code>chgrp</code> fails when a file specified on the command line
is a symbolic link.
By default, no diagnostic is issued for symbolic links encountered
during a recursive traversal, but see <samp>--verbose</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot-2"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-disallow-recursive-modification-1"></a>
<p>Fail upon any attempt to recursively change the root directory, <samp>/</samp>.
Without <samp>--recursive</samp>, this option has no effect.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot-2"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-allow-recursive-modification-1"></a>
<p>Cancel the effect of any preceding <samp>--preserve-root</samp> option.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reference=<var>ref_file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dreference-1"></a>
<p>Change the group of each <var>file</var> to be the same as that of
<var>ref_file</var>.  If <var>ref_file</var> is a symbolic link, do not use the
group of the symbolic link, but rather that of the file it refers to.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-13"></a>
<p>Output a diagnostic for every file processed.
If a symbolic link is encountered during a recursive traversal
on a system without the <code>lchown</code> system call, and <samp>--no-dereference</samp>
is in effect, then issue a diagnostic saying neither the symbolic link nor
its referent is being changed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--recursive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drecursive-4"></a>
<a name="index-recursively-changing-group-ownership"></a>
<p>Recursively change the group ownership of directories and their contents.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-4"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-if-on-the-command-line-2"></a>
<p>If <samp>--recursive</samp> (<samp>-R</samp>) is specified and
a command line argument is a symbolic link to a directory, traverse it.
See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-6"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-each-that-is-encountered-2"></a>
<p>In a recursive traversal, traverse every symbolic link to a directory
that is encountered.
</p>
<p>Combining this dereferencing option with the <samp>--recursive</samp> option
may create a security risk:
During the traversal of the directory tree, an attacker may be able to
introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when the tool reaches that,
the operation will be performed on the target of that symlink,
possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.
</p>
<p>See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-4"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-never-traverse-2"></a>
<p>Do not traverse any symbolic links.
This is the default if none of <samp>-H</samp>, <samp>-L</samp>,
or <samp>-P</samp> is specified.
See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Change the group of /u to &quot;staff&quot;.
chgrp staff /u

# Change the group of /u and subfiles to &quot;staff&quot;.
chgrp -hR staff /u
</pre></div>
