</div>
<a name="chmod_003a-Change-access-permissions"></a>
<h3 class="section">13.3 <code>chmod</code>: Change access permissions</h3>

<a name="index-chmod"></a>
<a name="index-changing-access-permissions"></a>
<a name="index-access-permissions_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-permissions_002c-changing-access"></a>

<p><code>chmod</code> changes the access permissions of the named files.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">chmod [<var>option</var>]&hellip; {<var>mode</var> | --reference=<var>ref_file</var>} <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-permissions-of"></a>
<p><code>chmod</code> never changes the permissions of symbolic links, since
the <code>chmod</code> system call cannot change their permissions.
This is not a problem since the permissions of symbolic links are
never used.  However, for each symbolic link listed on the command
line, <code>chmod</code> changes the permissions of the pointed-to file.
In contrast, <code>chmod</code> ignores symbolic links encountered during
recursive directory traversals.
</p>
<p>Only a process whose effective user ID matches the user ID of the file,
or a process with appropriate privileges, is permitted to change the
file mode bits of a file.
</p>
<p>A successful use of <code>chmod</code> clears the set-group-ID bit of a
regular file if the file&rsquo;s group ID does not match the user&rsquo;s
effective group ID or one of the user&rsquo;s supplementary group IDs,
unless the user has appropriate privileges.  Additional restrictions
may cause the set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of <var>mode</var> or
<var>ref_file</var> to be ignored.  This behavior depends on the policy and
functionality of the underlying <code>chmod</code> system call.  When in
doubt, check the underlying system behavior.
</p>
<p>If used, <var>mode</var> specifies the new file mode bits.
For details, see the section on <a href="#File-permissions">File permissions</a>.
If you really want <var>mode</var> to have a leading &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, you should
use <samp>--</samp> first, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>chmod -- -w file</samp>&rsquo;.  Typically,
though, &lsquo;<samp>chmod a-w file</samp>&rsquo; is preferable, and <code>chmod -w
file</code> (without the <samp>--</samp>) complains if it behaves differently
from what &lsquo;<samp>chmod a-w file</samp>&rsquo; would do.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--changes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dchanges-2"></a>
<p>Verbosely describe the action for each <var>file</var> whose permissions
actually changes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-7"></a>
<a name="index-error-messages_002c-omitting-2"></a>
<p>Do not print error messages about files whose permissions cannot be
changed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot-3"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-disallow-recursive-modification-2"></a>
<p>Fail upon any attempt to recursively change the root directory, <samp>/</samp>.
Without <samp>--recursive</samp>, this option has no effect.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot-3"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-allow-recursive-modification-2"></a>
<p>Cancel the effect of any preceding <samp>--preserve-root</samp> option.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-14"></a>
<p>Verbosely describe the action or non-action taken for every <var>file</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reference=<var>ref_file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dreference-2"></a>
<p>Change the mode of each <var>file</var> to be the same as that of <var>ref_file</var>.
See <a href="#File-permissions">File permissions</a>.
If <var>ref_file</var> is a symbolic link, do not use the mode
of the symbolic link, but rather that of the file it refers to.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--recursive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drecursive-5"></a>
<a name="index-recursively-changing-access-permissions"></a>
<p>Recursively change permissions of directories and their contents.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Examples:
</p>
<div class="smallexample">
<pre class="smallexample"># Change file permissions of FOO to be world readable
# and user writable, with no other permissions.
chmod 644 foo
chmod a=r,u+w foo

# Add user and group execute permissions to FOO.
chmod +110 file
chmod ug+x file

# Set file permissions of DIR and subsidiary files to
# be the umask default, assuming execute permissions for
# directories and for files already executable.
chmod -R a=,+rwX dir
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="touch-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#chmod-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">chmod invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Changing-file-attributes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Changing file attributes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="touch_003a-Change-file-timestamps"></a>
<h3 class="section">13.4 <code>touch</code>: Change file timestamps</h3>

<a name="index-touch"></a>
<a name="index-changing-file-timestamps"></a>
<a name="index-file-timestamps_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-timestamps_002c-changing-file"></a>

<p><code>touch</code> changes the access and/or modification timestamps of the
specified files.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">touch [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-empty-files_002c-creating"></a>
<p>Any <var>file</var> argument that does not exist is created empty, unless
option <samp>--no-create</samp> (<samp>-c</samp>) or <samp>--no-dereference</samp>
(<samp>-h</samp>) was in effect.
</p>
<p>A <var>file</var> argument string of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; is handled specially and
causes <code>touch</code> to change the times of the file associated with
standard output.
</p>
<p>By default, <code>touch</code> sets file timestamps to the current time.
Because <code>touch</code> acts on its operands left to right, the
resulting timestamps of earlier and later operands may disagree.
</p>
<a name="index-permissions_002c-for-changing-file-timestamps"></a>
<p>When setting file timestamps to the current time, <code>touch</code> can
change the timestamps for files that the user does not own but has
write permission for.  Otherwise, the user must own the files.  Some
older systems have a further restriction: the user must own the files
unless both the access and modification timestamps are being set to the
current time.
</p>
<p>The <code>touch</code> command cannot set a file&rsquo;s status change timestamp to
a user-specified value, and cannot change the file&rsquo;s birth time (if
supported) at all.  Also, <code>touch</code> has issues similar to those
affecting all programs that update file timestamps.  For example,
<code>touch</code> may set a file&rsquo;s timestamp to a value that differs
slightly from the requested time.  See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
<a name="index-TZ-2"></a>
<p>Timestamps assume the time zone rules specified by the <code>TZ</code>
environment variable, or by the system default rules if <code>TZ</code> is
not set.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable">Specifying the Time Zone with <code>TZ</code></a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
You can avoid ambiguities during
daylight saving transitions by using UTC timestamps.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=atime</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=access</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=use</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtime-2"></a>
<a name="index-atime_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-access-time_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-use-time_002c-changing"></a>
<p>Change the access timestamp only.  See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-create</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dcreate"></a>
<p>Do not warn about or create files that do not exist.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>time</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--date=<var>time</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddate"></a>
<a name="index-time"></a>
<p>Use <var>time</var> instead of the current time.  It can contain month names,
time zones, &lsquo;<samp>am</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>pm</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>yesterday</samp>&rsquo;, etc.  For
example, <samp>--date=&quot;2004-02-27 14:19:13.489392193 +0530&quot;</samp>
specifies the instant of time that is 489,392,193 nanoseconds after
February 27, 2004 at 2:19:13 PM in a time zone that is 5 hours and 30
minutes east of UTC.  See <a href="#Date-input-formats">Date input formats</a>.
File systems that do not support high-resolution timestamps
silently ignore any excess precision here.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-19"></a>
<a name="index-BSD-touch-compatibility"></a>
<p>Ignored; for compatibility with BSD versions of <code>touch</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-4"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-time"></a>
<a name="index-lutimes"></a>
<p>Attempt to change the timestamps of a symbolic link, rather than what
the link refers to.  When using this option, empty files are not
created, but option <samp>-c</samp> must also be used to avoid warning
about files that do not exist.  Not all systems support changing the
timestamps of symlinks, since underlying system support for this
action was not required until POSIX 2008.  Also, on some
systems, the mere act of examining a symbolic link changes the access
timestamp, such that only changes to the modification timestamp will persist
long enough to be observable.  When coupled with option <samp>-r</samp>, a
reference timestamp is taken from a symbolic link rather than the file
it refers to.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=mtime</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=modify</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtime-3"></a>
<a name="index-mtime_002c-changing"></a>
<a name="index-modify-time_002c-changing"></a>
<p>Change the modification timestamp only.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reference=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dreference-3"></a>
<p>Use the times of the reference <var>file</var> instead of the current time.
If this option is combined with the <samp>--date=<var>time</var></samp>
(<samp>-d <var>time</var></samp>) option, the reference <var>file</var>&rsquo;s time is
the origin for any relative <var>time</var>s given, but is otherwise ignored.
For example, &lsquo;<samp>-r foo -d '-5 seconds'</samp>&rsquo; specifies a timestamp
equal to five seconds before the corresponding timestamp for <samp>foo</samp>.
If <var>file</var> is a symbolic link, the reference timestamp is taken
from the target of the symlink, unless <samp>-h</samp> was also in effect.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t [[<var>cc</var>]<var>yy</var>]<var>mmddhhmm</var>[.<var>ss</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-leap-seconds"></a>
<p>Use the argument (optional four-digit or two-digit years, months,
days, hours, minutes, optional seconds) instead of the current time.
If the year is specified with only two digits, then <var>cc</var>
is 20 for years in the range 0 &hellip; 68, and 19 for years in
69 &hellip; 99.  If no digits of the year are specified,
the argument is interpreted as a date in the current year.
On the atypical systems that support leap seconds, <var>ss</var> may be
&lsquo;<samp>60</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-_005fPOSIX2_005fVERSION-4"></a>
<p>On systems predating POSIX 1003.1-2001,
<code>touch</code> supports an obsolete syntax, as follows.
If no timestamp is given with any of the <samp>-d</samp>, <samp>-r</samp>, or
<samp>-t</samp> options, and if there are two or more <var>file</var>s and the
first <var>file</var> is of the form &lsquo;<samp><var>mmddhhmm</var>[<var>yy</var>]</samp>&rsquo; and this
would be a valid argument to the <samp>-t</samp> option (if the <var>yy</var>, if
any, were moved to the front), and if the represented year
is in the range 1969&ndash;1999, that argument is interpreted as the time
for the other files instead of as a file name.
Although this obsolete behavior can be controlled with the
<code>_POSIX2_VERSION</code> environment variable (see <a href="#Standards-conformance">Standards conformance</a>), portable scripts should avoid commands whose
behavior depends on this variable.
For example, use &lsquo;<samp>touch ./12312359 main.c</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>touch -t
12312359 main.c</samp>&rsquo; rather than the ambiguous &lsquo;<samp>touch 12312359 main.c</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Disk-usage"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Printing-text" accesskey="n" rel="next">Printing text</a>, Previous: <a href="#Changing-file-attributes" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Changing file attributes</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Disk-usage-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">14 Disk usage</h2>

<a name="index-disk-usage"></a>

<p>No disk can hold an infinite amount of data.  These commands report
how much disk storage is in use or available, report other file and
file status information, and write buffers to disk.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#df-invocation" accesskey="1">df invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Report file system disk space usage.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#du-invocation" accesskey="2">du invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Estimate file space usage.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#stat-invocation" accesskey="3">stat invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Report file or file system status.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#sync-invocation" accesskey="4">sync invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Synchronize cached writes to persistent storage.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#truncate-invocation" accesskey="5">truncate invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Shrink or extend the size of a file.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="df-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#du-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">du invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Disk-usage" accesskey="u" rel="up">Disk usage</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="df_003a-Report-file-system-disk-space-usage"></a>
<h3 class="section">14.1 <code>df</code>: Report file system disk space usage</h3>

<a name="index-df"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-disk-usage"></a>
<a name="index-disk-usage-by-file-system"></a>

<p><code>df</code> reports the amount of disk space used and available on
file systems.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">df [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>With no arguments, <code>df</code> reports the space used and available on all
currently mounted file systems (of all types).  Otherwise, <code>df</code>
reports on the file system containing each argument <var>file</var>.
</p>
<p>Normally the disk space is printed in units of
1024 bytes, but this can be overridden (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
Non-integer quantities are rounded up to the next higher unit.
</p>
<p>For bind mounts and without arguments, <code>df</code> only outputs the statistics
for that device with the shortest mount point name in the list of file systems
(<var>mtab</var>), i.e., it hides duplicate entries, unless the <samp>-a</samp> option is
specified.
</p>
<p>With the same logic, <code>df</code> elides a mount entry of a dummy pseudo device
if there is another mount entry of a real block device for that mount point with
the same device number, e.g. the early-boot pseudo file system &lsquo;<samp>rootfs</samp>&rsquo; is
not shown per default when already the real root device has been mounted.
</p>
<a name="index-disk-device-file"></a>
<a name="index-device-file_002c-disk"></a>
<p>If an argument <var>file</var> resolves to a special file containing
a mounted file system, <code>df</code> shows the space available on that
file system rather than on the file system containing the device node.
GNU <code>df</code> does not attempt to determine the disk usage
on unmounted file systems, because on most kinds of systems doing so
requires extremely nonportable intimate knowledge of file system structures.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall-2"></a>
<a name="index-ignore-file-systems"></a>
<p>Include in the listing dummy, duplicate, or inaccessible file systems, which
are omitted by default.  Dummy file systems are typically special purpose
pseudo file systems such as &lsquo;<samp>/proc</samp>&rsquo;, with no associated storage.
Duplicate file systems are local or remote file systems that are mounted
at separate locations in the local file hierarchy, or bind mounted locations.
Inaccessible file systems are those which are mounted but subsequently
over-mounted by another file system at that point, or otherwise inaccessible
due to permissions of the mount point etc.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-B <var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--block-size=<var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dB-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dblock_002dsize-1"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-sizes"></a>
<p>Scale sizes by <var>size</var> before printing them (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
For example, <samp>-BG</samp> prints sizes in units of 1,073,741,824 bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--human-readable</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhuman_002dreadable-2"></a>
<a name="index-human_002dreadable-output-2"></a>
<p>Append a size letter to each size, such as &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; for mebibytes.
Powers of 1024 are used, not 1000; &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; stands for 1,048,576 bytes.
This option is equivalent to <samp>--block-size=human-readable</samp>.
Use the <samp>--si</samp> option if you prefer powers of 1000.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-5"></a>
<p>Equivalent to <samp>--si</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--inodes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinodes"></a>
<a name="index-inode-usage"></a>
<p>List inode usage information instead of block usage.  An inode (short
for index node) contains information about a file such as its owner,
permissions, timestamps, and location on the disk.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-k</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dk-4"></a>
<a name="index-kibibytes-for-file-system-sizes"></a>
<p>Print sizes in 1024-byte blocks, overriding the default block size
(see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
This option is equivalent to <samp>--block-size=1K</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--local</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlocal"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-types_002c-limiting-output-to-certain"></a>
<p>Limit the listing to local file systems.  By default, remote file systems
are also listed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-sync</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dsync"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-space_002c-retrieving-old-data-more-quickly"></a>
<p>Do not invoke the <code>sync</code> system call before getting any usage data.
This may make <code>df</code> run significantly faster on systems with many
disks, but on some systems (notably SunOS) the results may be slightly
out of date.  This is the default.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output[=<var>field_list</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002doutput-2"></a>
<p>Use the output format defined by <var>field_list</var>, or print all fields if
<var>field_list</var> is omitted.  In the latter case, the order of the columns
conforms to the order of the field descriptions below.
</p>
<p>The use of the <samp>--output</samp> together with each of the options <samp>-i</samp>,
<samp>-P</samp>, and <samp>-T</samp> is mutually exclusive.
</p>
<p>FIELD_LIST is a comma-separated list of columns to be included in <code>df</code>&rsquo;s
output and therefore effectively controls the order of output columns.
Each field can thus be used at the place of choice, but yet must only be
used once.
</p>
<p>Valid field names in the <var>field_list</var> are:
</p><dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>source</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>The source of the mount point, usually a device.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>fstype</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>File system type.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>itotal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Total number of inodes.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iused</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Number of used inodes.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iavail</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Number of available inodes.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ipcent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Percentage of <var>iused</var> divided by <var>itotal</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>size</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Total number of blocks.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>used</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Number of used blocks.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>avail</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Number of available blocks.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>pcent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Percentage of <var>used</var> divided by <var>size</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>file</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>The file name if specified on the command line.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>target</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>The mount point.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>The fields for block and inodes statistics are affected by the scaling
options like <samp>-h</samp> as usual.
</p>
<p>The definition of the <var>field_list</var> can even be split among several
<samp>--output</samp> uses.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/bin/sh
# Print the TARGET (i.e., the mount point) along with their percentage
# statistic regarding the blocks and the inodes.
df --out=target --output=pcent,ipcent

# Print all available fields.
df --o
</pre></div>


</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--portability</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dportability"></a>
<a name="index-one_002dline-output-format"></a>
<a name="index-POSIX-output-format"></a>
<a name="index-portable-output-format"></a>
<a name="index-output-format_002c-portable"></a>
<p>Use the POSIX output format.  This is like the default format except
for the following:
</p>
<ol>
<li> The information about each file system is always printed on exactly
one line; a mount device is never put on a line by itself.  This means
that if the mount device name is more than 20 characters long (e.g., for
some network mounts), the columns are misaligned.

</li><li> The labels in the header output line are changed to conform to POSIX.

</li><li> The default block size and output format are unaffected by the
<code>DF_BLOCK_SIZE</code>, <code>BLOCK_SIZE</code> and <code>BLOCKSIZE</code> environment
variables.  However, the default block size is still affected by
<code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code>: it is 512 if <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> is set, 1024
otherwise.  See <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>.
</li></ol>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--si</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsi-2"></a>
<a name="index-SI-output-2"></a>
<p>Append an SI-style abbreviation to each size, such as &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; for
megabytes.  Powers of 1000 are used, not 1024; &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; stands for
1,000,000 bytes.  This option is equivalent to
<samp>--block-size=si</samp>.  Use the <samp>-h</samp> or
<samp>--human-readable</samp> option if
you prefer powers of 1024.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--sync</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsync"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-space_002c-retrieving-current-data-more-slowly"></a>
<p>Invoke the <code>sync</code> system call before getting any usage data.  On
some systems (notably SunOS), doing this yields more up to date results,
but in general this option makes <code>df</code> much slower, especially when
there are many or very busy file systems.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--total</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtotal"></a>
<a name="index-grand-total-of-disk-size_002c-usage-and-available-space"></a>
<p>Print a grand total of all arguments after all arguments have
been processed.  This can be used to find out the total disk size, usage
and available space of all listed devices.  If no arguments are specified
df will try harder to elide file systems insignificant to the total
available space, by suppressing duplicate remote file systems.
</p>
<p>For the grand total line, <code>df</code> prints &lsquo;<samp>&quot;total&quot;</samp>&rsquo; into the
<var>source</var> column, and &lsquo;<samp>&quot;-&quot;</samp>&rsquo; into the <var>target</var> column.
If there is no <var>source</var> column (see <samp>--output</samp>), then
<code>df</code> prints &lsquo;<samp>&quot;total&quot;</samp>&rsquo; into the <var>target</var> column,
if present.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>fstype</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--type=<var>fstype</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtype"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-types_002c-limiting-output-to-certain-1"></a>
<p>Limit the listing to file systems of type <var>fstype</var>.  Multiple
file system types can be specified by giving multiple <samp>-t</samp> options.
By default, nothing is omitted.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--print-type</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dT-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dprint_002dtype"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-types_002c-printing"></a>
<p>Print each file system&rsquo;s type.  The types printed here are the same ones
you can include or exclude with <samp>-t</samp> and <samp>-x</samp>.  The particular
types printed are whatever is supported by the system.  Here are some of
the common names (this list is certainly not exhaustive):
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nfs</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-NFS-file-system-type"></a>
<p>An NFS file system, i.e., one mounted over a network from another
machine.  This is the one type name which seems to be used uniformly by
all systems.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ext2<span class="roman">, </span>ext3<span class="roman">, </span>ext4<span class="roman">, </span>xfs<span class="roman">, </span>btrfs&hellip;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-Linux-file-system-types"></a>
<a name="index-local-file-system-types"></a>
<a name="index-ext2-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-ext3-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-ext4-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-xfs-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-btrfs-file-system-type"></a>
<p>A file system on a locally-mounted hard disk.  (The system might even
support more than one type here; Linux does.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iso9660<span class="roman">, </span>cdfs</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-CD_002dROM-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-DVD-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-ISO9660-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-iso9660-file-system-type"></a>
<a name="index-cdfs-file-system-type"></a>
<p>A file system on a CD or DVD drive.  HP-UX uses &lsquo;<samp>cdfs</samp>&rsquo;, most other
systems use &lsquo;<samp>iso9660</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ntfs<span class="roman">,</span>fat</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-NTFS-file-system"></a>
<a name="index-DOS-file-system"></a>
<a name="index-MS_002dDOS-file-system"></a>
<a name="index-MS_002dWindows-file-system"></a>
<a name="index-ntfs-file-system-file"></a>
<a name="index-fat-file-system-file"></a>
<p>File systems used by MS-Windows / MS-DOS.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x <var>fstype</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--exclude-type=<var>fstype</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dexclude_002dtype"></a>
<p>Limit the listing to file systems not of type <var>fstype</var>.
Multiple file system types can be eliminated by giving multiple
<samp>-x</samp> options.  By default, no file system types are omitted.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Ignored; for compatibility with System V versions of <code>df</code>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p><code>df</code> is installed only on systems that have usable mount tables,
so portable scripts should not rely on its existence.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
Failure includes the case where no output is generated, so you can
inspect the exit status of a command like &lsquo;<samp>df -t ext3 -t reiserfs
<var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo; to test whether <var>dir</var> is on a file system of type
&lsquo;<samp>ext3</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>reiserfs</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>Since the list of file systems (<var>mtab</var>) is needed to determine the
file system type, failure includes the cases when that list cannot
be read and one or more of the options <samp>-a</samp>, <samp>-l</samp>, <samp>-t</samp>
or <samp>-x</samp> is used together with a file name argument.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="du-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#stat-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">stat invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#df-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">df invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Disk-usage" accesskey="u" rel="up">Disk usage</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="du_003a-Estimate-file-space-usage"></a>
<h3 class="section">14.2 <code>du</code>: Estimate file space usage</h3>

<a name="index-du"></a>
<a name="index-file-space-usage"></a>
<a name="index-disk-usage-for-files"></a>

<p><code>du</code> reports the amount of disk space used by the set of specified files
and for each subdirectory (of directory arguments).  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">du [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>With no arguments, <code>du</code> reports the disk space for the current
directory.  Normally the disk space is printed in units of
1024 bytes, but this can be overridden (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
Non-integer quantities are rounded up to the next higher unit.
</p>
<p>If two or more hard links point to the same file, only one of the hard
links is counted.  The <var>file</var> argument order affects which links
are counted, and changing the argument order may change the numbers
and entries that <code>du</code> outputs.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--null</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d0"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnull"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-2"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall-3"></a>
<p>Show counts for all files, not just directories.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--apparent-size</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dapparent_002dsize"></a>
<p>Print apparent sizes, rather than disk usage.  The apparent size of a
file is the number of bytes reported by <code>wc -c</code> on regular files,
or more generally, <code>ls -l --block-size=1</code> or <code>stat --format=%s</code>.
For example, a file containing the word &lsquo;<samp>zoo</samp>&rsquo; with no newline would,
of course, have an apparent size of 3.  Such a small file may require
anywhere from 0 to 16 KiB or more of disk space, depending on
the type and configuration of the file system on which the file resides.
However, a sparse file created with this command:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">dd bs=1 seek=2GiB if=/dev/null of=big
</pre></div>

<p>has an apparent size of 2 GiB, yet on most modern
systems, it actually uses almost no disk space.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-B <var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--block-size=<var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dB-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dblock_002dsize-2"></a>
<a name="index-file-sizes"></a>
<p>Scale sizes by <var>size</var> before printing them (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
For example, <samp>-BG</samp> prints sizes in units of 1,073,741,824 bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--bytes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dbytes-6"></a>
<p>Equivalent to <code>--apparent-size --block-size=1</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--total</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtotal-1"></a>
<a name="index-grand-total-of-disk-space"></a>
<p>Print a grand total of all arguments after all arguments have
been processed.  This can be used to find out the total disk usage of
a given set of files or directories.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-D</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference-args</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dD-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddereference_002dargs"></a>
<p>Dereference symbolic links that are command line arguments.
Does not affect other symbolic links.  This is helpful for finding
out the disk usage of directories, such as <samp>/usr/tmp</samp>, which
are often symbolic links.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>depth</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--max-depth=<var>depth</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-depth"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmax_002ddepth_003ddepth"></a>
<a name="index-limiting-output-of-du"></a>
<p>Show the total for each directory (and file if &ndash;all) that is at
most MAX_DEPTH levels down from the root of the hierarchy.  The root
is at level 0, so <code>du --max-depth=0</code> is equivalent to <code>du -s</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--files0-from=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfiles0_002dfrom_003dfile-2"></a>
<p>Disallow processing files named on the command line, and instead process
those named in file <var>file</var>; each name being terminated by a zero byte
(ASCII NUL).
This is useful 
when the list of file names is so long that it may exceed a command line
length limitation.
In such cases, running <code>du</code> via <code>xargs</code> is undesirable
because it splits the list into pieces and makes <code>du</code> print
with the <samp>--total</samp> (<samp>-c</samp>) option for each sublist rather than for the entire list.
One way to produce a list of ASCII NUL terminated file
names is with GNU
<code>find</code>, using its <samp>-print0</samp> predicate.
If <var>file</var> is &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; then the ASCII NUL terminated
file names are read from standard input.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-6"></a>
<p>Equivalent to <samp>--dereference-args</samp> (<samp>-D</samp>).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--human-readable</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhuman_002dreadable-3"></a>
<a name="index-human_002dreadable-output-3"></a>
<p>Append a size letter to each size, such as &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; for mebibytes.
Powers of 1024 are used, not 1000; &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; stands for 1,048,576 bytes.
This option is equivalent to <samp>--block-size=human-readable</samp>.
Use the <samp>--si</samp> option if you prefer powers of 1000.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--inodes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dinodes-1"></a>
<a name="index-inode-usage_002c-dereferencing-in-du"></a>
<p>List inode usage information instead of block usage.
This option is useful for finding directories which contain many files, and
therefore eat up most of the inodes space of a file system (see <code>df</code>,
option <samp>--inodes</samp>).
It can well be combined with the options <samp>-a</samp>, <samp>-c</samp>,
<samp>-h</samp>, <samp>-l</samp>, <samp>-s</samp>, <samp>-S</samp>, <samp>-t</samp> and
<samp>-x</samp>; however, passing other options regarding the block size, for
example <samp>-b</samp>, <samp>-m</samp> and <samp>--apparent-size</samp>, is ignored.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-k</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dk-5"></a>
<a name="index-kibibytes-for-file-sizes"></a>
<p>Print sizes in 1024-byte blocks, overriding the default block size
(see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
This option is equivalent to <samp>--block-size=1K</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddereference-4"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-in-du"></a>
<p>Dereference symbolic links (show the disk space used by the file
or directory that the link points to instead of the space used by
the link).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--count-links</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcount_002dlinks"></a>
<a name="index-hard-links_002c-counting-in-du"></a>
<p>Count the size of all files, even if they have appeared already (as a
hard link).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-10"></a>
<a name="index-mebibytes-for-file-sizes"></a>
<p>Print sizes in 1,048,576-byte blocks, overriding the default block size
(see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>).
This option is equivalent to <samp>--block-size=1M</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-5"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-in-du-1"></a>
<p>For each symbolic links encountered by <code>du</code>,
consider the disk space used by the symbolic link.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--separate-dirs</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dseparate_002ddirs"></a>
<p>Normally, in the output of <code>du</code> (when not using <samp>--summarize</samp>),
the size listed next to a directory name, <var>d</var>, represents the sum
of sizes of all entries beneath <var>d</var> as well as the size of <var>d</var> itself.
With <samp>--separate-dirs</samp>, the size reported for a directory name,
<var>d</var>, will exclude the size of any subdirectories.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--si</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsi-3"></a>
<a name="index-SI-output-3"></a>
<p>Append an SI-style abbreviation to each size, such as &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; for
megabytes.  Powers of 1000 are used, not 1024; &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo; stands for
1,000,000 bytes.  This option is equivalent to
<samp>--block-size=si</samp>.  Use the <samp>-h</samp> or
<samp>--human-readable</samp> option if
you prefer powers of 1024.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--summarize</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-19"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsummarize"></a>
<p>Display only a total for each argument.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--threshold=<var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dthreshold"></a>
<p>Exclude entries based on a given <var>size</var>.  The <var>size</var> refers to used
blocks in normal mode (see <a href="#Block-size">Block size</a>), or inodes count in conjunction
with the <samp>--inodes</samp> option.
</p>
<p>If <var>size</var> is positive, then <code>du</code> will only print entries with a size
greater than or equal to that.
</p>
<p>If <var>size</var> is negative, then <code>du</code> will only print entries with a size
smaller than or equal to that.
</p>
<p>Although GNU <code>find</code> can be used to find files of a certain size,
<code>du</code>&rsquo;s <samp>--threshold</samp> option can be used to also filter
directories based on a given size.
</p>
<p>Please note that the <samp>--threshold</samp> option can be combined with the
<samp>--apparent-size</samp> option, and in this case would elide entries based on
its apparent size.
</p>
<p>Please note that the <samp>--threshold</samp> option can be combined with the
<samp>--inodes</samp> option, and in this case would elide entries based on
its inodes count.
</p>
<p>Here&rsquo;s how you would use <samp>--threshold</samp> to find directories with a size
greater than or equal to 200 megabytes:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">du --threshold=200MB
</pre></div>

<p>Here&rsquo;s how you would use <samp>--threshold</samp> to find directories and files -
note the <samp>-a</samp> - with an apparent size smaller than or equal to 500 bytes:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">du -a -t -500 --apparent-size
</pre></div>

<p>Here&rsquo;s how you would use <samp>--threshold</samp> to find directories on the root
file system with more than 20000 inodes used in the directory tree below:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">du --inodes -x --threshold=20000 /
</pre></div>


</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtime-4"></a>
<a name="index-last-modified-dates_002c-displaying-in-du"></a>
<p>Show the most recent modification timestamp (mtime) of any file in the
directory, or any of its subdirectories.  See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=ctime</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=status</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=use</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtime-5"></a>
<a name="index-ctime_002c-show-the-most-recent"></a>
<a name="index-status-time_002c-show-the-most-recent"></a>
<a name="index-use-time_002c-show-the-most-recent"></a>
<p>Show the most recent status change timestamp (ctime) of any file in
the directory, or any of its subdirectories.  See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=atime</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time=access</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtime-6"></a>
<a name="index-atime_002c-show-the-most-recent"></a>
<a name="index-access-timestamp_002c-show-the-most-recent"></a>
<p>Show the most recent access timestamp (atime) of any file in the
directory, or any of its subdirectories.  See <a href="#File-timestamps">File timestamps</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time-style=<var>style</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dtime_002dstyle-1"></a>
<a name="index-time-style-1"></a>
<p>List timestamps in style <var>style</var>.  This option has an effect only if
the <samp>--time</samp> option is also specified.  The <var>style</var> should
be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>+<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-LC_005fTIME-5"></a>
<p>List timestamps using <var>format</var>, where <var>format</var> is interpreted
like the format argument of <code>date</code> (see <a href="#date-invocation">date invocation</a>).
For example, <samp>--time-style=&quot;+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S&quot;</samp> causes
<code>du</code> to list timestamps like &lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30 23:45:56</samp>&rsquo;.  As
with <code>date</code>, <var>format</var>&rsquo;s interpretation is affected by the
<code>LC_TIME</code> locale category.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>full-iso</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>List timestamps in full using ISO 8601-like date, time, and time zone
components with nanosecond precision, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30
23:45:56.477817180 -0700</samp>&rsquo;.  This style is equivalent to
&lsquo;<samp>+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%N %z</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>long-iso</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>List ISO 8601 date and time components with minute precision, e.g.,
&lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30 23:45</samp>&rsquo;.  These timestamps are shorter than
&lsquo;<samp>full-iso</samp>&rsquo; timestamps, and are usually good enough for everyday
work.  This style is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iso</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>List ISO 8601 dates for timestamps, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>2002-03-30</samp>&rsquo;.
This style is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>+%Y-%m-%d</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-TIME_005fSTYLE-1"></a>
<p>You can specify the default value of the <samp>--time-style</samp> option
with the environment variable <code>TIME_STYLE</code>; if <code>TIME_STYLE</code> is not set
the default style is &lsquo;<samp>long-iso</samp>&rsquo;.  For compatibility with <code>ls</code>,
if <code>TIME_STYLE</code> begins with &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; and contains a newline,
the newline and any later characters are ignored; if <code>TIME_STYLE</code>
begins with &lsquo;<samp>posix-</samp>&rsquo; the &lsquo;<samp>posix-</samp>&rsquo; is ignored; and if
<code>TIME_STYLE</code> is &lsquo;<samp>locale</samp>&rsquo; it is ignored.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-X <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--exclude-from=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dX-file"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dexclude_002dfrom_003dfile"></a>
<a name="index-excluding-files-from-du"></a>
<p>Like <samp>--exclude</samp>, except take the patterns to exclude from <var>file</var>,
one per line.  If <var>file</var> is &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, take the patterns from standard
input.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--exclude=<var>pattern</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dexclude_003dpattern"></a>
<a name="index-excluding-files-from-du-1"></a>
<p>When recursing, skip subdirectories or files matching <var>pattern</var>.
For example, <code>du --exclude='*.o'</code> excludes files whose names
end in &lsquo;<samp>.o</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--one-file-system</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002done_002dfile_002dsystem-2"></a>
<a name="index-one-file-system_002c-restricting-du-to"></a>
<p>Skip directories that are on different file systems from the one that
the argument being processed is on.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-NFS-mounts-from-BSD-to-HP_002dUX-1"></a>
<p>On BSD systems, <code>du</code> reports sizes that are half the correct
values for files that are NFS-mounted from HP-UX systems.  On HP-UX
systems, it reports sizes that are twice the correct values for
files that are NFS-mounted from BSD systems.  This is due to a flaw
in HP-UX; it also affects the HP-UX <code>du</code> program.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="stat-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#sync-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">sync invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#du-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">du invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Disk-usage" accesskey="u" rel="up">Disk usage</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="stat_003a-Report-file-or-file-system-status"></a>
<h3 class="section">14.3 <code>stat</code>: Report file or file system status</h3>

<a name="index-stat"></a>
<a name="index-file-status"></a>
<a name="index-file-system-status"></a>

<p><code>stat</code> displays information about the specified file(s).  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">stat [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>With no option, <code>stat</code> reports all information about the given files.
But it also can be used to report the information of the file systems the
given files are located on.  If the files are links, <code>stat</code> can
also give information about the files the links point to.
</p>
<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-1"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-1"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>stat</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>stat</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env stat &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddereference-5"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-in-stat"></a>
<p>Change how <code>stat</code> treats symbolic links.
With this option, <code>stat</code> acts on the file referenced
by each symbolic link argument.
Without it, <code>stat</code> acts on any symbolic link argument directly.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--file-system</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-20"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfile_002dsystem"></a>
<a name="index-file-systems"></a>
<p>Report information about the file systems where the given files are located
instead of information about the files themselves.
This option implies the <samp>-L</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-19"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat_003dformat"></a>
<a name="index-output-format"></a>
<p>Use <var>format</var> rather than the default format.
<var>format</var> is automatically newline-terminated, so
running a command like the following with two or more <var>file</var>
operands produces a line of output for each operand:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ stat --format=%d:%i / /usr
2050:2
2057:2
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--printf=<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dprintf_003dformat"></a>
<a name="index-output-format-1"></a>
<p>Use <var>format</var> rather than the default format.
Like <samp>--format</samp>, but interpret backslash escapes,
and do not output a mandatory trailing newline.
If you want a newline, include &lsquo;<samp>\n</samp>&rsquo; in the <var>format</var>.
Here&rsquo;s how you would use <samp>--printf</samp> to print the device
and inode numbers of <samp>/</samp> and <samp>/usr</samp>:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ stat --printf='%d:%i\n' / /usr
2050:2
2057:2
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--terse</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dterse"></a>
<a name="index-terse-output"></a>
<p>Print the information in terse form, suitable for parsing by other programs.
</p>
<p>The output of the following commands are identical and the <samp>--format</samp>
also identifies the items printed (in fuller form) in the default format.
Note the format string would include another &lsquo;<samp>%C</samp>&rsquo; at the end with an
active SELinux security context.
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ stat --format=&quot;%n %s %b %f %u %g %D %i %h %t %T %X %Y %Z %W %o&quot; ...
$ stat --terse ...
</pre></div>

<p>The same illustrating terse output in <samp>--file-system</samp> mode:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ stat -f --format=&quot;%n %i %l %t %s %S %b %f %a %c %d&quot; ...
$ stat -f --terse ...
</pre></div>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>The valid <var>format</var> directives for files with <samp>--format</samp> and
<samp>--printf</samp> are:
</p>
<ul>
<li> %a - Access rights in octal (note &lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; printf flags)
</li><li> %A - Access rights in human readable form
</li><li> %b - Number of blocks allocated (see &lsquo;<samp>%B</samp>&rsquo;)
</li><li> %B - The size in bytes of each block reported by &lsquo;<samp>%b</samp>&rsquo;
</li><li> %C - The SELinux security context of a file, if available
</li><li> %d - Device number in decimal
</li><li> %D - Device number in hex
</li><li> %f - Raw mode in hex
</li><li> %F - File type
</li><li> %g - Group ID of owner
</li><li> %G - Group name of owner
</li><li> %h - Number of hard links
</li><li> %i - Inode number
</li><li> %m - Mount point (See note below)
</li><li> %n - File name
</li><li> %N - Quoted file name with dereference if symbolic link (see below)
</li><li> %o - Optimal I/O transfer size hint
</li><li> %s - Total size, in bytes
</li><li> %t - Major device type in hex (see below)
</li><li> %T - Minor device type in hex (see below)
</li><li> %u - User ID of owner
</li><li> %U - User name of owner
</li><li> %w - Time of file birth, or &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; if unknown
</li><li> %W - Time of file birth as seconds since Epoch, or &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;
</li><li> %x - Time of last access
</li><li> %X - Time of last access as seconds since Epoch
</li><li> %y - Time of last data modification
</li><li> %Y - Time of last data modification as seconds since Epoch
</li><li> %z - Time of last status change
</li><li> %Z - Time of last status change as seconds since Epoch
</li></ul>

<p>The &lsquo;<samp>%a</samp>&rsquo; format prints the octal mode, and so it is useful
to control the zero padding of the output with the &lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;
printf flags. For example to pad to at least 3 wide while making larger
numbers unambiguously octal, you can use &lsquo;<samp>%#03a</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>%N</samp>&rsquo; format can be set with the environment variable
<code>QUOTING_STYLE</code>.  If that environment variable is not set,
the default value is &lsquo;<samp>shell-escape-always</samp>&rsquo;.  Valid quoting styles are:
</p><dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>literal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Output strings as-is; this is the same as the <samp>-N</samp> or
<samp>--literal</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings for the shell if they contain shell metacharacters or would
cause ambiguous output.
The quoting is suitable for POSIX-compatible shells like
<code>bash</code>, but it does not always work for incompatible shells
like <code>csh</code>.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell-always</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings for the shell, even if they would normally not require quoting.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell-escape</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Like &lsquo;<samp>shell</samp>&rsquo;, but also quoting non-printable characters using the POSIX
proposed &lsquo;<samp>$''</samp>&rsquo; syntax suitable for most shells.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>shell-escape-always</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Like &lsquo;<samp>shell-escape</samp>&rsquo;, but quote strings even if they would
normally not require quoting.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, including the
surrounding double-quote characters; this is the same as the
<samp>-Q</samp> or <samp>--quote-name</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>escape</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, except omit the
surrounding double-quote
characters; this is the same as the <samp>-b</samp> or <samp>--escape</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>clocale</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, except use
surrounding quotation marks appropriate for the
locale.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>locale</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Quote strings as for C character string literals, except use
surrounding quotation marks appropriate for the locale, and quote
<tt>'like this'</tt> instead of <tt>&quot;like
this&quot;</tt> in the default C locale.  This looks nicer on many displays.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>The &lsquo;<samp>%t</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>%T</samp>&rsquo; formats operate on the st_rdev member of
the stat(2) structure, and are only defined for character and block
special files.  On some systems or file types, st_rdev may be used to
represent other quantities.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>%W</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%X</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>%Z</samp>&rsquo; formats accept a
precision preceded by a period to specify the number of digits to
print after the decimal point.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>%.3X</samp>&rsquo; outputs the
access timestamp to millisecond precision.  If a period is given but no
precision, <code>stat</code> uses 9 digits, so &lsquo;<samp>%.X</samp>&rsquo; is equivalent to
&lsquo;<samp>%.9X</samp>&rsquo;.  When discarding excess precision, timestamps are truncated
toward minus infinity.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">zero pad:
  $ stat -c '[%015Y]' /usr
  [000001288929712]
space align:
  $ stat -c '[%15Y]' /usr
  [     1288929712]
  $ stat -c '[%-15Y]' /usr
  [1288929712     ]
precision:
  $ stat -c '[%.3Y]' /usr
  [1288929712.114]
  $ stat -c '[%.Y]' /usr
  [1288929712.114951834]
</pre></div>

<p>The mount point printed by &lsquo;<samp>%m</samp>&rsquo; is similar to that output
by <code>df</code>, except that:
</p><ul>
<li> stat does not dereference symlinks by default
(unless <samp>-L</samp> is specified)
</li><li> stat does not search for specified device nodes in the
file system list, instead operating on them directly
</li><li> <a name="index-bind-mount-1"></a>
stat outputs the alias for a bind mounted file, rather than
the initial mount point of its backing device.
One can recursively call stat until there is no change in output,
to get the current base mount point
</li></ul>

<p>When listing file system information (<samp>--file-system</samp> (<samp>-f</samp>)),
you must use a different set of <var>format</var> directives:
</p>
<ul>
<li> %a - Free blocks available to non-super-user
</li><li> %b - Total data blocks in file system
</li><li> %c - Total file nodes in file system
</li><li> %d - Free file nodes in file system
</li><li> %f - Free blocks in file system
</li><li> %i - File System ID in hex
</li><li> %l - Maximum length of file names
</li><li> %n - File name
</li><li> %s - Block size (for faster transfers)
</li><li> %S - Fundamental block size (for block counts)
</li><li> %t - Type in hex
</li><li> %T - Type in human readable form
</li></ul>

<a name="index-TZ-3"></a>
<p>Timestamps are listed according to the time zone rules specified by
the <code>TZ</code> environment variable, or by the system default rules if
<code>TZ</code> is not set.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable">Specifying the Time Zone
with <code>TZ</code></a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="sync-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#truncate-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">truncate invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#stat-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">stat invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Disk-usage" accesskey="u" rel="up">Disk usage</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="sync_003a-Synchronize-cached-writes-to-persistent-storage"></a>
<h3 class="section">14.4 <code>sync</code>: Synchronize cached writes to persistent storage</h3>

<a name="index-sync-1"></a>
<a name="index-synchronize-disk-and-memory"></a>
<a name="index-Synchronize-cached-writes-to-persistent-storage"></a>

<p><code>sync</code> synchronizes in memory files or file systems to persistent
storage.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sync [<var>option</var>] [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-superblock_002c-writing"></a>
<a name="index-inodes_002c-written-buffered"></a>
<p><code>sync</code> writes any data buffered in memory out to disk.  This can
include (but is not limited to) modified superblocks, modified inodes,
and delayed reads and writes.  This must be implemented by the kernel;
The <code>sync</code> program does nothing but exercise the <code>sync</code>,
<code>syncfs</code>, <code>fsync</code>, and <code>fdatasync</code> system calls.
</p>
<a name="index-crashes-and-corruption"></a>
<p>The kernel keeps data in memory to avoid doing (relatively slow) disk
reads and writes.  This improves performance, but if the computer
crashes, data may be lost or the file system corrupted as a
result.  The <code>sync</code> command instructs the kernel to write
data in memory to persistent storage.
</p>
<p>If any argument is specified then only those files will be
synchronized using the fsync(2) syscall by default.
</p>
<p>If at least one file is specified, it is possible to change the
synchronization method with the following options.  Also see
<a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--data</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002ddata"></a>
<p>Use fdatasync(2) to sync only the data for the file,
and any metadata required to maintain file system consistency.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--file-system</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfile_002dsystem-1"></a>
<p>Synchronize all the I/O waiting for the file systems that contain the file,
using the syscall syncfs(2).  Note you would usually <em>not</em> specify
this option if passing a device node like &lsquo;<samp>/dev/sda</samp>&rsquo; for example,
as that would sync the containing file system rather than the referenced one.
Note also that depending on the system, passing individual device nodes or files
may have different sync characteristics than using no arguments.
I.e., arguments passed to fsync(2) may provide greater guarantees through
write barriers, than a global sync(2) used when no arguments are provided.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="truncate-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#sync-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">sync invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Disk-usage" accesskey="u" rel="up">Disk usage</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="truncate_003a-Shrink-or-extend-the-size-of-a-file"></a>
<h3 class="section">14.5 <code>truncate</code>: Shrink or extend the size of a file</h3>

<a name="index-truncate"></a>
<a name="index-truncating_002c-file-sizes"></a>

<p><code>truncate</code> shrinks or extends the size of each <var>file</var> to the
specified size.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">truncate <var>option</var>&hellip; <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-files_002c-creating"></a>
<p>Any <var>file</var> that does not exist is created.
</p>
<a name="index-sparse-files_002c-creating"></a>
<a name="index-holes_002c-creating-files-with"></a>
<p>If a <var>file</var> is larger than the specified size, the extra data is lost.
If a <var>file</var> is shorter, it is extended and the extended part (or hole)
reads as zero bytes.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-create</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-20"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dcreate-1"></a>
<p>Do not create files that do not exist.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--io-blocks</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dio_002dblocks"></a>
<p>Treat <var>size</var> as number of I/O blocks of the <var>file</var> rather than bytes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r <var>rfile</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reference=<var>rfile</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dreference-4"></a>
<p>Base the size of each <var>file</var> on the size of <var>rfile</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--size=<var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-20"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsize-1"></a>
<p>Set or adjust the size of each <var>file</var> according to <var>size</var>.
<var>size</var> is in bytes unless <samp>--io-blocks</samp> is specified.
<var>size</var> may be, or may be an integer optionally followed by,
one of the following multiplicative suffixes:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>KB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;           1000 (KiloBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;           1024 (KibiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;      1000*1000 (MegaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;      1024*1024 (MebiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>GB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt; 1000*1000*1000 (GigaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; 1024*1024*1024 (GibiBytes)
</pre></div>
<p>and so on for &lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;.
Binary prefixes can be used, too: &lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>MiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;,
and so on.
</p>
<p><var>size</var> may also be prefixed by one of the following to adjust
the size of each <var>file</var> based on its current size:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; extend by
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; reduce by
&lsquo;<samp>&lt;</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; at most
&lsquo;<samp>&gt;</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; at least
&lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; round down to multiple of
&lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; round up to multiple of
</pre></div>

</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Printing-text"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
