</div>
<a name="Printing-text-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">15 Printing text</h2>

<a name="index-printing-text_002c-commands-for"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-printing-text"></a>

<p>This section describes commands that display text strings.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#echo-invocation" accesskey="1">echo invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print a line of text.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#printf-invocation" accesskey="2">printf invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Format and print data.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#yes-invocation" accesskey="3">yes invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print a string until interrupted.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="echo-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#printf-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">printf invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Printing-text" accesskey="u" rel="up">Printing text</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="echo_003a-Print-a-line-of-text"></a>
<h3 class="section">15.1 <code>echo</code>: Print a line of text</h3>

<a name="index-echo-1"></a>
<a name="index-displaying-text"></a>
<a name="index-printing-text"></a>
<a name="index-text_002c-displaying"></a>
<a name="index-arbitrary-text_002c-displaying"></a>

<p><code>echo</code> writes each given <var>string</var> to standard output, with a
space between each and a newline after the last one.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">echo [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>string</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-2"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-2"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>echo</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>echo</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env echo &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands, and the normally-special argument
&lsquo;<samp>--</samp>&rsquo; has no special meaning and is treated like any other
<var>string</var>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-15"></a>
<p>Do not output the trailing newline.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-5"></a>
<a name="index-backslash-escapes-1"></a>
<p>Enable interpretation of the following backslash-escaped characters in
each <var>string</var>:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>alert (bell)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>backspace
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>produce no further output
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>escape
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\f</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>form feed
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>newline
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>carriage return
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>horizontal tab
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>vertical tab
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\\</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>backslash
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\0<var>nnn</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>the eight-bit value that is the octal number <var>nnn</var>
(zero to three octal digits), if <var>nnn</var> is
a nine-bit value, the ninth bit is ignored
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\<var>nnn</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>the eight-bit value that is the octal number <var>nnn</var>
(one to three octal digits), if <var>nnn</var> is
a nine-bit value, the ninth bit is ignored
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>\x<var>hh</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>the eight-bit value that is the hexadecimal number <var>hh</var>
(one or two hexadecimal digits)
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-E</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dE-1"></a>
<a name="index-backslash-escapes-2"></a>
<p>Disable interpretation of backslash escapes in each <var>string</var>.
This is the default.  If <samp>-e</samp> and <samp>-E</samp> are both
specified, the last one given takes effect.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-6"></a>
<p>If the <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> environment variable is set, then when
<code>echo</code>&rsquo;s first argument is not <samp>-n</samp> it outputs
option-like arguments instead of treating them as options.  For
example, <code>echo -ne hello</code> outputs &lsquo;<samp>-ne hello</samp>&rsquo; instead of
plain &lsquo;<samp>hello</samp>&rsquo;.  Also backslash escapes are always enabled.
</p>
<p>POSIX does not require support for any options, and says
that the behavior of <code>echo</code> is implementation-defined if any
<var>string</var> contains a backslash or if the first argument is
<samp>-n</samp>.  Portable programs can use the <code>printf</code> command
if they need to omit trailing newlines or output control characters or
backslashes.  See <a href="#printf-invocation">printf invocation</a>.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="printf-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#yes-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">yes invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#echo-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">echo invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Printing-text" accesskey="u" rel="up">Printing text</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="printf_003a-Format-and-print-data"></a>
<h3 class="section">15.2 <code>printf</code>: Format and print data</h3>

<a name="index-printf"></a>
<p><code>printf</code> does formatted printing of text.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">printf <var>format</var> [<var>argument</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><code>printf</code> prints the <var>format</var> string, interpreting &lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo;
directives and &lsquo;<samp>\</samp>&rsquo; escapes to format numeric and string arguments
in a way that is mostly similar to the C &lsquo;<samp>printf</samp>&rsquo; function.
See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Output-Conversion-Syntax"><code>printf</code> format directives</a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>, for details.
The differences are listed below.
</p>
<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-3"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-3"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>printf</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>printf</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env printf &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<ul>
<li> The <var>format</var> argument is reused as necessary to convert all the
given <var>argument</var>s.  For example, the command &lsquo;<samp>printf %s a b</samp>&rsquo;
outputs &lsquo;<samp>ab</samp>&rsquo;.

</li><li> Missing <var>argument</var>s are treated as null strings or as zeros,
depending on whether the context expects a string or a number.  For
example, the command &lsquo;<samp>printf %sx%d</samp>&rsquo; prints &lsquo;<samp>x0</samp>&rsquo;.

</li><li> <a name="index-_005cc"></a>
An additional escape, &lsquo;<samp>\c</samp>&rsquo;, causes <code>printf</code> to produce no
further output.  For example, the command &lsquo;<samp>printf 'A%sC\cD%sF' B
E</samp>&rsquo; prints &lsquo;<samp>ABC</samp>&rsquo;.

</li><li> The hexadecimal escape sequence &lsquo;<samp>\x<var>hh</var></samp>&rsquo; has at most two
digits, as opposed to C where it can have an unlimited number of
digits.  For example, the command &lsquo;<samp>printf '\x07e'</samp>&rsquo; prints two
bytes, whereas the C statement &lsquo;<samp>printf (&quot;\x07e&quot;)</samp>&rsquo; prints just
one.

</li><li> <a name="index-_0025b"></a>
An additional directive &lsquo;<samp>%b</samp>&rsquo;, prints its
argument string with &lsquo;<samp>\</samp>&rsquo; escapes interpreted in the same way as in
the <var>format</var> string, except that octal escapes are of the form
&lsquo;<samp>\0<var>ooo</var></samp>&rsquo; where <var>ooo</var> is 0 to 3 octal digits.  If
&lsquo;<samp>\<var>ooo</var></samp>&rsquo; is nine-bit value, ignore the ninth bit.
If a precision is also given, it limits the number of bytes printed
from the converted string.

</li><li> <a name="index-_0025q"></a>
An additional directive &lsquo;<samp>%q</samp>&rsquo;, prints its argument string
in a format that can be reused as input by most shells.
Non-printable characters are escaped with the POSIX proposed &lsquo;<samp>$''</samp>&rsquo; syntax,
and shell metacharacters are quoted appropriately.
This is an equivalent format to <code>ls --quoting=shell-escape</code> output.

</li><li> Numeric arguments must be single C constants, possibly with leading
&lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>printf %.4d -3</samp>&rsquo; outputs
&lsquo;<samp>-0003</samp>&rsquo;.

</li><li> <a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-7"></a>
If the leading character of a numeric argument is &lsquo;<samp>&quot;</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>'</samp>&rsquo;
then its value is the numeric value of the immediately following
character.  Any remaining characters are silently ignored if the
<code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> environment variable is set; otherwise, a
warning is printed.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>printf &quot;%d&quot; &quot;'a&quot;</samp>&rsquo; outputs
&lsquo;<samp>97</samp>&rsquo; on hosts that use the ASCII character set, since
&lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo; has the numeric value 97 in ASCII.

</li></ul>

<a name="index-LC_005fNUMERIC-5"></a>
<p>A floating point argument is interpreted according to
the <code>LC_NUMERIC</code> category of either the current or the C locale,
and is printed according to the current locale.
For example, in a locale whose decimal point character is a comma,
the command &lsquo;<samp>printf '%g %g' 2,5 2.5</samp>&rsquo; outputs &lsquo;<samp>2,5 2,5</samp>&rsquo;.
See <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>.
</p>
<a name="index-_005cooo"></a>
<a name="index-_005cxhh"></a>
<p><code>printf</code> interprets &lsquo;<samp>\<var>ooo</var></samp>&rsquo; in <var>format</var> as an octal number
(if <var>ooo</var> is 1 to 3 octal digits) specifying a byte to print,
and &lsquo;<samp>\x<var>hh</var></samp>&rsquo; as a hexadecimal number (if <var>hh</var> is 1 to 2 hex
digits) specifying a character to print.
Note however that when &lsquo;<samp>\<var>ooo</var></samp>&rsquo; specifies a number larger than 255,
<code>printf</code> ignores the ninth bit.
For example, &lsquo;<samp>printf '\400'</samp>&rsquo; is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>printf '\0'</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<a name="index-_005cuhhhh"></a>
<a name="index-_005cUhhhhhhhh"></a>
<a name="index-Unicode"></a>
<a name="index-ISO_002fIEC-10646"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fCTYPE-4"></a>
<p><code>printf</code> interprets two character syntaxes introduced in
ISO C 99:
&lsquo;<samp>\u</samp>&rsquo; for 16-bit Unicode (ISO/IEC 10646)
characters, specified as
four hexadecimal digits <var>hhhh</var>, and &lsquo;<samp>\U</samp>&rsquo; for 32-bit Unicode
characters, specified as eight hexadecimal digits <var>hhhhhhhh</var>.
<code>printf</code> outputs the Unicode characters
according to the <code>LC_CTYPE</code> locale.  Unicode characters in the ranges
U+0000&hellip;U+009F, U+D800&hellip;U+DFFF cannot be specified by this syntax,
except for U+0024 ($), U+0040 (@), and U+0060 ()`.
</p>
<p>The processing of &lsquo;<samp>\u</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>\U</samp>&rsquo; requires a full-featured
<code>iconv</code> facility.  It is activated on systems with glibc 2.2 (or newer),
or when <code>libiconv</code> is installed prior to this package.  Otherwise
&lsquo;<samp>\u</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>\U</samp>&rsquo; will print as-is.
</p>
<p>The only options are a lone <samp>--help</samp> or
<samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<p>The Unicode character syntaxes are useful for writing strings in a locale
independent way.  For example, a string containing the Euro currency symbol
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env printf '\u20AC 14.95'
</pre></div>

<p>will be output correctly in all locales supporting the Euro symbol
(ISO-8859-15, UTF-8, and others).  Similarly, a Chinese string
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env printf '\u4e2d\u6587'
</pre></div>

<p>will be output correctly in all Chinese locales (GB2312, BIG5, UTF-8, etc).
</p>
<p>Note that in these examples, the <code>printf</code> command has been
invoked via <code>env</code> to ensure that we run the program found via
your shell&rsquo;s search path, and not a shell alias or a built-in function.
</p>
<p>For larger strings, you don&rsquo;t need to look up the hexadecimal code
values of each character one by one.  ASCII characters mixed with \u
escape sequences is also known as the JAVA source file encoding.  You can
use GNU recode 3.5c (or newer) to convert strings to this encoding.  Here
is how to convert a piece of text into a shell script which will output
this text in a locale-independent way:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ LC_CTYPE=zh_CN.big5 /usr/local/bin/printf \
    '\u4e2d\u6587\n' &gt; sample.txt
$ recode BIG5..JAVA &lt; sample.txt \
    | sed -e &quot;s|^|/usr/local/bin/printf '|&quot; -e &quot;s|$|\\\\n'|&quot; \
    &gt; sample.sh
</pre></div>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="yes-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#printf-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">printf invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Printing-text" accesskey="u" rel="up">Printing text</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="yes_003a-Print-a-string-until-interrupted"></a>
<h3 class="section">15.3 <code>yes</code>: Print a string until interrupted</h3>

<a name="index-yes"></a>
<a name="index-repeated-output-of-a-string"></a>

<p><code>yes</code> prints the command line arguments, separated by spaces and
followed by a newline, forever until it is killed.  If no arguments are
given, it prints &lsquo;<samp>y</samp>&rsquo; followed by a newline forever until killed.
</p>
<p>Upon a write error, <code>yes</code> exits with status &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The only options are a lone <samp>--help</samp> or <samp>--version</samp>.
To output an argument that begins with
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, precede it with <samp>--</samp>, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>yes -- --help</samp>&rsquo;.
See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Conditions"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Redirection" accesskey="n" rel="next">Redirection</a>, Previous: <a href="#Printing-text" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Printing text</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Conditions-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">16 Conditions</h2>

<a name="index-conditions"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-exit-status"></a>
<a name="index-exit-status-commands"></a>

<p>This section describes commands that are primarily useful for their exit
status, rather than their output.  Thus, they are often used as the
condition of shell <code>if</code> statements, or as the last command in a
pipeline.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#false-invocation" accesskey="1">false invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Do nothing, unsuccessfully.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#true-invocation" accesskey="2">true invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Do nothing, successfully.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="3">test invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Check file types and compare values.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="4">expr invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Evaluate expressions.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="false-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#true-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">true invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Conditions" accesskey="u" rel="up">Conditions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="false_003a-Do-nothing_002c-unsuccessfully"></a>
<h3 class="section">16.1 <code>false</code>: Do nothing, unsuccessfully</h3>

<a name="index-false"></a>
<a name="index-do-nothing_002c-unsuccessfully"></a>
<a name="index-failure-exit-status"></a>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-false"></a>

<p><code>false</code> does nothing except return an exit status of 1, meaning
<em>failure</em>.  It can be used as a place holder in shell scripts
where an unsuccessful command is needed.
In most modern shells, <code>false</code> is a built-in command, so when
you use &lsquo;<samp>false</samp>&rsquo; in a script, you&rsquo;re probably using the built-in
command, not the one documented here.
</p>
<p><code>false</code> honors the <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp> options.
</p>
<p>This version of <code>false</code> is implemented as a C program, and is thus
more secure and faster than a shell script implementation, and may safely
be used as a dummy shell for the purpose of disabling accounts.
</p>
<p>Note that <code>false</code> (unlike all other programs documented herein)
exits unsuccessfully, even when invoked with
<samp>--help</samp> or <samp>--version</samp>.
</p>
<p>Portable programs should not assume that the exit status of
<code>false</code> is 1, as it is greater than 1 on some
non-GNU hosts.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="true-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">test invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#false-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">false invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Conditions" accesskey="u" rel="up">Conditions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="true_003a-Do-nothing_002c-successfully"></a>
<h3 class="section">16.2 <code>true</code>: Do nothing, successfully</h3>

<a name="index-true"></a>
<a name="index-do-nothing_002c-successfully"></a>
<a name="index-no_002dop"></a>
<a name="index-successful-exit"></a>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-true"></a>

<p><code>true</code> does nothing except return an exit status of 0, meaning
<em>success</em>.  It can be used as a place holder in shell scripts
where a successful command is needed, although the shell built-in
command <code>:</code> (colon) may do the same thing faster.
In most modern shells, <code>true</code> is a built-in command, so when
you use &lsquo;<samp>true</samp>&rsquo; in a script, you&rsquo;re probably using the built-in
command, not the one documented here.
</p>
<p><code>true</code> honors the <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp> options.
</p>
<p>Note, however, that it is possible to cause <code>true</code>
to exit with nonzero status: with the <samp>--help</samp> or <samp>--version</samp>
option, and with standard
output already closed or redirected to a file that evokes an I/O error.
For example, using a Bourne-compatible shell:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ ./true --version &gt;&amp;-
./true: write error: Bad file number
$ ./true --version &gt; /dev/full
./true: write error: No space left on device
</pre></div>

<p>This version of <code>true</code> is implemented as a C program, and is thus
more secure and faster than a shell script implementation, and may safely
be used as a dummy shell for the purpose of disabling accounts.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="test-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">expr invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#true-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">true invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Conditions" accesskey="u" rel="up">Conditions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="test_003a-Check-file-types-and-compare-values"></a>
<h3 class="section">16.3 <code>test</code>: Check file types and compare values</h3>

<a name="index-test"></a>
<a name="index-check-file-types"></a>
<a name="index-compare-values"></a>
<a name="index-expression-evaluation"></a>

<p><code>test</code> returns a status of 0 (true) or 1 (false) depending on the
evaluation of the conditional expression <var>expr</var>.  Each part of the
expression must be a separate argument.
</p>
<p><code>test</code> has file status checks, string operators, and numeric
comparison operators.
</p>
<p><code>test</code> has an alternate form that uses opening and closing
square brackets instead a leading &lsquo;<samp>test</samp>&rsquo;.  For example, instead
of &lsquo;<samp>test -d /</samp>&rsquo;, you can write &lsquo;<samp>[ -d / ]</samp>&rsquo;.  The square
brackets must be separate arguments; for example, &lsquo;<samp>[-d /]</samp>&rsquo; does
not have the desired effect.  Since &lsquo;<samp>test <var>expr</var></samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>[
<var>expr</var> ]</samp>&rsquo; have the same meaning, only the former form is discussed
below.
</p>
<p>Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">test <var>expression</var>
test
[ <var>expression</var> ]
[ ]
[ <var>option</var>
</pre></div>

<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-4"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-4"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>test</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>test</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env test &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<p>If <var>expression</var> is omitted, <code>test</code> returns false.
If <var>expression</var> is a single argument,
<code>test</code> returns false if the argument is null and true
otherwise.  The argument
can be any string, including strings like &lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>-1</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>--</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>--help</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>--version</samp>&rsquo; that most other
programs would treat as options.  To get help and version information,
invoke the commands &lsquo;<samp>[ --help</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>[ --version</samp>&rsquo;, without
the usual closing brackets.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-test"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if the expression is true,
1 if the expression is false,
2 if an error occurred.
</pre></div>

<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#File-type-tests" accesskey="1">File type tests</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">-[bcdfhLpSt]
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Access-permission-tests" accesskey="2">Access permission tests</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">-[gkruwxOG]
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#File-characteristic-tests" accesskey="3">File characteristic tests</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">-e -s -nt -ot -ef
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#String-tests" accesskey="4">String tests</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">-z -n = == !=
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Numeric-tests" accesskey="5">Numeric tests</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">-eq -ne -lt -le -gt -ge
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Connectives-for-test" accesskey="6">Connectives for test</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">! -a -o
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="File-type-tests"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Access-permission-tests" accesskey="n" rel="next">Access permission tests</a>, Up: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">test invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="File-type-tests-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.3.1 File type tests</h4>

<a name="index-file-type-tests"></a>

<p>These options test for particular types of files.  (Everything&rsquo;s a file,
but not all files are the same!)
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-19"></a>
<a name="index-block-special-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is a block special device.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-21"></a>
<a name="index-character-special-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is a character special device.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-15"></a>
<a name="index-directory-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is a directory.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-21"></a>
<a name="index-regular-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is a regular file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002dh-10"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is a symbolic link.
Unlike all other file-related tests, this test does not dereference
<var>file</var> if it is a symbolic link.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-7"></a>
<a name="index-named-pipe-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is a named pipe.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-11"></a>
<a name="index-socket-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is a socket.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>fd</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-17"></a>
<a name="index-terminal-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>fd</var> is a file descriptor that is associated with a
terminal.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Access-permission-tests"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#File-characteristic-tests" accesskey="n" rel="next">File characteristic tests</a>, Previous: <a href="#File-type-tests" accesskey="p" rel="prev">File type tests</a>, Up: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">test invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Access-permission-tests-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.3.2 Access permission tests</h4>

<a name="index-access-permission-tests"></a>
<a name="index-permission-tests"></a>

<p>These options test for particular access permissions.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg-5"></a>
<a name="index-set_002dgroup_002dID-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and has its set-group-ID bit set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-k <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dk-6"></a>
<a name="index-sticky-bit-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and has its <em>sticky</em> bit set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-12"></a>
<a name="index-readable-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and read permission is granted.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-9"></a>
<a name="index-set_002duser_002dID-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and has its set-user-ID bit set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-11"></a>
<a name="index-writable-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and write permission is granted.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-x <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dx-7"></a>
<a name="index-executable-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and execute permission is granted
(or search permission, if it is a directory).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-O <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dO-1"></a>
<a name="index-owned-by-effective-user-ID-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is owned by the current effective user ID.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-G <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dG-1"></a>
<a name="index-owned-by-effective-group-ID-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and is owned by the current effective group ID.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<hr>
<a name="File-characteristic-tests"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#String-tests" accesskey="n" rel="next">String tests</a>, Previous: <a href="#Access-permission-tests" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Access permission tests</a>, Up: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">test invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="File-characteristic-tests-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.3.3 File characteristic tests</h4>

<a name="index-file-characteristic-tests"></a>

<p>These options test other file characteristics.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-6"></a>
<a name="index-existence_002dof_002dfile-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-21"></a>
<a name="index-nonempty-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and has a size greater than zero.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>file1</var> -nt <var>file2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dnt"></a>
<a name="index-newer_002dthan-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file1</var> is newer (according to modification date) than
<var>file2</var>, or if <var>file1</var> exists and <var>file2</var> does not.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>file1</var> -ot <var>file2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dot"></a>
<a name="index-older_002dthan-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file1</var> is older (according to modification date) than
<var>file2</var>, or if <var>file2</var> exists and <var>file1</var> does not.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>file1</var> -ef <var>file2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002def"></a>
<a name="index-same-file-check"></a>
<a name="index-hard-link-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file1</var> and <var>file2</var> have the same device and inode
numbers, i.e., if they are hard links to each other.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-N <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dN-3"></a>
<a name="index-mtime_002dgreater_002datime-file-check"></a>
<p>True if <var>file</var> exists and has been modified (mtime) since it was
last read (atime).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="String-tests"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Numeric-tests" accesskey="n" rel="next">Numeric tests</a>, Previous: <a href="#File-characteristic-tests" accesskey="p" rel="prev">File characteristic tests</a>, Up: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">test invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="String-tests-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.3.4 String tests</h4>

<a name="index-string-tests"></a>

<p>These options test string characteristics.  You may need to quote
<var>string</var> arguments for the shell.  For example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">test -n &quot;$V&quot;
</pre></div>

<p>The quotes here prevent the wrong arguments from being passed to
<code>test</code> if &lsquo;<samp>$V</samp>&rsquo; is empty or contains special characters.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-13"></a>
<a name="index-zero_002dlength-string-check"></a>
<p>True if the length of <var>string</var> is zero.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-16"></a>
<a name="index-nonzero_002dlength-string-check"></a>
<p>True if the length of <var>string</var> is nonzero.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>string1</var> = <var>string2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_003d-1"></a>
<a name="index-equal-string-check"></a>
<p>True if the strings are equal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>string1</var> == <var>string2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_003d_003d-1"></a>
<a name="index-equal-string-check-1"></a>
<p>True if the strings are equal (synonym for =).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>string1</var> != <var>string2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_0021_003d"></a>
<a name="index-not_002dequal-string-check"></a>
<p>True if the strings are not equal.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Numeric-tests"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Connectives-for-test" accesskey="n" rel="next">Connectives for test</a>, Previous: <a href="#String-tests" accesskey="p" rel="prev">String tests</a>, Up: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">test invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Numeric-tests-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.3.5 Numeric tests</h4>

<a name="index-numeric-tests"></a>
<a name="index-arithmetic-tests"></a>

<p>Numeric relational operators.  The arguments must be entirely numeric
(possibly negative), or the special expression <code><span class="nolinebreak">-l</span>&nbsp;<var>string</var></code><!-- /@w -->,
which evaluates to the length of <var>string</var>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>arg1</var> -eq <var>arg2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>arg1</var> -ne <var>arg2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>arg1</var> -lt <var>arg2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>arg1</var> -le <var>arg2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>arg1</var> -gt <var>arg2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>arg1</var> -ge <var>arg2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002deq"></a>
<a name="index-_002dne"></a>
<a name="index-_002dlt"></a>
<a name="index-_002dle"></a>
<a name="index-_002dgt"></a>
<a name="index-_002dge"></a>
<p>These arithmetic binary operators return true if <var>arg1</var> is equal,
not-equal, less-than, less-than-or-equal, greater-than, or
greater-than-or-equal than <var>arg2</var>, respectively.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>For example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">test -1 -gt -2 &amp;&amp; echo yes
&rArr; yes
test -l abc -gt 1 &amp;&amp; echo yes
&rArr; yes
test 0x100 -eq 1
error&rarr; test: integer expression expected before -eq
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="Connectives-for-test"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Numeric-tests" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Numeric tests</a>, Up: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">test invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Connectives-for-test-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.3.6 Connectives for <code>test</code></h4>

<a name="index-logical-connectives"></a>
<a name="index-connectives_002c-logical"></a>

<p>Note it&rsquo;s preferred to use shell logical primitives
rather than these logical connectives internal to <code>test</code>,
because an expression may become ambiguous
depending on the expansion of its parameters.
</p>
<p>For example, this becomes ambiguous when &lsquo;<samp>$1</samp>&rsquo;
is set to &lsquo;<samp>'!'</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>$2</samp>&rsquo; to the empty string &lsquo;<samp>''</samp>&rsquo;:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">test &quot;$1&quot; -a &quot;$2&quot;
</pre></div>

<p>and should be written as:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">test &quot;$1&quot; &amp;&amp; test &quot;$2&quot;
</pre></div>

<p>Note the shell logical primitives also benefit from
short circuit operation, which can be significant
for file attribute tests.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>! <var>expr</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_0021"></a>
<p>True if <var>expr</var> is false.
&lsquo;<samp>!</samp>&rsquo; has lower precedence than all parts of <var>expr</var>.
Note &lsquo;<samp>!</samp>&rsquo; needs to be specified to the left
of a binary expression, I.e., &lsquo;<samp>'!' 1 -gt 2</samp>&rsquo;
rather than &lsquo;<samp>1 '!' -gt 2</samp>&rsquo;.
Also &lsquo;<samp>!</samp>&rsquo; is often a shell special character
and is best used quoted.
</p>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>expr1</var> -a <var>expr2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-10"></a>
<a name="index-logical-and-operator"></a>
<a name="index-and-operator"></a>
<p>True if both <var>expr1</var> and <var>expr2</var> are true.
&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo; is left associative,
and has a higher precedence than &lsquo;<samp>-o</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>expr1</var> -o <var>expr2</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-8"></a>
<a name="index-logical-or-operator"></a>
<a name="index-or-operator"></a>
<p>True if either <var>expr1</var> or <var>expr2</var> is true.
&lsquo;<samp>-o</samp>&rsquo; is left associative.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="expr-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">test invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Conditions" accesskey="u" rel="up">Conditions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="expr_003a-Evaluate-expressions"></a>
<h3 class="section">16.4 <code>expr</code>: Evaluate expressions</h3>

<a name="index-expr"></a>
<a name="index-expression-evaluation-1"></a>
<a name="index-evaluation-of-expressions"></a>

<p><code>expr</code> evaluates an expression and writes the result on standard
output.  Each token of the expression must be a separate argument.
</p>
<p>Operands are either integers or strings.  Integers consist of one or
more decimal digits, with an optional leading &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.
<code>expr</code> converts
anything appearing in an operand position to an integer or a string
depending on the operation being applied to it.
</p>
<p>Strings are not quoted for <code>expr</code> itself, though you may need to
quote them to protect characters with special meaning to the shell,
e.g., spaces.  However, regardless of whether it is quoted, a string
operand should not be a parenthesis or any of <code>expr</code>&rsquo;s
operators like <code>+</code>, so you cannot safely pass an arbitrary string
<code>$str</code> to expr merely by quoting it to the shell.  One way to
work around this is to use the GNU extension <code>+</code>,
(e.g., <code>+ &quot;$str&quot; = foo</code>); a more portable way is to use
<code>&quot;&nbsp;$str&quot;<!-- /@w --></code> and to adjust the rest of the expression to take
the leading space into account (e.g., <code>&quot;&nbsp;$str&quot;&nbsp;=&nbsp;&quot;&nbsp;foo&quot;<!-- /@w --></code>).
</p>
<p>You should not pass a negative integer or a string with leading
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; as <code>expr</code>&rsquo;s first argument, as it might be
misinterpreted as an option; this can be avoided by parenthesization.
Also, portable scripts should not use a string operand that happens to
take the form of an integer; this can be worked around by inserting
leading spaces as mentioned above.
</p>
<a name="index-parentheses-for-grouping"></a>
<p>Operators may be given as infix symbols or prefix keywords.  Parentheses
may be used for grouping in the usual manner.  You must quote
parentheses and many operators to avoid the shell evaluating them,
however.
</p>
<p>When built with support for the GNU MP library, <code>expr</code> uses
arbitrary-precision arithmetic; otherwise, it uses native arithmetic
types and may fail due to arithmetic overflow.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.  Options must precede operands.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-expr"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if the expression is neither null nor 0,
1 if the expression is null or 0,
2 if the expression is invalid,
3 if an internal error occurred (e.g., arithmetic overflow).
</pre></div>

<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#String-expressions" accesskey="1">String expressions</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">+ : match substr index length
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Numeric-expressions" accesskey="2">Numeric expressions</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">+ - * / %
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Relations-for-expr" accesskey="3">Relations for expr</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">| &amp; &lt; &lt;= = == != &gt;= &gt;
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Examples-of-expr" accesskey="4">Examples of expr</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Examples.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="String-expressions"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Numeric-expressions" accesskey="n" rel="next">Numeric expressions</a>, Up: <a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">expr invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="String-expressions-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.4.1 String expressions</h4>

<a name="index-string-expressions"></a>
<a name="index-expressions_002c-string"></a>

<p><code>expr</code> supports pattern matching and other string operators.  These
have higher precedence than both the numeric and relational operators (in
the next sections).
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>string</var> : <var>regex</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-pattern-matching"></a>
<a name="index-regular-expression-matching"></a>
<a name="index-matching-patterns"></a>
<p>Perform pattern matching.  The arguments are converted to strings and the
second is considered to be a (basic, a la GNU <code>grep</code>) regular
expression, with a <code>^</code> implicitly prepended.  The first argument is
then matched against this regular expression.
</p>
<p>If the match succeeds and <var>regex</var> uses &lsquo;<samp>\(</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>\)</samp>&rsquo;, the
<code>:</code> expression returns the part of <var>string</var> that matched the
subexpression; otherwise, it returns the number of characters matched.
</p>
<p>If the match fails, the <code>:</code> operator returns the null string if
&lsquo;<samp>\(</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>\)</samp>&rsquo; are used in <var>regex</var>, otherwise 0.
</p>
<a name="index-_005c_0028-regexp-operator"></a>
<p>Only the first &lsquo;<samp>\( &hellip; \)</samp>&rsquo; pair is relevant to the return
value; additional pairs are meaningful only for grouping the regular
expression operators.
</p>
<a name="index-_005c_002b-regexp-operator"></a>
<a name="index-_005c_003f-regexp-operator"></a>
<a name="index-_005c_007c-regexp-operator"></a>
<p>In the regular expression, <code>\+</code>, <code>\?</code>, and <code>\|</code> are
operators which respectively match one or more, zero or one, or separate
alternatives.  SunOS and other <code>expr</code>&rsquo;s treat these as regular
characters.  (POSIX allows either behavior.)
See <a href="regex.html#Top">Regular Expression Library</a> in <cite>Regex</cite>, for details of
regular expression syntax.  Some examples are in <a href="#Examples-of-expr">Examples of expr</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>match <var>string</var> <var>regex</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-match"></a>
<p>An alternative way to do pattern matching.  This is the same as
&lsquo;<samp><var>string</var>&nbsp;:&nbsp;<var>regex</var></samp>&rsquo;<!-- /@w -->.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>substr <var>string</var> <var>position</var> <var>length</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-substr"></a>
<p>Returns the substring of <var>string</var> beginning at <var>position</var>
with length at most <var>length</var>.  If either <var>position</var> or
<var>length</var> is negative, zero, or non-numeric, returns the null string.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>index <var>string</var> <var>charset</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-index"></a>
<p>Returns the first position in <var>string</var> where the first character in
<var>charset</var> was found.  If no character in <var>charset</var> is found in
<var>string</var>, return 0.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>length <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-length"></a>
<p>Returns the length of <var>string</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>+ <var>token</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002b"></a>
<p>Interpret <var>token</var> as a string, even if it is a keyword like <var>match</var>
or an operator like <code>/</code>.
This makes it possible to test <code>expr length + &quot;$x&quot;</code> or
<code>expr + &quot;$x&quot; : '.*/\(.\)'</code> and have it do the right thing even if
the value of <var>$x</var> happens to be (for example) <code>/</code> or <code>index</code>.
This operator is a GNU extension.  Portable shell scripts should use
<code>&quot;&nbsp;$token&quot;<!-- /@w --> : '&nbsp;\(.*\)'<!-- /@w --></code> instead of <code>+ &quot;$token&quot;</code>.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>To make <code>expr</code> interpret keywords as strings, you must use the
<code>quote</code> operator.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Numeric-expressions"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Relations-for-expr" accesskey="n" rel="next">Relations for expr</a>, Previous: <a href="#String-expressions" accesskey="p" rel="prev">String expressions</a>, Up: <a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">expr invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Numeric-expressions-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.4.2 Numeric expressions</h4>

<a name="index-numeric-expressions"></a>
<a name="index-expressions_002c-numeric"></a>

<p><code>expr</code> supports the usual numeric operators, in order of increasing
precedence.  These numeric operators have lower precedence than the
string operators described in the previous section, and higher precedence
than the connectives (next section).
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>+ -</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002b-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d"></a>
<a name="index-addition"></a>
<a name="index-subtraction"></a>
<p>Addition and subtraction.  Both arguments are converted to integers;
an error occurs if this cannot be done.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>* / %</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002a"></a>
<a name="index-_002f"></a>
<a name="index-_0025"></a>
<a name="index-multiplication"></a>
<a name="index-division"></a>
<a name="index-remainder"></a>
<p>Multiplication, division, remainder.  Both arguments are converted to
integers; an error occurs if this cannot be done.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Relations-for-expr"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Examples-of-expr" accesskey="n" rel="next">Examples of expr</a>, Previous: <a href="#Numeric-expressions" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Numeric expressions</a>, Up: <a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">expr invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Relations-for-expr-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.4.3 Relations for <code>expr</code></h4>

<a name="index-connectives_002c-logical-1"></a>
<a name="index-logical-connectives-1"></a>
<a name="index-relations_002c-numeric-or-string"></a>

<p><code>expr</code> supports the usual logical connectives and relations.  These
have lower precedence than the string and numeric operators
(previous sections).  Here is the list, lowest-precedence operator first.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>|</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_007c"></a>
<a name="index-logical-or-operator-1"></a>
<a name="index-or-operator-1"></a>
<p>Returns its first argument if that is neither null nor zero, otherwise
its second argument if it is neither null nor zero, otherwise 0.  It
does not evaluate its second argument if its first argument is neither
null nor zero.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>&amp;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_0026"></a>
<a name="index-logical-and-operator-1"></a>
<a name="index-and-operator-1"></a>
<p>Return its first argument if neither argument is null or zero, otherwise
0.  It does not evaluate its second argument if its first argument is
null or zero.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>&lt; &lt;= = == != &gt;= &gt;</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_003c"></a>
<a name="index-_003c_003d"></a>
<a name="index-_003d"></a>
<a name="index-_003d_003d"></a>
<a name="index-_003e"></a>
<a name="index-_003e_003d"></a>
<a name="index-comparison-operators"></a>
<a name="index-LC_005fCOLLATE-4"></a>
<p>Compare the arguments and return 1 if the relation is true, 0 otherwise.
<code>==</code> is a synonym for <code>=</code>.  <code>expr</code> first tries to convert
both arguments to integers and do a numeric comparison; if either
conversion fails, it does a lexicographic comparison using the character
collating sequence specified by the <code>LC_COLLATE</code> locale.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Examples-of-expr"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Relations-for-expr" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Relations for expr</a>, Up: <a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">expr invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Examples-of-using-expr"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">16.4.4 Examples of using <code>expr</code></h4>

<a name="index-examples-of-expr"></a>
<p>Here are a few examples, including quoting for shell metacharacters.
</p>
<p>To add 1 to the shell variable <code>foo</code>, in Bourne-compatible shells:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">foo=$(expr $foo + 1)
</pre></div>

<p>To print the non-directory part of the file name stored in
<code>$fname</code>, which need not contain a <code>/</code>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">expr $fname : '.*/\(.*\)' '|' $fname
</pre></div>

<p>An example showing that <code>\+</code> is an operator:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">expr aaa : 'a\+'
&rArr; 3
</pre></div>

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">expr abc : 'a\(.\)c'
&rArr; b
expr index abcdef cz
&rArr; 3
expr index index a
error&rarr; expr: syntax error
expr index + index a
&rArr; 0
</pre></div>

<a name="Redirection"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="n" rel="next">File name manipulation</a>, Previous: <a href="#Conditions" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Conditions</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Redirection-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">17 Redirection</h2>

<a name="index-redirection"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-redirection"></a>

<p>Unix shells commonly provide several forms of <em>redirection</em>&mdash;ways
to change the input source or output destination of a command.  But one
useful redirection is performed by a separate command, not by the shell;
it&rsquo;s described here.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#tee-invocation" accesskey="1">tee invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Redirect output to multiple files or processes.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="tee-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Up: <a href="#Redirection" accesskey="u" rel="up">Redirection</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="tee_003a-Redirect-output-to-multiple-files-or-processes"></a>
<h3 class="section">17.1 <code>tee</code>: Redirect output to multiple files or processes</h3>

<a name="index-tee"></a>
<a name="index-pipe-fitting"></a>
<a name="index-destinations_002c-multiple-output"></a>
<a name="index-read-from-stdin-and-write-to-stdout-and-files"></a>

<p>The <code>tee</code> command copies standard input to standard output and also
to any files given as arguments.  This is useful when you want not only
to send some data down a pipe, but also to save a copy.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tee [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>file</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If a file being written to does not already exist, it is created.  If a
file being written to already exists, the data it previously contained
is overwritten unless the <samp>-a</samp> option is used.
</p>
<p>In previous versions of GNU coreutils (v5.3.0 - v8.23), a <var>file</var> of &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;
caused <code>tee</code> to send another copy of input to standard output.
However, as the interleaved output was not very useful, <code>tee</code> now
conforms to POSIX which explicitly mandates it to treat &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; as a file
with such name.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--append</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dappend"></a>
<p>Append standard input to the given files rather than overwriting
them.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-interrupts</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002dinterrupts"></a>
<p>Ignore interrupt signals.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output-error[=<var>mode</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002doutput_002derror"></a>
<p>Adjust the behavior with errors on the outputs,
with the long form option supporting selection
between the following <var>mode</var>s:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>warn</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Warn on error opening or writing any output, including pipes.
Writing is continued to still open files/pipes.
Exit status indicates failure if any output has an error.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>warn-nopipe</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>This is the default <var>mode</var> when not specified,
or when the short form <samp>-p</samp> is used.
Warn on error opening or writing any output, except pipes.
Writing is continued to still open files/pipes.
Exit status indicates failure if any non pipe output had an error.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>exit</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Exit on error opening or writing any output, including pipes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>exit-nopipe</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Exit on error opening or writing any output, except pipes.
</p></dd>
</dl>

</dd>
</dl>

<p>The <code>tee</code> command is useful when you happen to be transferring a large
amount of data and also want to summarize that data without reading
it a second time.  For example, when you are downloading a DVD image,
you often want to verify its signature or checksum right away.
The inefficient way to do it is simply:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">wget https://example.com/some.iso &amp;&amp; sha1sum some.iso
</pre></div>

<p>One problem with the above is that it makes you wait for the
download to complete before starting the time-consuming SHA1 computation.
Perhaps even more importantly, the above requires reading
the DVD image a second time (the first was from the network).
</p>
<p>The efficient way to do it is to interleave the download
and SHA1 computation.  Then, you&rsquo;ll get the checksum for
free, because the entire process parallelizes so well:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># slightly contrived, to demonstrate process substitution
wget -O - https://example.com/dvd.iso \
  | tee &gt;(sha1sum &gt; dvd.sha1) &gt; dvd.iso
</pre></div>

<p>That makes <code>tee</code> write not just to the expected output file,
but also to a pipe running <code>sha1sum</code> and saving the final
checksum in a file named <samp>dvd.sha1</samp>.
</p>
<p>Note, however, that this example relies on a feature of modern shells
called <em>process substitution</em>
(the &lsquo;<samp>&gt;(command)</samp>&rsquo; syntax, above;
See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/bash.html#Process-Substitution">Process Substitution</a> in <cite>The Bash Reference Manual</cite>.),
so it works with <code>zsh</code>, <code>bash</code>, and <code>ksh</code>,
but not with <code>/bin/sh</code>.  So if you write code like this
in a shell script, be sure to start the script with &lsquo;<samp>#!/bin/bash</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>Note also that if any of the process substitutions (or piped stdout)
might exit early without consuming all the data, the <samp>-p</samp> option
is needed to allow <code>tee</code> to continue to process the input
to any remaining outputs.
</p>
<p>Since the above example writes to one file and one process,
a more conventional and portable use of <code>tee</code> is even better:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">wget -O - https://example.com/dvd.iso \
  | tee dvd.iso | sha1sum &gt; dvd.sha1
</pre></div>

<p>You can extend this example to make <code>tee</code> write to two processes,
computing MD5 and SHA1 checksums in parallel.  In this case,
process substitution is required:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">wget -O - https://example.com/dvd.iso \
  | tee &gt;(sha1sum &gt; dvd.sha1) \
        &gt;(md5sum &gt; dvd.md5) \
  &gt; dvd.iso
</pre></div>

<p>This technique is also useful when you want to make a <em>compressed</em>
copy of the contents of a pipe.
Consider a tool to graphically summarize disk usage data from &lsquo;<samp>du -ak</samp>&rsquo;.
For a large hierarchy, &lsquo;<samp>du -ak</samp>&rsquo; can run for a long time,
and can easily produce terabytes of data, so you won&rsquo;t want to
rerun the command unnecessarily.  Nor will you want to save
the uncompressed output.
</p>
<p>Doing it the inefficient way, you can&rsquo;t even start the GUI
until after you&rsquo;ve compressed all of the <code>du</code> output:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">du -ak | gzip -9 &gt; /tmp/du.gz
gzip -d /tmp/du.gz | xdiskusage -a
</pre></div>

<p>With <code>tee</code> and process substitution, you start the GUI
right away and eliminate the decompression completely:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">du -ak | tee &gt;(gzip -9 &gt; /tmp/du.gz) | xdiskusage -a
</pre></div>

<p>Finally, if you regularly create more than one type of
compressed tarball at once, for example when <code>make dist</code> creates
both <code>gzip</code>-compressed and <code>bzip2</code>-compressed tarballs,
there may be a better way.
Typical <code>automake</code>-generated <samp>Makefile</samp> rules create
the two compressed tar archives with commands in sequence, like this
(slightly simplified):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tardir=your-pkg-M.N
tar chof - &quot;$tardir&quot; | gzip  -9 -c &gt; your-pkg-M.N.tar.gz
tar chof - &quot;$tardir&quot; | bzip2 -9 -c &gt; your-pkg-M.N.tar.bz2
</pre></div>

<p>However, if the hierarchy you are archiving and compressing is larger
than a couple megabytes, and especially if you are using a multi-processor
system with plenty of memory, then you can do much better by reading the
directory contents only once and running the compression programs in parallel:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tardir=your-pkg-M.N
tar chof - &quot;$tardir&quot; \
  | tee &gt;(gzip -9 -c &gt; your-pkg-M.N.tar.gz) \
  | bzip2 -9 -c &gt; your-pkg-M.N.tar.bz2
</pre></div>

<p>If you want to further process the output from process substitutions,
and those processes write atomically (i.e., write less than the system&rsquo;s
PIPE_BUF size at a time), that&rsquo;s possible with a construct like:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tardir=your-pkg-M.N
tar chof - &quot;$tardir&quot; \
  | tee &gt;(md5sum --tag) &gt; &gt;(sha256sum --tag) \
  | sort | gpg --clearsign &gt; your-pkg-M.N.tar.sig
</pre></div>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>

<div class="header">
