<a name="File-name-manipulation-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">18 File name manipulation</h2>

<a name="index-file-name-manipulation"></a>
<a name="index-manipulation-of-file-names"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-file-name-manipulation"></a>

<p>This section describes commands that manipulate file names.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#basename-invocation" accesskey="1">basename invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Strip directory and suffix from a file name.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#dirname-invocation" accesskey="2">dirname invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Strip last file name component.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#pathchk-invocation" accesskey="3">pathchk invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Check file name validity and portability.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#mktemp-invocation" accesskey="4">mktemp invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Create temporary file or directory.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#realpath-invocation" accesskey="5">realpath invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print resolved file names.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="basename-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#dirname-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">dirname invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="u" rel="up">File name manipulation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="basename_003a-Strip-directory-and-suffix-from-a-file-name"></a>
<h3 class="section">18.1 <code>basename</code>: Strip directory and suffix from a file name</h3>

<a name="index-basename"></a>
<a name="index-strip-directory-and-suffix-from-file-names"></a>
<a name="index-directory_002c-stripping-from-file-names"></a>
<a name="index-suffix_002c-stripping-from-file-names"></a>
<a name="index-file-names_002c-stripping-directory-and-suffix"></a>
<a name="index-leading-directory-components_002c-stripping"></a>

<p><code>basename</code> removes any leading directory components from
<var>name</var>.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">basename <var>name</var> [<var>suffix</var>]
basename <var>option</var>&hellip; <var>name</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If <var>suffix</var> is specified and is identical to the end of <var>name</var>,
it is removed from <var>name</var> as well.  Note that since trailing slashes
are removed prior to suffix matching, <var>suffix</var> will do nothing if it
contains slashes.  <code>basename</code> prints the result on standard
output.
</p>
<p>Together, <code>basename</code> and <code>dirname</code> are designed such
that if &lsquo;<samp>ls &quot;$name&quot;</samp>&rsquo; succeeds, then the command sequence &lsquo;<samp>cd
&quot;$(dirname &quot;$name&quot;)&quot;; ls &quot;$(basename &quot;$name&quot;)&quot;</samp>&rsquo; will, too.  This works
for everything except file names containing a trailing newline.
</p>
<p>POSIX allows the implementation to define the results if
<var>name</var> is empty or &lsquo;<samp>//</samp>&rsquo;.  In the former case, GNU
<code>basename</code> returns the empty string.  In the latter case, the
result is &lsquo;<samp>//</samp>&rsquo; on platforms where <var>//</var> is distinct from
<var>/</var>, and &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; on platforms where there is no difference.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--multiple</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmultiple"></a>
<p>Support more than one argument.  Treat every argument as a <var>name</var>.
With this, an optional <var>suffix</var> must be specified using the
<samp>-s</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-22"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix-5"></a>
<p>Remove a trailing <var>suffix</var>.
This option implies the <samp>-a</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero-3"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-3"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Output &quot;sort&quot;.
basename /usr/bin/sort

# Output &quot;stdio&quot;.
basename include/stdio.h .h

# Output &quot;stdio&quot;.
basename -s .h include/stdio.h

# Output &quot;stdio&quot; followed by &quot;stdlib&quot;
basename -a -s .h include/stdio.h include/stdlib.h
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="dirname-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#pathchk-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">pathchk invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#basename-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">basename invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="u" rel="up">File name manipulation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="dirname_003a-Strip-last-file-name-component"></a>
<h3 class="section">18.2 <code>dirname</code>: Strip last file name component</h3>

<a name="index-dirname"></a>
<a name="index-directory-components_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-stripping-non_002ddirectory-suffix"></a>
<a name="index-non_002ddirectory-suffix_002c-stripping"></a>

<p><code>dirname</code> prints all but the final slash-delimited component
of each <var>name</var>.  Slashes on either side of the final component are
also removed.  If the string contains no slash, <code>dirname</code>
prints &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; (meaning the current directory).  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">dirname [<var>option</var>] <var>name</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><var>name</var> need not be a file name, but if it is, this operation
effectively lists the directory that contains the final component,
including the case when the final component is itself a directory.
</p>
<p>Together, <code>basename</code> and <code>dirname</code> are designed such
that if &lsquo;<samp>ls &quot;$name&quot;</samp>&rsquo; succeeds, then the command sequence &lsquo;<samp>cd
&quot;$(dirname &quot;$name&quot;)&quot;; ls &quot;$(basename &quot;$name&quot;)&quot;</samp>&rsquo; will, too.  This works
for everything except file names containing a trailing newline.
</p>
<p>POSIX allows the implementation to define the results if
<var>name</var> is &lsquo;<samp>//</samp>&rsquo;.  With GNU <code>dirname</code>, the
result is &lsquo;<samp>//</samp>&rsquo; on platforms where <var>//</var> is distinct from
<var>/</var>, and &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; on platforms where there is no difference.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following option.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero-4"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-4"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>Examples:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Output &quot;/usr/bin&quot;.
dirname /usr/bin/sort
dirname /usr/bin//.//

# Output &quot;dir1&quot; followed by &quot;dir2&quot;
dirname dir1/str dir2/str

# Output &quot;.&quot;.
dirname stdio.h
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="pathchk-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#mktemp-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">mktemp invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#dirname-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">dirname invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="u" rel="up">File name manipulation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="pathchk_003a-Check-file-name-validity-and-portability"></a>
<h3 class="section">18.3 <code>pathchk</code>: Check file name validity and portability</h3>

<a name="index-pathchk"></a>
<a name="index-file-names_002c-checking-validity-and-portability"></a>
<a name="index-valid-file-names_002c-checking-for"></a>
<a name="index-portable-file-names_002c-checking-for"></a>

<p><code>pathchk</code> checks validity and portability of file names.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">pathchk [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>name</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>For each <var>name</var>, <code>pathchk</code> prints an error message if any of
these conditions is true:
</p>
<ol>
<li> One of the existing directories in <var>name</var> does not have search
(execute) permission,
</li><li> The length of <var>name</var> is larger than the maximum supported by the
operating system.
</li><li> The length of one component of <var>name</var> is longer than
its file system&rsquo;s maximum.
</li></ol>

<p>A nonexistent <var>name</var> is not an error, so long a file with that
name could be created under the above conditions.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-9"></a>
<p>Instead of performing checks based on the underlying file system,
print an error message if any of these conditions is true:
</p>
<ol>
<li> A file name is empty.

</li><li> A file name contains a character outside the POSIX portable file
name character set, namely, the ASCII letters and digits, &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>_</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo;.

</li><li> The length of a file name or one of its components exceeds the
POSIX minimum limits for portability.
</li></ol>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-7"></a>
<p>Print an error message if a file name is empty, or if it contains a component
that begins with &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--portability</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dportability-1"></a>
<p>Print an error message if a file name is not portable to all POSIX
hosts.  This option is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>-p -P</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-pathchk"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if all specified file names passed all checks,
1 otherwise.
</pre></div>

<hr>
<a name="mktemp-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#realpath-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">realpath invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#pathchk-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">pathchk invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="u" rel="up">File name manipulation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="mktemp_003a-Create-temporary-file-or-directory"></a>
<h3 class="section">18.4 <code>mktemp</code>: Create temporary file or directory</h3>

<a name="index-mktemp"></a>
<a name="index-file-names_002c-creating-temporary"></a>
<a name="index-directory_002c-creating-temporary"></a>
<a name="index-temporary-files-and-directories"></a>

<p><code>mktemp</code> manages the creation of temporary files and
directories.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">mktemp [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>template</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>Safely create a temporary file or directory based on <var>template</var>,
and print its name.  If given, <var>template</var> must include at least
three consecutive &lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo;s in the last component.  If omitted, the template
&lsquo;<samp>tmp.XXXXXXXXXX</samp>&rsquo; is used, and option <samp>--tmpdir</samp> is
implied.  The final run of &lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo;s in the <var>template</var> will be replaced
by alpha-numeric characters; thus, on a case-sensitive file system,
and with a <var>template</var> including a run of <var>n</var> instances of &lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo;,
there are &lsquo;<samp>62**<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo; potential file names.
</p>
<p>Older scripts used to create temporary files by simply joining the
name of the program with the process id (&lsquo;<samp>$$</samp>&rsquo;) as a suffix.
However, that naming scheme is easily predictable, and suffers from a
race condition where the attacker can create an appropriately named
symbolic link, such that when the script then opens a handle to what
it thought was an unused file, it is instead modifying an existing
file.  Using the same scheme to create a directory is slightly safer,
since the <code>mkdir</code> will fail if the target already exists, but
it is still inferior because it allows for denial of service attacks.
Therefore, modern scripts should use the <code>mktemp</code> command to
guarantee that the generated name will be unpredictable, and that
knowledge of the temporary file name implies that the file was created
by the current script and cannot be modified by other users.
</p>
<p>When creating a file, the resulting file has read and write
permissions for the current user, but no permissions for the group or
others; these permissions are reduced if the current umask is more
restrictive.
</p>
<p>Here are some examples (although note that if you repeat them, you
will most likely get different file names):
</p>
<ul>
<li> Create a temporary file in the current directory.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ mktemp file.XXXX
file.H47c
</pre></div>

</li><li> Create a temporary file with a known suffix.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ mktemp --suffix=.txt file-XXXX
file-H08W.txt
$ mktemp file-XXXX-XXXX.txt
file-XXXX-eI9L.txt
</pre></div>

</li><li> Create a secure fifo relative to the user&rsquo;s choice of <code>TMPDIR</code>,
but falling back to the current directory rather than <samp>/tmp</samp>.
Note that <code>mktemp</code> does not create fifos, but can create a
secure directory in which the fifo can live.  Exit the shell if the
directory or fifo could not be created.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ dir=$(mktemp -p &quot;${TMPDIR:-.}&quot; -d dir-XXXX) || exit 1
$ fifo=$dir/fifo
$ mkfifo &quot;$fifo&quot; || { rmdir &quot;$dir&quot;; exit 1; }
</pre></div>

</li><li> Create and use a temporary file if possible, but ignore failure.  The
file will reside in the directory named by <code>TMPDIR</code>, if specified,
or else in <samp>/tmp</samp>.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ file=$(mktemp -q) &amp;&amp; {
&gt;   # Safe to use $file only within this block.  Use quotes,
&gt;   # since $TMPDIR, and thus $file, may contain whitespace.
&gt;   echo ... &gt; &quot;$file&quot;
&gt;   rm &quot;$file&quot;
&gt; }
</pre></div>

</li><li> Act as a semi-random character generator (it is not fully random,
since it is impacted by the contents of the current directory).  To
avoid security holes, do not use the resulting names to create a file.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ mktemp -u XXX
Gb9
$ mktemp -u XXX
nzC
</pre></div>

</li></ul>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--directory</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddirectory-3"></a>
<p>Create a directory rather than a file.  The directory will have read,
write, and search permissions for the current user, but no permissions
for the group or others; these permissions are reduced if the current
umask is more restrictive.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dq-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-8"></a>
<p>Suppress diagnostics about failure to create a file or directory.  The
exit status will still reflect whether a file was created.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dry-run</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddry_002drun"></a>
<p>Generate a temporary name that does not name an existing file, without
changing the file system contents.  Using the output of this command
to create a new file is inherently unsafe, as there is a window of
time between generating the name and using it where another process
can create an object by the same name.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p <var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--tmpdir[=<var>dir</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtmpdir"></a>
<p>Treat <var>template</var> relative to the directory <var>dir</var>.  If
<var>dir</var> is not specified (only possible with the long option
<samp>--tmpdir</samp>) or is the empty string, use the value of
<code>TMPDIR</code> if available, otherwise use &lsquo;<samp>/tmp</samp>&rsquo;.  If this is
specified, <var>template</var> must not be absolute.  However,
<var>template</var> can still contain slashes, although intermediate
directories must already exist.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix-6"></a>
<p>Append <var>suffix</var> to the <var>template</var>.  <var>suffix</var> must not
contain slash.  If <samp>--suffix</samp> is specified, <var>template</var> must
end in &lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo;; if it is not specified, then an appropriate
<samp>--suffix</samp> is inferred by finding the last &lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo; in
<var>template</var>.  This option exists for use with the default
<var>template</var> and for the creation of a <var>suffix</var> that starts with
&lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-18"></a>
<p>Treat <var>template</var> as a single file relative to the value of
<code>TMPDIR</code> if available, or to the directory specified by
<samp>-p</samp>, otherwise to &lsquo;<samp>/tmp</samp>&rsquo;.  <var>template</var> must not
contain slashes.  This option is deprecated; the use of <samp>-p</samp>
without <samp>-t</samp> offers better defaults (by favoring the command
line over <code>TMPDIR</code>) and more flexibility (by allowing intermediate
directories).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-mktemp"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if the file was created,
1 otherwise.
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="realpath-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#mktemp-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">mktemp invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="u" rel="up">File name manipulation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="realpath_003a-Print-the-resolved-file-name_002e"></a>
<h3 class="section">18.5 <code>realpath</code>: Print the resolved file name.</h3>

<a name="index-realpath-2"></a>
<a name="index-file-names_002c-canonicalization"></a>
<a name="index-symlinks_002c-resolution"></a>
<a name="index-canonical-file-name-1"></a>
<a name="index-canonicalize-a-file-name-1"></a>
<a name="index-realpath-3"></a>
<a name="index-realpath-1"></a>

<p><code>realpath</code> expands all symbolic links and resolves references to
&lsquo;<samp>/./</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>/../</samp>&rsquo; and extra &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; characters.  By default,
all but the last component of the specified files must exist.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">realpath [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The file name canonicalization functionality overlaps with that of the
<code>readlink</code> command.  This is the preferred command for
canonicalization as it&rsquo;s a more suitable and standard name.  In addition
this command supports relative file name processing functionality.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--canonicalize-existing</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dexisting-1"></a>
<p>Ensure that all components of the specified file names exist.
If any component is missing or unavailable, <code>realpath</code> will output
a diagnostic unless the <samp>-q</samp> option is specified, and exit with a
nonzero exit code.  A trailing slash requires that the name resolve to a
directory.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--canonicalize-missing</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dmissing-1"></a>
<p>If any component of a specified file name is missing or unavailable,
treat it as a directory.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--logical</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlogical-1"></a>
<p>Symbolic links are resolved in the specified file names,
but they are resolved after any subsequent &lsquo;<samp>..</samp>&rsquo; components are processed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--physical</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dphysical-1"></a>
<p>Symbolic links are resolved in the specified file names,
and they are resolved before any subsequent &lsquo;<samp>..</samp>&rsquo; components are processed.
This is the default mode of operation.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dq-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-9"></a>
<p>Suppress diagnostic messages for specified file names.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--relative-to=<var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002drelative_002dto"></a>
<a name="index-relpath"></a>
<p>Print the resolved file names relative to the specified directory.
Note this option honors the <samp>-m</samp> and <samp>-e</samp> options
pertaining to file existence.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--relative-base=<var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002drelative_002dbase"></a>
<p>Print the resolved file names as relative <em>if</em> the files
are descendants of <var>dir</var>.
Otherwise, print the resolved file names as absolute.
Note this option honors the <samp>-m</samp> and <samp>-e</samp> options
pertaining to file existence.
For details about combining <samp>--relative-to</samp> and <samp>--relative-base</samp>,
see <a href="#Realpath-usage-examples">Realpath usage examples</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--strip</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-symlinks</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-23"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dstrip-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dsymlinks"></a>
<p>Do not resolve symbolic links.  Only resolve references to
&lsquo;<samp>/./</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>/../</samp>&rsquo; and remove extra &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo; characters.
When combined with the <samp>-m</samp> option, realpath operates
only on the file name, and does not touch any actual file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero-5"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-5"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-realpath"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if all file names were printed without issue.
1 otherwise.
</pre></div>

<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Realpath-usage-examples" accesskey="1">Realpath usage examples</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Realpath usage examples.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="Realpath-usage-examples"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Up: <a href="#realpath-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">realpath invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Realpath-usage-examples-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">18.5.1 Realpath usage examples</h4>

<a name="index-_002d_002drelative_002dto-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drelative_002dbase-1"></a>

<p>By default, <code>realpath</code> prints the absolute file name of given files
(symlinks are resolved, <samp>words</samp> is resolved to <samp>american-english</samp>):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">cd /home/user
realpath /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
&rArr; /usr/bin/sort
&rArr; /tmp/foo
&rArr; /usr/share/dict/american-english
&rArr; /home/user/1.txt
</pre></div>

<p>With <samp>--relative-to</samp>, file names are printed relative to
the given directory:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">realpath --relative-to=/usr/bin \
         /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
&rArr; sort
&rArr; ../../tmp/foo
&rArr; ../share/dict/american-english
&rArr; ../../home/user/1.txt
</pre></div>

<p>With <samp>--relative-base</samp>, relative file names are printed <em>if</em>
the resolved file name is below the given base directory. For files outside the
base directory absolute file names are printed:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">realpath --relative-base=/usr \
         /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
&rArr; bin/sort
&rArr; /tmp/foo
&rArr; share/dict/american-english
&rArr; /home/user/1.txt
</pre></div>

<p>When both <samp>--relative-to=DIR1</samp> and <samp>--relative-base=DIR2</samp>
are used, file names are printed relative to <var>dir1</var> <em>if</em> they are
located below <var>dir2</var>. If the files are not below <var>dir2</var>, they are
printed as absolute file names:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">realpath --relative-to=/usr/bin --relative-base=/usr \
         /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
&rArr; sort
&rArr; /tmp/foo
&rArr; ../share/dict/american-english
&rArr; /home/user/1.txt
</pre></div>

<p>When both <samp>--relative-to=DIR1</samp> and <samp>--relative-base=DIR2</samp>
are used, <var>dir1</var> <em>must</em> be a subdirectory of <var>dir2</var>. Otherwise,
<code>realpath</code> prints absolutes file names.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Working-context"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="n" rel="next">User information</a>, Previous: <a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">File name manipulation</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Working-context-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">19 Working context</h2>

<a name="index-working-context"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-printing-the-working-context"></a>

<p>This section describes commands that display or alter the context in
which you are working: the current directory, the terminal settings, and
so forth.  See also the user-related commands in the next section.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#pwd-invocation" accesskey="1">pwd invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print working directory.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="2">stty invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print or change terminal characteristics.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#printenv-invocation" accesskey="3">printenv invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print environment variables.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#tty-invocation" accesskey="4">tty invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print file name of terminal on standard input.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="pwd-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">stty invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Working-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">Working context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="pwd_003a-Print-working-directory"></a>
<h3 class="section">19.1 <code>pwd</code>: Print working directory</h3>

<a name="index-pwd"></a>
<a name="index-print-name-of-current-directory"></a>
<a name="index-current-working-directory_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-working-directory_002c-printing"></a>


<p><code>pwd</code> prints the name of the current directory.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">pwd [<var>option</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--logical</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlogical-2"></a>
<p>If the contents of the environment variable <code>PWD</code> provide an
absolute name of the current directory with no &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>..</samp>&rsquo;
components, but possibly with symbolic links, then output those
contents.  Otherwise, fall back to default <samp>-P</samp> handling.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--physical</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dphysical-2"></a>
<p>Print a fully resolved name for the current directory.  That is, all
components of the printed name will be actual directory names&mdash;none
will be symbolic links.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-symbolic-links-and-pwd"></a>
<p>If <samp>-L</samp> and <samp>-P</samp> are both given, the last one takes
precedence.  If neither option is given, then this implementation uses
<samp>-P</samp> as the default unless the <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code>
environment variable is set.
</p>
<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-5"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-5"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>pwd</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>pwd</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env pwd &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>

<div class="header">
<p>

</div>
<a name="stty_003a-Print-or-change-terminal-characteristics"></a>
<h3 class="section">19.2 <code>stty</code>: Print or change terminal characteristics</h3>

<a name="index-stty"></a>
<a name="index-change-or-print-terminal-settings"></a>
<a name="index-terminal-settings"></a>
<a name="index-line-settings-of-terminal"></a>

<p><code>stty</code> prints or changes terminal characteristics, such as baud rate.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">stty [<var>option</var>] [<var>setting</var>]&hellip;
stty [<var>option</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>If given no line settings, <code>stty</code> prints the baud rate, line
discipline number (on systems that support it), and line settings
that have been changed from the values set by &lsquo;<samp>stty sane</samp>&rsquo;.
By default, mode reading and setting are performed on the tty line
connected to standard input, although this can be modified by the
<samp>--file</samp> option.
</p>
<p><code>stty</code> accepts many non-option arguments that change aspects of
the terminal line operation, as described below.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall-4"></a>
<p>Print all current settings in human-readable form.  This option may not
be used in combination with any line settings.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-F <var>device</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--file=<var>device</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dF-5"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfile"></a>
<p>Set the line opened by the file name specified in <var>device</var> instead of
the tty line connected to standard input.  This option is necessary
because opening a POSIX tty requires use of the
<code>O_NONDELAY</code> flag to prevent a POSIX tty from blocking
until the carrier detect line is high if
the <code>clocal</code> flag is not set.  Hence, it is not always possible
to allow the shell to open the device in the traditional manner.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--save</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg-6"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsave"></a>
<a name="index-machine_002dreadable-stty-output"></a>
<p>Print all current settings in a form that can be used as an argument to
another <code>stty</code> command to restore the current settings.  This option
may not be used in combination with any line settings.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>Many settings can be turned off by preceding them with a &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.
Such arguments are marked below with &ldquo;May be negated&rdquo; in their
description.  The descriptions themselves refer to the positive
case, that is, when <em>not</em> negated (unless stated otherwise,
of course).
</p>
<p>Some settings are not available on all POSIX systems, since they use
extensions.  Such arguments are marked below with
&ldquo;Non-POSIX&rdquo; in their description.  On non-POSIX
systems, those or other settings also may not
be available, but it&rsquo;s not feasible to document all the variations: just
try it and see.
</p>
<p><code>stty</code> is installed only on platforms with the POSIX terminal
interface, so portable scripts should not rely on its existence on
non-POSIX platforms.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Control" accesskey="1">Control</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Control settings
</td></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Local" accesskey="4">Local</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Local settings
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Combination" accesskey="5">Combination</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Combination settings
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Characters" accesskey="6">Characters</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Special characters
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Special" accesskey="7">Special</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Special settings
</td></tr>
</table>

<a name="Control"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Input" accesskey="n" rel="next">Input</a>, Up: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">stty invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Control-settings"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">19.2.1 Control settings</h4>

<a name="index-control-settings"></a>
<p>Control settings:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>parenb</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-parenb"></a>
<a name="index-two_002dway-parity"></a>
<p>Generate parity bit in output and expect parity bit in input.
May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>parodd</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-parodd"></a>
<a name="index-odd-parity"></a>
<a name="index-even-parity"></a>
<p>Set odd parity (even if negated).  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cmspar</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cmspar"></a>
<a name="index-constant-parity"></a>
<a name="index-stick-parity"></a>
<a name="index-mark-parity"></a>
<a name="index-space-parity"></a>
<p>Use &quot;stick&quot; (mark/space) parity.  If parodd is set, the parity bit is
always 1; if parodd is not set, the parity bit is always zero.
Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cs5</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cs6</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cs7</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cs8</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-csn"></a>
<a name="index-character-size"></a>
<a name="index-eight_002dbit-characters"></a>
<p>Set character size to 5, 6, 7, or 8 bits.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>hup</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>hupcl</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-hup_005bcl_005d"></a>
<p>Send a hangup signal when the last process closes the tty.  May be
negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cstopb</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cstopb"></a>
<a name="index-stop-bits"></a>
<p>Use two stop bits per character (one if negated).  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cread</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cread"></a>
<p>Allow input to be received.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>clocal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-clocal"></a>
<a name="index-modem-control"></a>
<p>Disable modem control signals.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>crtscts</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-crtscts"></a>
<a name="index-hardware-flow-control"></a>
<a name="index-flow-control_002c-hardware"></a>
<a name="index-RTS_002fCTS-flow-control"></a>
<p>Enable RTS/CTS flow control.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cdtrdsr</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cdtrdsr"></a>
<a name="index-hardware-flow-control-1"></a>
<a name="index-flow-control_002c-hardware-1"></a>
<a name="index-DTR_002fDSR-flow-control"></a>
<p>Enable DTR/DSR flow control. Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Input"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Output" accesskey="n" rel="next">Output</a>, Previous: <a href="#Control" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Control</a>, Up: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">stty invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Input-settings"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">19.2.2 Input settings</h4>

<a name="index-input-settings"></a>
<p>These settings control operations on data received from the terminal.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ignbrk</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ignbrk"></a>
<a name="index-breaks_002c-ignoring"></a>
<p>Ignore break characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>brkint</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-brkint"></a>
<a name="index-breaks_002c-cause-interrupts"></a>
<p>Make breaks cause an interrupt signal.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ignpar</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ignpar"></a>
<a name="index-parity_002c-ignoring"></a>
<p>Ignore characters with parity errors.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>parmrk</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-parmrk"></a>
<a name="index-parity-errors_002c-marking"></a>
<p>Mark parity errors (with a 255-0-character sequence).  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>inpck</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-inpck"></a>
<p>Enable input parity checking.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>istrip</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-istrip"></a>
<a name="index-eight_002dbit-input"></a>
<p>Clear high (8th) bit of input characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>inlcr</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-inlcr"></a>
<a name="index-newline_002c-translating-to-return"></a>
<p>Translate newline to carriage return.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>igncr</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-igncr"></a>
<a name="index-return_002c-ignoring"></a>
<p>Ignore carriage return.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>icrnl</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-icrnl"></a>
<a name="index-return_002c-translating-to-newline"></a>
<p>Translate carriage return to newline.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iutf8</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-iutf8"></a>
<a name="index-input-encoding_002c-UTF_002d8"></a>
<p>Assume input characters are UTF-8 encoded.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ixon</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ixon"></a>
<a name="index-C_002ds_002fC_002dq-flow-control"></a>
<a name="index-XON_002fXOFF-flow-control"></a>
<p>Enable XON/XOFF flow control (that is, <kbd>Ctrl-S</kbd>/<kbd>Ctrl-Q</kbd>).  May
be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ixoff</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>tandem</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ixoff"></a>
<a name="index-tandem"></a>
<a name="index-software-flow-control"></a>
<a name="index-flow-control_002c-software"></a>
<p>Enable sending of <code>stop</code> character when the system input buffer
is almost full, and <code>start</code> character when it becomes almost
empty again.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iuclc</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-iuclc"></a>
<a name="index-uppercase_002c-translating-to-lowercase"></a>
<p>Translate uppercase characters to lowercase.  Non-POSIX.  May be
negated.  Note ilcuc is not implemented, as one would not be able to issue
almost any (lowercase) Unix command, after invoking it.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ixany</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ixany"></a>
<p>Allow any character to restart output (only the start character
if negated).  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>imaxbel</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-imaxbel"></a>
<a name="index-beeping-at-input-buffer-full"></a>
<p>Enable beeping and not flushing input buffer if a character arrives
when the input buffer is full.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Output"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Local" accesskey="n" rel="next">Local</a>, Previous: <a href="#Input" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Input</a>, Up: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">stty invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Output-settings"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">19.2.3 Output settings</h4>

<a name="index-output-settings"></a>
<p>These settings control operations on data sent to the terminal.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>opost</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-opost"></a>
<p>Postprocess output.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>olcuc</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-olcuc"></a>
<a name="index-lowercase_002c-translating-to-output"></a>
<p>Translate lowercase characters to uppercase.  Non-POSIX.  May be
negated.  (Note ouclc is not currently implemented.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ocrnl</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ocrnl"></a>
<a name="index-return_002c-translating-to-newline-1"></a>
<p>Translate carriage return to newline.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>onlcr</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-onlcr"></a>
<a name="index-newline_002c-translating-to-crlf"></a>
<p>Translate newline to carriage return-newline.  Non-POSIX.  May be
negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>onocr</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-onocr"></a>
<p>Do not print carriage returns in the first column.  Non-POSIX.
May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>onlret</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-onlret"></a>
<p>Newline performs a carriage return.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ofill</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ofill"></a>
<a name="index-pad-instead-of-timing-for-delaying"></a>
<p>Use fill (padding) characters instead of timing for delays.
Non-POSIX.
May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ofdel</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ofdel"></a>
<a name="index-pad-character"></a>
<p>Use ASCII DEL characters for fill instead of
ASCII NUL characters.  Non-POSIX.
May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nl1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nl0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-nln"></a>
<p>Newline delay style.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cr3</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cr2</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cr1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cr0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-crn"></a>
<p>Carriage return delay style.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>tab3</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>tab2</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>tab1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>tab0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-tabn"></a>
<p>Horizontal tab delay style.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>bs1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>bs0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-bsn"></a>
<p>Backspace delay style.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>vt1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>vt0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-vtn"></a>
<p>Vertical tab delay style.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ff1</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ff0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ffn"></a>
<p>Form feed delay style.  Non-POSIX.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>

<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Combination" accesskey="n" rel="next">Combination</a>, Previous: <a href="#Output" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Output</a>, Up: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">stty invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Local-settings"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">19.2.4 Local settings</h4>

<a name="index-local-settings"></a>

<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>isig</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-isig"></a>
<p>Enable <code>interrupt</code>, <code>quit</code>, and <code>suspend</code> special
characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>icanon</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-icanon"></a>
<p>Enable <code>erase</code>, <code>kill</code>, <code>werase</code>, and <code>rprnt</code>
special characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>iexten</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-iexten"></a>
<p>Enable non-POSIX special characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>echo</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-echo"></a>
<p>Echo input characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>echoe</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>crterase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-echoe"></a>
<a name="index-crterase"></a>
<p>Echo <code>erase</code> characters as backspace-space-backspace.  May be
negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>echok</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-echok"></a>
<a name="index-newline-echoing-after-kill"></a>
<p>Echo a newline after a <code>kill</code> character.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>echonl</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-echonl"></a>
<a name="index-newline_002c-echoing"></a>
<p>Echo newline even if not echoing other characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>noflsh</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-noflsh"></a>
<a name="index-flushing_002c-disabling"></a>
<p>Disable flushing after <code>interrupt</code> and <code>quit</code> special
characters.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>xcase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-xcase"></a>
<a name="index-case-translation"></a>
<p>Enable input and output of uppercase characters by preceding their
lowercase equivalents with &lsquo;<samp>\</samp>&rsquo;, when <code>icanon</code> is set.
Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>tostop</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-tostop"></a>
<a name="index-background-jobs_002c-stopping-at-terminal-write"></a>
<p>Stop background jobs that try to write to the terminal.  Non-POSIX.
May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>echoprt</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>prterase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-echoprt"></a>
<a name="index-prterase"></a>
<p>Echo erased characters backward, between &lsquo;<samp>\</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>/</samp>&rsquo;.
Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>echoctl</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ctlecho</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-echoctl"></a>
<a name="index-ctlecho"></a>
<a name="index-control-characters_002c-using-_005ec"></a>
<a name="index-hat-notation-for-control-characters"></a>
<p>Echo control characters in hat notation (&lsquo;<samp>^<var>c</var></samp>&rsquo;) instead
of literally.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>echoke</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>crtkill</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-echoke"></a>
<a name="index-crtkill"></a>
<p>Echo the <code>kill</code> special character by erasing each character on
the line as indicated by the <code>echoprt</code> and <code>echoe</code> settings,
instead of by the <code>echoctl</code> and <code>echok</code> settings.
Non-POSIX.
May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>extproc</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-extproc"></a>
<p>Enable &lsquo;<samp>LINEMODE</samp>&rsquo;, which is used to avoid echoing
each character over high latency links.  See also
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc1116">Internet RFC 1116</a>.
Non-POSIX.
May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>flusho</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-flusho"></a>
<p>Discard output.
Note this setting is currently ignored on GNU/Linux systems.
Non-POSIX.
May be negated.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Combination"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Characters" accesskey="n" rel="next">Characters</a>, Previous: <a href="#Local" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Local</a>, Up: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">stty invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Combination-settings"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">19.2.5 Combination settings</h4>

<a name="index-combination-settings"></a>
<p>Combination settings:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>evenp</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-evenp"></a>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>parity</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-parity"></a>
<p>Same as <code>parenb -parodd cs7</code>.  May be negated.  If negated, same
as <code>-parenb cs8</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>oddp</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-oddp"></a>
<p>Same as <code>parenb parodd cs7</code>.  May be negated.  If negated, same
as <code>-parenb cs8</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>nl</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-nl"></a>
<p>Same as <code>-icrnl -onlcr</code>.  May be negated.  If negated, same as
<code>icrnl -inlcr -igncr onlcr -ocrnl -onlret</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ek</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ek"></a>
<p>Reset the <code>erase</code> and <code>kill</code> special characters to their default
values.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>sane</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-sane"></a>
<p>Same as:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">cread -ignbrk brkint -inlcr -igncr icrnl
icanon iexten echo echoe echok -echonl -noflsh
-ixoff -iutf8 -iuclc -ixany imaxbel -xcase -olcuc -ocrnl
opost -ofill onlcr -onocr -onlret nl0 cr0 tab0 bs0 vt0 ff0
isig -tostop -ofdel -echoprt echoctl echoke -extproc
</pre></div>

<p>and also sets all special characters to their default values.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cooked</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cooked"></a>
<p>Same as <code>brkint ignpar istrip icrnl ixon opost isig icanon</code>, plus
sets the <code>eof</code> and <code>eol</code> characters to their default values
if they are the same as the <code>min</code> and <code>time</code> characters.
May be negated.  If negated, same as <code>raw</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>raw</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-raw"></a>
<p>Same as:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">-ignbrk -brkint -ignpar -parmrk -inpck -istrip
-inlcr -igncr -icrnl -ixon -ixoff -icanon -opost
-isig -iuclc -ixany -imaxbel -xcase min 1 time 0
</pre></div>

<p>May be negated.  If negated, same as <code>cooked</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cbreak</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cbreak"></a>
<p>Same as <samp>-icanon</samp>.  May be negated.  If negated, same as
<code>icanon</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>pass8</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-pass8"></a>
<a name="index-eight_002dbit-characters-1"></a>
<p>Same as <code>-parenb -istrip cs8</code>.  May be negated.  If negated,
same as <code>parenb istrip cs7</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>litout</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-litout"></a>
<p>Same as <samp>-parenb -istrip -opost cs8</samp>.  May be negated.
If negated, same as <code>parenb istrip opost cs7</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>decctlq</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-decctlq"></a>
<p>Same as <samp>-ixany</samp>.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>tabs</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-tabs"></a>
<p>Same as <code>tab0</code>.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.  If negated, same
as <code>tab3</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>lcase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>LCASE</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-lcase"></a>
<a name="index-LCASE"></a>
<p>Same as <code>xcase iuclc olcuc</code>.  Non-POSIX.  May be negated.
(Used for terminals with uppercase characters only.)
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>crt</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-crt"></a>
<p>Same as <code>echoe echoctl echoke</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>dec</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-dec"></a>
<p>Same as <code>echoe echoctl echoke -ixany intr ^C erase ^? kill C-u</code>.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Characters"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Special" accesskey="n" rel="next">Special</a>, Previous: <a href="#Combination" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Combination</a>, Up: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">stty invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Special-characters"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">19.2.6 Special characters</h4>

<a name="index-special-characters"></a>
<a name="index-characters_002c-special"></a>

<p>The special characters&rsquo; default values vary from system to system.
They are set with the syntax &lsquo;<samp>name value</samp>&rsquo;, where the names are
listed below and the value can be given either literally, in hat
notation (&lsquo;<samp>^<var>c</var></samp>&rsquo;), or as an integer which may start with
&lsquo;<samp>0x</samp>&rsquo; to indicate hexadecimal, &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; to indicate octal, or
any other digit to indicate decimal.
</p>
<a name="index-disabling-special-characters"></a>
<a name="index-u_002c-and-disabling-special-characters"></a>
<p>For GNU stty, giving a value of <code>^-</code> or <code>undef</code> disables that
special character.  (This is incompatible with Ultrix <code>stty</code>,
which uses  a value of &lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo; to disable a special character.  GNU
<code>stty</code> treats a value &lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo; like any other, namely to set that
special character to <tt class="key">U</tt>.)
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>intr</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-intr"></a>
<p>Send an interrupt signal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>quit</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-quit"></a>
<p>Send a quit signal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>erase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-erase"></a>
<p>Erase the last character typed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>kill</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-kill"></a>
<p>Erase the current line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>eof</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-eof"></a>
<p>Send an end of file (terminate the input).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>eol</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-eol"></a>
<p>End the line.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>eol2</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-eol2"></a>
<p>Alternate character to end the line.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>discard</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-discard"></a>
<a name="index-flush"></a>
<p>Alternate character to toggle discarding of output.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>swtch</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-swtch"></a>
<p>Switch to a different shell layer.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>status</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-status-1"></a>
<p>Send an info signal.  Not currently supported on Linux.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>start</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-start"></a>
<p>Restart the output after stopping it.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>stop</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-stop"></a>
<p>Stop the output.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>susp</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-susp"></a>
<p>Send a terminal stop signal.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>dsusp</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-dsusp"></a>
<p>Send a terminal stop signal after flushing the input.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>rprnt</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-rprnt"></a>
<p>Redraw the current line.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>werase</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-werase"></a>
<p>Erase the last word typed.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>lnext</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-lnext"></a>
<p>Enter the next character typed literally, even if it is a special
character.  Non-POSIX.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Special"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Characters" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Characters</a>, Up: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">stty invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Special-settings"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">19.2.7 Special settings</h4>

<a name="index-special-settings"></a>

<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>min <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-min"></a>
<p>Set the minimum number of characters that will satisfy a read until
the time value has expired, when <samp>-icanon</samp> is set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>time <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-time-1"></a>
<p>Set the number of tenths of a second before reads time out if the minimum
number of characters have not been read, when <samp>-icanon</samp> is set.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ispeed <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ispeed"></a>
<p>Set the input speed to <var>n</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ospeed <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-ospeed"></a>
<p>Set the output speed to <var>n</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>rows <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-rows"></a>
<p>Tell the tty kernel driver that the terminal has <var>n</var> rows.
Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>cols <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>columns <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-cols"></a>
<a name="index-columns"></a>
<p>Tell the kernel that the terminal has <var>n</var> columns.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>drain</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-drain"></a>
<a name="index-nonblocking-stty-setting"></a>
<p>Apply settings after first waiting for pending output to be transmitted.
This is enabled by default for GNU <code>stty</code>.
It is useful to disable this option
in cases where the system may be in a state where serial transmission
is not possible.
For example, if the system has received the &lsquo;<samp>DC3</samp>&rsquo; character
with <code>ixon</code> (software flow control) enabled, then <code>stty</code> would
block without <code>-drain</code> being specified.
May be negated. Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>size</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-size"></a>
<a name="index-LINES"></a>
<a name="index-COLUMNS-1"></a>
<p>Print the number of rows and columns that the kernel thinks the
terminal has.  (Systems that don&rsquo;t support rows and columns in the kernel
typically use the environment variables <code>LINES</code> and <code>COLUMNS</code>
instead; however, GNU <code>stty</code> does not know anything about them.)
Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>line <var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-line"></a>
<p>Use line discipline <var>n</var>.  Non-POSIX.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>speed</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-speed"></a>
<p>Print the terminal speed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-baud-rate_002c-setting"></a>
<p>Set the input and output speeds to <var>n</var>.  <var>n</var> can be one of: 0
50 75 110 134 134.5 150 200 300 600 1200 1800 2400 4800 9600 19200
38400 <code>exta</code> <code>extb</code>.  <code>exta</code> is the same as 19200;
<code>extb</code> is the same as 38400.  Many systems, including GNU/Linux,
support higher speeds.  The <code>stty</code> command includes support
for speeds of
57600,
115200,
230400,
460800,
500000,
576000,
921600,
1000000,
1152000,
1500000,
2000000,
2500000,
3000000,
3500000,
or
4000000 where the system supports these.
0 hangs up the line if <samp>-clocal</samp> is set.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="printenv-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#tty-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">tty invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#stty-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">stty invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Working-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">Working context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="printenv_003a-Print-all-or-some-environment-variables"></a>
<h3 class="section">19.3 <code>printenv</code>: Print all or some environment variables</h3>

<a name="index-printenv"></a>
<a name="index-printing-all-or-some-environment-variables"></a>
<a name="index-environment-variables_002c-printing"></a>

<p><code>printenv</code> prints environment variable values.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">printenv [<var>option</var>] [<var>variable</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If no <var>variable</var>s are specified, <code>printenv</code> prints the value of
every environment variable.  Otherwise, it prints the value of each
<var>variable</var> that is set, and nothing for those that are not set.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following option.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--null</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d0-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnull-1"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-6"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-printenv"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if all variables specified were found
1 if at least one specified variable was not found
2 if a write error occurred
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="tty-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#printenv-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">printenv invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Working-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">Working context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="tty_003a-Print-file-name-of-terminal-on-standard-input"></a>
<h3 class="section">19.4 <code>tty</code>: Print file name of terminal on standard input</h3>

<a name="index-tty"></a>
<a name="index-print-terminal-file-name"></a>
<a name="index-terminal-file-name_002c-printing"></a>

<p><code>tty</code> prints the file name of the terminal connected to its standard
input.  It prints &lsquo;<samp>not a tty</samp>&rsquo; if standard input is not a terminal.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">tty [<var>option</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The program accepts the following option.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--silent</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--quiet</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-24"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsilent-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dquiet-10"></a>
<p>Print nothing; only return an exit status.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-tty"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0 if standard input is a terminal
1 if standard input is a non-terminal file
2 if given incorrect arguments
3 if a write error occurs
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="User-information"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="n" rel="next">System context</a>, Previous: <a href="#Working-context" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Working context</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="User-information-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">20 User information</h2>

<a name="index-user-information_002c-commands-for"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-printing-user-information"></a>

<p>This section describes commands that print user-related information:
logins, groups, and so forth.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#id-invocation" accesskey="1">id invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print user identity.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#logname-invocation" accesskey="2">logname invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print current login name.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#whoami-invocation" accesskey="3">whoami invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print effective user ID.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#groups-invocation" accesskey="4">groups invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print group names a user is in.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#users-invocation" accesskey="5">users invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print login names of users currently logged in.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#who-invocation" accesskey="6">who invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print who is currently logged in.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="id-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#logname-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">logname invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="u" rel="up">User information</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="id_003a-Print-user-identity"></a>
<h3 class="section">20.1 <code>id</code>: Print user identity</h3>

<a name="index-id"></a>
<a name="index-real-user-and-group-IDs_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-effective-user-and-group-IDs_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-printing-real-and-effective-user-and-group-IDs"></a>

<p><code>id</code> prints information about the given user, or the process
running it if no user is specified.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">id [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>user</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><var>user</var> can be either a user ID or a name, with name look-up
taking precedence unless the ID is specified with a leading &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;.
See <a href="#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs">Disambiguating names and IDs</a>.
</p>
<a name="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-8"></a>
<p>By default, it prints the real user ID, real group ID, effective user ID
if different from the real user ID, effective group ID if different from
the real group ID, and supplemental group IDs.
In addition, if SELinux
is enabled and the <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> environment variable is not set,
then print &lsquo;<samp>context=<var>c</var></samp>&rsquo;, where <var>c</var> is the security context.
</p>
<p>Each of these numeric values is preceded by an identifying string and
followed by the corresponding user or group name in parentheses.
</p>
<p>The options cause <code>id</code> to print only part of the above information.
Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-g</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--group</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dg-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dgroup-2"></a>
<p>Print only the group ID.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-G</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--groups</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dG-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dgroups"></a>
<p>Print only the group ID and the supplementary groups.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--name</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dname"></a>
<p>Print the user or group name instead of the ID number.  Requires
<samp>-u</samp>, <samp>-g</samp>, or <samp>-G</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--real</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dreal"></a>
<p>Print the real, instead of effective, user or group ID.  Requires
<samp>-u</samp>, <samp>-g</samp>, or <samp>-G</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--user</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002duser"></a>
<p>Print only the user ID.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--context</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dZ-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcontext-7"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux-2"></a>
<a name="index-security-context-8"></a>
<p>Print only the security context of the process, which is generally
the user&rsquo;s security context inherited from the parent process.
If neither SELinux or SMACK is enabled then print a warning and
set the exit status to 1.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero-6"></a>
<p>Delimit output items with ASCII NUL characters.
This option is not permitted when using the default format.
When multiple users are specified, and the <samp>--groups</samp> option
is also in effect, groups are delimited with a single NUL character,
while users are delimited with two NUL characters.
</p>
<p>Example:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ id -Gn --zero
users &lt;NUL&gt; devs &lt;NUL&gt;
</pre></div>

</dd>
</dl>

<p>Primary and supplementary groups for a process are normally inherited
from its parent and are usually unchanged since login.  This means
that if you change the group database after logging in, <code>id</code>
will not reflect your changes within your existing login session.
Running <code>id</code> with a user argument causes the user and group
database to be consulted afresh, and so will give a different result.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="logname-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#whoami-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">whoami invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#id-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">id invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="u" rel="up">User information</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="logname_003a-Print-current-login-name"></a>
<h3 class="section">20.2 <code>logname</code>: Print current login name</h3>

<a name="index-logname"></a>
<a name="index-printing-user_0027s-login-name"></a>
<a name="index-login-name_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-user-name_002c-printing"></a>

<a name="index-utmp"></a>
<p><code>logname</code> prints the calling user&rsquo;s name, as found in a
system-maintained file (often <samp>/var/run/utmp</samp> or
<samp>/etc/utmp</samp>), and exits with a status of 0.  If there is no entry
for the calling process, <code>logname</code> prints
an error message and exits with a status of 1.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="whoami-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#groups-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">groups invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#logname-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">logname invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="u" rel="up">User information</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="whoami_003a-Print-effective-user-ID"></a>
<h3 class="section">20.3 <code>whoami</code>: Print effective user ID</h3>

<a name="index-whoami"></a>
<a name="index-effective-user-ID_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-printing-the-effective-user-ID"></a>

<p><code>whoami</code> prints the user name associated with the current
effective user ID.  It is equivalent to the command &lsquo;<samp>id -un</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="groups-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#users-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">users invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#whoami-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">whoami invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="u" rel="up">User information</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="groups_003a-Print-group-names-a-user-is-in"></a>
<h3 class="section">20.4 <code>groups</code>: Print group names a user is in</h3>

<a name="index-groups"></a>
<a name="index-printing-groups-a-user-is-in"></a>
<a name="index-supplementary-groups_002c-printing"></a>

<p><code>groups</code> prints the names of the primary and any supplementary
groups for each given <var>username</var>, or the current process if no names
are given.  If more than one name is given, the name of each user is
printed before
the list of that user&rsquo;s groups and the user name is separated from the
group list by a colon.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">groups [<var>username</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>The group lists are equivalent to the output of the command &lsquo;<samp>id -Gn</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>Primary and supplementary groups for a process are normally inherited
from its parent and are usually unchanged since login.  This means
that if you change the group database after logging in, <code>groups</code>
will not reflect your changes within your existing login session.
Running <code>groups</code> with a list of users causes the user and group
database to be consulted afresh, and so will give a different result.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="users-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#who-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">who invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#groups-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">groups invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="u" rel="up">User information</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="users_003a-Print-login-names-of-users-currently-logged-in"></a>
<h3 class="section">20.5 <code>users</code>: Print login names of users currently logged in</h3>

<a name="index-users"></a>
<a name="index-printing-current-usernames"></a>
<a name="index-usernames_002c-printing-current"></a>

<a name="index-login-sessions_002c-printing-users-with"></a>
<p><code>users</code> prints on a single line a blank-separated list of user
names of users currently logged in to the current host.  Each user name
corresponds to a login session, so if a user has more than one login
session, that user&rsquo;s name will appear the same number of times in the
output.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">users [<var>file</var>]
</pre></div>

<a name="index-utmp-1"></a>
<a name="index-wtmp"></a>
<p>With no <var>file</var> argument, <code>users</code> extracts its information from
a system-maintained file (often <samp>/var/run/utmp</samp> or
<samp>/etc/utmp</samp>).  If a file argument is given, <code>users</code> uses
that file instead.  A common choice is <samp>/var/log/wtmp</samp>.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>The <code>users</code> command is installed only on platforms with the
POSIX <code>&lt;utmpx.h&gt;</code> include file or equivalent, so portable scripts
should not rely on its existence on non-POSIX platforms.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="who-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
