Previous: <a href="#users-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">users invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="u" rel="up">User information</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="who_003a-Print-who-is-currently-logged-in"></a>
<h3 class="section">20.6 <code>who</code>: Print who is currently logged in</h3>

<a name="index-who"></a>
<a name="index-printing-current-user-information"></a>
<a name="index-information_002c-about-current-users"></a>

<p><code>who</code> prints information about users who are currently logged on.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"><code>who</code> [<var>option</var>] [<var>file</var>] [am i]
</pre></div>

<a name="index-terminal-lines_002c-currently-used"></a>
<a name="index-login-time"></a>
<a name="index-remote-hostname"></a>
<p>If given no non-option arguments, <code>who</code> prints the following
information for each user currently logged on: login name, terminal
line, login time, and remote hostname or X display.
</p>
<a name="index-utmp-2"></a>
<a name="index-wtmp-1"></a>
<p>If given one non-option argument, <code>who</code> uses that instead of
a default system-maintained file (often <samp>/var/run/utmp</samp> or
<samp>/etc/utmp</samp>) as the name of the file containing the record of
users logged on.  <samp>/var/log/wtmp</samp> is commonly given as an argument
to <code>who</code> to look at who has previously logged on.
</p>
<a name="index-am-i"></a>
<a name="index-who-am-i"></a>
<p>If given two non-option arguments, <code>who</code> prints only the entry
for the user running it (determined from its standard input), preceded
by the hostname.  Traditionally, the two arguments given are &lsquo;<samp>am
i</samp>&rsquo;, as in &lsquo;<samp>who am i</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<a name="index-TZ-4"></a>
<p>Timestamps are listed according to the time zone rules specified by
the <code>TZ</code> environment variable, or by the system default rules if
<code>TZ</code> is not set.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable">Specifying the Time Zone
with <code>TZ</code></a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall-5"></a>
<p>Same as &lsquo;<samp>-b -d --login -p -r -t -T -u</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--boot</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002db-20"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dboot"></a>
<p>Print the date and time of last system boot.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dead</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddead"></a>
<p>Print information corresponding to dead processes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--heading</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dheading"></a>
<p>Print a line of column headings.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--login</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dlogin"></a>
<p>List only the entries that correspond to processes via which the
system is waiting for a user to login.  The user name is always &lsquo;<samp>LOGIN</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--lookup</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dlookup"></a>
<p>Attempt to canonicalize hostnames found in utmp through a DNS lookup.  This
is not the default because it can cause significant delays on systems with
automatic dial-up internet access.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-12"></a>
<p>Same as &lsquo;<samp>who am i</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--process</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dprocess"></a>
<p>List active processes spawned by init.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--count</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dq-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcount-1"></a>
<p>Print only the login names and the number of users logged on.
Overrides all other options.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--runlevel</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drunlevel"></a>
<p>Print the current (and maybe previous) run-level of the init process.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-25"></a>
<p>Ignored; for compatibility with other versions of <code>who</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--time</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-19"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtime-7"></a>
<p>Print last system clock change.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-12"></a>
<a name="index-idle-time"></a>
<p>After the login time, print the number of hours and minutes that the
user has been idle.  &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; means the user was active in the last minute.
&lsquo;<samp>old</samp>&rsquo; means the user has been idle for more than 24 hours.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--mesg</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--message</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--writable</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002dT-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmesg"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmessage"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dwritable"></a>
<a name="index-message-status"></a>
<a name="index-write_002c-allowed"></a>
<p>After each login name print a character indicating the user&rsquo;s message status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">&lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; allowing <code>write</code> messages
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; disallowing <code>write</code> messages
&lsquo;<samp>?</samp>&rsquo; cannot find terminal device
</pre></div>

</dd>
</dl>

<p>The <code>who</code> command is installed only on platforms with the
POSIX <code>&lt;utmpx.h&gt;</code> include file or equivalent, so portable scripts
should not rely on its existence on non-POSIX platforms.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="System-context"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#SELinux-context" accesskey="n" rel="next">SELinux context</a>, Previous: <a href="#User-information" accesskey="p" rel="prev">User information</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="System-context-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">21 System context</h2>

<a name="index-system-context"></a>
<a name="index-context_002c-system"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-system-context"></a>

<p>This section describes commands that print or change system-wide
information.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="1">date invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print or set system date and time.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#arch-invocation" accesskey="2">arch invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print machine hardware name.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#nproc-invocation" accesskey="3">nproc invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print the number of processors.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#uname-invocation" accesskey="4">uname invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print system information.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#hostname-invocation" accesskey="5">hostname invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print or set system name.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#hostid-invocation" accesskey="6">hostid invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print numeric host identifier.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#uptime-invocation" accesskey="7">uptime invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print system uptime and load.
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="date-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#arch-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">arch invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">System context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="date_003a-Print-or-set-system-date-and-time"></a>
<h3 class="section">21.1 <code>date</code>: Print or set system date and time</h3>

<a name="index-date"></a>
<a name="index-time_002c-printing-or-setting"></a>
<a name="index-printing-the-current-time"></a>

<p>Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [+<var>format</var>]
date [-u|--utc|--universal] [ MMDDhhmm[[CC]YY][.ss] ]
</pre></div>

<a name="index-LC_005fTIME-6"></a>
<p>Invoking <code>date</code> with no <var>format</var> argument is equivalent to invoking
it with a default format that depends on the <code>LC_TIME</code> locale category.
In the default C locale, this format is &lsquo;<samp>'+%a %b %e %H:%M:%S %Z %Y'</samp>&rsquo;,
so the output looks like &lsquo;<samp>Thu Mar &nbsp;3 13:47:51 PST 2005</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<a name="index-TZ-5"></a>
<p>Normally, <code>date</code> uses the time zone rules indicated by the
<code>TZ</code> environment variable, or the system default rules if <code>TZ</code>
is not set.  See <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable">Specifying the Time Zone with
<code>TZ</code></a> in <cite>The GNU C Library Reference Manual</cite>.
</p>
<a name="index-strftime-and-date"></a>
<a name="index-time-formats-1"></a>
<a name="index-formatting-times-1"></a>
<p>If given an argument that starts with a &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;, <code>date</code> prints the
current date and time (or the date and time specified by the
<samp>--date</samp> option, see below) in the format defined by that argument,
which is similar to that of the <code>strftime</code> function.  Except for
conversion specifiers, which start with &lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo;, characters in the
format string are printed unchanged.  The conversion specifiers are
described below.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Time-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="1">Time conversion specifiers</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">%[HIklMNpPrRsSTXzZ]
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Date-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="2">Date conversion specifiers</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">%[aAbBcCdDeFgGhjmuUVwWxyY]
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Literal-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="3">Literal conversion specifiers</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">%[%nt]
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Padding-and-other-flags" accesskey="4">Padding and other flags</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Pad with zeros, spaces, etc.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Setting-the-time" accesskey="5">Setting the time</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Changing the system clock.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Options-for-date" accesskey="6">Options for date</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Instead of the current time.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Date-input-formats" accesskey="7">Date input formats</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Specifying date strings.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Examples-of-date" accesskey="8">Examples of date</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Examples.
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="Time-conversion-specifiers"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Date-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="n" rel="next">Date conversion specifiers</a>, Up: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">date invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Time-conversion-specifiers-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">21.1.1 Time conversion specifiers</h4>

<a name="index-time-conversion-specifiers"></a>
<a name="index-conversion-specifiers_002c-time"></a>

<p><code>date</code> conversion specifiers related to times.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hour (&lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>23</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%I</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hour (&lsquo;<samp>01</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>12</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%k</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hour, space padded (&lsquo;<samp> 0</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>23</samp>&rsquo;); equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>%_H</samp>&rsquo;.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%l</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hour, space padded (&lsquo;<samp> 1</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>12</samp>&rsquo;); equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>%_I</samp>&rsquo;.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%M</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>minute (&lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>59</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%N</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>nanoseconds (&lsquo;<samp>000000000</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>999999999</samp>&rsquo;).
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s equivalent of either &lsquo;<samp>AM</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>PM</samp>&rsquo;;
blank in many locales.
Noon is treated as &lsquo;<samp>PM</samp>&rsquo; and midnight as &lsquo;<samp>AM</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>like &lsquo;<samp>%p</samp>&rsquo;, except lower case.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s 12-hour clock time (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>11:11:04 PM</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>24-hour hour and minute.  Same as &lsquo;<samp>%H:%M</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-epoch_002c-seconds-since"></a>
<a name="index-seconds-since-the-epoch"></a>
<a name="index-beginning-of-time"></a>
<a name="index-leap-seconds-1"></a>
<p>seconds since the epoch, i.e., since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.
Leap seconds are not counted unless leap second support is available.
See <a href="#g_t_0025s_002dexamples">%s-examples</a>, for examples.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%S</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-leap-seconds-2"></a>
<p>second (&lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>60</samp>&rsquo;).
This may be &lsquo;<samp>60</samp>&rsquo; if leap seconds are supported.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%T</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>24-hour hour, minute, and second.  Same as &lsquo;<samp>%H:%M:%S</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%X</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s time representation (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>23:13:48</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Four-digit numeric time zone, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>-0600</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>+0530</samp>&rsquo;, or
&lsquo;<samp>-0000</samp>&rsquo; if no
time zone is determinable.  This value reflects the numeric time zone
appropriate for the current time, using the time zone rules specified
by the <code>TZ</code> environment variable.  A time zone is not determinable if
its numeric offset is zero and its abbreviation begins with &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;.
The time (and optionally, the time zone rules) can be overridden
by the <samp>--date</samp> option.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%:z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Numeric time zone with &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo;, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>-06:00</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>+05:30</samp>&rsquo;), or &lsquo;<samp>-00:00</samp>&rsquo; if no time zone is determinable.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%::z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Numeric time zone to the nearest second with &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo; (e.g.,
&lsquo;<samp>-06:00:00</samp>&rsquo; or &lsquo;<samp>+05:30:00</samp>&rsquo;), or &lsquo;<samp>-00:00:00</samp>&rsquo; if no time zone is
determinable.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%:::z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Numeric time zone with &lsquo;<samp>:</samp>&rsquo; using the minimum necessary precision
(e.g., &lsquo;<samp>-06</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>+05:30</samp>&rsquo;, or &lsquo;<samp>-04:56:02</samp>&rsquo;), or &lsquo;<samp>-00</samp>&rsquo; if
no time zone is determinable.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%Z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>alphabetic time zone abbreviation (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>EDT</samp>&rsquo;), or nothing if no
time zone is determinable.  See &lsquo;<samp>%z</samp>&rsquo; for how it is determined.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Date-conversion-specifiers"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Literal-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="n" rel="next">Literal conversion specifiers</a>, Previous: <a href="#Time-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Time conversion specifiers</a>, Up: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">date invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Date-conversion-specifiers-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">21.1.2 Date conversion specifiers</h4>

<a name="index-date-conversion-specifiers"></a>
<a name="index-conversion-specifiers_002c-date"></a>

<p><code>date</code> conversion specifiers related to dates.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s abbreviated weekday name (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>Sun</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%A</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s full weekday name, variable length (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>Sunday</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%b</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s abbreviated month name (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>Jan</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%B</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s full month name, variable length (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>January</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s date and time (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>Thu Mar &nbsp;3 23:05:25 2005</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%C</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>century.  This is like &lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo;, except the last two digits are omitted.
For example, it is &lsquo;<samp>20</samp>&rsquo; if &lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo; is &lsquo;<samp>2000</samp>&rsquo;,
and is &lsquo;<samp>-0</samp>&rsquo; if &lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo; is &lsquo;<samp>-001</samp>&rsquo;.
It is normally at least two characters, but it may be more.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>day of month (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>01</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%D</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>date; same as &lsquo;<samp>%m/%d/%y</samp>&rsquo;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%e</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>day of month, space padded; same as &lsquo;<samp>%_d</samp>&rsquo;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%F</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>full date in ISO 8601 format; like &lsquo;<samp>%+4Y-%m-%d</samp>&rsquo;
except that any flags or field width override the &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;
and (after subtracting 6) the &lsquo;<samp>4</samp>&rsquo;.
This is a good choice for a date format, as it is standard and
is easy to sort in the usual case where years are in the range
0000&hellip;9999.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%g</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>year corresponding to the ISO week number, but without the century
(range &lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo; through &lsquo;<samp>99</samp>&rsquo;).  This has the same format and value
as &lsquo;<samp>%y</samp>&rsquo;, except that if the ISO week number (see
&lsquo;<samp>%V</samp>&rsquo;) belongs
to the previous or next year, that year is used instead.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%G</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>year corresponding to the ISO week number.  This has the
same format and value as &lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo;, except that if the ISO
week number (see
&lsquo;<samp>%V</samp>&rsquo;) belongs to the previous or next year, that year is used
instead.
It is normally useful only if &lsquo;<samp>%V</samp>&rsquo; is also used;
for example, the format &lsquo;<samp>%G-%m-%d</samp>&rsquo; is probably a mistake,
since it combines the ISO week number year with the conventional month and day.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>same as &lsquo;<samp>%b</samp>&rsquo;
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%j</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>day of year (&lsquo;<samp>001</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>366</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>month (&lsquo;<samp>01</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>12</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%q</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>quarter of year (&lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>4</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>day of week (&lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>7</samp>&rsquo;) with &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo; corresponding to Monday
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%U</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>week number of year, with Sunday as the first day of the week
(&lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>53</samp>&rsquo;).
Days in a new year preceding the first Sunday are in week zero.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%V</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>ISO week number, that is, the
week number of year, with Monday as the first day of the week
(&lsquo;<samp>01</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>53</samp>&rsquo;).
If the week containing January 1 has four or more days in
the new year, then it is considered week 1; otherwise, it is week 53 of
the previous year, and the next week is week 1.  (See the ISO 8601
standard.)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%w</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>day of week (&lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>6</samp>&rsquo;) with 0 corresponding to Sunday
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%W</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>week number of year, with Monday as first day of week
(&lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>53</samp>&rsquo;).
Days in a new year preceding the first Monday are in week zero.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%x</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>locale&rsquo;s date representation (e.g., &lsquo;<samp>12/31/99</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%y</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>last two digits of year (&lsquo;<samp>00</samp>&rsquo;&hellip;&lsquo;<samp>99</samp>&rsquo;)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>year.  This is normally at least four characters, but it may be more.
Year &lsquo;<samp>0000</samp>&rsquo; precedes year &lsquo;<samp>0001</samp>&rsquo;, and year &lsquo;<samp>-001</samp>&rsquo;
precedes year &lsquo;<samp>0000</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Literal-conversion-specifiers"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Padding-and-other-flags" accesskey="n" rel="next">Padding and other flags</a>, Previous: <a href="#Date-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Date conversion specifiers</a>, Up: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">date invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Literal-conversion-specifiers-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">21.1.3 Literal conversion specifiers</h4>

<a name="index-literal-conversion-specifiers"></a>
<a name="index-conversion-specifiers_002c-literal"></a>

<p><code>date</code> conversion specifiers that produce literal strings.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%%</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>a literal %
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>a newline
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>%t</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>a horizontal tab
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Padding-and-other-flags"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Setting-the-time" accesskey="n" rel="next">Setting the time</a>, Previous: <a href="#Literal-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Literal conversion specifiers</a>, Up: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">date invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Padding-and-other-flags-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">21.1.4 Padding and other flags</h4>

<a name="index-numeric-field-padding"></a>
<a name="index-padding-of-numeric-fields"></a>
<a name="index-fields_002c-padding-numeric"></a>

<p>Unless otherwise specified, <code>date</code> normally pads numeric fields
with zeros, so that, for
example, numeric months are always output as two digits.
Seconds since the epoch are not padded, though,
since there is no natural width for them.
</p>
<p>The following optional flags can appear after the &lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo;:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>(hyphen) Do not pad the field; useful if the output is intended for
human consumption.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>_</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>(underscore) Pad with spaces; useful if you need a fixed
number of characters in the output, but zeros are too distracting.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>(zero) Pad with zeros even if the conversion specifier
would normally pad with spaces.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Pad with zeros, like &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;.  In addition, precede any year number
with &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; if it exceeds 9999 or if its field width exceeds 4;
similarly, precede any century number with &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; if it exceeds 99
or if its field width exceeds 2.  This supports ISO 8601 formats
for dates far in the future; for example, the command <code>date
--date=12019-02-25 +%+13F</code> outputs the string &lsquo;<samp>+012019-02-25</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>^</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Use upper case characters if possible.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Use opposite case characters if possible.
A field that is normally upper case becomes lower case, and vice versa.
This is a GNU extension.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Here are some examples of padding:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date +%d/%m -d &quot;Feb 1&quot;
&rArr; 01/02
date +%-d/%-m -d &quot;Feb 1&quot;
&rArr; 1/2
date +%_d/%_m -d &quot;Feb 1&quot;
&rArr;  1/ 2
</pre></div>

<p>You can optionally specify the field width
(after any flag, if present) as a decimal number.  If the natural size of the
output of the field has less than the specified number of characters,
the result is written right adjusted and padded to the given
size.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>%9B</samp>&rsquo; prints the right adjusted month name in
a field of width 9.
</p>
<p>An optional modifier can follow the optional flag and width
specification.  The modifiers are:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Use the locale&rsquo;s alternate representation for date and time.  This
modifier applies to the &lsquo;<samp>%c</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%C</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%x</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%X</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>%y</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo; conversion specifiers.  In a Japanese locale, for
example, &lsquo;<samp>%Ex</samp>&rsquo; might yield a date format based on the Japanese
Emperors&rsquo; reigns.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>O</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Use the locale&rsquo;s alternate numeric symbols for numbers.  This modifier
applies only to numeric conversion specifiers.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>If the format supports the modifier but no alternate representation
is available, it is ignored.
</p>
<p>POSIX specifies the behavior of flags and field widths only for
&lsquo;<samp>%C</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%F</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%G</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>%Y</samp>&rsquo; (all without
modifiers), and requires a flag to be present if and only if a field
width is also present.  Other combinations of flags, field widths and
modifiers are GNU extensions.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Setting-the-time"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Options-for-date" accesskey="n" rel="next">Options for date</a>, Previous: <a href="#Padding-and-other-flags" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Padding and other flags</a>, Up: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">date invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Setting-the-time-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">21.1.5 Setting the time</h4>

<a name="index-setting-the-time"></a>
<a name="index-time-setting"></a>
<a name="index-appropriate-privileges-1"></a>

<p>If given an argument that does not start with &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;, <code>date</code> sets
the system clock to the date and time specified by that argument (as
described below).  You must have appropriate privileges to set the
system clock.  Note for changes to persist across a reboot, the
hardware clock may need to be updated from the system clock, which
might not happen automatically on your system.
</p>
<p>The argument must consist entirely of digits, which have the following
meaning:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>MM</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>month
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>DD</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>day within month
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>hh</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hour
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>mm</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>minute
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>CC</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>first two digits of year (optional)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>YY</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>last two digits of year (optional)
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ss</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>second (optional)
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Note, the <samp>--date</samp> and <samp>--set</samp> options may not be used with an
argument in the above format.  The <samp>--universal</samp> option may be used
with such an argument to indicate that the specified date and time are
relative to Universal Time rather than to the local time zone.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="Options-for-date"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Examples-of-date" accesskey="n" rel="next">Examples of date</a>, Previous: <a href="#Setting-the-time" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Setting the time</a>, Up: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">date invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Options-for-date-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">21.1.6 Options for <code>date</code></h4>

<a name="index-date-options"></a>
<a name="index-options-for-date"></a>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>datestr</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--date=<var>datestr</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddate-1"></a>
<a name="index-parsing-date-strings"></a>
<a name="index-date-strings_002c-parsing"></a>
<a name="index-arbitrary-date-strings_002c-parsing"></a>
<a name="index-yesterday"></a>
<a name="index-tomorrow"></a>
<a name="index-next-day-1"></a>
<a name="index-last-day-1"></a>
<p>Display the date and time specified in <var>datestr</var> instead of the
current date and time.  <var>datestr</var> can be in almost any common
format.  It can contain month names, time zones, &lsquo;<samp>am</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>pm</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>yesterday</samp>&rsquo;, etc.  For example, <samp>--date=&quot;2004-02-27
14:19:13.489392193 +0530&quot;</samp> specifies the instant of time that is
489,392,193 nanoseconds after February 27, 2004 at 2:19:13 PM in a
time zone that is 5 hours and 30 minutes east of UTC.<br>
Note: input currently must be in locale independent format.  E.g., the
LC_TIME=C below is needed to print back the correct date in many locales:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">date -d &quot;$(LC_TIME=C date)&quot;
</pre></div>
<p>See <a href="#Date-input-formats">Date input formats</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--debug</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002ddebug"></a>
<a name="index-debugging-date-strings"></a>
<a name="index-date-strings_002c-debugging"></a>
<a name="index-arbitrary-date-strings_002c-debugging"></a>
<p>Annotate the parsed date, display the effective time zone, and warn about
potential misuse.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f <var>datefile</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--file=<var>datefile</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-22"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dfile-1"></a>
<p>Parse each line in <var>datefile</var> as with <samp>-d</samp> and display the
resulting date and time.  If <var>datefile</var> is &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, use standard
input.  This is useful when you have many dates to process, because the
system overhead of starting up the <code>date</code> executable many times can
be considerable.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-I[<var>timespec</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--iso-8601[=<var>timespec</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dI_005btimespec_005d"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002diso_002d8601_005b_003dtimespec_005d"></a>
<p>Display the date using an ISO 8601 format, &lsquo;<samp>%Y-%m-%d</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The argument <var>timespec</var> specifies the number of additional
terms of the time to include.  It can be one of the following:
</p><dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>auto</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print just the date.  This is the default if <var>timespec</var> is omitted.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>hours</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Append the hour of the day to the date.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>minutes</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Append the hours and minutes.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>seconds</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Append the hours, minutes and seconds.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ns</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Append the hours, minutes, seconds and nanoseconds.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>If showing any time terms, then include the time zone using the format
&lsquo;<samp>%:z</samp>&rsquo;.
This format is always suitable as input
for the <samp>--date</samp> (<samp>-d</samp>) and <samp>--file</samp>
(<samp>-f</samp>) options, regardless of the current locale.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r <var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reference=<var>file</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dreference-5"></a>
<p>Display the date and time of the last modification of <var>file</var>,
instead of the current date and time.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--rfc-email</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drfc_002demail"></a>
<p>Display the date and time using the format &lsquo;<samp>%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S
%z</samp>&rsquo;, evaluated in the C locale so abbreviations are always in English.
For example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">Fri, 09 Sep 2005 13:51:39 -0700
</pre></div>

<a name="index-_002d_002drfc_002d822"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drfc_002d2822"></a>
<p>This format conforms to Internet RFCs
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc5322">5322</a>,
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc2822">2822</a> and
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc822">822</a>, the
current and previous standards for Internet email.
For compatibility with older versions of <code>date</code>,
<samp>--rfc-2822</samp> and <samp>--rfc-822</samp> are aliases for
<samp>--rfc-email</samp>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--rfc-3339=<var>timespec</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002drfc_002d3339_003dtimespec"></a>
<p>Display the date using a format specified by
<a href="https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc3339">Internet
RFC 3339</a>.  This is like <samp>--iso-8601</samp>, except that a space rather
than a &lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo; separates dates from times.
This format is always suitable as input
for the <samp>--date</samp> (<samp>-d</samp>) and <samp>--file</samp>
(<samp>-f</samp>) options, regardless of the current locale.
</p>
<p>The argument <var>timespec</var> specifies how much of the time to include.
It can be one of the following:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>date</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print just the full-date, e.g., &lsquo;<samp>2005-09-14</samp>&rsquo;.
This is equivalent to the format &lsquo;<samp>%Y-%m-%d</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>seconds</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print the full-date and full-time separated by a space, e.g.,
&lsquo;<samp>2005-09-14 00:56:06+05:30</samp>&rsquo;.  The output ends with a numeric
time-offset; here the &lsquo;<samp>+05:30</samp>&rsquo; means that local time is five
hours and thirty minutes east of UTC.  This is equivalent to
the format &lsquo;<samp>%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S%:z</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>ns</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Like &lsquo;<samp>seconds</samp>&rsquo;, but also print nanoseconds, e.g.,
&lsquo;<samp>2005-09-14 00:56:06.998458565+05:30</samp>&rsquo;.
This is equivalent to the format &lsquo;<samp>%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%N%:z</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>datestr</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--set=<var>datestr</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-26"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dset"></a>
<p>Set the date and time to <var>datestr</var>.  See <samp>-d</samp> above.
See also <a href="#Setting-the-time">Setting the time</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--utc</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--universal</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dutc"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002duniversal"></a>
<a name="index-Coordinated-Universal-Time"></a>
<a name="index-UTC"></a>
<a name="index-Greenwich-Mean-Time"></a>
<a name="index-GMT"></a>
<a name="index-leap-seconds-3"></a>
<a name="index-TZ-6"></a>
<a name="index-Universal-Time"></a>
<p>Use Universal Time by operating as if the
<code>TZ</code> environment variable were set to the string &lsquo;<samp>UTC0</samp>&rsquo;.
UTC stands for Coordinated Universal Time, established in 1960.
Universal Time is often called &ldquo;Greenwich Mean Time&rdquo; (GMT) for
historical reasons.
Typically, systems ignore leap seconds and thus implement an
approximation to UTC rather than true UTC.
</p></dd>
</dl>


<hr>
<a name="Examples-of-date"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Options-for-date" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Options for date</a>, Up: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">date invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Examples-of-date-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">21.1.7 Examples of <code>date</code></h4>

<a name="index-examples-of-date"></a>

<p>Here are a few examples.  Also see the documentation for the <samp>-d</samp>
option in the previous section.
</p>
<ul>
<li> To print the date of the day before yesterday:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date --date='2 days ago'
</pre></div>

</li><li> To print the date of the day three months and one day hence:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date --date='3 months 1 day'
</pre></div>

</li><li> To print the day of year of Christmas in the current year:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date --date='25 Dec' +%j
</pre></div>

</li><li> To print the current full month name and the day of the month:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date '+%B %d'
</pre></div>

<p>But this may not be what you want because for the first nine days of
the month, the &lsquo;<samp>%d</samp>&rsquo; expands to a zero-padded two-digit field,
for example &lsquo;<samp>date -d 1may '+%B %d'</samp>&rsquo; will print &lsquo;<samp>May 01</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</li><li> To print a date without the leading zero for one-digit days
of the month, you can use the (GNU extension)
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; flag to suppress
the padding altogether:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date -d 1may '+%B %-d'
</pre></div>

</li><li> To print the current date and time in the format required by many
non-GNU versions of <code>date</code> when setting the system clock:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date +%m%d%H%M%Y.%S
</pre></div>

</li><li> To set the system clock forward by two minutes:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date --set='+2 minutes'
</pre></div>

</li><li> To print the date in Internet RFC 5322 format,
use &lsquo;<samp>date --rfc-email</samp>&rsquo;.  Here is some example output:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">Fri, 09 Sep 2005 13:51:39 -0700
</pre></div>

<a name="g_t_0025s_002dexamples"></a></li><li> To convert a date string to the number of seconds since the epoch
(which is 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC), use the <samp>--date</samp> option with
the &lsquo;<samp>%s</samp>&rsquo; format.  That can be useful in sorting and/or graphing
and/or comparing data by date.  The following command outputs the
number of the seconds since the epoch for the time two minutes after the
epoch:

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date --date='1970-01-01 00:02:00 +0000' +%s
120
</pre></div>

<p>If you do not specify time zone information in the date string,
<code>date</code> uses your computer&rsquo;s idea of the time zone when
interpreting the string.  For example, if your computer&rsquo;s time zone is
that of Cambridge, Massachusetts, which was then 5 hours (i.e., 18,000
seconds) behind UTC:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># local time zone used
date --date='1970-01-01 00:02:00' +%s
18120
</pre></div>

</li><li> If you&rsquo;re sorting or graphing dated data, your raw date values may be
represented as seconds since the epoch.  But few people can look at
the date &lsquo;<samp>946684800</samp>&rsquo; and casually note &ldquo;Oh, that&rsquo;s the first second
of the year 2000 in Greenwich, England.&rdquo;

<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date --date='2000-01-01 UTC' +%s
946684800
</pre></div>

<p>An alternative is to use the <samp>--utc</samp> (<samp>-u</samp>) option.
Then you may omit &lsquo;<samp>UTC</samp>&rsquo; from the date string.  Although this
produces the same result for &lsquo;<samp>%s</samp>&rsquo; and many other format sequences,
with a time zone offset different from zero, it would give a different
result for zone-dependent formats like &lsquo;<samp>%z</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date -u --date=2000-01-01 +%s
946684800
</pre></div>

<p>To convert such an unwieldy number of seconds back to
a more readable form, use a command like this:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># local time zone used
date -d '1970-01-01 UTC 946684800 seconds' +&quot;%Y-%m-%d %T %z&quot;
1999-12-31 19:00:00 -0500
</pre></div>

<p>Or if you do not mind depending on the &lsquo;<samp>@</samp>&rsquo; feature present since
coreutils 5.3.0, you could shorten this to:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date -d @946684800 +&quot;%F %T %z&quot;
1999-12-31 19:00:00 -0500
</pre></div>

<p>Often it is better to output UTC-relative date and time:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">date -u -d '1970-01-01 946684800 seconds' +&quot;%Y-%m-%d %T %z&quot;
2000-01-01 00:00:00 +0000
</pre></div>

</li><li> <a name="index-leap-seconds-4"></a>
Typically the seconds count omits leap seconds, but some systems are
exceptions.  Because leap seconds are not predictable, the mapping
between the seconds count and a future timestamp is not reliable on
the atypical systems that include leap seconds in their counts.

<p>Here is how the two kinds of systems handle the leap second at
2012-06-30 23:59:60 UTC:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Typical systems ignore leap seconds:
date --date='2012-06-30 23:59:59 +0000' +%s
1341100799
date --date='2012-06-30 23:59:60 +0000' +%s
date: invalid date '2012-06-30 23:59:60 +0000'
date --date='2012-07-01 00:00:00 +0000' +%s
1341100800
</pre></div>

<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Atypical systems count leap seconds:
date --date='2012-06-30 23:59:59 +0000' +%s
1341100823
date --date='2012-06-30 23:59:60 +0000' +%s
1341100824
date --date='2012-07-01 00:00:00 +0000' +%s
1341100825
</pre></div>

</li></ul>


<hr>
<a name="arch-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#nproc-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">nproc invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#date-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">date invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">System context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="arch_003a-Print-machine-hardware-name"></a>
<h3 class="section">21.2 <code>arch</code>: Print machine hardware name</h3>

<a name="index-arch"></a>
<a name="index-print-machine-hardware-name"></a>
<a name="index-system-information_002c-printing"></a>

<p><code>arch</code> prints the machine hardware name,
and is equivalent to &lsquo;<samp>uname -m</samp>&rsquo;.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">arch [<var>option</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>The program accepts the <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a> only.
</p>
<p><code>arch</code> is not installed by default, so portable scripts should
not rely on its existence.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="nproc-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#uname-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">uname invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#arch-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">arch invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">System context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="nproc_003a-Print-the-number-of-available-processors"></a>
<h3 class="section">21.3 <code>nproc</code>: Print the number of available processors</h3>

<a name="index-nproc"></a>
<a name="index-Print-the-number-of-processors"></a>
<a name="index-system-information_002c-printing-1"></a>

<p>Print the number of processing units available to the current process,
which may be less than the number of online processors.
If this information is not accessible, then print the number of
processors installed.  If the <code>OMP_NUM_THREADS</code> or <code>OMP_THREAD_LIMIT</code>
environment variables are set, then they will determine the minimum
and maximum returned value respectively.  The result is guaranteed to be
greater than zero.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">nproc [<var>option</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dall-6"></a>
<p>Print the number of installed processors on the system, which may
be greater than the number online or available to the current process.
The <code>OMP_NUM_THREADS</code> or <code>OMP_THREAD_LIMIT</code> environment variables
are not honored in this case.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore=<var>number</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dignore"></a>
<p>If possible, exclude this <var>number</var> of processing units.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="uname-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#hostname-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">hostname invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#nproc-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">nproc invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">System context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="uname_003a-Print-system-information"></a>
<h3 class="section">21.4 <code>uname</code>: Print system information</h3>

<a name="index-uname"></a>
<a name="index-print-system-information"></a>
<a name="index-system-information_002c-printing-2"></a>

<p><code>uname</code> prints information about the machine and operating system
it is run on.  If no options are given, <code>uname</code> acts as if the
<samp>-s</samp> option were given.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">uname [<var>option</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If multiple options or <samp>-a</samp> are given, the selected information is
printed in this order:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"><var>kernel-name</var> <var>nodename</var> <var>kernel-release</var> <var>kernel-version</var>
<var>machine</var> <var>processor</var> <var>hardware-platform</var> <var>operating-system</var>
</pre></div>

<p>The information may contain internal spaces, so such output cannot be
parsed reliably.  In the following example, <var>release</var> is
&lsquo;<samp>2.2.18ss.e820-bda652a #4 SMP Tue Jun 5 11:24:08 PDT 2001</samp>&rsquo;:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">uname -a
&rArr; Linux dumdum 2.2.18 #4 SMP Tue Jun 5 11:24:08 PDT 2001 i686 unknown unknown GNU/Linux
</pre></div>


<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-a</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--all</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002da-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dall-7"></a>
<p>Print all of the below information, except omit the processor type
and the hardware platform name if they are unknown.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--hardware-platform</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dhardware_002dplatform"></a>
<a name="index-implementation_002c-hardware"></a>
<a name="index-hardware-platform"></a>
<a name="index-platform_002c-hardware"></a>
<p>Print the hardware platform name
(sometimes called the hardware implementation).
Print &lsquo;<samp>unknown</samp>&rsquo; if this information is not available.
Note this is non-portable (even across GNU/Linux distributions).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--machine</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dm-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dmachine"></a>
<a name="index-machine-type"></a>
<a name="index-hardware-class"></a>
<a name="index-hardware-type"></a>
<p>Print the machine hardware name (sometimes called the hardware class
or hardware type).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--nodename</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnodename"></a>
<a name="index-hostname"></a>
<a name="index-node-name"></a>
<a name="index-network-node-name"></a>
<p>Print the network node hostname.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-p</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--processor</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dp-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dprocessor"></a>
<a name="index-host-processor-type"></a>
<p>Print the processor type (sometimes called the instruction set
architecture or ISA).
Print &lsquo;<samp>unknown</samp>&rsquo; if this information is not available.
Note this is non-portable (even across GNU/Linux distributions).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--operating-system</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002doperating_002dsystem"></a>
<a name="index-operating-system-name"></a>
<p>Print the name of the operating system.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--kernel-release</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dkernel_002drelease"></a>
<a name="index-kernel-release"></a>
<a name="index-release-of-kernel"></a>
<p>Print the kernel release.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--kernel-name</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-27"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dkernel_002dname"></a>
<a name="index-kernel-name"></a>
<a name="index-name-of-kernel"></a>
<p>Print the kernel name.
POSIX 1003.1-2001 (see <a href="#Standards-conformance">Standards conformance</a>) calls this
&ldquo;the implementation of the operating system&rdquo;, because the
POSIX specification itself has no notion of &ldquo;kernel&rdquo;.
The kernel name might be the same as the operating system name printed
by the <samp>-o</samp> or <samp>--operating-system</samp> option, but it might
differ.  Some operating systems (e.g., FreeBSD, HP-UX) have the same
name as their underlying kernels; others (e.g., GNU/Linux, Solaris)
do not.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--kernel-version</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-19"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dkernel_002dversion"></a>
<a name="index-kernel-version"></a>
<a name="index-version-of-kernel"></a>
<p>Print the kernel version.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="hostname-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#hostid-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">hostid invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#uname-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">uname invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">System context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="hostname_003a-Print-or-set-system-name"></a>
<h3 class="section">21.5 <code>hostname</code>: Print or set system name</h3>

<a name="index-hostname-1"></a>
<a name="index-setting-the-hostname"></a>
<a name="index-printing-the-hostname"></a>
<a name="index-system-name_002c-printing"></a>
<a name="index-appropriate-privileges-2"></a>

<p>With no arguments, <code>hostname</code> prints the name of the current host
system.  With one argument, it sets the current host name to the
specified string.  You must have appropriate privileges to set the host
name.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">hostname [<var>name</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p><code>hostname</code> is not installed by default, and other packages
also supply a <code>hostname</code> command, so portable scripts should
not rely on its existence or on the exact behavior documented above.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="hostid-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#uptime-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">uptime invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#hostname-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">hostname invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">System context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="hostid_003a-Print-numeric-host-identifier"></a>
<h3 class="section">21.6 <code>hostid</code>: Print numeric host identifier</h3>

<a name="index-hostid"></a>
<a name="index-printing-the-host-identifier"></a>

<p><code>hostid</code> prints the numeric identifier of the current host
in hexadecimal.  This command accepts no arguments.
The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.
See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>For example, here&rsquo;s what it prints on one system I use:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ hostid
1bac013d
</pre></div>

<p>On that system, the 32-bit quantity happens to be closely
related to the system&rsquo;s Internet address, but that isn&rsquo;t always
the case.
</p>
<p><code>hostid</code> is installed only on systems that have the
<code>gethostid</code> function, so portable scripts should not rely on its
existence.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="uptime-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#hostid-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">hostid invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#System-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">System context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="uptime_003a-Print-system-uptime-and-load"></a>
<h3 class="section">21.7 <code>uptime</code>: Print system uptime and load</h3>

<a name="index-uptime"></a>
<a name="index-printing-the-system-uptime-and-load"></a>

<p><code>uptime</code> prints the current time, the system&rsquo;s uptime, the
number of logged-in users and the current load average.
</p>
<p>If an argument is specified, it is used as the file to be read
to discover how many users are logged in.  If no argument is
specified, a system default is used (<code>uptime --help</code> indicates
the default setting).
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.
See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>For example, here&rsquo;s what it prints right now on one system I use:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ uptime
 14:07  up   3:35,  3 users,  load average: 1.39, 1.15, 1.04
</pre></div>

<p>The precise method of calculation of load average varies somewhat
between systems.  Some systems calculate it as the average number of
runnable processes over the last 1, 5 and 15 minutes, but some systems
also include processes in the uninterruptible sleep state (that is,
those processes which are waiting for disk I/O).  The Linux kernel
includes uninterruptible processes.
</p>
<p><code>uptime</code> is installed only on platforms with infrastructure
for obtaining the boot time, and other packages also supply an
<code>uptime</code> command, so portable scripts should not rely on its
existence or on the exact behavior documented above.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<hr>

</div>
<a name="SELinux-context-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">22 SELinux context</h2>

<a name="index-SELinux-context"></a>
<a name="index-SELinux_002c-context"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-SELinux-context"></a>

<p>This section describes commands for operations with SELinux
contexts.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#chcon-invocation" accesskey="1">chcon invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Change SELinux context of file
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#runcon-invocation" accesskey="2">runcon invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Run a command in specified SELinux context
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="chcon-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#runcon-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">runcon invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#SELinux-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">SELinux context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="chcon_003a-Change-SELinux-context-of-file"></a>
<h3 class="section">22.1 <code>chcon</code>: Change SELinux context of file</h3>

<a name="index-chcon"></a>
<a name="index-changing-security-context"></a>
<a name="index-change-SELinux-context"></a>

<p><code>chcon</code> changes the SELinux security context of the selected files.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">chcon [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>context</var> <var>file</var>&hellip;
chcon [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [-u <var>user</var>] [-r <var>role</var>] [-l <var>range</var>] [-t <var>type</var>] <var>file</var>&hellip;
chcon [<var>option</var>]&hellip; --reference=<var>rfile</var> <var>file</var>&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>Change the SELinux security context of each <var>file</var> to <var>context</var>.
With <samp>--reference</samp>, change the security context of each <var>file</var>
to that of <var>rfile</var>.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002ddereference-6"></a>
<p>Do not affect symbolic links but what they refer to; this is the default.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-dereference</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dh-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-6"></a>
<a name="index-no-dereference"></a>
<p>Affect the symbolic links themselves instead of any referenced file.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--reference=<var>rfile</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dreference-6"></a>
<a name="index-reference-file"></a>
<p>Use <var>rfile</var>&rsquo;s security context rather than specifying a <var>context</var> value.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-R</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--recursive</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dR-9"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drecursive-6"></a>
<p>Operate on files and directories recursively.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot-4"></a>
<p>Refuse to operate recursively on the root directory, <samp>/</samp>,
when used together with the <samp>--recursive</samp> option.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--no-preserve-root</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot-4"></a>
<p>Do not treat the root directory, <samp>/</samp>, specially when operating
recursively; this is the default.
See <a href="#Treating-_002f-specially">Treating / specially</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-H</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dH-8"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-if-on-the-command-line-3"></a>
<p>If <samp>--recursive</samp> (<samp>-R</samp>) is specified and
a command line argument is a symbolic link to a directory, traverse it.
See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dL-12"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-each-that-is-encountered-3"></a>
<p>In a recursive traversal, traverse every symbolic link to a directory
that is encountered.
See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-P</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dP-10"></a>
<a name="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-never-traverse-3"></a>
<p>Do not traverse any symbolic links.
This is the default if none of <samp>-H</samp>, <samp>-L</samp>,
or <samp>-P</samp> is specified.
See <a href="#Traversing-symlinks">Traversing symlinks</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-20"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-15"></a>
<a name="index-diagnostic"></a>
<p>Output a diagnostic for every file processed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u <var>user</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--user=<var>user</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-14"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002duser-1"></a>
<p>Set user <var>user</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r <var>role</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--role=<var>role</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-17"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drole"></a>
<p>Set role <var>role</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>type</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--type=<var>type</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-20"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtype-1"></a>
<p>Set type <var>type</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l <var>range</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--range=<var>range</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-11"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drange"></a>
<p>Set range <var>range</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="runcon-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#chcon-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">chcon invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#SELinux-context" accesskey="u" rel="up">SELinux context</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="runcon_003a-Run-a-command-in-specified-SELinux-context"></a>
<h3 class="section">22.2 <code>runcon</code>: Run a command in specified SELinux context</h3>

<a name="index-runcon"></a>
<a name="index-run-with-security-context"></a>


<p><code>runcon</code> runs file in specified SELinux security context.
</p>
<p>Synopses:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">runcon <var>context</var> <var>command</var> [<var>args</var>]
runcon [ -c ] [-u <var>user</var>] [-r <var>role</var>] [-t <var>type</var>] [-l <var>range</var>] <var>command</var> [<var>args</var>]
</pre></div>

<p>Run <var>command</var> with completely-specified <var>context</var>, or with
current or transitioned security context modified by one or more of <var>level</var>,
<var>role</var>, <var>type</var> and <var>user</var>.
</p>
<p>If none of <samp>-c</samp>, <samp>-t</samp>, <samp>-u</samp>, <samp>-r</samp>, or <samp>-l</samp>
is specified, the first argument is used as the complete context.
Any additional arguments after <var>command</var>
are interpreted as arguments to the command.
</p>
<p>With neither <var>context</var> nor <var>command</var>, print the current
security context.
</p>
<a name="index-restricted-security-context"></a>
<a name="index-NO_005fNEW_005fPRIVS"></a>
<p>Note also the <code>setpriv</code> command which can be used to set the
NO_NEW_PRIVS bit using <code>setpriv --no-new-privs runcon ...</code>,
thus disallowing usage of a security context with more privileges
than the process would normally have.
</p>
<p><code>runcon</code> accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-c</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--compute</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dc-22"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dcompute"></a>
<p>Compute process transition context before modifying.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u <var>user</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--user=<var>user</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-15"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002duser-2"></a>
<p>Set user <var>user</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-r <var>role</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--role=<var>role</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dr-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drole-1"></a>
<p>Set role <var>role</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-t <var>type</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--type=<var>type</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dt-21"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dtype-2"></a>
<p>Set type <var>type</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-l <var>range</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--range=<var>range</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dl-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002drange-1"></a>
<p>Set range <var>range</var> in the target security context.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-runcon"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">126 if <var>command</var> is found but cannot be invoked
127 if <code>runcon</code> itself fails or if <var>command</var> cannot be found
the exit status of <var>command</var> otherwise
</pre></div>

<hr>
