</div>
<a name="chroot_003a-Run-a-command-with-a-different-root-directory"></a>
<h3 class="section">23.1 <code>chroot</code>: Run a command with a different root directory</h3>

<a name="index-chroot"></a>
<a name="index-running-a-program-in-a-specified-root-directory"></a>
<a name="index-root-directory_002c-running-a-program-in-a-specified"></a>

<p><code>chroot</code> runs a command with a specified root directory.
On many systems, only the super-user can do this.<a name="DOCF5" href="#FOOT5"><sup>5</sup></a>.
Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">chroot <var>option</var> <var>newroot</var> [<var>command</var> [<var>args</var>]&hellip;]
chroot <var>option</var>
</pre></div>

<p>Ordinarily, file names are looked up starting at the root of the
directory structure, i.e., <samp>/</samp>.  <code>chroot</code> changes the root to
the directory <var>newroot</var> (which must exist), then changes the working
directory to <samp>/</samp>, and finally runs <var>command</var> with optional <var>args</var>.
If <var>command</var> is not specified, the default is the value of the <code>SHELL</code>
environment variable or <code>/bin/sh</code> if not set, invoked with the
<samp>-i</samp> option.
<var>command</var> must not be a special built-in utility
(see <a href="#Special-built_002din-utilities">Special built-in utilities</a>).
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--groups=<var>groups</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dgroups-1"></a>
<p>Use this option to override the supplementary <var>groups</var> to be
used by the new process.
The items in the list (names or numeric IDs) must be separated by commas.
Use &lsquo;<samp>--groups=''</samp>&rsquo; to disable the supplementary group look-up
implicit in the <samp>--userspec</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--userspec=<var>user</var>[:<var>group</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002duserspec"></a>
<p>By default, <var>command</var> is run with the same credentials
as the invoking process.
Use this option to run it as a different <var>user</var> and/or with a
different primary <var>group</var>.
If a <var>user</var> is specified then the supplementary groups
are set according to the system defined list for that user,
unless overridden with the <samp>--groups</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--skip-chdir</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dskip_002dchdir"></a>
<p>Use this option to not change the working directory to <samp>/</samp> after changing
the root directory to <var>newroot</var>, i.e., inside the chroot.
This option is only permitted when <var>newroot</var> is the old <samp>/</samp> directory,
and therefore is mostly useful together with the <samp>--groups</samp> and
<samp>--userspec</samp> options to retain the previous working directory.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>The user and group name look-up performed by the <samp>--userspec</samp>
and <samp>--groups</samp> options, is done both outside and inside
the chroot, with successful look-ups inside the chroot taking precedence.
If the specified user or group items are intended to represent a numeric ID,
then a name to ID resolving step is avoided by specifying a leading &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;.
See <a href="#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs">Disambiguating names and IDs</a>.
</p>
<p>Here are a few tips to help avoid common problems in using chroot.
To start with a simple example, make <var>command</var> refer to a statically
linked binary.  If you were to use a dynamically linked executable, then
you&rsquo;d have to arrange to have the shared libraries in the right place under
your new root directory.
</p>
<p>For example, if you create a statically linked <code>ls</code> executable,
and put it in <samp>/tmp/empty</samp>, you can run this command as root:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ chroot /tmp/empty /ls -Rl /
</pre></div>

<p>Then you&rsquo;ll see output like this:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">/:
total 1023
-rwxr-xr-x 1 0 0 1041745 Aug 16 11:17 ls
</pre></div>

<p>If you want to use a dynamically linked executable, say <code>bash</code>,
then first run &lsquo;<samp>ldd bash</samp>&rsquo; to see what shared objects it needs.
Then, in addition to copying the actual binary, also copy the listed
files to the required positions under your intended new root directory.
Finally, if the executable requires any other files (e.g., data, state,
device files), copy them into place, too.
</p>
<p><code>chroot</code> is installed only on systems that have the
<code>chroot</code> function, so portable scripts should not rely on its
existence.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-chroot"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">125 if <code>chroot</code> itself fails
126 if <var>command</var> is found but cannot be invoked
127 if <var>command</var> cannot be found
the exit status of <var>command</var> otherwise
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="env-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#nice-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">nice invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#chroot-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">chroot invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Modified-command-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">Modified command invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="env_003a-Run-a-command-in-a-modified-environment"></a>
<h3 class="section">23.2 <code>env</code>: Run a command in a modified environment</h3>

<a name="index-env"></a>
<a name="index-environment_002c-running-a-program-in-a-modified"></a>
<a name="index-modified-environment_002c-running-a-program-in-a"></a>
<a name="index-running-a-program-in-a-modified-environment"></a>

<p><code>env</code> runs a command with a modified environment.  Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>name</var>=<var>value</var>]&hellip; [<var>command</var> [<var>args</var>]&hellip;]
env -[v]S'[<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>name</var>=<var>value</var>]&hellip; [<var>command</var> [<var>args</var>]&hellip;]'
env
</pre></div>

<p><code>env</code> is commonly used on first line of scripts (shebang line):
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/usr/bin/env <var>command</var>
#!/usr/bin/env -[v]S[<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>name</var>=<var>value</var>]&hellip; <var>command</var> [<var>args</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>Operands of the form &lsquo;<samp><var>variable</var>=<var>value</var></samp>&rsquo; set
the environment variable <var>variable</var> to value <var>value</var>.
<var>value</var> may be empty (&lsquo;<samp><var>variable</var>=</samp>&rsquo;).  Setting a variable
to an empty value is different from unsetting it.
These operands are evaluated left-to-right, so if two operands
mention the same variable the earlier is ignored.
</p>
<p>Environment variable names can be empty, and can contain any
characters other than &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; and ASCII NUL.
However, it is wise to limit yourself to names that
consist solely of underscores, digits, and ASCII letters,
and that begin with a non-digit, as applications like the shell do not
work well with other names.
</p>
<a name="index-PATH"></a>
<p>The first operand that does not contain the character &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo;
specifies the program to invoke; it is
searched for according to the <code>PATH</code> environment variable.  Any
remaining arguments are passed as arguments to that program.
The program should not be a special built-in utility
(see <a href="#Special-built_002din-utilities">Special built-in utilities</a>).
</p>
<p>Modifications to <code>PATH</code> take effect prior to searching for
<var>command</var>.  Use caution when reducing <code>PATH</code>; behavior is
not portable when <code>PATH</code> is undefined or omits key directories
such as <samp>/bin</samp>.
</p>
<p>In the rare case that a utility contains a &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; in the name, the
only way to disambiguate it from a variable assignment is to use an
intermediate command for <var>command</var>, and pass the problematic
program name via <var>args</var>.  For example, if <samp>./prog=</samp> is an
executable in the current <code>PATH</code>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env prog= true # runs 'true', with prog= in environment
env ./prog= true # runs 'true', with ./prog= in environment
env -- prog= true # runs 'true', with prog= in environment
env sh -c '\prog= true' # runs 'prog=' with argument 'true'
env sh -c 'exec &quot;$@&quot;' sh prog= true # also runs 'prog='
</pre></div>

<a name="index-environment_002c-printing"></a>

<p>If no command name is specified following the environment
specifications, the resulting environment is printed.  This is like
specifying the <code>printenv</code> program.
</p>
<p>For some examples, suppose the environment passed to <code>env</code>
contains &lsquo;<samp>LOGNAME=rms</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>EDITOR=emacs</samp>&rsquo;, and
&lsquo;<samp>PATH=.:/gnubin:/hacks</samp>&rsquo;:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Output the current environment.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env | LC_ALL=C sort
EDITOR=emacs
LOGNAME=rms
PATH=.:/gnubin:/hacks
</pre></div>

</li><li> Run <code>foo</code> with a reduced environment, preserving only the
original <code>PATH</code> to avoid problems in locating <code>foo</code>.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env - PATH=&quot;$PATH&quot; foo
</pre></div>

</li><li> Run <code>foo</code> with the environment containing &lsquo;<samp>LOGNAME=rms</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>EDITOR=emacs</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>PATH=.:/gnubin:/hacks</samp>&rsquo;, and guarantees
that <code>foo</code> was found in the file system rather than as a shell
built-in.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env foo
</pre></div>

</li><li> Run <code>nemacs</code> with the environment containing &lsquo;<samp>LOGNAME=foo</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>EDITOR=emacs</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>PATH=.:/gnubin:/hacks</samp>&rsquo;, and
&lsquo;<samp>DISPLAY=gnu:0</samp>&rsquo;.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env DISPLAY=gnu:0 LOGNAME=foo nemacs
</pre></div>

</li><li> Attempt to run the program <code>/energy/--</code> (as that is the only
possible path search result); if the command exists, the environment
will contain &lsquo;<samp>LOGNAME=rms</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>PATH=/energy</samp>&rsquo;, and the
arguments will be &lsquo;<samp>e=mc2</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>bar</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>baz</samp>&rsquo;.
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env -u EDITOR PATH=/energy -- e=mc2 bar baz
</pre></div>

</li></ul>


<a name="General-options-2"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">23.2.1 General options</h4>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--null</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d0-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dnull-2"></a>
<a name="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-7"></a>
<p>Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line,
rather than a newline.  This option enables other programs to parse the
output even when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-u <var>name</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--unset=<var>name</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002du-16"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dunset"></a>
<p>Remove variable <var>name</var> from the environment, if it was in the
environment.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-environment</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d-1"></a>
<a name="index-_002di-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dignore_002denvironment"></a>
<p>Start with an empty environment, ignoring the inherited environment.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-C <var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--chdir=<var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dC-3"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dchdir"></a>
<p>Change the working directory to <var>dir</var> before invoking <var>command</var>.
This differs from the shell built-in <code>cd</code> in that it starts
<var>command</var> as a subprocess rather than altering the shell&rsquo;s own working
directory; this allows it to be chained with other commands that run commands
in a different context.  For example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Run 'true' with /chroot as its root directory and /srv as its working
# directory.
chroot /chroot env --chdir=/srv true
# Run 'true' with /build as its working directory, FOO=bar in its
# environment, and a time limit of five seconds.
env --chdir=/build FOO=bar timeout 5 true
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--default-signal[=<var>sig</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Unblock and reset signal <var>sig</var> to its default signal handler.
Without <var>sig</var> all known signals are unblocked and reset to their defaults.
Multiple signals can be comma-separated.  The following command runs
<code>seq</code> with SIGINT and SIGPIPE set to their default
(which is to terminate the program):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env --default-signal=PIPE,INT seq 1000 | head -n1
</pre></div>

<p>In the following example, we see how this is not
possible to do with traditional shells.
Here the first trap command sets SIGPIPE to ignore.
The second trap command ostensibly sets it back to its default,
but POSIX mandates that the shell must not change inherited
state of the signal - so it is a no-op.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">trap '' PIPE &amp;&amp; sh -c 'trap - PIPE ; seq inf | head -n1'
</pre></div>

<p>Using <samp>--default-signal=PIPE</samp> we can
ensure the signal handling is set to its default behavior:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">trap '' PIPE &amp;&amp; sh -c 'env --default-signal=PIPE seq inf | head -n1'
</pre></div>


</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--ignore-signal[=<var>sig</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Ignore signal <var>sig</var> when running a program.  Without <var>sig</var> all
known signals are set to ignore.  Multiple signals can be
comma-separated.  The following command runs <code>seq</code> with SIGINT set
to be ignored - pressing <kbd>Ctrl-C</kbd> will not terminate it:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env --ignore-signal=INT seq inf &gt; /dev/null
</pre></div>

<p>&lsquo;<samp>SIGCHLD</samp>&rsquo; is special, in that <samp>--ignore-signal=CHLD</samp> might have
no effect (POSIX says it&rsquo;s unspecified).
</p>
<p>Most operating systems do not allow ignoring &lsquo;<samp>SIGKILL</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>SIGSTOP</samp>&rsquo;
(and possibly other signals).  Attempting to ignore these signals will fail.
</p>
<p>Multiple (and contradictory) <samp>--default-signal=SIG</samp> and
<samp>--ignore-signal=SIG</samp> options are processed left-to-right,
with the latter taking precedence.  In the following example, &lsquo;<samp>SIGPIPE</samp>&rsquo; is
set to default while &lsquo;<samp>SIGINT</samp>&rsquo; is ignored:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">env --default-signal=INT,PIPE --ignore-signal=INT
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--block-signal[=<var>sig</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Block signal(s) <var>sig</var> from being delivered.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--list-signal-handling</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>List blocked or ignored signals to stderr, before executing a command.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--debug</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-21"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddebug-1"></a>
<p>Show verbose information for each processing step.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env -v -uTERM A=B uname -s
unset:    TERM
setenv:   A=B
executing: uname
   arg[0]= 'uname'
   arg[1]= '-s'
Linux
</pre></div>

<p>When combined with <samp>-S</samp> it is recommended to list <samp>-v</samp>
first, e.g. <code>env -vS'string'</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-S <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--split-string=<var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dS-12"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsplit_002dstring"></a>
<a name="index-shebang-arguments"></a>
<a name="index-scripts-arguments"></a>
<a name="index-env-in-scripts"></a>
<p>process and split <var>string</var> into separate arguments used to pass
multiple arguments on shebang lines.  <code>env</code> supports FreeBSD&rsquo;s
syntax of several escape sequences and environment variable
expansions. See below for details and examples.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-exit-status-of-env"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0   if no <var>command</var> is specified and the environment is output
125 if <code>env</code> itself fails
126 if <var>command</var> is found but cannot be invoked
127 if <var>command</var> cannot be found
the exit status of <var>command</var> otherwise
</pre></div>

<a name="g_t_002dS_002f_002d_002dsplit_002dstring-usage-in-scripts"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">23.2.2 <samp>-S</samp>/<samp>--split-string</samp> usage in scripts</h4>

<p>The <samp>-S</samp>/<samp>--split-string</samp> options enable using multiple
arguments on the first one of scripts (shebang line, &lsquo;<samp>#!</samp>&rsquo;).
</p>
<p>When a script&rsquo;s interpreter is in a known location, scripts typically
contain the absolute file name in their first line:
</p>
<table>
<tr><td>Shell script:</td><td><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/bin/sh
echo hello
</pre></div></td></tr>
<tr><td>Perl script:</td><td><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/usr/bin/perl
print &quot;hello\n&quot;;
</pre></div></td></tr>
<tr><td>Python script:</td><td><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/usr/bin/python3
print(&quot;hello&quot;)
</pre></div></td></tr>
</table>

<p>When a script&rsquo;s interpreter is in a non-standard location
in the <code>PATH</code> environment variable, it is recommended
to use <code>env</code> on the first line of the script to
find the executable and run it:
</p>
<table>
<tr><td>Shell script:</td><td><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/usr/bin/env bash
echo hello
</pre></div></td></tr>
<tr><td>Perl script:</td><td><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/usr/bin/env perl
print &quot;hello\n&quot;;
</pre></div></td></tr>
<tr><td>Python script:</td><td><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/usr/bin/env python3
print(&quot;hello&quot;)
</pre></div></td></tr>
</table>

<p>Most operating systems (e.g. GNU/Linux, BSDs) treat all text after the
first space as a single argument. When using <code>env</code> in a script
it is thus not possible to specify multiple arguments.
</p>
<p>In the following example:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">#!/usr/bin/env perl -T -w
print &quot;hello\n&quot;;
</pre></div>

<p>The operating system treats &lsquo;<samp>perl -T -w</samp>&rsquo; as one argument (the
program&rsquo;s name), and executing the script fails with:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">/usr/bin/env: 'perl -T -w': No such file or directory
</pre></div>

<p>The <samp>-S</samp> option instructs <code>env</code> to split the single string
into multiple arguments. The following example works as expected:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat hello.pl
#!/usr/bin/env -S perl -T -w
print &quot;hello\n&quot;;

$ chmod a+x hello.pl
$ ./hello.pl
hello
</pre></div>

<p>And is equivalent to running <code>perl -T -w hello.pl</code> on the command line
prompt.
</p>
<a name="Testing-and-troubleshooting"></a>
<h4 class="unnumberedsubsubsec">Testing and troubleshooting</h4>

<a name="index-single-quotes_002c-and-env-_002dS"></a>
<a name="index-env-_002dS_002c-and-single-quotes"></a>
<a name="index-_002dS_002c-env-and-single-quotes"></a>
<p>To test <code>env -S</code> on the command line, use single quotes for the
<samp>-S</samp> string to emulate a single paramter. Single quotes are not
needed when using <code>env -S</code> in a shebang line on the first line of a
script (the operating system already treats it as one argument).
</p>
<p>The following command is equivalent to the <samp>hello.pl</samp> script above:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env -S'perl -T -w' hello.pl
</pre></div>

<a name="index-env-_002dS_002c-debugging"></a>
<a name="index-debugging_002c-env-_002dS"></a>

<p>To troubleshoot <samp>-S</samp> usage add the <samp>-v</samp> as the first
argument (before <samp>-S</samp>).
</p>
<p>Using <samp>-vS</samp> on a shebang line in a script:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat hello-debug.pl
#!/usr/bin/env -vS perl -T -w
print &quot;hello\n&quot;;

$ chmod a+x hello-debug.pl
$ ./hello-debug.pl
split -S:  'perl -T -w'
 into:    'perl'
     &amp;    '-T'
     &amp;    '-w'
executing: perl
   arg[0]= 'perl'
   arg[1]= '-T'
   arg[2]= '-w'
   arg[3]= './hello-debug.pl'
hello
</pre></div>

<p>Using <samp>-vS</samp> on the command line prompt (adding single quotes):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env -vS'perl -T -w' hello-debug.pl
split -S:  'perl -T -w'
 into:    'perl'
     &amp;    '-T'
     &amp;    '-w'
executing: perl
   arg[0]= 'perl'
   arg[1]= '-T'
   arg[2]= '-w'
   arg[3]= 'hello-debug.pl'
hello
</pre></div>

<a name="g_t_002dS_002f_002d_002dsplit_002dstring-syntax"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">23.2.3 <samp>-S</samp>/<samp>--split-string</samp> syntax</h4>

<a name="Splitting-arguments-by-whitespace"></a>
<h4 class="unnumberedsubsubsec">Splitting arguments by whitespace</h4>

<p>Running <code>env -Sstring</code> splits the <var>string</var> into
arguments based on unquoted spaces or tab characters.
</p>
<p>In the following contrived example the <code>awk</code> variable
&lsquo;<samp>OFS</samp>&rsquo; will be <code>&lt;space&gt;xyz&lt;space&gt;</code> as these spaces are inside
double quotes. The other space characters are used as argument separators:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat one.awk
#!/usr/bin/env -S awk -v OFS=&quot; xyz &quot; -f
BEGIN {print 1,2,3}

$ chmod a+x one.awk
$ ./one.awk
1 xyz 2 xyz 3
</pre></div>

<p>When using <samp>-S</samp> on the command line prompt, remember to add
single quotes around the entire string:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env -S'awk -v OFS=&quot; xyz &quot; -f' one.awk
1 xyz 2 xyz 3
</pre></div>

<a name="Escape-sequences"></a>
<h4 class="unnumberedsubsubsec">Escape sequences</h4>

<p><code>env</code> supports several escape sequences. These sequences
are processed when unquoted or inside double quotes (unless otherwise noted).
Single quotes disable escape sequences except &lsquo;<samp>\'</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>\\</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<table>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\c</code></td><td width="90%">Ignore the remaining characters in the string.
Cannot be used inside double quotes.</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\f</code></td><td width="90%">form-feed character (ASCII 0x0C)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\n</code></td><td width="90%">new-line character (ASCII 0x0A)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\r</code></td><td width="90%">carriage-return character (ASCII 0x0D)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\t</code></td><td width="90%">tab character (ASCII 0x09)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\v</code></td><td width="90%">vertical tab character (ASCII 0x0B)</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\#</code></td><td width="90%">A hash &lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo; character. Used when a &lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo; character
is needed as the first character of an argument (see &rsquo;comments&rsquo; section
below).</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\$</code></td><td width="90%">A dollar-sign character &lsquo;<samp>$</samp>&rsquo;. Unescaped &lsquo;<samp>$</samp>&rsquo; characters
are used to expand environment variables (see &rsquo;variables&rsquo; section below).</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\_</code></td><td width="90%">Inside double-quotes, replaced with a single space character.
Outside quotes, treated as an argument separator. &lsquo;<samp>\_</samp>&rsquo; can be used
to avoid space characters in a shebang line (see examples below).</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\&quot;</code></td><td width="90%">A double-quote character.</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\'</code></td><td width="90%">A single-quote character.
This escape sequence works inside single-quoted strings.</td></tr>
<tr><td width="10%"><code>\\</code></td><td width="90%">A backslash character.
This escape sequence works inside single-quoted strings.</td></tr>
</table>

<p>The following <code>awk</code> script will use tab character as input and output
field separator (instead of spaces and tabs):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat tabs.awk
#!/usr/bin/env -S awk -v FS=&quot;\t&quot; -v OFS=&quot;\t&quot; -f
...
</pre></div>

<a name="Comments"></a>
<h4 class="unnumberedsubsubsec">Comments</h4>

<p>The escape sequence &lsquo;<samp>\c</samp>&rsquo; (used outside single/double quotes)
causes <code>env</code> to ignore the rest of the string.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>#</samp>&rsquo; character causes <code>env</code> to ignore the rest of
the string when it appears as the first character of an argument.
Use &lsquo;<samp>\#</samp>&rsquo; to reverse this behavior.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env -S'printf %s\n A B C'
A
B
C

$ env -S'printf %s\n A# B C'
A#
B
C

$ env -S'printf %s\n A #B C'
A

$ env -S'printf %s\n A \#B C'
A
#B
C

$ env -S'printf %s\n A\cB C'
A
</pre></div>

<p>NOTE: The above examples use single quotes as they are executed
on the command-line.
</p>


<a name="Environment-variable-expansion"></a>
<h4 class="unnumberedsubsubsec">Environment variable expansion</h4>

<p>The pattern &lsquo;<samp>${VARNAME}</samp>&rsquo; is used to substitute a value from
the environment variable. The pattern must include the curly braces
(&lsquo;<samp>{</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>}</samp>&rsquo;). Without them <code>env</code> will reject the string.
Special shell variables (such as &lsquo;<samp>$@</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>$*</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>$$</samp>&rsquo;) are
not supported.
</p>
<p>If the environment variable is empty or not set, the pattern will be replaced
by an empty string. The value of &lsquo;<samp>${VARNAME}</samp>&rsquo; will be that of
the executed <code>env</code>, before any modifications using
<samp>-i</samp>/<samp>--ignore-environment</samp>/<samp>-u</samp>/<samp>--unset</samp> or
setting new values using &lsquo;<samp>VAR=VALUE</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The following python script prepends <samp>/opt/custom/modules</samp> to the python
module search path environment variable (&lsquo;<samp>PYTHONPATH</samp>&rsquo;):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat custom.py
#!/usr/bin/env -S PYTHONPATH=/opt/custom/modules/:${PYTHONPATH} python
print &quot;hello&quot;
...
</pre></div>

<p>The expansion of &lsquo;<samp>${PYTHONPATH}</samp>&rsquo; is performed by <code>env</code>,
not by a shell. If the curly braces are omitted, <code>env</code> will fail:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ cat custom.py
#!/usr/bin/env -S PYTHONPATH=/opt/custom/modules/:$PYTHONPATH python
print &quot;hello&quot;
...

$ chmod a+x custom.py
$ custom.py
/usr/bin/env: only ${VARNAME} expansion is supported, error at: $PYTHONPATH python
</pre></div>

<p>Environment variable expansion happens before clearing the environment
(with <samp>-i</samp>) or unsetting specific variables (with <samp>-u</samp>):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env -S'-i OLDUSER=${USER} env'
OLDUSER=gordon
</pre></div>

<p>Use <samp>-v</samp> to diagnose the operations step-by-step:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ env -vS'-i OLDUSER=${USER} env'
expanding ${USER} into 'gordon'
split -S:  '-i OLDUSER=${USER} env'
 into:    '-i'
     &amp;    'OLDUSER=gordon'
     &amp;    'env'
cleaning environ
setenv:   OLDUSER=gordon
executing: env
   arg[0]= 'env'
OLDUSER=gordon
</pre></div>



<hr>
<a name="nice-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#nohup-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">nohup invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#env-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">env invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Modified-command-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">Modified command invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="nice_003a-Run-a-command-with-modified-niceness"></a>
<h3 class="section">23.3 <code>nice</code>: Run a command with modified niceness</h3>

<a name="index-nice"></a>
<a name="index-niceness"></a>
<a name="index-scheduling_002c-affecting"></a>
<a name="index-appropriate-privileges-3"></a>

<p><code>nice</code> prints a process&rsquo;s <em>niceness</em>, or runs
a command with modified niceness.  <em>niceness</em> affects how
favorably the process is scheduled in the system.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">nice [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>command</var> [<var>arg</var>]&hellip;]
</pre></div>

<p>If no arguments are given, <code>nice</code> prints the current niceness.
Otherwise, <code>nice</code> runs the given <var>command</var> with its
niceness adjusted.  By default, its niceness is incremented by 10.
</p>
<p>Niceness values range at least from -20 (process has high priority
and gets more resources, thus slowing down other processes) through 19
(process has lower priority and runs slowly itself, but has less impact
on the speed of other running processes).  Some systems
may have a wider range of niceness values; conversely, other systems may
enforce more restrictive limits.  An attempt to set the niceness
outside the supported range is treated as an attempt to use the
minimum or maximum supported value.
</p>
<p>A niceness should not be confused with a scheduling priority, which
lets applications determine the order in which threads are scheduled
to run.  Unlike a priority, a niceness is merely advice to the
scheduler, which the scheduler is free to ignore.  Also, as a point of
terminology, POSIX defines the behavior of <code>nice</code> in
terms of a <em>nice value</em>, which is the non-negative difference
between a niceness and the minimum niceness.  Though <code>nice</code>
conforms to POSIX, its documentation and diagnostics use the
term &ldquo;niceness&rdquo; for compatibility with historical practice.
</p>
<p><var>command</var> must not be a special built-in utility (see <a href="#Special-built_002din-utilities">Special built-in utilities</a>).
</p>
<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-6"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-6"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>nice</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>nice</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env nice &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<p>Note to change the <em>niceness</em> of an existing process,
one needs to use the <code>renice</code> command.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following option.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-n <var>adjustment</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--adjustment=<var>adjustment</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dn-19"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dadjustment"></a>
<p>Add <var>adjustment</var> instead of 10 to the command&rsquo;s niceness.  If
<var>adjustment</var> is negative and you lack appropriate privileges,
<code>nice</code> issues a warning but otherwise acts as if you specified
a zero adjustment.
</p>
<p>For compatibility <code>nice</code> also supports an obsolete
option syntax <samp>-<var>adjustment</var></samp>.  New scripts should use
<samp>-n <var>adjustment</var></samp> instead.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p><code>nice</code> is installed only on systems that have the POSIX
<code>setpriority</code> function, so portable scripts should not rely on
its existence on non-POSIX platforms.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-nice"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">0   if no <var>command</var> is specified and the niceness is output
125 if <code>nice</code> itself fails
126 if <var>command</var> is found but cannot be invoked
127 if <var>command</var> cannot be found
the exit status of <var>command</var> otherwise
</pre></div>

<p>It is sometimes useful to run a non-interactive program with reduced niceness.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ nice factor 4611686018427387903
</pre></div>

<p>Since <code>nice</code> prints the current niceness,
you can invoke it through itself to demonstrate how it works.
</p>
<p>The default behavior is to increase the niceness by &lsquo;<samp>10</samp>&rsquo;:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ nice
0
$ nice nice
10
$ nice -n 10 nice
10
</pre></div>

<p>The <var>adjustment</var> is relative to the current niceness.  In the
next example, the first <code>nice</code> invocation runs the second one
with niceness 10, and it in turn runs the final one with a niceness
that is 3 more:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ nice nice -n 3 nice
13
</pre></div>

<p>Specifying a niceness larger than the supported range
is the same as specifying the maximum supported value:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ nice -n 10000000000 nice
19
</pre></div>

<p>Only a privileged user may run a process with lower niceness:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ nice -n -1 nice
nice: cannot set niceness: Permission denied
0
$ sudo nice -n -1 nice
-1
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="nohup-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#stdbuf-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">stdbuf invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#nice-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">nice invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Modified-command-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">Modified command invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="nohup_003a-Run-a-command-immune-to-hangups"></a>
<h3 class="section">23.4 <code>nohup</code>: Run a command immune to hangups</h3>

<a name="index-nohup"></a>
<a name="index-hangups_002c-immunity-to"></a>
<a name="index-immunity-to-hangups"></a>
<a name="index-logging-out-and-continuing-to-run"></a>

<a name="index-nohup_002eout"></a>
<p><code>nohup</code> runs the given <var>command</var> with hangup signals ignored,
so that the command can continue running in the background after you log
out.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">nohup <var>command</var> [<var>arg</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p>If standard input is a terminal, redirect it so that terminal sessions
do not mistakenly consider the terminal to be used by the command.
Make the substitute file descriptor unreadable, so that commands that
mistakenly attempt to read from standard input can report an error.
This redirection is a GNU extension; programs intended to be portable
to non-GNU hosts can use &lsquo;<samp>nohup <var>command</var> [<var>arg</var>]&hellip;
0&gt;/dev/null</samp>&rsquo; instead.
</p>
<a name="index-nohup_002eout-1"></a>
<p>If standard output is a terminal, the command&rsquo;s standard output is appended
to the file <samp>nohup.out</samp>; if that cannot be written to, it is appended
to the file <samp>$HOME/nohup.out</samp>; and if that cannot be written to, the
command is not run.
Any <samp>nohup.out</samp> or <samp>$HOME/nohup.out</samp> file created by
<code>nohup</code> is made readable and writable only to the user,
regardless of the current umask settings.
</p>
<p>If standard error is a terminal, it is normally redirected to the same file
descriptor as the (possibly-redirected) standard output.
However, if standard output is closed, standard error terminal output
is instead appended to the file <samp>nohup.out</samp> or
<samp>$HOME/nohup.out</samp> as above.
</p>
<p>To capture the command&rsquo;s output to a file other than <samp>nohup.out</samp>
you can redirect it.  For example, to capture the output of
<code>make</code>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">nohup make &gt; make.log
</pre></div>

<p><code>nohup</code> does not automatically put the command it runs in the
background; you must do that explicitly, by ending the command line
with an &lsquo;<samp>&amp;</samp>&rsquo;.  Also, <code>nohup</code> does not alter the
niceness of <var>command</var>; use <code>nice</code> for that,
e.g., &lsquo;<samp>nohup nice <var>command</var></samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p><var>command</var> must not be a special built-in utility (see <a href="#Special-built_002din-utilities">Special built-in utilities</a>).
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.  Options must precede operands.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-nohup"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">125 if <code>nohup</code> itself fails, and <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> is not set
126 if <var>command</var> is found but cannot be invoked
127 if <var>command</var> cannot be found
the exit status of <var>command</var> otherwise
</pre></div>

<p>If <code>POSIXLY_CORRECT</code> is set, internal failures give status 127
instead of 125.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="stdbuf-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#timeout-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">timeout invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#nohup-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">nohup invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Modified-command-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">Modified command invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="stdbuf_003a-Run-a-command-with-modified-I_002fO-stream-buffering"></a>
<h3 class="section">23.5 <code>stdbuf</code>: Run a command with modified I/O stream buffering</h3>

<a name="index-stdbuf"></a>
<a name="index-standard-streams_002c-buffering"></a>
<a name="index-line-buffered"></a>

<p><code>stdbuf</code> allows one to modify the buffering operations of the
three standard I/O streams associated with a program.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">stdbuf <var>option</var>&hellip; <var>command</var>
</pre></div>

<p><var>command</var> must start with the name of a program that
</p><ol>
<li> uses the ISO C <code>FILE</code> streams for input/output (note the
programs <code>dd</code> and <code>cat</code> don&rsquo;t do that),

</li><li> does not adjust the buffering of its standard streams (note the
program <code>tee</code> is not in this category).
</li></ol>

<p>Any additional <var>arg</var>s are passed as additional arguments to the
<var>command</var>.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-i <var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--input=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002di-19"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dinput"></a>
<p>Adjust the standard input stream buffering.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-o <var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--output=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002do-10"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002doutput-3"></a>
<p>Adjust the standard output stream buffering.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-e <var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--error=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002de-8"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002derror"></a>
<p>Adjust the standard error stream buffering.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>The <var>mode</var> can be specified as follows:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>L</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Set the stream to line buffered mode.
In this mode data is coalesced until a newline is output or
input is read from any stream attached to a terminal device.
This option is invalid with standard input.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Disable buffering of the selected stream.
In this mode, data is output immediately and only the
amount of data requested is read from input.
Note the difference in function for input and output.
Disabling buffering for input will not influence the responsiveness
or blocking behavior of the stream input functions.
For example <code>fread</code> will still block until <code>EOF</code> or error,
even if the underlying <code>read</code> returns less data than requested.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp><var>size</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Specify the size of the buffer to use in fully buffered mode.
<var>size</var> may be, or may be an integer optionally followed by,
one of the following multiplicative suffixes:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>KB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;           1000 (KiloBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;           1024 (KibiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>MB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt;      1000*1000 (MegaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;      1024*1024 (MebiBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>GB</samp>&rsquo; =&gt; 1000*1000*1000 (GigaBytes)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt; 1024*1024*1024 (GibiBytes)
</pre></div>
<p>and so on for &lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;, and &lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;.
Binary prefixes can be used, too: &lsquo;<samp>KiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>MiB</samp>&rsquo;=&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;,
and so on.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p><code>stdbuf</code> is installed only on platforms that use the
Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) and support the
<code>constructor</code> attribute, so portable scripts should not rely on
its existence.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-stdbuf"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">125 if <code>stdbuf</code> itself fails
126 if <var>command</var> is found but cannot be invoked
127 if <var>command</var> cannot be found
the exit status of <var>command</var> otherwise
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="timeout-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#stdbuf-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">stdbuf invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Modified-command-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">Modified command invocation</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="timeout_003a-Run-a-command-with-a-time-limit"></a>
<h3 class="section">23.6 <code>timeout</code>: Run a command with a time limit</h3>

<a name="index-timeout"></a>
<a name="index-time-limit"></a>
<a name="index-run-commands-with-bounded-time"></a>

<p><code>timeout</code> runs the given <var>command</var> and kills it if it is
still running after the specified time interval.  Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">timeout [<var>option</var>] <var>duration</var> <var>command</var> [<var>arg</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<p><var>command</var> must not be a special built-in utility (see <a href="#Special-built_002din-utilities">Special built-in utilities</a>).
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--preserve-status</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002dstatus"></a>
<p>Return the exit status of the managed <var>command</var> on timeout, rather than
a specific exit status indicating a timeout.  This is useful if the
managed <var>command</var> supports running for an indeterminate amount of time.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--foreground</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dforeground"></a>
<p>Don&rsquo;t create a separate background program group, so that
the managed <var>command</var> can use the foreground TTY normally.
This is needed to support timing out commands not started
directly from an interactive shell, in two situations.
</p><ol>
<li> <var>command</var> is interactive and needs to read from the terminal for example
</li><li> the user wants to support sending signals directly to <var>command</var>
from the terminal (like Ctrl-C for example)
</li></ol>

<p>Note in this mode of operation, any children of <var>command</var>
will not be timed out.  Also SIGCONT will not be sent to <var>command</var>,
as it&rsquo;s generally not needed with foreground processes, and can
cause intermittent signal delivery issues with programs that are monitors
themselves (like GDB for example).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-k <var>duration</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--kill-after=<var>duration</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dk-7"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dkill_002dafter"></a>
<p>Ensure the monitored <var>command</var> is killed by also sending a &lsquo;<samp>KILL</samp>&rsquo;
signal, after the specified <var>duration</var>.  Without this option, if the
selected signal proves not to be fatal, <code>timeout</code> does not kill
the <var>command</var>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>signal</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--signal=<var>signal</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-28"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dsignal"></a>
<p>Send this <var>signal</var> to <var>command</var> on timeout, rather than the
default &lsquo;<samp>TERM</samp>&rsquo; signal.  <var>signal</var> may be a name like &lsquo;<samp>HUP</samp>&rsquo;
or a number.  See <a href="#Signal-specifications">Signal specifications</a>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-v</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--verbose</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dv-22"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dverbose-16"></a>
<p>Diagnose to stderr, any signal sent upon timeout.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<a name="index-time-units"></a>
<p><var>duration</var> is a floating point number in either the current or the
C locale (see <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>) followed by an optional unit:
</p><div class="display">
<pre class="display">&lsquo;<samp>s</samp>&rsquo; for seconds (the default)
&lsquo;<samp>m</samp>&rsquo; for minutes
&lsquo;<samp>h</samp>&rsquo; for hours
&lsquo;<samp>d</samp>&rsquo; for days
</pre></div>
<p>A duration of 0 disables the associated timeout.
Note that the actual timeout duration is dependent on system conditions,
which should be especially considered when specifying sub-second timeouts.
</p>
<a name="index-exit-status-of-timeout"></a>
<p>Exit status:
</p>
<div class="display">
<pre class="display">124 if <var>command</var> times out
125 if <code>timeout</code> itself fails
126 if <var>command</var> is found but cannot be invoked
127 if <var>command</var> cannot be found
137 if <var>command</var> is sent the KILL(9) signal (128+9)
the exit status of <var>command</var> otherwise
</pre></div>


<hr>

<a name="Process-control-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">24 Process control</h2>

<a name="index-processes_002c-commands-for-controlling"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-controlling-processes"></a>

<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#kill-invocation" accesskey="1">kill invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Sending a signal to processes.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="kill-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Up: <a href="#Process-control" accesskey="u" rel="up">Process control</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="kill_003a-Send-a-signal-to-processes"></a>
<h3 class="section">24.1 <code>kill</code>: Send a signal to processes</h3>

<a name="index-kill-1"></a>
<a name="index-send-a-signal-to-processes"></a>

<p>The <code>kill</code> command sends a signal to processes, causing them
to terminate or otherwise act upon receiving the signal in some way.
Alternatively, it lists information about signals.  Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">kill [-s <var>signal</var> | --signal <var>signal</var> | -<var>signal</var>] <var>pid</var>&hellip;
kill [-l | --list | -t | --table] [<var>signal</var>]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-7"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-7"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>kill</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>kill</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env kill &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<p>The first form of the <code>kill</code> command sends a signal to all
<var>pid</var> arguments.  The default signal to send if none is specified
is &lsquo;<samp>TERM</samp>&rsquo;.  The special signal number &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; does not denote a
valid signal, but can be used to test whether the <var>pid</var> arguments
specify processes to which a signal could be sent.
</p>
<p>If <var>pid</var> is positive, the signal is sent to the process with the
process ID <var>pid</var>.  If <var>pid</var> is zero, the signal is sent to all
processes in the process group of the current process.  If <var>pid</var>
is -1, the signal is sent to all processes for which the user has
permission to send a signal.  If <var>pid</var> is less than -1, the signal
is sent to all processes in the process group that equals the absolute
value of <var>pid</var>.
</p>
<p>If <var>pid</var> is not positive, a system-dependent set of system
processes is excluded from the list of processes to which the signal
is sent.
</p>
<p>If a negative <var>pid</var> argument is desired as the first one, it
should be preceded by <samp>--</samp>.  However, as a common extension to
POSIX, <samp>--</samp> is not required with &lsquo;<samp>kill
-<var>signal</var> -<var>pid</var></samp>&rsquo;.  The following commands are equivalent:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">kill -15 -1
kill -TERM -1
kill -s TERM -- -1
kill -- -1
</pre></div>

<p>The first form of the <code>kill</code> command succeeds if every <var>pid</var>
argument specifies at least one process that the signal was sent to.
</p>
<p>The second form of the <code>kill</code> command lists signal information.
Either the <samp>-l</samp> or <samp>--list</samp> option, or the <samp>-t</samp>
or <samp>--table</samp> option must be specified.  Without any
<var>signal</var> argument, all supported signals are listed.  The output
of <samp>-l</samp> or <samp>--list</samp> is a list of the signal names, one
per line; if <var>signal</var> is already a name, the signal number is
printed instead.  The output of <samp>-t</samp> or <samp>--table</samp> is a
table of signal numbers, names, and descriptions.  This form of the
<code>kill</code> command succeeds if all <var>signal</var> arguments are valid
and if there is no output error.
</p>
<p>The <code>kill</code> command also supports the <samp>--help</samp> and
<samp>--version</samp> options.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<p>A <var>signal</var> may be a signal name like &lsquo;<samp>HUP</samp>&rsquo;, or a signal
number like &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;, or an exit status of a process terminated by the
signal.  A signal name can be given in canonical form or prefixed by
&lsquo;<samp>SIG</samp>&rsquo;.  The case of the letters is ignored, except for the
<samp>-<var>signal</var></samp> option which must use upper case to avoid
ambiguity with lower case option letters.
See <a href="#Signal-specifications">Signal specifications</a>, for a list of supported
signal names and numbers.
</p>
<hr>

<div class="header">

<a name="Delaying-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">25 Delaying</h2>

<a name="index-delaying-commands"></a>
<a name="index-commands-for-delaying"></a>


<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#sleep-invocation" accesskey="1">sleep invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Delay for a specified time.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="sleep-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Up: <a href="#Delaying" accesskey="u" rel="up">Delaying</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="sleep_003a-Delay-for-a-specified-time"></a>
<h3 class="section">25.1 <code>sleep</code>: Delay for a specified time</h3>

<a name="index-sleep"></a>
<a name="index-delay-for-a-specified-time"></a>

<p><code>sleep</code> pauses for an amount of time specified by the sum of
the values of the command line arguments.
Synopsis:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">sleep <var>number</var>[smhd]&hellip;
</pre></div>

<a name="index-time-units-1"></a>
<p>Each argument is a non-negative number followed by an optional unit; the default
is seconds.  The units are:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>s</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>seconds
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>m</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>minutes
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>h</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>hours
</p></dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>d</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>days
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Although portable POSIX scripts must give <code>sleep</code> a single
non-negative integer argument without a suffix, GNU <code>sleep</code>
also accepts two or more arguments, unit suffixes, and floating-point
numbers in either the current or the C locale.  See <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>.
</p>
<p>The only options are <samp>--help</samp> and <samp>--version</samp>.  See <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<a name="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-8"></a>
<a name="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-8"></a>
<p>Due to shell aliases and built-in <code>sleep</code> functions, using an
unadorned <code>sleep</code> interactively or in a script may get you
different functionality than that described here.  Invoke it via
<code>env</code> (i.e., <code>env sleep &hellip;</code>) to avoid interference
from the shell.
</p>

<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
