<a name="Numeric-operations-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">26 Numeric operations</h2>

<a name="index-numeric-operations"></a>
<p>These programs do numerically-related operations.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#factor-invocation" accesskey="1">factor invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Show factors of numbers.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#numfmt-invocation" accesskey="2">numfmt invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Reformat numbers.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#seq-invocation" accesskey="3">seq invocation</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Print sequences of numbers.
</td></tr>
</table>


<hr>
<a name="factor-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#numfmt-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">numfmt invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Numeric-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Numeric operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="factor_003a-Print-prime-factors"></a>
<h3 class="section">26.1 <code>factor</code>: Print prime factors</h3>

<a name="index-factor"></a>
<a name="index-prime-factors"></a>

<p><code>factor</code> prints prime factors.  Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">factor [<var>number</var>]&hellip;
factor <var>option</var>
</pre></div>

<p>If no <var>number</var> is specified on the command line, <code>factor</code> reads
numbers from standard input, delimited by newlines, tabs, or spaces.
</p>
<p>The <code>factor</code> command supports only a small number of options:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--help</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print a short help on standard output, then exit without further
processing.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--version</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><p>Print the program version on standard output, then exit without further
processing.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Factoring the product of the eighth and ninth Mersenne primes
takes about 30 milliseconds of CPU time on a 2.2 GHz Athlon.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">M8=$(echo 2^31-1|bc)
M9=$(echo 2^61-1|bc)
n=$(echo &quot;$M8 * $M9&quot; | bc)
/usr/bin/time -f %U factor $n
4951760154835678088235319297: 2147483647 2305843009213693951
0.03
</pre></div>

<p>Similarly, factoring the eighth Fermat number <em>2^{256}+1</em> takes
about 20 seconds on the same machine.
</p>
<p>Factoring large numbers is, in general, hard.  The Pollard-Brent rho
algorithm used by <code>factor</code> is particularly effective for
numbers with relatively small factors.  If you wish to factor large
numbers which do not have small factors (for example, numbers which
are the product of two large primes), other methods are far better.
</p>
<p>If <code>factor</code> is built without using GNU MP, only
single-precision arithmetic is available, and so large numbers
(typically <em>2^{128}</em> and above) will not be supported.
The single-precision code uses an algorithm which is designed
for factoring smaller numbers.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="numfmt-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#seq-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">seq invocation</a>, Previous: <a href="#factor-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">factor invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Numeric-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Numeric operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="numfmt_003a-Reformat-numbers"></a>
<h3 class="section">26.2 <code>numfmt</code>: Reformat numbers</h3>

<a name="index-numfmt"></a>

<p><code>numfmt</code> reads numbers in various representations and reformats them
as requested.  The most common usage is converting numbers to/from <em>human</em>
representation (e.g. &lsquo;<samp>4G</samp>&rsquo; &rarr; &lsquo;<samp>4,000,000,000</samp>&rsquo;).
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">numfmt [<var>option</var>]&hellip; [<var>number</var>]
</pre></div>

<p><code>numfmt</code> converts each <var>number</var> on the command-line according to the
specified options (see below).  If no <var>number</var>s are given, it reads numbers
from standard input.  <code>numfmt</code> can optionally extract numbers from
specific columns, maintaining proper line padding and alignment.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>
<p>See <samp>--invalid</samp> for additional information regarding exit status.
</p>
<a name="General-options-3"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">26.2.1 General options</h4>

<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--debug</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002ddebug-2"></a>
<p>Print (to standard error) warning messages about possible erroneous usage.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-d <var>d</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--delimiter=<var>d</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dd-19"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002ddelimiter-1"></a>
<p>Use the character <var>d</var> as input field separator (default: whitespace).
<em>Note</em>: Using non-default delimiter turns off automatic padding.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--field=<var>fields</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfield"></a>
<p>Convert the number in input field <var>fields</var> (default: 1).
<var>fields</var> supports <code>cut</code> style field ranges:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">N    N'th field, counted from 1
N-   from N'th field, to end of line
N-M  from N'th to M'th field (inclusive)
-M   from first to M'th field (inclusive)
-    all fields
</pre></div>


</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dformat-6"></a>
<p>Use printf-style floating FORMAT string.  The <var>format</var> string must contain
one &lsquo;<samp>%f</samp>&rsquo; directive, optionally with &lsquo;<samp>'</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;, width
or precision modifiers.  The &lsquo;<samp>'</samp>&rsquo; modifier will enable <samp>--grouping</samp>,
the &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; modifier will enable left-aligned <samp>--padding</samp> and the width
modifier will enable right-aligned <samp>--padding</samp>.  The &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; width
modifier (without the &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; modifier) will generate leading zeros on the
number, up to the specified width.  A precision specification like &lsquo;<samp>%.1f</samp>&rsquo;
will override the precision determined from the input data or set due to
<samp>--to</samp> option auto scaling.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--from=<var>unit</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfrom-1"></a>
<p>Auto-scales input numbers according to <var>unit</var>.  See UNITS below.
The default is no scaling, meaning suffixes (e.g. &lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;) will
trigger an error.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--from-unit=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dfrom_002dunit"></a>
<p>Specify the input unit size (instead of the default 1).  Use this option when
the input numbers represent other units (e.g. if the input number &lsquo;<samp>10</samp>&rsquo;
represents 10 units of 512 bytes, use &lsquo;<samp>--from-unit=512</samp>&rsquo;).
Suffixes are handled as with &lsquo;<samp>--from=auto</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--grouping</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dgrouping"></a>
<p>Group digits in output numbers according to the current locale&rsquo;s grouping rules
(e.g <em>Thousands Separator</em> character, commonly &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; (dot) or &lsquo;<samp>,</samp>&rsquo;
comma).  This option has no effect in &lsquo;<samp>POSIX/C</samp>&rsquo; locale.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--header[=<var>n</var>]</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dheader-2"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dheader_003dN"></a>
<p>Print the first <var>n</var> (default: 1) lines without any conversion.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--invalid=<var>mode</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dinvalid"></a>
<p>The default action on input errors is to exit immediately with status code 2.
<samp>--invalid=&lsquo;<samp>abort</samp>&rsquo;</samp> explicitly specifies this default mode.
With a <var>mode</var> of &lsquo;<samp>fail</samp>&rsquo;, print a warning for <em>each</em> conversion
error, and exit with status 2.  With a <var>mode</var> of &lsquo;<samp>warn</samp>&rsquo;, exit with
status 0, even in the presence of conversion errors, and with a <var>mode</var> of
&lsquo;<samp>ignore</samp>&rsquo; do not even print diagnostics.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--padding=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dpadding"></a>
<p>Pad the output numbers to <var>n</var> characters, by adding spaces.  If <var>n</var> is
a positive number, numbers will be right-aligned.  If <var>n</var> is a negative
number, numbers will be left-aligned.  By default, numbers are automatically
aligned based on the input line&rsquo;s width (only with the default delimiter).
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--round=<var>method</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dround"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dround_003dup"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dround_003ddown"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dround_003dfrom_002dzero"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dround_003dtowards_002dzero"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dround_003dnearest"></a>
<p>When converting number representations, round the number according to
<var>method</var>, which can be &lsquo;<samp>up</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>down</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>from-zero</samp>&rsquo; (the default), &lsquo;<samp>towards-zero</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>nearest</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--suffix=<var>suffix</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dsuffix-7"></a>
<p>Add &lsquo;<samp>SUFFIX</samp>&rsquo; to the output numbers, and accept optional &lsquo;<samp>SUFFIX</samp>&rsquo; in
input numbers.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--to=<var>unit</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dto"></a>
<p>Auto-scales output numbers according to <var>unit</var>.  See <em>Units</em> below.
The default is no scaling, meaning all the digits of the number are printed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--to-unit=<var>n</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002d_002dto_002dunit"></a>
<p>Specify the output unit size (instead of the default 1).  Use this option when
the output numbers represent other units (e.g. to represent &lsquo;<samp>4,000,000</samp>&rsquo;
bytes in blocks of 1KB, use &lsquo;<samp>--to=si --to-unit=1000</samp>&rsquo;).
Suffixes are handled as with &lsquo;<samp>--from=auto</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-z</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--zero-terminated</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dz-18"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dzero_002dterminated-9"></a>
<a name="index-process-zero_002dterminated-items-9"></a>
<p>Delimit items with a zero byte rather than a newline (ASCII LF).
I.e., treat input as items separated by ASCII NUL
and terminate output items with ASCII NUL.
This option can be useful in conjunction with &lsquo;<samp>perl -0</samp>&rsquo; or
&lsquo;<samp>find -print0</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>xargs -0</samp>&rsquo; which do the same in order to
reliably handle arbitrary file names (even those containing blanks
or other special characters).
Note with <samp>-z</samp> the newline character is treated as a field separator.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="Possible-units_003a"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">26.2.2 Possible <var>unit</var>s:</h4>

<p>The following are the possible <var>unit</var> options with <samp>--from=UNITS</samp> and
<samp>--to=UNITS</samp>:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt><var>none</var></dt>
<dd><p>No scaling is performed.  For input numbers, no suffixes are accepted, and any
trailing characters following the number will trigger an error.  For output
numbers, all digits of the numbers will be printed.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><var>si</var></dt>
<dd><p>Auto-scale numbers according to the <em>International System of Units (SI)</em>
standard.
For input numbers, accept one of the following suffixes.
For output numbers, values larger than 1000 will be rounded, and printed with
one of the following suffixes:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^1 = 10^3</em> (Kilo)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^2 = 10^6</em> (Mega)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^3 = 10^9</em> (Giga)
&lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^4 = 10^{12}</em> (Tera)
&lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^5 = 10^{15}</em> (Peta)
&lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^6 = 10^{18}</em> (Exa)
&lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^7 = 10^{21}</em> (Zetta)
&lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1000^8 = 10^{24}</em> (Yotta)
</pre></div>

</dd>
<dt><var>iec</var></dt>
<dd><p>Auto-scale numbers according to the <em>International Electrotechnical
Commission (IEC)</em> standard.
For input numbers, accept one of the following suffixes.
For output numbers, values larger than 1024 will be rounded, and printed with
one of the following suffixes:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^1 = 2^{10}</em> (Kibi)
&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^2 = 2^{20}</em> (Mebi)
&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^3 = 2^{30}</em> (Gibi)
&lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^4 = 2^{40}</em> (Tebi)
&lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^5 = 2^{50}</em> (Pebi)
&lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^6 = 2^{60}</em> (Exbi)
&lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^7 = 2^{70}</em> (Zebi)
&lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^8 = 2^{80}</em> (Yobi)
</pre></div>

<p>The <samp>iec</samp> option uses a single letter suffix (e.g. &lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;), which is
not fully standard, as the <em>iec</em> standard recommends a two-letter symbol
(e.g &lsquo;<samp>Gi</samp>&rsquo;) - but in practice, this method common.  Compare with
the <samp>iec-i</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><var>iec-i</var></dt>
<dd><p>Auto-scale numbers according to the <em>International Electrotechnical
Commission (IEC)</em> standard.
For input numbers, accept one of the following suffixes.
For output numbers, values larger than 1024 will be rounded, and printed with
one of the following suffixes:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">&lsquo;<samp>Ki</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^1 = 2^{10}</em> (Kibi)
&lsquo;<samp>Mi</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^2 = 2^{20}</em> (Mebi)
&lsquo;<samp>Gi</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^3 = 2^{30}</em> (Gibi)
&lsquo;<samp>Ti</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^4 = 2^{40}</em> (Tebi)
&lsquo;<samp>Pi</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^5 = 2^{50}</em> (Pebi)
&lsquo;<samp>Ei</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^6 = 2^{60}</em> (Exbi)
&lsquo;<samp>Zi</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^7 = 2^{70}</em> (Zebi)
&lsquo;<samp>Yi</samp>&rsquo;  =&gt;  <em>1024^8 = 2^{80}</em> (Yobi)
</pre></div>

<p>The <samp>iec-i</samp> option uses a two-letter suffix symbol (e.g. &lsquo;<samp>Gi</samp>&rsquo;),
as the <em>iec</em> standard recommends, but this is not always common in
practice.  Compare with the <samp>iec</samp> option.
</p>
</dd>
<dt><var>auto</var></dt>
<dd><p>&lsquo;<samp>auto</samp>&rsquo; can only be used with <samp>--from</samp>.  With this method, numbers
with &lsquo;<samp>K</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>M</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>G</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>T</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>P</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>E</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Z</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Y</samp>&rsquo;
suffixes are interpreted as <em>SI</em> values, and numbers with &lsquo;<samp>Ki</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>Mi</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Gi</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Ti</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Pi</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Ei</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Zi</samp>&rsquo;,&lsquo;<samp>Yi</samp>&rsquo; suffixes
are interpreted as <em>IEC</em> values.
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<a name="Examples-of-using-numfmt"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">26.2.3 Examples of using <code>numfmt</code></h4>

<p>Converting a single number from/to <em>human</em> representation:
</p><div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ numfmt --to=si 500000
500K

$ numfmt --to=iec 500000
489K

$ numfmt --to=iec-i 500000
489Ki

$ numfmt --from=si 1M
1000000

$ numfmt --from=iec 1M
1048576

# with '--from=auto', M=Mega, Mi=Mebi
$ numfmt --from=auto 1M
1000000
$ numfmt --from=auto 1Mi
1048576
</pre></div>

<p>Converting from &lsquo;<samp>SI</samp>&rsquo; to &lsquo;<samp>IEC</samp>&rsquo; scales (e.g. when a harddisk capacity is
advertised as &lsquo;<samp>1TB</samp>&rsquo;, while checking the drive&rsquo;s capacity gives lower
values):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ numfmt --from=si --to=iec 1T
932G
</pre></div>


<p>Converting a single field from an input file / piped input (these contrived
examples are for demonstration purposes only, as both <code>ls</code> and
<code>df</code> support the <samp>--human-readable</samp> option to
output sizes in human-readable format):
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Third field (file size) will be shown in SI representation
$ ls -log | numfmt --field 3 --header --to=si | head -n4
-rw-r--r--  1     94K Aug 23  2011 ABOUT-NLS
-rw-r--r--  1    3.7K Jan  7 16:15 AUTHORS
-rw-r--r--  1     36K Jun  1  2011 COPYING
-rw-r--r--  1       0 Jan  7 15:15 ChangeLog

# Second field (size) will be shown in IEC representation
$ df --block-size=1 | numfmt --field 2 --header --to=iec | head -n4
File system   1B-blocks        Used  Available Use% Mounted on
rootfs             132G   104741408   26554036  80% /
tmpfs              794M        7580     804960   1% /run/shm
/dev/sdb1          694G   651424756   46074696  94% /home
</pre></div>


<p>Output can be tweaked using <samp>--padding</samp> or <samp>--format</samp>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># Pad to 10 characters, right-aligned
$ du -s * | numfmt --to=si --padding=10
      2.5K config.log
       108 config.status
      1.7K configure
        20 configure.ac

# Pad to 10 characters, left-aligned
$ du -s * | numfmt --to=si --padding=-10
2.5K       config.log
108        config.status
1.7K       configure
20         configure.ac

# Pad to 10 characters, left-aligned, using 'format'
$ du -s * | numfmt --to=si --format=&quot;%10f&quot;
      2.5K config.log
       108 config.status
      1.7K configure
        20 configure.ac

# Pad to 10 characters, left-aligned, using 'format'
$ du -s * | numfmt --to=si --padding=&quot;%-10f&quot;
2.5K       config.log
108        config.status
1.7K       configure
20         configure.ac
</pre></div>

<p>With locales that support grouping digits, using <samp>--grouping</samp> or
<samp>--format</samp> enables grouping.  In &lsquo;<samp>POSIX</samp>&rsquo; locale, grouping is
silently ignored:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ LC_ALL=C numfmt --from=iec --grouping 2G
2147483648

$ LC_ALL=en_US.utf8 numfmt --from=iec --grouping 2G
2,147,483,648

$ LC_ALL=ta_IN numfmt --from=iec --grouping 2G
2,14,74,83,648

$ LC_ALL=C ./src/numfmt --from=iec --format=&quot;==%'15f==&quot; 2G
==     2147483648==

$ LC_ALL=en_US.utf8 ./src/numfmt --from=iec --format=&quot;==%'15f==&quot; 2G
==  2,147,483,648==

$ LC_ALL=en_US.utf8 ./src/numfmt --from=iec --format=&quot;==%'-15f==&quot; 2G
==2,147,483,648  ==

$ LC_ALL=ta_IN ./src/numfmt --from=iec --format=&quot;==%'15f==&quot; 2G
== 2,14,74,83,648==
</pre></div>


<hr>
<a name="seq-invocation"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#numfmt-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">numfmt invocation</a>, Up: <a href="#Numeric-operations" accesskey="u" rel="up">Numeric operations</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="seq_003a-Print-numeric-sequences"></a>
<h3 class="section">26.3 <code>seq</code>: Print numeric sequences</h3>

<a name="index-seq"></a>
<a name="index-numeric-sequences"></a>
<a name="index-sequence-of-numbers"></a>

<p><code>seq</code> prints a sequence of numbers to standard output.  Synopses:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">seq [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>last</var>
seq [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>first</var> <var>last</var>
seq [<var>option</var>]&hellip; <var>first</var> <var>increment</var> <var>last</var>
</pre></div>

<p><code>seq</code> prints the numbers from <var>first</var> to <var>last</var> by
<var>increment</var>.  By default, each number is printed on a separate line.
When <var>increment</var> is not specified, it defaults to &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;,
even when <var>first</var> is larger than <var>last</var>.
<var>first</var> also defaults to &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;.  So <code>seq 1</code> prints
&lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;, but <code>seq 0</code> and <code>seq 10 5</code> produce no output.
The sequence of numbers ends when the sum of the current number and
<var>increment</var> would become greater than <var>last</var>,
so <code>seq 1 10 10</code> only produces &lsquo;<samp>1</samp>&rsquo;.
<var>increment</var> must not be &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;; use the tool <code>yes</code> to get
repeated output of a constant number.
<var>first</var>, <var>increment</var> and <var>last</var> must not be <code>NaN</code>.
Floating-point numbers may be specified in either the current or
the C locale.  See <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>.
</p>
<p>The program accepts the following options.  Also see <a href="#Common-options">Common options</a>.
Options must precede operands.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-f <var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--format=<var>format</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002df-23"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dformat-7"></a>
<a name="index-formatting-of-numbers-in-seq"></a>
<p>Print all numbers using <var>format</var>.
<var>format</var> must contain exactly one of the &lsquo;<samp>printf</samp>&rsquo;-style
floating point conversion specifications &lsquo;<samp>%a</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%e</samp>&rsquo;,
&lsquo;<samp>%f</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%g</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%A</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%E</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%F</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>%G</samp>&rsquo;.
The &lsquo;<samp>%</samp>&rsquo; may be followed by zero or more flags taken from the set
&lsquo;<samp>-+#0 '</samp>&rsquo;, then an optional width containing one or more digits,
then an optional precision consisting of a &lsquo;<samp>.</samp>&rsquo; followed by zero
or more digits.  <var>format</var> may also contain any number of &lsquo;<samp>%%</samp>&rsquo;
conversion specifications.  All conversion specifications have the
same meaning as with &lsquo;<samp>printf</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The default format is derived from <var>first</var>, <var>step</var>, and
<var>last</var>.  If these all use a fixed point decimal representation,
the default format is &lsquo;<samp>%.<var>p</var>f</samp>&rsquo;, where <var>p</var> is the minimum
precision that can represent the output numbers exactly.  Otherwise,
the default format is &lsquo;<samp>%g</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-s <var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--separator=<var>string</var></samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002ds-29"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dseparator-3"></a>
<a name="index-separator-for-numbers-in-seq"></a>
<p>Separate numbers with <var>string</var>; default is a newline.
The output always terminates with a newline.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>-w</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dt>&lsquo;<samp>--equal-width</samp>&rsquo;</dt>
<dd><a name="index-_002dw-13"></a>
<a name="index-_002d_002dequal_002dwidth"></a>
<p>Print all numbers with the same width, by padding with leading zeros.
<var>first</var>, <var>step</var>, and <var>last</var> should all use a fixed point
decimal representation.
(To have other kinds of padding, use <samp>--format</samp>).
</p>
</dd>
</dl>

<p>You can get finer-grained control over output with <samp>-f</samp>:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq -f '(%9.2E)' -9e5 1.1e6 1.3e6
(-9.00E+05)
( 2.00E+05)
( 1.30E+06)
</pre></div>

<p>If you want hexadecimal integer output, you can use <code>printf</code>
to perform the conversion:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ printf '%x\n' $(seq 1048575 1024 1050623)
fffff
1003ff
1007ff
</pre></div>

<p>For very long lists of numbers, use xargs to avoid
system limitations on the length of an argument list:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq 1000000 | xargs printf '%x\n' | tail -n 3
f423e
f423f
f4240
</pre></div>

<p>To generate octal output, use the printf <code>%o</code> format instead
of <code>%x</code>.
</p>
<p>On most systems, seq can produce whole-number output for values up to
at least <em>2^{53}</em>.  Larger integers are approximated.  The details
differ depending on your floating-point implementation.
See <a href="#Floating-point">Floating point</a>.  A common
case is that <code>seq</code> works with integers through <em>2^{64}</em>,
and larger integers may not be numerically correct:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">$ seq 50000000000000000000 2 50000000000000000004
50000000000000000000
50000000000000000000
50000000000000000004
</pre></div>

<p>However, note that when limited to non-negative whole numbers,
an increment of 1 and no format-specifying option, seq can print
arbitrarily large numbers.
</p>
<p>Be careful when using <code>seq</code> with outlandish values: otherwise
you may see surprising results, as <code>seq</code> uses floating point
internally.  For example, on the x86 platform, where the internal
representation uses a 64-bit fraction, the command:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">seq 1 0.0000000000000000001 1.0000000000000000009
</pre></div>

<p>outputs 1.0000000000000000007 twice and skips 1.0000000000000000008.
</p>
<p>An exit status of zero indicates success,
and a nonzero value indicates failure.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="File-permissions"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#File-timestamps" accesskey="n" rel="next">File timestamps</a>, Previous: <a href="#Numeric-operations" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Numeric operations</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="File-permissions-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">27 File permissions</h2>



<p>Each file has a set of <em>file mode bits</em> that control the kinds of
access that users have to that file.  They can be represented either in
symbolic form or as an octal number.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Mode-Structure" accesskey="1">Mode Structure</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Structure of file mode bits.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="2">Symbolic Modes</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Mnemonic representation of file mode bits.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Numeric-Modes" accesskey="3">Numeric Modes</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">File mode bits as octal numbers.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Operator-Numeric-Modes" accesskey="4">Operator Numeric Modes</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">ANDing, ORing, and setting modes octally.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid" accesskey="5">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Set-user-ID and set-group-ID on directories.
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="Mode-Structure"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="n" rel="next">Symbolic Modes</a>, Up: <a href="#File-permissions" accesskey="u" rel="up">File permissions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Structure-of-File-Mode-Bits"></a>
<h3 class="section">27.1 Structure of File Mode Bits</h3>

<p>The file mode bits have two parts: the <em>file permission bits</em>,
which control ordinary access to the file, and <em>special mode
bits</em>, which affect only some files.
</p>
<p>There are three kinds of permissions that a user can have for a file:
</p>
<ol>
<li> <a name="index-read-permission"></a>
permission to read the file.  For directories, this means permission to
list the contents of the directory.
</li><li> <a name="index-write-permission"></a>
permission to write to (change) the file.  For directories, this means
permission to create and remove files in the directory.
</li><li> <a name="index-execute_002fsearch-permission"></a>
permission to execute the file (run it as a program).  For directories,
this means permission to access files in the directory.
</li></ol>

<p>There are three categories of users who may have different permissions
to perform any of the above operations on a file:
</p>
<ol>
<li> the file&rsquo;s owner;
</li><li> other users who are in the file&rsquo;s group;
</li><li> everyone else.
</li></ol>

<a name="index-owner_002c-default"></a>
<a name="index-group-owner_002c-default"></a>
<p>Files are given an owner and group when they are created.  Usually the
owner is the current user and the group is the group of the directory
the file is in, but this varies with the operating system, the
file system the file is created on, and the way the file is created.  You
can change the owner and group of a file by using the <code>chown</code> and
<code>chgrp</code> commands.
</p>
<p>In addition to the three sets of three permissions listed above, the
file mode bits have three special components, which affect only
executable files (programs) and, on most systems, directories:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>The <em>set-user-ID bit</em> (<em>setuid bit</em>).</dt>
<dd><a name="index-set_002duser_002dID"></a>
<a name="index-setuid"></a>
<p>On execution, set the process&rsquo;s effective user ID to that of the file.
For directories on a few systems, give files created in the directory
the same owner as the directory, no matter who creates them, and set
the set-user-ID bit of newly-created subdirectories.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>The <em>set-group-ID bit</em> (<em>setgid bit</em>).</dt>
<dd><a name="index-set_002dgroup_002dID"></a>
<a name="index-setgid"></a>
<p>On execution, set the process&rsquo;s effective group ID to that of the file.
For directories on most systems, give files created in the directory
the same group as the directory, no matter what group the user who
creates them is in, and set the set-group-ID bit of newly-created
subdirectories.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>The <em>restricted deletion flag</em> or <em>sticky bit</em>.</dt>
<dd><a name="index-sticky"></a>
<a name="index-swap-space_002c-saving-text-image-in"></a>
<a name="index-text-image_002c-saving-in-swap-space"></a>
<a name="index-restricted-deletion-flag"></a>
<p>Prevent unprivileged users from removing or renaming a file in a directory
unless they own the file or the directory; this is commonly
found on world-writable directories like <samp>/tmp</samp>.
For regular files on some older systems, save the program&rsquo;s text image on the
swap device so it will load more quickly when run, so that the image
is &ldquo;sticky&rdquo;.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>In addition to the file mode bits listed above, there may be file attributes
specific to the file system, e.g., access control lists (ACLs), whether a
file is compressed, whether a file can be modified (immutability), and whether
a file can be dumped.  These are usually set using programs
specific to the file system.  For example:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt>ext2</dt>
<dd><p>On GNU and GNU/Linux the file attributes specific to
the ext2 file system are set using <code>chattr</code>.
</p>
</dd>
<dt>FFS</dt>
<dd><p>On FreeBSD the file flags specific to the FFS
file system are set using <code>chflags</code>.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>Even if a file&rsquo;s mode bits allow an operation on that file,
that operation may still fail, because:
</p>
<ul>
<li> the file-system-specific attributes or flags do not permit it; or

</li><li> the file system is mounted as read-only.
</li></ul>

<p>For example, if the immutable attribute is set on a file,
it cannot be modified, regardless of the fact that you
may have just run <code>chmod a+w FILE</code>.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Symbolic-Modes"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Numeric-Modes" accesskey="n" rel="next">Numeric Modes</a>, Previous: <a href="#Mode-Structure" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Mode Structure</a>, Up: <a href="#File-permissions" accesskey="u" rel="up">File permissions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Symbolic-Modes-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">27.2 Symbolic Modes</h3>

<a name="index-symbolic-modes"></a>
<p><em>Symbolic modes</em> represent changes to files&rsquo; mode bits as
operations on single-character symbols.  They allow you to modify either
all or selected parts of files&rsquo; mode bits, optionally based on
their previous values, and perhaps on the current <code>umask</code> as well
(see <a href="#Umask-and-Protection">Umask and Protection</a>).
</p>
<p>The format of symbolic modes is:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"><span class="roman">[</span>ugoa&hellip;<span class="roman">][</span>-+=<span class="roman">]</span><var>perms</var>&hellip;<span class="roman">[</span>,&hellip;<span class="roman">]</span>
</pre></div>

<p>where <var>perms</var> is either zero or more letters from the set
&lsquo;<samp>rwxXst</samp>&rsquo;, or a single letter from the set &lsquo;<samp>ugo</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The following sections describe the operators and other details of
symbolic modes.
</p>
<table class="menu" border="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Setting-Permissions" accesskey="1">Setting Permissions</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Basic operations on permissions.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Copying-Permissions" accesskey="2">Copying Permissions</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Copying existing permissions.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Changing-Special-Mode-Bits" accesskey="3">Changing Special Mode Bits</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Special mode bits.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Conditional-Executability" accesskey="4">Conditional Executability</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Conditionally affecting executability.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Multiple-Changes" accesskey="5">Multiple Changes</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">Making multiple changes.
</td></tr>
<tr><td align="left" valign="top">&bull; <a href="#Umask-and-Protection" accesskey="6">Umask and Protection</a>:</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="left" valign="top">The effect of the umask.
</td></tr>
</table>

<hr>
<a name="Setting-Permissions"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Copying-Permissions" accesskey="n" rel="next">Copying Permissions</a>, Up: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Symbolic Modes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Setting-Permissions-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">27.2.1 Setting Permissions</h4>

<p>The basic symbolic operations on a file&rsquo;s permissions are adding,
removing, and setting the permission that certain users have to read,
write, and execute or search the file.  These operations have the following
format:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"><var>users</var> <var>operation</var> <var>permissions</var>
</pre></div>

<p>The spaces between the three parts above are shown for readability only;
symbolic modes cannot contain spaces.
</p>
<p>The <var>users</var> part tells which users&rsquo; access to the file is changed.
It consists of one or more of the following letters (or it can be empty;
see <a href="#Umask-and-Protection">Umask and Protection</a>, for a description of what happens then).  When
more than one of these letters is given, the order that they are in does
not matter.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt><code>u</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-owner-of-file_002c-permissions-for"></a>
<p>the user who owns the file;
</p></dd>
<dt><code>g</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-group_002c-permissions-for"></a>
<p>other users who are in the file&rsquo;s group;
</p></dd>
<dt><code>o</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-other-permissions"></a>
<p>all other users;
</p></dd>
<dt><code>a</code></dt>
<dd><p>all users; the same as &lsquo;<samp>ugo</samp>&rsquo;.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>The <var>operation</var> part tells how to change the affected users&rsquo; access
to the file, and is one of the following symbols:
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt><code>+</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-adding-permissions"></a>
<p>to add the <var>permissions</var> to whatever permissions the <var>users</var>
already have for the file;
</p></dd>
<dt><code>-</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-removing-permissions"></a>
<a name="index-subtracting-permissions"></a>
<p>to remove the <var>permissions</var> from whatever permissions the
<var>users</var> already have for the file;
</p></dd>
<dt><code>=</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-setting-permissions"></a>
<p>to make the <var>permissions</var> the only permissions that the <var>users</var>
have for the file.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>The <var>permissions</var> part tells what kind of access to the file should
be changed; it is normally zero or more of the following letters.  As with the
<var>users</var> part, the order does not matter when more than one letter is
given.  Omitting the <var>permissions</var> part is useful only with the
&lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; operation, where it gives the specified <var>users</var> no access
at all to the file.
</p>
<dl compact="compact">
<dt><code>r</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-read-permission_002c-symbolic"></a>
<p>the permission the <var>users</var> have to read the file;
</p></dd>
<dt><code>w</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-write-permission_002c-symbolic"></a>
<p>the permission the <var>users</var> have to write to the file;
</p></dd>
<dt><code>x</code></dt>
<dd><a name="index-execute_002fsearch-permission_002c-symbolic"></a>
<p>the permission the <var>users</var> have to execute the file,
or search it if it is a directory.
</p></dd>
</dl>

<p>For example, to give everyone permission to read and write a regular file,
but not to execute it, use:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">a=rw
</pre></div>

<p>To remove write permission for all users other than the file&rsquo;s
owner, use:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">go-w
</pre></div>

<p>The above command does not affect the access that the owner of
the file has to it, nor does it affect whether other users can
read or execute the file.
</p>
<p>To give everyone except a file&rsquo;s owner no permission to do anything with
that file, use the mode below.  Other users could still remove the file,
if they have write permission on the directory it is in.
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">go=
</pre></div>

<p>Another way to specify the same thing is:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">og-rwx
</pre></div>

<hr>
<a name="Copying-Permissions"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Changing-Special-Mode-Bits" accesskey="n" rel="next">Changing Special Mode Bits</a>, Previous: <a href="#Setting-Permissions" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Setting Permissions</a>, Up: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Symbolic Modes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Copying-Existing-Permissions"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">27.2.2 Copying Existing Permissions</h4>

<a name="index-copying-existing-permissions"></a>
<a name="index-permissions_002c-copying-existing"></a>
<p>You can base a file&rsquo;s permissions on its existing permissions.  To do
this, instead of using a series of &lsquo;<samp>r</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>w</samp>&rsquo;, or &lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;
letters after the
operator, you use the letter &lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>g</samp>&rsquo;, or &lsquo;<samp>o</samp>&rsquo;.  For
example, the mode
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">o+g
</pre></div>

<p>adds the permissions for users who are in a file&rsquo;s group to the
permissions that other users have for the file.  Thus, if the file
started out as mode 664 (&lsquo;<samp>rw-rw-r--</samp>&rsquo;), the above mode would change
it to mode 666 (&lsquo;<samp>rw-rw-rw-</samp>&rsquo;).  If the file had started out as mode
741 (&lsquo;<samp>rwxr----x</samp>&rsquo;), the above mode would change it to mode 745
(&lsquo;<samp>rwxr--r-x</samp>&rsquo;).  The &lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; operations work
analogously.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Changing-Special-Mode-Bits"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Conditional-Executability" accesskey="n" rel="next">Conditional Executability</a>, Previous: <a href="#Copying-Permissions" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Copying Permissions</a>, Up: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Symbolic Modes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Changing-Special-Mode-Bits-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">27.2.3 Changing Special Mode Bits</h4>

<a name="index-changing-special-mode-bits"></a>
<p>In addition to changing a file&rsquo;s read, write, and execute/search permissions,
you can change its special mode bits.  See <a href="#Mode-Structure">Mode Structure</a>, for a
summary of these special mode bits.
</p>
<p>To change the file mode bits to set the user ID on execution, use
&lsquo;<samp>u</samp>&rsquo; in the <var>users</var> part of the symbolic mode and
&lsquo;<samp>s</samp>&rsquo; in the <var>permissions</var> part.
</p>
<p>To change the file mode bits to set the group ID on execution, use
&lsquo;<samp>g</samp>&rsquo; in the <var>users</var> part of the symbolic mode and
&lsquo;<samp>s</samp>&rsquo; in the <var>permissions</var> part.
</p>
<p>To set both user and group ID on execution, omit the <var>users</var> part
of the symbolic mode (or use &lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo;) and use &lsquo;<samp>s</samp>&rsquo; in the
<var>permissions</var> part.
</p>
<p>To change the file mode bits to set the restricted deletion flag or sticky bit,
omit the <var>users</var> part of the symbolic mode (or use &lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo;) and use
&lsquo;<samp>t</samp>&rsquo; in the <var>permissions</var> part.
</p>
<p>For example, to set the set-user-ID mode bit of a program,
you can use the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">u+s
</pre></div>

<p>To remove both set-user-ID and set-group-ID mode bits from
it, you can use the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">a-s
</pre></div>

<p>To set the restricted deletion flag or sticky bit, you can use
the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">+t
</pre></div>

<p>The combination &lsquo;<samp>o+s</samp>&rsquo; has no effect.  On GNU systems
the combinations &lsquo;<samp>u+t</samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>g+t</samp>&rsquo; have no effect, and
&lsquo;<samp>o+t</samp>&rsquo; acts like plain &lsquo;<samp>+t</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>The &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; operator is not very useful with special mode bits.
For example, the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">o=t
</pre></div>

<p>does set the restricted deletion flag or sticky bit, but it also
removes all read, write, and execute/search permissions that users not in the
file&rsquo;s group might have had for it.
</p>
<p>See <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>, for additional rules concerning
set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits and directories.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Conditional-Executability"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Multiple-Changes" accesskey="n" rel="next">Multiple Changes</a>, Previous: <a href="#Changing-Special-Mode-Bits" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Changing Special Mode Bits</a>, Up: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Symbolic Modes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Conditional-Executability-1"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">27.2.4 Conditional Executability</h4>

<a name="index-conditional-executability"></a>
<p>There is one more special type of symbolic permission: if you use
&lsquo;<samp>X</samp>&rsquo; instead of &lsquo;<samp>x</samp>&rsquo;, execute/search permission is affected only if the
file is a directory or already had execute permission.
</p>
<p>For example, this mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">a+X
</pre></div>

<p>gives all users permission to search directories, or to execute files if
anyone could execute them before.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Multiple-Changes"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Umask-and-Protection" accesskey="n" rel="next">Umask and Protection</a>, Previous: <a href="#Conditional-Executability" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Conditional Executability</a>, Up: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Symbolic Modes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Making-Multiple-Changes"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">27.2.5 Making Multiple Changes</h4>

<a name="index-multiple-changes-to-permissions"></a>
<p>The format of symbolic modes is actually more complex than described
above (see <a href="#Setting-Permissions">Setting Permissions</a>).  It provides two ways to make
multiple changes to files&rsquo; mode bits.
</p>
<p>The first way is to specify multiple <var>operation</var> and
<var>permissions</var> parts after a <var>users</var> part in the symbolic mode.
</p>
<p>For example, the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">og+rX-w
</pre></div>

<p>gives users other than the owner of the file read permission and, if
it is a directory or if someone already had execute permission
to it, gives them execute/search permission; and it also denies them write
permission to the file.  It does not affect the permission that the
owner of the file has for it.  The above mode is equivalent to
the two modes:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">og+rX
og-w
</pre></div>

<p>The second way to make multiple changes is to specify more than one
simple symbolic mode, separated by commas.  For example, the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">a+r,go-w
</pre></div>

<p>gives everyone permission to read the file and removes write
permission on it for all users except its owner.  Another example:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">u=rwx,g=rx,o=
</pre></div>

<p>sets all of the permission bits for the file explicitly.  (It
gives users who are not in the file&rsquo;s group no permission at all for
it.)
</p>
<p>The two methods can be combined.  The mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">a+r,g+x-w
</pre></div>

<p>gives all users permission to read the file, and gives users who are in
the file&rsquo;s group permission to execute/search it as well, but not permission
to write to it.  The above mode could be written in several different
ways; another is:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">u+r,g+rx,o+r,g-w
</pre></div>

<hr>
<a name="Umask-and-Protection"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Multiple-Changes" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Multiple Changes</a>, Up: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="u" rel="up">Symbolic Modes</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="The-Umask-and-Protection"></a>
<h4 class="subsection">27.2.6 The Umask and Protection</h4>

<a name="index-umask-and-modes"></a>
<a name="index-modes-and-umask"></a>
<p>If the <var>users</var> part of a symbolic mode is omitted, it defaults to
&lsquo;<samp>a</samp>&rsquo; (affect all users), except that any permissions that are
<em>set</em> in the system variable <code>umask</code> are <em>not affected</em>.
The value of <code>umask</code> can be set using the
<code>umask</code> command.  Its default value varies from system to system.
</p>
<a name="index-giving-away-permissions"></a>
<p>Omitting the <var>users</var> part of a symbolic mode is generally not useful
with operations other than &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;.  It is useful with &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo; because
it allows you to use <code>umask</code> as an easily customizable protection
against giving away more permission to files than you intended to.
</p>
<p>As an example, if <code>umask</code> has the value 2, which removes write
permission for users who are not in the file&rsquo;s group, then the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">+w
</pre></div>

<p>adds permission to write to the file to its owner and to other users who
are in the file&rsquo;s group, but <em>not</em> to other users.  In contrast,
the mode:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">a+w
</pre></div>

<p>ignores <code>umask</code>, and <em>does</em> give write permission for
the file to all users.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Numeric-Modes"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Operator-Numeric-Modes" accesskey="n" rel="next">Operator Numeric Modes</a>, Previous: <a href="#Symbolic-Modes" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Symbolic Modes</a>, Up: <a href="#File-permissions" accesskey="u" rel="up">File permissions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Numeric-Modes-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">27.3 Numeric Modes</h3>

<a name="index-numeric-modes"></a>
<a name="index-file-mode-bits_002c-numeric"></a>
<a name="index-octal-numbers-for-file-modes"></a>
<p>As an
alternative to giving a symbolic mode, you can give an octal (base 8)
number that represents the mode.
</p>
<p>The permissions granted to the user,
to other users in the file&rsquo;s group,
and to other users not in the file&rsquo;s group each require three
bits: one bit for read, one for write, and one for execute/search permission.
These three bits are represented as one octal digit;
for example, if all three are present, the resulting 111 (in binary)
is represented as the digit 7 (in octal).  The three special
mode bits also require one bit each, and they are as a group
represented as another octal digit.  Here is how the bits are arranged,
starting with the highest valued bit:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example">Value in  Corresponding
Mode      Mode Bit

          Special mode bits:
4000      Set user ID
2000      Set group ID
1000      Restricted deletion flag or sticky bit

          The file's owner:
 400      Read
 200      Write
 100      Execute/search

          Other users in the file's group:
  40      Read
  20      Write
  10      Execute/search

          Other users not in the file's group:
   4      Read
   2      Write
   1      Execute/search
</pre></div>

<p>For example, numeric mode &lsquo;<samp>4751</samp>&rsquo; corresponds to symbolic mode
&lsquo;<samp>u=srwx,g=rx,o=x</samp>&rsquo;, and numeric mode &lsquo;<samp>664</samp>&rsquo; corresponds to symbolic mode
&lsquo;<samp>ug=rw,o=r</samp>&rsquo;.  Numeric mode &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo; corresponds to symbolic mode
&lsquo;<samp>a=</samp>&rsquo;.
</p>
<p>A numeric mode is usually shorter than the corresponding symbolic
mode, but it is limited in that normally it cannot take into account the
previous file mode bits; it can only set them absolutely.
The set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of directories are an exception
to this general limitation.  See <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>.
Also, operator numeric modes can take previous file mode bits into
account.  See <a href="#Operator-Numeric-Modes">Operator Numeric Modes</a>.
</p>
<p>Numeric modes are always interpreted in octal; you do not have to add a
leading &lsquo;<samp>0</samp>&rsquo;, as you do in C.  Mode &lsquo;<samp>0055</samp>&rsquo; is the same as
mode &lsquo;<samp>55</samp>&rsquo;.  However, modes of five digits or more, such as
&lsquo;<samp>00055</samp>&rsquo;, are sometimes special (see <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>).
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Operator-Numeric-Modes"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid" accesskey="n" rel="next">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>, Previous: <a href="#Numeric-Modes" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Numeric Modes</a>, Up: <a href="#File-permissions" accesskey="u" rel="up">File permissions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Operator-Numeric-Modes-1"></a>
<h3 class="section">27.4 Operator Numeric Modes</h3>

<p>An operator numeric mode is a numeric mode that is prefixed by a
&lsquo;<samp>-</samp>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<samp>+</samp>&rsquo;, or &lsquo;<samp>=</samp>&rsquo; operator, which has the same
interpretation as in symbolic modes.  For example, &lsquo;<samp>+440</samp>&rsquo; enables
read permission for the file&rsquo;s owner and group, &lsquo;<samp>-1</samp>&rsquo; disables
execute permission for other users, and &lsquo;<samp>=600</samp>&rsquo; clears all
permissions except for enabling read-write permissions for the file&rsquo;s
owner.  Operator numeric modes can be combined with symbolic modes by
separating them with a comma; for example, &lsquo;<samp>=0,u+r</samp>&rsquo; clears all
permissions except for enabling read permission for the file&rsquo;s owner.
</p>
<p>The commands &lsquo;<samp>chmod =755 <var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<samp>chmod 755
<var>dir</var></samp>&rsquo; differ in that the former clears the directory <var>dir</var>&rsquo;s
setuid and setgid bits, whereas the latter preserves them.
See <a href="#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid">Directory Setuid and Setgid</a>.
</p>
<p>Operator numeric modes are a GNU extension.
</p>
<hr>
<a name="Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Previous: <a href="#Operator-Numeric-Modes" accesskey="p" rel="prev">Operator Numeric Modes</a>, Up: <a href="#File-permissions" accesskey="u" rel="up">File permissions</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="Directories-and-the-Set_002dUser_002dID-and-Set_002dGroup_002dID-Bits"></a>
<h3 class="section">27.5 Directories and the Set-User-ID and Set-Group-ID Bits</h3>

<p>On most systems, if a directory&rsquo;s set-group-ID bit is set, newly
created subfiles inherit the same group as the directory, and newly
created subdirectories inherit the set-group-ID bit of the parent
directory.  On a few systems, a directory&rsquo;s set-user-ID bit has a
similar effect on the ownership of new subfiles and the set-user-ID
bits of new subdirectories.  These mechanisms let users share files
more easily, by lessening the need to use <code>chmod</code> or
<code>chown</code> to share new files.
</p>
<p>These convenience mechanisms rely on the set-user-ID and set-group-ID
bits of directories.  If commands like <code>chmod</code> and
<code>mkdir</code> routinely cleared these bits on directories, the
mechanisms would be less convenient and it would be harder to share
files.  Therefore, a command like <code>chmod</code> does not affect the
set-user-ID or set-group-ID bits of a directory unless the user
specifically mentions them in a symbolic mode, or uses an operator
numeric mode such as &lsquo;<samp>=755</samp>&rsquo;, or sets them in a numeric mode, or
clears them in a numeric mode that has five or more octal digits.
For example, on systems that support
set-group-ID inheritance:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># These commands leave the set-user-ID and
# set-group-ID bits of the subdirectories alone,
# so that they retain their default values.
mkdir A B C
chmod 755 A
chmod 0755 B
chmod u=rwx,go=rx C
mkdir -m 755 D
mkdir -m 0755 E
mkdir -m u=rwx,go=rx F
</pre></div>

<p>If you want to try to set these bits, you must mention them
explicitly in the symbolic or numeric modes, e.g.:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># These commands try to set the set-user-ID
# and set-group-ID bits of the subdirectories.
mkdir G
chmod 6755 G
chmod +6000 G
chmod u=rwx,go=rx,a+s G
mkdir -m 6755 H
mkdir -m +6000 I
mkdir -m u=rwx,go=rx,a+s J
</pre></div>

<p>If you want to try to clear these bits, you must mention them
explicitly in a symbolic mode, or use an operator numeric mode, or
specify a numeric mode with five or more octal digits, e.g.:
</p>
<div class="example">
<pre class="example"># These commands try to clear the set-user-ID
# and set-group-ID bits of the directory D.
chmod a-s D
chmod -6000 D
chmod =755 D
chmod 00755 D
</pre></div>

<p>This behavior is a GNU extension.  Portable scripts should
not rely on requests to set or clear these bits on directories, as
POSIX allows implementations to ignore these requests.
The GNU behavior with numeric modes of four or fewer digits
is intended for scripts portable to systems that preserve these bits;
the behavior with numeric modes of five or more digits is for scripts
portable to systems that do not preserve the bits.
</p>

<hr>
<a name="File-timestamps"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
Next: <a href="#Date-input-formats" accesskey="n" rel="next">Date input formats</a>, Previous: <a href="#File-permissions" accesskey="p" rel="prev">File permissions</a>, Up: <a href="#Top" accesskey="u" rel="up">Top</a> &nbsp; [<a href="#SEC_Contents" title="Table of contents" rel="contents">Contents</a>][<a href="#Concept-index" title="Index" rel="index">Index</a>]</p>
</div>
<a name="File-timestamps-1"></a>
<h2 class="chapter">28 File timestamps</h2>

<a name="index-atime"></a>
<a name="index-birthtime"></a>
<a name="index-ctime"></a>
<a name="index-mtime"></a>
<p>Standard POSIX files have three timestamps: the access timestamp
(atime) of the last read, the modification timestamp (mtime) of the
last write, and the status change timestamp (ctime) of the last change
to the file&rsquo;s meta-information.  Some file systems support a
fourth time: the birth timestamp (birthtime) of when the file was
created; by definition, birthtime never changes.
</p>
<p>One common example of a ctime change is when the permissions of a file
change.  Changing the permissions doesn&rsquo;t access the file, so atime
doesn&rsquo;t change, nor does it modify the file, so the mtime doesn&rsquo;t
change.  Yet, something about the file itself has changed, and this
must be noted somewhere.  This is the job of the ctime field.  This is
necessary, so that, for example, a backup program can make a fresh
copy of the file, including the new permissions value.  Another
operation that modifies a file&rsquo;s ctime without affecting the others is
renaming.
</p>
<p>Naively, a file&rsquo;s atime, mtime, and ctime are set to the current time
whenever you read, write, or change the attributes of the file
respectively, and searching a directory counts as reading it.  A
file&rsquo;s atime and mtime can also be set directly, via the
<code>touch</code> command (see <a href="#touch-invocation">touch invocation</a>).  In practice,
though, timestamps are not updated quite that way.
</p>
<p>For efficiency reasons, many systems are lazy about updating atimes:
when a program accesses a file, they may delay updating the file&rsquo;s
atime, or may not update the file&rsquo;s atime if the file has been
accessed recently, or may not update the atime at all.  Similar
laziness, though typically not quite so extreme, applies to mtimes and
ctimes.
</p>
<p>Some systems emulate timestamps instead of supporting them directly,
and these emulations may disagree with the naive interpretation.  For
example, a system may fake an atime or ctime by using the mtime.
</p>
<a name="index-clock-skew-1"></a>
<p>The determination of what time is &ldquo;current&rdquo; depends on the
platform.  Platforms with network file systems often use different
clocks for the operating system and for file systems; because
updates typically uses file systems&rsquo; clocks by default, clock
skew can cause the resulting file timestamps to appear to be in a
program&rsquo;s &ldquo;future&rdquo; or &ldquo;past&rdquo;.
</p>
<a name="index-file-timestamp-resolution"></a>
<p>When the system updates a file timestamp to a desired time <var>t</var>
(which is either the current time, or a time specified via the
<code>touch</code> command), there are several reasons the file&rsquo;s
timestamp may be set to a value that differs from <var>t</var>.  First,
<var>t</var> may have a higher resolution than supported.  Second, a file
system may use different resolutions for different types of times.
Third, file timestamps may use a different resolution than operating
system timestamps.  Fourth, the operating system primitives used to
update timestamps may employ yet a different resolution.  For example,
in theory a file system might use 10-microsecond resolution for access
timestamp and 100-nanosecond resolution for modification timestamp, and the
operating system might use nanosecond resolution for the current time
and microsecond resolution for the primitive that <code>touch</code> uses
to set a file&rsquo;s timestamp to an arbitrary value.
</p>

<a name="Date-input-formats"></a>
<div class="header">
<p>
